416.title: Comment on Oracle in Le Mouvement des images
416.ref_bibliographic: Anon, Le Mouvement des images au Musée national d’art moderne. Centre Pompidou. Available at: http://www.centrepompidou.fr/Pompidou/Manifs.nsf/AllExpositions/F64415EF7EC115ECC125709900470B9D [Accessed April 22, 2012].
416.text: Les collages cubistes de Braque ou Picasso, surréalistes de Max Ernst ou Man Ray, les assemblages pop de Martial Raysse ou James Rosenquist agencent une multiplicité d'images ou de fragments d'images en une séquence unique : ils rassemblent dans la simultanéité ce que l'expérience ordinaire du cinéma déploie dans la succession. Les arts plastiques produisent un équivalent statique de la dynamique et de l'enchaînement des plans cinématographiques ; ainsi, Oracle, 1962-1965 de Robert Rauschenberg propose en contrepoint des collages visuels de l'artiste un collage sonore, composé aléatoirement à partir des ondes radio environnantes. Oracle est un condensé de la vie urbaine : les fragments disparates qui le constituent ont été prélevés dans la métropole new-yorkaise avant d'être montés en un assemblage qui fait coexister dans le même espace différents bâtiments, états et situations de la ville. La collision des sources sonores qui proviennent de chaque élément achève de figurer la cacophonie, le brouillage, la simultanéité des bruits et la rumeur propres au paysage urbain contemporain.

66.title: Klüver on the design and production of Oracle in 1960-1965
66.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy ; Martin, Julie, « Working with Rauschenberg », in Walter Hopps and Susan Davidson (eds). Robert Rauschenberg : a retrospective, New York : Guggenheim Museum Publications, 1997, p. 310-327.
66.text:
My collaboration with Rauschenberg on what was to become Oracle (1962-65; cat. no. 246) began shortly after the Homage to New York performance, when I ran into him at the end of March 1960 at the Martha Jackson Gallery during an Antoni Tapies exhibition. He asked me if it was possible to make an interactive environment where the temperature, sound, smell, lights, etc., could be affected by the person who moved through it.
Over the next year or two, my colleagues and I tried to work out Rauschenberg's idea for an interactive or, better, reactive environment, but it proved very difficult to achieve what he wanted. We would only work on it in our "free" time, which really meant that we took the time for it whenever we chose. Bell Laboratories, like any good research laboratory, left us alone to carry on our own experimental or theoretical research. During this time, I brought Rauschenberg to Bell Labs to see what my colleagues and I were working on.
By 1962, after many discussions with Rauschenberg, the idea of the work boiled down to a sound environment in which the sounds would come from five AM radios, and the audience could vary the volume and scan rate of each radio from a control unit. Originally, Rauschenberg had anticipated placing the five radios behind five large panels and housing the controls in a stand in front of them. We referred to the piece as an orchestra with the viewer as the conductor. Or as Rauschenberg remarked, "The intent was to make a musical instrument that could be performed on, with or without sophistication.(7)
Rauschenberg did not want wires between the control unit and the radios. He insisted on using the AM band; in those days, FM was the outlet for cultural and classical-music programming. In addition, Rauschenberg wanted the visitor to be able to vary the speed of the scanning from station to station but not be able to stay at or tune in to any given station. Harold Hodges came up with a solution: the tuning dial was turned by a small, variable-speed, DC motor, and the visitor controlled the speed of the motor.
After a lot of experimentation, Harold and I began work on a design in which the speakers on the AM radios would be removed, and the output from each radio would be re-transmitted by small AM transmitters to receivers, amplifiers, and speakers mounted behind each panel. At least two complete versions were built and rejected, because of interference between the control signals from the homemade AM transmitters and the AM radio signals, which generated a nightmare of noise.
All this had taken us a few more years, and what I remember most was working in my small apartment in Murray Hill and standing in endless lines in the electronics shops. By the time we felt that we could finish the system, by the end of 1964, Rauschenberg had long since turned the five panels into the painting Ace (1962; see fig. 90) and had begun to think of our project as a five-piece sculpture.
In the summer of 1964, the technology caught up with us. We found one of the first crystal-controlled, fully transistorized, wireless microphone systems. Then we were able to put all the AM radio controls for the volume and scanning speed in one of the sculpture pieces and retransmit the sound of the AM radios over the FM band, with a minimum of interference, to FM receivers, amplifiers, and speakers in each of the other sculpture pieces. From the control unit in one of the pieces, the visitors would be able to vary the sound level and the sweep rate of the five radios' station scanners, each associated with sounds in one of the sculpture pieces. For the FM transmitters and receivers, we used a Comdex wireless microphone system, and the radios were GE transistor radio receivers.(8)
Many choices in projects like this one are not made purely on the basis of engineering considerations but are aesthetic choices. Rauschenberg chose the size and shape of the control knobs, the size of the speakers, and where to place the technical components in each piece. When I could no longer make "midnight requisitions" of the large gray-blue Bell Laboratories telephone batteries we had been using for the radios, I went to the store and bought the only substitute I could find: bright-red RCA batteries. I brought them to Rauschenberg's loft expecting that he would find the color terrible, but, of course, he immediately fell in love with it. And the red batteries were the only bright color in the piece, until they were discontinued by the manufacturer.(9)

67.title: Klüver on the design and production of Oracle in 1960-1965
67.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
67.text:
During the time I was working with Tinguely on Homage to New York, Robert Rauschenberg asked me to collaborate on what he described as an interactive environment. After many discussions, the idea boiled down to a sound environment where the sounds from five AM radios emanate from five sculptures. The viewer can vary the volume and the rate of scanning through the frequency band from knobs on the control unit, but cannot stop the scanning at any one station. Rauschenberg wanted no wires from the control unit to the other pieces, so that they could ail be moved freely in relation to one another.
With the limited technology available in the early 1960's, we designed and built a system where ail the AM radios were located in the control unit and the sound was re-transmitted on the FM band to receivers and speakers in the other pieces. Interference between the FM transmitters and noise from the scanning motors were problems we had to solve. In this photograph Rauschenberg and I are working on Oracle.
[...]
When Harold Hodges and I were finishing the technical system, Rauschenberg put together the five sculptures that make up Oracle from objects he found in the streets. The pieces consist of a car door mounted on a typewriter table; a tub with an air conditioning duct through which water flows with, a small wire basket attached to the tub by a chain; a window frame attached to another long duct; an exhaust pipe on large wheels; and a large aluminum staircase which houses the control unit. I had ordered the aluminum staircase according to Bob's specs, and he added other objects to it. Bob located the speakers in each piece so that the piece had its own unique sound.

69.title: Klüver on the exhibition of Oracle at the Leo Castelli Gallery in 1965
69.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy ; Martin, Julie, « Working with Rauschenberg », in Walter Hopps and Susan Davidson (eds). Robert Rauschenberg : a retrospective, New York : Guggenheim Museum Publications, 1997, p. 310-327.
69.text:
Oracle was shown at Leo Castelli Gallery on Seventy-seventh Street in Manhattan in May 1965. At the gallery, using an awl, Rauschenberg signed Oracle on the side of the staircase. He thought I should sign it as well, so I scratched in my name, adding, "Sound Engineer." To minimize the pristine feeling of the gallery space, Rauschenberg covered the floor with a black rubber mat. The pieces were placed throughout the front room, and the viewer could freely walk among them and operate the controls on the staircase.
In full operation, Oracle becomes an animated cityscape. Using materials discarded from buildings and discovered on sidewalks, the sculptures are themselves as varied as the sights of a busy city street. The units can be placed anywhere in relation to one other, and the sound, too, can be "re-arranged" in ever-changing bits of music, talk, and noise— loud, soft, clear, or out of tune. The sound from the five radios comes to you as it would in a city neighborhood on a hot summer day. To this is added the only constant in the piece, the rushing sound of water from the fountain. Oracle has no fixed visual or aural shape. Any arrangement of the sculpture pieces in a room leaves open the possibility of another arrangement. It presents an open invitation to walk into it. When you do, the experience is as changing and provocative as the city it is reporting on.

70.title: Klüver on the restoration of Oracle in 1977
70.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy ; Martin, Julie, « Working with Rauschenberg », in Walter Hopps and Susan Davidson (eds). Robert Rauschenberg : a retrospective, New York : Guggenheim Museum Publications, 1997, p. 310-327.
70.text: In 1976, Oracle was sold to Mme Sào Schlumberger, who donated it to the Musée National d'Art Moderne, Paris. Twelve years of wear on the system, and further advances in technology, made it clear that the piece should be redesigned for its new location. With the redesign, we moved the AM radios and the DC motors out of the control console and into each piece. We installed what was called a "digital, proportional, remote radio control system" designed for remote-controlled hobby airplanes. Digital control signals for volume and sweep rate were transmitted in the seventy megahertz band to servo motors in the other four pieces.

71.title: Rauschenberg on the design and production of Oracle
71.ref_bibliographic: Oral history interview with Robert Rauschenberg, 1965 Dec. 21, Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.
71.text:
DS: Would that have been the case just before your show that was called Oracle? I mean how did that very different adventure come about? Well, I suppose it wasn't so different from some of the objects you'd made before.
RR: Oracle was I had started it I guess two and a half years ago, maybe even longer than that, closer to three. And it was going to be a radio painting but a concert variation. I did Broadcast, a painting that has three radios in it but only two tuning knobs, one for volume and one for tuning. And I objected to the fact that one had to be standing so close to the picture that the sound didn't seem to be using the space and the way the images were reacting to each other. And that was all right. That was one aspect of it. But through that, having made that and feeling that limitation with that piece, I wanted to do something that was remote control, that could be separated in the room. I had some canvases stretched, but it took so long I needed help with the radios. And it took so long for me to find the help that I used the paintings for something else. Then later I decided that was a good idea because once I started seeing what was involved I saw that with the weight problem, and the depth the painting would have to be to house the equipment, that painting was the wrong form for that to take. So I started on a sculpture. Then I went to Amsterdam to work at the Stadtlijk Museum with what was going to be a collaboration of about five artists, or six. And because I was working in sculpture, I had three weeks; we found that our ideas were so different that it was very difficult to get together and just make a piece.
[...] So I was working with the sculpture which became Oracle with the radios. And painting didn't really interest me. So in a kind of crash program of three weeks I made four pieces of sculpture and some of them quite large. One of them is about ten or twelve feet high and was very densely massed, about eight feet by five feet, and twelve feet high. That was by far the largest work. But I'm not really a sculptor in any traditional sense. I tend to work with materials that are a little heavier and put them together as practically as I can. By being a sculptor, I mean I don't weld or solder.
[...]
DS: Has it continued to interest you since then? I mean, are you likely to resume?
RR: I think the radio piece probably is the closest thing to what I'm about to do next as one can predict without knowing where one's going, because I like very much that mixture of technology and aesthetics.
DS: I was interested in what you said last time we talked, I think, about the sound having been important in shifting the focus of the audience, in a sense, in that insuring a certain movement through the exhibition ...
RR: Literally.
DS: Literally, yes.
RR: You had a sense of distance that as often as not was distorted. You had the feeling possibly of knowing where you were but where you were was lost.
DS: That's very expressive. And another thing that you had mentioned which we haven't recorded was your feeling that it was important that the sound frequencies, that the radio sources, be actual ones, not taped; and your feeling that if you had been able to tape them, it would have been rather like commercial art in that not being an actual ...
RR: Yes.
DS: Would you like to enlarge on that in any way?
RR: No, I think that just about says it. I like for the sound to be as fresh as the daily fall of the dust and rust and dirt that accumulates, which doesn't mean that one doesn't clean it off from time to time. But then that's another thing. It's an actuality of a literal insistence on the piece's operating and existing in the time situation that it's observed in. It's another one of those things trying to put off the death of the work.
DS: Yes. Did I hear you mention before that you had in mind possibly using at some time in the future a piece in which the wind might work as an actual force?
RR: Yes. I'd like to work with wind and water and plants. It sounds like it's going to be a garden, but I don't think it's going to be, but if it turns out to be a garden that may be my own sneaky way of moving out into the country. I hope I don't pick this new building out just in order to discover that what I really needed was a farm. In fact, having two dogs now is also an indication that I'm trying to get out.

72.title: Klüver on the design and production of Oracle in 1962-1965
72.ref_bibliographic: Billy Klüver. « Teknologi för Livet » in Konstrevy, Vol 42, n°2, February 1966.
72.text:
We had worked on the technical equipment for Oracle for about three years before it was finished. We didn’t work continuously, of course, and constantly there were [always ] unsolved problems. My assistant at the laboratory, Harold Hodges, did most of the construction work. It seems to me as if I spent most of the time in endless queues in the electronic shops. Two complete systems were built and discarded as technically unsatisfactory. The third and last system was built during the end of 1964 and the beginning of 1965. It was installed in the last weeks before the opening on the 15th of May, 1965. My daughter was born the same day, and it was not until a week later that could I find out that the system worked better than I had expected. The costs for the electronic components had then surpassed thirty thousand crowns, while the labor costs were about fifteen thousand. 
At this time it goes without saying that Robert Rauschenberg’s sculpture Oracle is magnificent. It is a work of art which sums up much in his work to date and also points forward and gives a clue of what will come. When you work so closely with an artist for such a long time and have the opportunity to get discouraged many times and then become greatly surprised over the results, you appreciate [feel] more than ever the specific and the glorious way in which the artist sees. 
[...]
The difficulties that arose during the work with Oracle were maybe not so much of a technical nature (the minute we had decided on the solution the technical problems were normal), as in the collaboration with Rauschenberg.  I don’t mean that Rauschenberg in any way is difficult to work with; he is in reality of wonder of patience.  It is simply difficult for an engineer to have a conversation with an artist. The engineer speaks slowly and with a natural hesitation. He knows that the problem can be solved even if he can’t solve it at that moment. He is worried about costs and needs time to experiment and to find out which materials are available. He tries to press the artist for a more detailed description. What is the goal ?  How strong should the amplifiers be ? What noise level is permissible ? Can interference between the local oscillators in the radio receivers be permitted? What was the maximum and minimum sweep speed ? Should it be possible for a visitor to stop at a certain station ? How many hours should the batteries last ? The artist works, on his side, fast and with his hands. He works with facts and does not bind himself to theoretical details which concern the future. In a month, in a year, maybe his attitude will be completely different from today. He does not know the engineer’s language, he does not know the meaning of the words. Can the engineer be trusted ? And the engineer needs complete information in order to solve the problem. The artist wants as much freedom as is possible over the result. It is not a question of a collaboration, but rather a contractual relationship between the artist and the engineer so that in the end the engineer is only part of the total work of the artist. The artist has to accept the engineer as he is.  
During our work with Oracle, several of these questions came up. We never arrived at any rational way of working, but I understood that we had to work, apart from the costs, with such a margin that Rauschenberg had as much freedom as possible as we worked towards the final solution.  In this way the high sound level was not present in the original specifications for the system. We did give Rauschenberg the means to change the sound level, which he wanted to keep high, something we had not foreseen but that he used. On the other hand, every amplifier was attached to a speaker of good quality. These Rauschenberg replaced with smaller speakers of worse quality.
Oracle needed a high sound level but a relatively bad sound quality (in order to give the impression that you listened to somebody else’s radio.)  Other amusing questions appeared repeatedly:  What was a technical decision, and what was an “aesthetic” decision.  The color of the batteries, the size of the controls, the placement of the technical components were all aesthetic decisions.  It’s easy for an engineer to get trapped in what he’s doing and make decisions on the basis of what is “beautiful” instead of what is technically necessary. The engineer cannot see what he does as art.  In regards to aesthetic questions, working with Rauschenberg became very intimate.  
We’ve learned that the painting is an object among other objects in a room.  Jasper Johns shows the back side of a painting.  During a piece by John Cage we are forced to accept all sounds as an equal part of the composition. Claus Oldenburg let the people whom he uses in his happenings play themselves (in most cases the actors are not conscious of this fact.) Oldenburg writes roles in his happenings for a certain person.  In such a way the individuals’ shyness, nervousness, and sexuality become part of the happening.  
Tradition can therefore not tell us anything else but that the technical material in Oracle is an integral part of the sculpture just like the car door, the basin or the window frame.  It is impossible to treat the sound as part of the work of art and not the radios themselves. But what is the engineer’s relationship to the artist?  He uses his creativity and his experience to create something at the direction of the artist, which he obviously could not make by himself.  In the same way that Oldenburg works with and accepts the peculiarities of his actors, the artist has to accept the engineer.  The artist is a means for the engineer to arrive at a result, and the artist is equally bound to him as Michelangelo was to his marble. Oracle points to the fact that a new type of relationship is possible between the artist and the engineer, and perhaps even between the artist and the scientist.  A relationship where the artist tries to use the enormous richness of technology and science to achieve his goal.  The goal of the artist may be equally as technically complicated as building a huge accelerator or launching of  a satellite, but his goals should lie within as yet undiscovered areas of art and science:  to create new wonders, new sensual experiences, new pressures, new ways to experience each other, new ways to experience light, dark, coldness, heat; new ways to sleep, to be, and to eat.  Every engineer is conscious today of the fact that no exaggerations can describe the capacity of technology, but at the same time, the inventiveness of the engineers, how technology can be used, limited by his laziness, one-sidedness, and psychological attitude.  The relation of the engineer to the use of technology in art can today be compared to the people who insist that the only goal of art is to create a beautiful object full of a higher order.  The engineer cannot believe that the technology can be used to create disorder, but the artist can.  The artist, and only the artist, can show the engineer how technology can be used at its full capacity.  The technical part of Oracle is senseless from any engineering point of view possible.  From the radios all tuned to the AM four radio programs are re-transmitted to four other transceivers--in the same room.  The engineer can only shake his head when he hears that such a project cost almost 50,000 crowns.

76.title: Klüver on the donation of Oracle in 1976
76.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy ; Martin, Julie, « Working with Rauschenberg », in Walter Hopps and Susan Davidson (eds). Robert Rauschenberg : a retrospective, New York : Guggenheim Museum Publications, 1997, p. 310-327.
76.text: In 1976, Oracle was sold to Mme Sào Schlumberger, who donated it to the Musée National d'Art Moderne, Paris.

77.title: Klüver on the restoration and exhibition of Oracle in 1977
77.ref_bibliographic: Billy Klüver, "Four Collaborations" in Cornelia Faist, Alfred Kren (eds). Robert Rauschenberg : haywire : major technological works of the 1960s. Ostfildern-Ruit : Hatje, 1997. 111 p.
77.text:
The Sculpture was to be shown at the grand opening of the Centre Pompidou in 1977, and Hodges and I got involved again. Twelve years of wear and tear on the system and further advances in technology made it clear that the piece should be redesigned for its new location. We also saw a chance to get rid of the last remaining problems of noise and interference. With the redesign, we were now able to move the AM radios and the DC motors out of the control console and into each piece, eliminating the need to retransmit the control signals from the console. We installed what was called a "digital proportional remote radio control system" designed for remote-controlled hobby airplanes. Digital control signals for volume and sweep rate were transmitted in the 70 MHz band to servomotors in the other four pieces. Oracle had now entered the space age.
I went to Paris to install Oracle and found that Beaubourg was not a friendly place for it. The steel structure of the building acted as a Faraday cage, shielding the interior from the relatively long electromagnetic waves of the AM frequency band, so that only static could be heard on Oracle's radios. To overcome this problem, I had to install a master receiving antenna on the roof. (The only access to the roof was a thirty foot ladder from the sixth floor outside walk-way and I found myself all alone on the roof stringing the wire for the large antenna.) To get the AM signal to the gallery where Oracle was shown, I used a Jerrold Broadcast Band Amplifier, which was designed for radio showrooms and promised "you can turn on your AM radios and demonstrate the static-free humfree reception that generate sales." Hardly space-age technology, but the best I could do. What made the situation worse was that there were only 3 AM radio stations in Paris and a few audible stations from the rest of France. I had hoped to be able to tune the system to receive other European stations, but lack of time and help made this impossible in time for the opening.
Rauschenberg arrived and we worked frenetically to get Oracle going. An hour before the official opening, we plugged in the pump motor for the shower and blew all the fuses in our section of the museum. The electricians had gone home for the day and no one knew where to find the fuse box. When Minister of Culture Michel Guy and the director Pontus Hulten brought President Giscard d'Estaing and Princess Grace by, we were standing in semi-darkness. The sound from a few lonely radio stations could be heard from Oracle, and with the refrigeration coils inoperative, the frozen fat was slowly melting in Joseph Beuys' piece nearby.

78.title: Klüver on the restoration of Oracle in 1979
78.ref_bibliographic: Billy Klüver, "Four Collaborations" in Cornelia Faist, Alfred Kren (eds). Robert Rauschenberg : haywire : major technological works of the 1960s. Ostfildern-Ruit : Hatje, 1997. 111 p.
78.text:
I was able to plan a re-design of the system for Oracle in 1979. Engineer Ted Dillenkofer built a re-designed system for Oracle, which he and I installed in February 1979, after installing Solstice in the museum in Japan. All the electronics had been shipped to New Jersey and Ted worked with his father in his father's radio workshop to design and build the new system. Ted remembered:
An five AM band radios were put in the staircase unit and the visitor could directly control their volumes and sweep rates from the sets of knobs on the top of the staircase. The audio outputs from each of those AM radios went into a small wireless FM microphone which transmitted the signals to small FM receivers that were out in each of the individual pieces of the sculpture, which in turn were connected to the speakers. So the only thing that was actually being transmitted was the audio output of the AM radios.
The microphones were basically connected to the audio outputs of the radios. I don't remember whether they are connected to the speaker outputs or whether we bypassed the amplification section and just took it from the initial stages of the amplification system in those AM radios. There is a small coil in the transmitting microphones and you can adjust the frequency of each one individually. These were pretty primitive devices. You couldn't punch in what frequency they are supposed to transmit. But you can sit there and fiddle with them and fiddle with the radio; and it's a process where you set one and you set the radio for it, then you set the next one and you set the radio for if and you try not to get any interference between them; and then set the third one and try to set its radio, and it's an iterative thing.
The problem I had to deal with in setting the frequencies was interference in the FM transmitting frequency and with harmonies. There are not very tight filters on the signals. If you ever look at the frequency spectrum of the transmitted signal there is a big peak around where the center frequency is supposed to be and there are smaller peaks out to the side. Since with Oracle everything is being transmitted within ten feet, those smaller peaks are still pretty sizable peaks and they get locked on and get picked up by those FM receivers, so you wind up hearing things that you shouldn't hear on the various receivers, which sound like two radios rather than one radio.
I tried to make the main peaks as far apart as possible and not mathematically related. If you have a peak that is at a harmonic frequency of one of the other frequencies that is set, well naturally it is already locked in there and picks up that harmonic tao. You spread the frequencies across the band as far as you can and then you fiddle with them a little at a time to make sure they are just off from each other."

79.title: Klüver on the restoration of Oracle in 1981
79.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy ; Martin, Julie, « Working with Rauschenberg », in Walter Hopps and Susan Davidson (eds). Robert Rauschenberg : a retrospective, New York : Guggenheim Museum Publications, 1997, p. 310-327.
79.text: In 1981, the radios were changed to FM radios. Rauschenberg agreed to this change because the French government had opened up the FM band to independent stations. Within months, the number of stations on the FM band grew to about thirty-five with a mixture of news, classical music, popular music, and talk shows; the FM band in Paris became like the AM band in New York.

80.title: Klüver on the restoration of Oracle in 1992
80.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy ; Martin, Julie, « Working with Rauschenberg », in Walter Hopps and Susan Davidson (eds). Robert Rauschenberg : a retrospective, New York : Guggenheim Museum Publications, 1997, p. 310-327.
80.text: A re-design of the system in 1992 brought all the radios back into the control console and used an infrared system to transmit the resulting sound to the receivers and speakers in the other four pieces.

81.title: Klüver on the restauration of Oracle in 1997
81.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy ; Martin, Julie, « Working with Rauschenberg », in Walter Hopps and Susan Davidson (eds). Robert Rauschenberg : a retrospective, New York : Guggenheim Museum Publications, 1997, p. 310-327.
81.text: In 1997, Per Biorn and Toby Fitch updated the system. The five radios receiving either the AM or FM band are located in the control console in the staircase. Volume and sweep rate are controlled by potentiometers on the top of the staircase. Sweep rate is changed by using DC motors. The AM or FM band signal is then transmitted in the UHF band to receivers, amplifiers, and speakers in each of the other pieces.

90.title: Forge on the conception and production of Oracle
90.ref_bibliographic: Andrew Forge. Rauschenberg. New York: Harry N. Abrams, 1969.
90.text:
G.R. Swenson's account of Rauschenberg's studio (1) deals with a crucial period in 1962 when he was contemplating several new directions. These included both the silk-screen paintings and the "Concert Project", which appeared at last in 1965 as Oracle (2). This was a development of an earlier experiment with sound, the painting Broadcast of 1959, in which he had used three radios.
"In Broadcast", he told, Swenson, "I was interested, academically, in the relation sound would have to looking... I assumed that because the picture would have a voice, it would have to be bright and loud." At first he had used large letters and strongly contrasted colors, but when he finally inserted and used the radios he found that the whole painting flattened "like a poster" and that "loud" lost its double meaning. Something visually loud and emphatic, "which you could see from across the room", had the opposite effect with regard to sound and noise. "The painting went dead. All the boldness looked superficial, it implied merely static strength. I realized that the details should not be taken in at a glance, that you should be able to look from place to place without feeling the bigger image. I had to make a surface which invited a constant change of focus and an examination of detail. Listening happens in time. Looking also happens in time".
The three radios in Broadcast were set into the back of the painting, their tuning knobs projecting from its surface. The onlooker was free to tune them as he wished, but Rauschenberg was dissatisfied with the limitation that this placed on his movement in front of the picture. If the relation of sound and looking was to be developped it had to be realized in the appropriate space. The first form of the "Concert Project" was as five painting with speakers that could be remotely controlled. This idea was set aside (the five panels later becoming the painting Ace), and Rauschenberg became increasingly absorbed in the prospect of giving the five speakers to five free standing objects.
In its final form Oracle consists of a console with steps that one can mount and four other objects, of which the main features are a length of industrial duct in the form of a funnel, a window frame with duct, a car door, and a cistern.
In action each piece can be placed anywhere within the receiving range of the tuning system housed in the console. Each piece, the console included, has its own battery-operated radio, the tuning of which is in turn radio-operated. From the console on can control the volume and the tuning of each one, and also one can set the tuning motion so that a particular radio moves through the wave bands at a given speed. Thus, any one piece, which has its own distinctive timbre -the funnel deep and sonorous, the window dry and vibrant like snare drums, the car door raucous- can be set loud or soft, to music or speech, to any program that happens to be, or just static, off or on tune, fast or slow, swelling and ebbing from this station to the next, or stationary, or going through the band so fast that it twitters like a pack of cards sprung against the thumb. The one fixed point is the citern, which, in addition to its radio, pumps water through a shower spray into a tank. Its solid downward gush, turned in on itself, not broadcast, is a soothing alternative to the restless electronic sound.
To stand by the console is to be aware of a continual coming and going of sound, predominantly spatial. Yet it is not a space demarcated by its points of origin. It is a space that one hears, not a visible one. What one hears is a total sound, even though its parts can be identified as five voices; its movement seems to disintegrate the actual space marked out by the machines and to reconstitute it as something plastic, expanding and contracting, warping and cockling, a billowing whole whose boundaries token an utterly different order from the visible boundaries of the junk pieces. The very sensation of hearing, it seems, has become a kind of looking. One doesn't know which way to point one's eyes, so strikingly does the sound reframe the appearance of the machines, giving them a kind of speed -despite the fact that they just stand there dinning- or if not speed, a kind of flashing nowhereness like parked cars seen peripherally from a speeding scooter. And as soon as you move away from the console, among the pieces, you find your movements, your familiar physical measuring of close distances becoming a matter of urgency to be set alongside this new space that you are hearing inside your head. Pacing, steering, or the avoidance of edges is set beside the expanding elastic space in your head.

91.title: Solomon on the Exhibition of Oracle at the Leo Castelli Gallery (Alan Solomon)
91.ref_bibliographic: Alan Solomon, "Leo Castelli. Next Exhibition: Robert Rauschenberg "Oracle" May 15 - June 12, 1965", in ?, 1965

LEO CASTELLI 4 E.77  N.Y.21

NEXT EXHIBITION:
Robert Rauschenberg "Oracle" May 15 - June 12, 1965

Out of the blue, here is a major undertaking in sculpture by Rauschenberg. Five pieces, in the round, with sound, called Oracle. Five wheeled vehicules, responsibly plumb and electronically neat, or canted, askew, subtly aged with the Rauschenberg patina or metropolitan fallout and gutter gangrene. From each a shiny chrome tail protudes, an FM antenna, no less, because the sound part is serious and complex. (Well, not serious, but complicated).

That special sense of humor is operating again. How can one convey the irony, the wry understatement, the hilarious sense of absurd juxtaposition of things, the rock solid motion of bizarre appropriateness? Who ever heard of such objects (a car door, a typewriter table, the most outrageously textured piece of metal since the invention of abstract expressionism) cohabiting?

Last summer in Venice, the europeans (for them, pop means using objects), seeing his most recent pictures, the pure silk screen paintings of 1963-1964, said that Rauschenberg had transcended pop, even though he invented it. He certainly seemed to have put aside his involvement in the combine-painting through this long episode of flat painting. But now that is over; His restless inventiveness requires him to keep moving, and we should not be surprised to see him become interested in objects again.

Actually, this project has a long history, even if Rauschenberg may have finished the work at this time because of a renewed engagement with the problems. The idea originates in his first sound painting with radios, Broadcast, of 1959. In that piece, Knobs projecting from the surface permitted one to tune an ensemble of radios, producing a collage of sound. Rauschenberg felt that Broadcast could not function for the viewer/listener as well as he would have liked because one had to stand so close to tune it. He envisioned another project which could be remotely controlled, so that you could see and hear the result from a distance. He settled on a scheme of five independent paintings ("Five is the first complicated number; it's not two pairs, three or a couple"). The five panels were stretched, but the electronic problems became so complex that they held up the project. Typically, the canvases somehow promptly disappeared into Ace, one of his best and largest (20 feet) paintings of the period.

The radio parts imposed a certain depth on the paintings in this scheme (Broadcast is seven or eight inches deep), and it occured to Rauschenberg that sculpture would offer more interesting possibilities than the flat surfaces. As a result, he began to work on the five parts of Oracle in the spring of that year, 1962, but the project was interrupted by a trip to Amsterdam that summer. Until this winter, the work has progressed very slowly, constantly delayed by painting and by Rauschenberg's dance activities. The pieces had been close to their present state for some time, but once more electronic complexities held up the job.

Billy Klüver, the Edison-Tesla-Steinmetz-Marconi-Leonardo Da Vinci of the American Avant Garde (almost all the gadgetry which has figured so prominently in object art during the past five years was engineered and executed by Klüver, a Bell Laboratories research scientist), designed and built the radio system, which seems simple but is really quite elaborate. From the console unit five radios can be controlled, four in the other pieces via transmitters from the console; on five different FM frequencies, signals from the panel govern the volume and the speed of continuous tuning of the five radios. The result is a complex spectrum of sound which can be constantly altered by one person at the controls. Technical difficulties which had to be resolved included problems like that of interference among the transmitters; furthermore, the apparatus had to be foolproof and stable in performance.

Most difficult of all, of course, was the condition that the pieces had to be wholly mobile; otherwise they might simply have been connected by cables. Each of the units is self-contained and battery operated. Time has helped to solve some of the problems. The transmitters used were simply not available when the project was started three years ago; The present electronic system is the third since the work began.

Apart from the accidental melange of sound produced by the random tuning of the radios, the quality of sound varies from piece to piece according to the acoustical properties of each, so that they boom, rattle or trumpet through their insane gimcrackery of compulsive metalwork ducting and miscegenated vehicles. The electronic impurity of the sound suffers adulteration from only one source, the absolutely idiotic waterworks which may well be the only mobile fountain in existence.

Rauschenberg conceived the ensemble as being freely adaptable to any space and circumstance. The units may be placed anywhere within the range of the transmitters; Their mobility encourages rearrangement. The pieces seem daftly on the go. One wishes the controls also operated motors. What an antic traffic jam that would make!

Alan Solomon.

254.text:
eM 95
Robert RAUSCHENBERG
Oracle, 1965
Assemblage composé de 5 éléments: baignoire avec douche et tôle galvanisée et zinc montée sur roulettes en fer (178 x 115 x 60 cm), tuyau en tôle galvanisée monté sur roues de fer (143 x 116 x 73 cm), escalier en tôle d'aluminium monté sur roulettes (148 x 139 x 90 cm), montant de fenêtre 'en bois monté sur roulettes (158 x 236 x 47 cm), portière de voiture (avec vitre) monté sur bâti en fer à roulettes (160 x 133 x 85 cm). Chacun des 5 éléments comporte en outre une batterie, un poste- émetteur et un haut-parleur.
Musée National d'Art Moderne, Centre Georges Pompidou.
Oracle est l'aboutissement d'une recherche sur les collages sonores, contrepoints des collages visuels de l'artiste (ses «combine paintings » composées de fragments de bois, de tissus, de sérigraphies etc...). Trois ans d'expérimentations ininterrompues avec Billy Kluver aboutirent à Oracle. A l'origine c'était un raccourci de New York: les éléments proviennent de bâtiments de la ville, en voie de dégradation comme la ville elle-même, et les récepteurs placés dans chacune des pièces captaient toutes les longueurs d'ondes des radios new-yorkaises, en passant sans cesse d'une station émettrice à l'autre. Placée désormais dans une autre ville, l'œuvre peut être désormais comme un concentré de la vie urbaine. A Paris les postes reçoivent toutes les stations de la Tchécoslovaquie à l'Irlande, de Milan à Hambourg. La cacophonie qui en résulte est la voix même de la cité dans laquelle tous les bruits interfèrent un mélange aléatoire.
Hélène Lassalle in catalogue « Cinq années d'enrichissement du patrimoine national 1975-1980, Grand Palais, 1980 ».

255.title: G.R. Swenson's account of Rauschenberg's studio
255.ref_bibliographic: Swenson, G.R. “Rauschenberg Paints a Picture.” Art News 62, no. 2 (1963): 44-47; 65-67.
255.text:
When I first met him, in January, 1962, Robert Rauschenberg had just returned from an electronics laboratory in New Jersey. In his studio stood five large, tall white canvas panels, leaning against the longest wall of his newly painted white loft. He had been making arrangements at the laboratory for a system of radio loud speakers, one to go behind each panel, which would operate by remote control from a central cabinet. But the five panels which he had intended to use in the radio project were instead used for the quiet and majestic Ace, finished a few weeks later.
	There had been several large metal objects in the corner of his studio the day he returned from the electronics laboratory. They began to occupy more and more of his interest, and over a period of time they were moved to his central working area [fig. 6]. There were five pieces and he planned to put a radio into each of them; he also played with the idea of using running water, and eventually one of the pieces of the "concert project" became a fountain.
	One of the pieces for that project was a car door. The stages of response which changes in and around the door gradually evoked led to a better understanding of one aspect of Rauschenberg's work—the way he "transforms" objects. He does not use them as pure form and color, destroying our sense of their origin—which is what is usually meant by "transformation." Rather he seeks to retain or reinstate some quality the object possessed in its original environment. The door of a car is not noticeably distinguished from the frame of the car; it is seldom noticed, even when we use it. If we were to encounter such an object alone on the street, however, we would probably begin to notice the form of the door itself. When we see such an object in an artist's studio, we see a mere form with overtones of an automobile. Such a transformation had already taken place when I first saw the car door. What surprised me most was the way it gradually lost its quality of being a "transformed" object. It was re-integrated into a situation—given an environment in which it was both in place, as originally, and yet not smothered as pure form. Between the first time I saw it and the last, it had acquired literacy and an ability to communicate. I once mentioned that his objects often assert themselves so strongly that only time can integrate them for me. He said, "I don't like to take advantage of an object that can't defend itself.
	"When an object you're using does not stand out but yields its presence to what you're doing, it collaborates, so to speak—it implies a kind of harmony." The object blends indistinguishable into the pure colors and forms of the painting. "It ceases to be a simple tonality, but is part of a harmony in which no note can really be heard because the over-all vibrations are so unified. I like the idea of one sound, but I really don't like the idea that it is none of its components." He would not achieve a large harmonic structure at the expense of its components. "I would like my pictures to be able to be taken apart as easily as they're put together—so you can recognize an object when you're looking at it. Oil paint really does look like oil paint even in the most photographic painting."
	Several months after he finished Ace and started to work on the "concert" project, he began the piece whose progress was to be photographed and reported. Rauschenberg intended to do a small and simple combine-painting; the initial focus for the painting was a small wooden door. During the following months he worked intermittently on both this piece and the concert-radio project. His alternations reflected in part difficulties arising from being observed as well as from felt responsibilities not connected with his work itself. "I became too interested in the radio piece. The only honest thing to do was let that be the object of attention. Then I became embarrassed because it was taking shape so slowly and I was holding up the article. I decided to abandon the sculpture and concentrate only on the combine. I did, but, paid for it by not working well."

14.title: Variations V_2003_Klüver_design & production
14.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
14.text: John Cage made Variations V in 1965 for the Merce Cunningham Dance Company. He and David Tudor settled on two systems for the sound to be affected by movement. For the first, my colleagues and I set up a system of directional photocells aimed at the stage lights, so that the dancers triggered sounds as they cut the light beams with their movements. A second system used a series of antennas. When a dancer came within four feet of an antenna a sound would result. Ten photocells were wired to activate tape-recorders and short-wave radios. Cecil Coker designed a control circuit, which was built by my assistant Witt Wittnebert. Film footage by Stan VanDerBeek and Nam June Paik's manipulated television images were projected on screens behind the dancers.

15.title: Variations V_2003_Klüver_performance
15.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
15.text: In this photograph Variations V is performed for a television taping session in Hamburg. The photocells were located at the base of the five-foot antennas placed around the stage. Cage, Tudor, and Gordon Mumma operate equipment to modify and determine the final sounds.

phases.description: distinguer les deux performances (les acteurs étaient-ils présents à chaque fois ? ex : mumma)

16.title: Klüver on the design and production of Silver Clouds
16.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
16.text: At the 47th Street Factory, Andy Warhol asked me for a floating light bulb. We made some calculations and discovered it was not possible with existing battery technology. While working on the idea, my colleague at Bell Laboratories found a material called ScotchpakTM which was relatively impermeable to helium and could be heat sealed. It was used by the United States Army for wrapping sandwiches. When I brought this material to Andy he decided to make clouds and while we were figuring out how to heat-seal curves, he simply folded the material over and made these Silver Clouds, which were first shown at Leo Castelli's gallery in 1966. The sculptures had a wonderful buoyancy as they hovered gently in the room. The heat gradient between the floor and ceiling creates a slight pressure differential; we could balance the Silver Clouds using paperclips to make them float between ceiling and floor.

17.title: Klüver on the exhibition of Silver Clouds
17.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
17.text: When I brought this material to Andy he decided to make clouds and while we were figuring out how to heat-seal curves, he simply folded the material over and made these Silver Clouds, which were first shown at Leo Castelli's gallery in 1966. 542.title: Liberman on Silver Clouds in the Exhibition of the E.A.T. Press Conference
542.ref_bibliographic: Lieberman, Henry. «Art and science proclaim alliance in avant-garde loft». The New York Times. (Oct. 11, 1967). P. 49.
542.text:
In a sound-drenched Lower Manhattan loft building that was enlivened by revolving painted disks, film projections, floating pillows and miniskirted girls in paper smocks, representatives of industry and labor joined a number of artists and scientists yesterday to proclaim a "working alliance" between art and technology.
[...]
	While 20 helium-filled pillows floated eerily in a two-story room called "the Chapel," the need for bringing artist and technologist together was stressed in speeches by Senator Jacob K. Javits, a traditionalist who sees merit in modern art; Ralph C. Gross, president of the Commerce and Industry Association; Edwin Langsam, film projection supervisor of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company; Herman D. Kenin, head of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s new Scientific, Professional and Cultural Employes Council, and Dr. Warren Brodey, a psychiatrist, of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

6.name: First Meeting Planning of artists and engineers for the 9 Evenings

772.title: 9 Evenings catalogue (Addenda)
772.ref_bibliographic: 9 evenings : theatre and engineering. Edited by Pontus Hultén and Frank Königsberg. [New York] : Experiments in Art and Technology : The Foundation for Contemporary Performance Arts, [1966]. [12] p.

29.title: 9 Evenings_2003_Klüver_Performances
29.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
29.text: 9 Evenings: Theatre and Engineering opened on October 13, 1966, at the 69th Regiment Armory, a huge space on Lexington Avenue at 25th Street in New York City. The art community in New York became involved in helping us with 9 Evenings, as fellow artists, dancers, musicians, and performers volunteered their time for setting up and trouble shooting, and then appeared in the performances. A high-powered, but slightly distorted publicity campaign resulted in more than 1500 people each night attended the performances, many of them unprepared for the avant-garde performances they saw. In this photograph the crowd is entering the Armory on opening night. The 9 EVENINGS poster, designed by Rauschenberg, hangs on either side of the entrance, and an Army transport truck sits on the street, displaced from its usual parking place on the Armory floor.

18.title: Physical Things_2003_Klüver_Performance
18.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
18.text: In Steve Paxton's work, Physical Things, a polyethylene air-inflated structure occupied most of the Armory floor and a tower rose to the peak of the Armory roof. The audience walked through the structure, encountering slide projections, sounds and performers. Emerging from the structure, they used small receivers to hear different sounds broadcast from wire loops suspended in a net overhead.

724.title: Projects for Stockholm Festival (9 Evenings)
724.ref_bibliographic: E.A.T. news. Vol. 2, no. 1 (Mar. 18, 1968). New York : Experiments in Art and Technology, 1968. 18 p.
724.text:
Projects for Stockholm Festival
Feb. 13,1966
The following is a list of the projects which have so far been proposed. The tentativeness of the suggestions should be emphasized. Some projects will be scrapped and others will be added as we go along. A: artist who is mainly interested. T : technicians who will be mainly concerned.
1. 500 kc doppler sonar to pick up ordinary motion by the body. Beat frequency should be directly audible. A: Childs T: Coker, Klüver
2."Cocktailpartyeffect" Many (50 ? , 100 ?) speakers of low power placed on walls or around the room, or outside.Each speaker giving a different sound. What is the minimum amount of tape recorders that need be used? How many channels can be put on one tape? A: Paxton T : Mc Gee end others.
3. Stretch rubber or fabric in two directions so that area is multiplied many times. Probably use textured yarn and have commercial knitter make fabric to specification. A: D. Hay T: Wagner and others.
4. Use of air wall. Find out what is commercially available. Is it possible to make the wall opaque by adding powder to the airstream? How large do the air walls come? A; D. Bay and Mothers T: ?
5. Jello in which parts of the body can be immersed. A:Fahlström T: Winslow and others.
6. Clouds. Solid and otherwise. Use of styrene foams is possible if they are hollowed. And filled with helium. One liter helium can lift one gram, one liter foam weighs 1.5 grams. A: Fahlström and others. T ?
7. Gases. Which gases are nontoxic and innocent and affect people? ( Helium). A: Fahlström T : ?
8. Alex Hay wants to be raised. How can this be done? Compressed air, foam, or what? A: A.Hay T: ?
9. Subsonic sounds. A: Fahlström T: ?
10. Large ( more than ten feet ) mirrors made up of aluminized mylar, circular and stre[t]ched. The radius of curvature of the mirror can be changed continuously by applying pressure or vacuum behind aluminized sheeth. A: Paxton T : ?
11. All body functions which relate to use of energy: Use of CO., swaet, ECG, breathing to be converted into sound. A: Childs T : ?
12. 10 - 12 FM transmitters and rec[ei]vers which can be used for audio as well as switching . Price about 50 dollars / piece. A : all T : all
13. Battery driven photocell with relay A : all T : ?
14. Powerpak. What is the maximum power which can be obtained during ten minutes from batteries and which weights less than 30 pounds? A : Paxton. D.Hay T : ? Cannot be liquid batteries.
15. Time compression and extension. The recording of an actual event can either be speeded up of slowed down and shown instantaneously, at the same time as the event occurs. Use of tv or film? A: Whitman, Childs, T: ?
16: Feedback. Use of feedback through speakers and mikes carried by people to create variable sound A: Rauschenberg. T: Coker and others.
17. Infrared tv. Find out what tv pickup tubes are available on the market. What frequencies do body and other objects emit? What infrared light sources are available? How strong? The room in which the action occurs should be "dark" to visible light. Forms of rebroadcast: snooperscopes, tv sets, Eidaphor. A: Rauschenberg T: Heilos and others
18. Instant heat and cold. Use of infrared sources and liquid air. A: Whitman and others T : ?
19. Low frequency transmission loops, simple and with low definition. Each of the spectators to carry a receiver. A : some T : ?
20. Debbie Hay wants to be able to approach two objects (comb and hair, knife and fork / and connect a sound source (tape recorder) . In how many ways could such a switch be made? A : D.Hay T : ?
21. Fahlström and Rauschenberg want to float, suspended in air. A: Rauschenberg Fahlström T: Hailos
This list does not contain suggestions from [C]age or Tudor. They are out of town and will be back shortly.

2nd list Feb 20,1966
22. Doppler sonar. Display of velocity of moving objects. A. Lucinda Childs T: Coker.
23. Change frequency of heart beat - transform up or down. Use of filter. A: Fahlström T:?
24. Transform words. (Frequency, amplitude, filter) A: Paxton T: ?
25. Control objects at distance A : Fahlström
26. One or more floating forms following man that moves. A : Fahlström
27. Activate objects at distance with vortex gun, heat, light beam. A: Fahlström.
28. Photocells sensitive to light on movie or tv screen, A : Fahlström.
29. Suspension in air by 30 m3 of helium or rocket belt. A Fahlström
30. Balloons coming out of hat. Like thought balloons. A Fahlström
31. Clouds. A Fahlström
32. Display on large screen of image under microscope. A: Fahlström.
33. Write on wall with laser beam? Fluorescent material? A: Fahlström.

3rd list March 1,1966 (following 5th meeting )
34. It appears possible that impulses from flexing of muscles can be used to trigger switches (in connection with proposed wireless system for instance). Suggestion by Jim Mc Gee. T. Coker A. ?
35. Use of vocoder to transform voice sounds. Application in Debbies dance where the sound of combing ones hair will be heard as doves. There will be a taping session in which we will have a[c]cess to the vocoder. T. Coker A ? (Fahlström)
36. Red laser-light reflected back and forth across floor. Smoke to make light visible. T. Klüver. A Debbie
37. Changing colors. Needs moisture and acid. Change from colorless situation to color. Should be investigated. T. Winslow A (many)
38. Variation of 37. Fahlström wants to have blood [poisoning?] appear on arm by itself. Start dye reaction at certain time. T. Winslow. A Fahlström. Arm slowly turning blue.
39. Vacuum forming of plastics sheets. Heat polystyrene to boiling water? T. Winslow A Paxton. Use of mold.
40. Vinyl acetates such as Lucite return to original shape when heated to 100 ° C. Should get samples of Lucite. How large does it come.
41. In general inter[est] in materials which change phase (from solid to liquid or liquid to gas) at room temperature or close to it.
42. Light pipes made of Lucite. T ? A. Whitman.
43. Light sensitive chemical which changes color (or from colorless to color) in presence of light. Not ultraviolet. This should happen in controlled area. A. Rauschenberg.

757.title: 9 Evenings catalogue (page 16: program)

735.title: Kluver on the conception of 9 Evenings
735.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy ; Martin, Julie, « Working with Rauschenberg », in Walter Hopps and Susan Davidson (eds). Robert Rauschenberg : a retrospective, New York : Guggenheim Museum Publications, 1997, p. 310-327.
735.text: At the first meeting between the artists and the engineers, on January 14, 1966, I told the artists that they could ask for anything they wanted, and I asked the engineers to respond with suggestions on how to accomplish these ideas, if they could be realized at all. (Several of the artists wanted to float in the air.) These meetings lasted through March, and we gathered seventy artists' requests. Then one engineer was assigned to each artist depending on the artist's project and the engineer's field of expertise. Other engineers worked on sound and control equipment and systems that would be used by all the performers.

293.title: Grass Field in the catalogue 9 evenings: theater and engineering
293.ref_bibliographic: 9 evenings : theatre and engineering. Edited by Pontus Hultén and Frank Königsberg. [New York] : Experiments in Art and Technology : The Foundation for Contemporary Performance Arts, [1966]. [12] p.
293.text:
grass field

by: Alex Hay
performance engineer: Herb Schneider

sound distributor: David Tudor

cast: Steve Paxton [,] Robert Rauschenberg

credits: Schweber Electronics for integrated circuits; Mount Sinai Laboratory
for technical information

	A work built around three elements divided into parts equal in time.
Three elements:
1. Internal sound potentials of the body
2. External body color
3. A singular work activity
	The body sounds, example: brain waves, muscle movement, eye movement, will be
picked up by differential amplifiers and transmitted to the central control stations to be distributed by the sound person.
	All properties and dress will have the color identity of the skin of the performers.
	The work activity is the random placement of 100 numbered six foot squares of duck in a ten by ten modular pattern and then retrieved in a correct arithmetic progression and placed centrally. The placement and retrieving of the squares will be a designation of the two parts.

295.title: Corrections and Additions to the Program (Grass Field)
295.ref_bibliographic: ADDENDA: Corrections and Additions to the Program. [included in Hultén, Pontus, and Frank Königsberg (eds). 9 Evenings : Theatre and Engineering. [New York]: Experiments in Art and Technology : The Foundation for Contemporary Performance Arts, 1966.]
295.text:
GRASS FIELD by Alex Hay
Performance Engineer - Bob Kieronski
Critical terminal work on the amplifiers - David Davis, electronics technician, Mt. Sinai Hospital

746.title: Simone Forti on the conception of Grass Field
746.ref_bibliographic: Whitman, Simone. «Theater and engineering : an experiment : notes by a participant». Artforum. (Feb. 1967). P. 26-30.
746.text: Alex Hay: My first ideas were fantasy, science-fiction type ideas. I had ideas about machines that were going to move me about. A whole environment just for the purpose of various ways to deal with the human body. Then I began to feel that this didn't fit in with the technical things that were going to be available. For the most part, what they've been talking about, what seems to be more available are materials and processes and methods in communications.

747.title: Simone Forti on the conception/production of Grass Field
747.ref_bibliographic: Whitman, Simone. «Theater and engineering : an experiment : notes by a participant». Artforum. (Feb. 1967). P. 26-30.
747.text:
Meeting, 6/15, Steve Paxton: When can we have the wireless to play with? Kluver: August first. The first week in July will be a time when we'll show as many things as possible. There are a lot of decisions, like amplifiers and the choice of speakers. I have bought about eight or nine different speakers which have all kinds of criteria. Alex Hay: We need baffles for speakers. Kluver: You've got to start from the beginning; what the speakers are, then the baffles. The general situation is that we have people working on all the aspects of this wireless. (Billy gives a lot of technical description of the wireless system. The artists look blank.) It is just too difficult for me to act as an in-between and handle twenty engineers and ten artists. I can't call people for every single screw. I tell artists fo call scientists and scientists to call artists and no one calls. If there isn't direct human contact between you and the person working with you, if I have to do it, then it isn't contact. There are so many decisions going on now that you should be making along with the engineers. like, should the boxes be square or flat. Hay: As functional as possible. Kluver: That's not how things are made. You take what's on the shelf and if something special is needed, you ...
[...]
Alex Hay, 9/17: I want to pick up faint body sounds like brain waves, cardiac sounds, muscle sounds, and to amplify activity, its changing tempo and value. But we'd underestimated the problems about the transmitters. And Schneider was only assigned to me three weeks ago, and the first tests were just made last Wednesday. Billy thought the amplifiers they had could be modified but they can't. Now Cumminsky and Coker are working on it.

19.title: Klüver on the design and production of Grass Field
19.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
19.text: For Grass Field Alex Hay wanted to pick up body sounds: brain waves, muscle activity and eye movements. Pete Kaminsky, Fred Waldhauer and Cecil Coker built a battery-driven differential amplifier which had a peak gain of 80 db at low frequencies from 1/2 Hz to 10Hz. The whole unit, batteries and all fit into a 1"x3"x5" box, no mean feat to do this in 1966. The signal from the differential amplifier was fed into a voltage-controlled oscillator, then to a transmitter, which sent the sound to the speakers. Electrodes were placed on Hay's head and body and ail the equipment was attached to a plastic plate fastened on Hay's back. These body sounds were heard through the speakers as Hay carefully laid out 64 numbered pieces of cloth. Here Hay is sitting in front of a television camera and the image of his face is projected on the screen behind him as Robert Rauschenberg picks up numbered cloths.

724.title: Projects for Stockholm Festival (9 Evenings)

1. 500 kc doppler sonar to pick up ordinary motion by the body. Beat frequency should be directly audible. A: Childs T: Coker, Klüver
2."Cocktailpartyeffect" Many (50 ? , 100 ?) speakers of low power placed on walls or around the room, or outside.Each speaker giving a different sound. What is the minimum amount of tape recorders that need be used? How many channels can be put on one tape? A: Paxton T : Mc Gee end others.
3. Stretch rubber or fabric in two directions so that area is multiplied many times. Probably use textured yarn and have commercial knitter make fabric to specification. A: D. Hay T: Wagner and others.
4. Use of air wall. Find out what is commercially available. Is it possible to make the wall opaque by adding powder to the airstream? How large do the air walls come? A; D. Bay and Mothers T: ?
5. Jello in which parts of the body can be immersed. A:Fahlström T: Winslow and others.
6. Clouds. Solid and otherwise. Use of styrene foams is possible if they are hollowed. And filled with helium. One liter helium can lift one gram, one liter foam weighs 1.5 grams. A: Fahlström and others. T ?
7. Gases. Which gases are nontoxic and innocent and affect people? ( Helium). A: Fahlström T : ?
8. Alex Hay wants to be raised. How can this be done? Compressed air, foam, or what? A: A.Hay T: ?
9. Subsonic sounds. A: Fahlström T: ?
10. Large ( more than ten feet ) mirrors made up of aluminized mylar, circular and stre[t]ched. The radius of curvature of the mirror can be changed continuously by applying pressure or vacuum behind aluminized sheeth. A: Paxton T : ?
11. All body functions which relate to use of energy: Use of CO., swaet, ECG, breathing to be converted into sound. A: Childs T : ?
12. 10 - 12 FM transmitters and rec[ei]vers which can be used for audio as well as switching . Price about 50 dollars / piece. A : all T : all
13. Battery driven photocell with relay A : all T : ?
14. Powerpak. What is the maximum power which can be obtained during ten minutes from batteries and which weights less than 30 pounds? A : Paxton. D.Hay T : ? Cannot be liquid batteries.
15. Time compression and extension. The recording of an actual event can either be speeded up of slowed down and shown instantaneously, at the same time as the event occurs. Use of tv or film? A: Whitman, Childs, T: ?
16: Feedback. Use of feedback through speakers and mikes carried by people to create variable sound A: Rauschenberg. T: Coker and others.
17. Infrared tv. Find out what tv pickup tubes are available on the market. What frequencies do body and other objects emit? What infrared light sources are available? How strong? The room in which the action occurs should be "dark" to visible light. Forms of rebroadcast: snooperscopes, tv sets, Eidaphor. A: Rauschenberg T: Heilos and others
18. Instant heat and cold. Use of infrared sources and liquid air. A: Whitman and others T : ?
19. Low frequency transmission loops, simple and with low definition. Each of the spectators to carry a receiver. A : some T : ?
20. Debbie Hay wants to be able to approach two objects (comb and hair, knife and fork / and connect a sound source (tape recorder) . In how many ways could such a switch be made? A : D.Hay T : ?
21. Fahlström and Rauschenberg want to float, suspended in air. A: Rauschenberg Fahlström T: Hailos
This list does not contain suggestions from [C]age or Tudor. They are out of town and will be back shortly.

2nd list Feb 20,1966
22. Doppler sonar. Display of velocity of moving objects. A. Lucinda Childs T: Coker.
23. Change frequency of heart beat - transform up or down. Use of filter. A: Fahlström T:?
24. Transform words. (Frequency, amplitude, filter) A: Paxton T: ?
25. Control objects at distance A : Fahlström
26. One or more floating forms following man that moves. A : Fahlström
27. Activate objects at distance with vortex gun, heat, light beam. A: Fahlström.
28. Photocells sensitive to light on movie or tv screen, A : Fahlström.
29. Suspension in air by 30 m3 of helium or rocket belt. A Fahlström
30. Balloons coming out of hat. Like thought balloons. A Fahlström
31. Clouds. A Fahlström
32. Display on large screen of image under microscope. A: Fahlström.
33. Write on wall with laser beam? Fluorescent material? A: Fahlström.

3rd list March 1,1966 (following 5th meeting )
34. It appears possible that impulses from flexing of muscles can be used to trigger switches (in connection with proposed wireless system for instance). Suggestion by Jim Mc Gee. T. Coker A. ?
35. Use of vocoder to transform voice sounds. Application in Debbies dance where the sound of combing ones hair will be heard as doves. There will be a taping session in which we will have a[c]cess to the vocoder. T. Coker A ? (Fahlström)
36. Red laser-light reflected back and forth across floor. Smoke to make light visible. T. Klüver. A Debbie
37. Changing colors. Needs moisture and acid. Change from colorless situation to color. Should be investigated. T. Winslow A (many)
38. Variation of 37. Fahlström wants to have blood [poisoning?] appear on arm by itself. Start dye reaction at certain time. T. Winslow. A Fahlström. Arm slowly turning blue.
39. Vacuum forming of plastics sheets. Heat polystyrene to boiling water? T. Winslow A Paxton. Use of mold.
40. Vinyl acetates such as Lucite return to original shape when heated to 100 ° C. Should get samples of Lucite. How large does it come.
41. In general inter[est] in materials which change phase (from solid to liquid or liquid to gas) at room temperature or close to it.
42. Light pipes made of Lucite. T ? A. Whitman.
43. Light sensitive chemical which changes color (or from colorless to color) in presence of light. Not ultraviolet. This should happen in controlled area. A. Rauschenberg.
44. Temperature and pressure sensitive colors. Color cha[n]ge with pressure. Live fabrics. A Rauschenberg.
45. Lenses and prisms made of Lucite. Large lenses - two surfaces with water or ether liquid with high index of refraction in between. Make enormous telescope. Variable focal length lenses of large size. T. Hodges Winslow and others. A. Whitman and others.
46. Silicones. From GE in Waterford. Transparent silicones. How large volume? Could lenses be made? Get samples and info.
47. Lucite in acetone- get bubbles for Fahlströms thoughtballons. Nr 30.
48. Decomposition. Large structure that crumbles. Sugar. Collapse» Rubber frozen in liquid air will break like glass. Something that melts at room temperature. Rubber frozen with water inside. Chair that thus collapses after sometime. T. ? A Fahlström.
49. Concentrated, strong, battery-driven lights. A . Debbie.
50. Use of magnetic fields in connection with low friction surface. Objects moving on low friction surface (teflon) (grafite etc). Use of large electromagnets in general. A Lucinda, Fahlström etc.
51. Holy smokes. very light stable smokes. Thin wall bubbles. Try.
52. Nitrous Iodine. Cracks and pops on the floor when you walk on it. Very dangerous. A Rauschenberg Get.
53. Something that grows. Sponge under pressure (when dried) will grow and swell. It increases in size. A Fahlström.
54. Suassage [sausage ?] containing polyurethane in mouth. A Fahlström. Try.
55. Suction cups in the ceiling.
56.Hollow fiber or tube in which gas or liquid changes color. A Steve and Debbie.
57. Cars controlled at a distance. A. Debbie.

4th list March 8th, 1966. After 5th and 6th meetings.
58. Moving sound source to be adapted to wireless system. A Paxton and others. T Coker
59. Nowhere sound. Use of time delay in general. A Rauschenberg T Coker
60. A great amount of miniature surplus tape recorders. Have these adapted. A Paxton T McGee
61. Home tv projection system. Small screens. Cheep. A Whitman and others T Heilos and others.
62. Movie-tape-movie transfer system for color to manipulate colors locally on film. Design Coker. A Whitman.
63. Using TV tape for mixing of sound and image in superimposition economically ( black and white ) A Rauschenberg T Heilos
64. Printing of tape manually - without tape recorders. A . Rauschenberg
65. Audio tape cartridges. A Paxton
66. Investigate color tv tape-projection system. A Whitman T Heilos and others.

NEW PROJECTS
67. smoke to come out of costume at different points, different color.A. Whitman
68, snowfall that doesn't fall A. Fahlström
69. Strong continuous or intermittent light to light up a room. A. Rauschenberg, Whitman, [F]ahlström
70. Heilos and Trossolo are looking into different types of projector schemes and microprojectors

296.title: Solo in the catalogue 9 evenings: theater and engineering
296.ref_bibliographic: 9 evenings : theatre and engineering. Edited by Pontus Hultén and Frank Königsberg. [New York] : Experiments in Art and Technology : The Foundation for Contemporary Performance Arts, [1966]. [12] p.
296.text:
solo
by: Deborah Hay
performance engineer: Larry Heilos

performers: Franny Breer[,] Lucinda Childs[,] William Davis[,] Jim Jardy[,] Alex Hay[,] Deborah Hay[,] Margaret Hecht[,] Ed Iverson[,] Kathy Iverson[,] Julie Judd[,] Olga Klüver[,] Vernon Lobb[,] Fujiko Kakaya[,] Steve Paxton[,] Bob Rauschenberg[,] Joe Schlichter[,] Bob Schüler[,] Marjorie Strider[,] Carol Summers[,] James Tenny

music: "Funakakushi" by Toshi Ichiyanagi

men's costumes by Letty Lou Eisenhauer

Solo is a white, even, clear event in space. The performers are part of the space and light. They continue the quality of the area - a white environment.  All movement is with the intention of maintaining a balance of order and eveness.
"Solo" is cumulative, gradually accumulating more light, more platforms, more performers, more activity --yet remaining as still and composed as in the beginning.
There are 24 performers.  Eight of the performers remain stationery.  Formally dressed, they are seated as a musical ensemble. From this position they operate eight remote control platforms, which move in and around the space. Sixteen of the performers also move in and around the space, sometimes on the platforms.
Bright lights around the stage area are strongly reflected by the white costumes of the 16 moving performers. The extreme intensity of light bouncing off the costumes modifies the lines of the human body.  At times there are no lights.  I am interested in creating a middle ground between seeing and not seeing.
The principal visual elements of the piece are moving performers, lights, darkness, remote control platforms, and movement.  It is my main intention to make all these elements in equal in energy and visibility.

28.title: Klüver on the performance of Solo
28.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
28.text:
Eight formally dressed performers entered and sat like a musical ensemble in front of antennas that transmitted the FM signal to the platforms. They operated the radio-control system to move the platforms into and around the space. Composer Jim Tenney acted as "conductor" of the orchestra.
Sixteen dancers, wearing shiny white costumes, entered the brightly lit space either walking or riding on a cart. They then walked or rode on the moving platforms in solo, duet, or trio formations, following specific rules for dancer and platform movement in relation to the performance area and to each other. David Tudor performed Toshi Ichiyanagi's work Funakakushi. From time to time the lights were turned out, coming back on to find dancers and platforms in different positions as they had continued performing in the darkness.
