772.ref_bibliographic: 9 evenings : theatre and engineering. Edited by Pontus Hultén and Frank Königsberg. [New York] : Experiments in Art and Technology : The Foundation for Contemporary Performance Arts, [1966]. [12] p.

741.title: Simone Forti on the conception of Kisses Sweeter than Wine
741.ref_bibliographic: Whitman, Simone. «Theater and engineering : an experiment : notes by a participant». Artforum. (Feb. 1967). P. 26-30.
741.text: Oyvind Fahlstrom: I'm interested in enlarging and renewing conventional theatre. In combining different aspects of one thing that is going on. Different angles. Closeups. I want to pick up and highlight details. In theatre it's usually hard to convey anything but large clear goings on. I've been interested in details in the past. In Sweden I did a piece in which I used the image of pricking skin with a pin. Of course, few people in the audience could see it. Now you can pick things like this up (with closed circuit TV) and get a many-faceted impression.

742.title: Simone Forti on the conception/production of Kisses Sweeter than Wine
742.ref_bibliographic: Whitman, Simone. «Theater and engineering : an experiment : notes by a participant». Artforum. (Feb. 1967). P. 26-30.
742.text:
Jim McGee (technician) 3/9: I called Steve (Paxton) a few times. There's a lack of understanding by the scientists of what the artists want. They would accept a lot of things but it's a question of what they would prefer. For example, Harold H. is building Fahlstrom's antimissilemissile (a balloon which follows a performer around). He was working hard to make a rectangular balloon. I suggested he make it round. Harold called Fahlstrom who said that was even better. I can see the other side; it's difficult to know what the finished product will look like. 
[...]
Larry Heilos (tech) 4/5: The artists shouldn't feel restricted in their demands. We can tell them if what they want can be done now. Cage wants to get video through audio. People in industry would throw up their hands and say you can't do it. We have to try it out. We may lose a few dollars worth of tape. The requests are not surprising. Many are on electronics. Many are challenging, such as Fahlstrom's missile. I'm running down TV information. And I've been on the tail of a guy at Beva Electronics who says he can build infrared TV. The only thing to do is to tell the guys in industry from the very beginning what you have in mind. The cooperation has been great. I've talked with NBC on occasion and they're very cooperative.

724.title: Projects for Stockholm Festival (9 Evenings)
724.ref_bibliographic: E.A.T. news. Vol. 2, no. 1 (Mar. 18, 1968). New York : Experiments in Art and Technology, 1968. 18 p.
724.text:
Projects for Stockholm Festival
Feb. 13,1966
The following is a list of the projects which have so far been proposed. The tentativeness of the suggestions should be emphasized. Some projects will be scrapped and others will be added as we go along. A: artist who is mainly interested. T : technicians who will be mainly concerned.
1. 500 kc doppler sonar to pick up ordinary motion by the body. Beat frequency should be directly audible. A: Childs T: Coker, Klüver
2."Cocktailpartyeffect" Many (50 ? , 100 ?) speakers of low power placed on walls or around the room, or outside.Each speaker giving a different sound. What is the minimum amount of tape recorders that need be used? How many channels can be put on one tape? A: Paxton T : Mc Gee end others.
3. Stretch rubber or fabric in two directions so that area is multiplied many times. Probably use textured yarn and have commercial knitter make fabric to specification. A: D. Hay T: Wagner and others.
4. Use of air wall. Find out what is commercially available. Is it possible to make the wall opaque by adding powder to the airstream? How large do the air walls come? A; D. Bay and Mothers T: ?
5. Jello in which parts of the body can be immersed. A:Fahlström T: Winslow and others.
6. Clouds. Solid and otherwise. Use of styrene foams is possible if they are hollowed. And filled with helium. One liter helium can lift one gram, one liter foam weighs 1.5 grams. A: Fahlström and others. T ?
7. Gases. Which gases are nontoxic and innocent and affect people? ( Helium). A: Fahlström T : ?
8. Alex Hay wants to be raised. How can this be done? Compressed air, foam, or what? A: A.Hay T: ?
9. Subsonic sounds. A: Fahlström T: ?
10. Large ( more than ten feet ) mirrors made up of aluminized mylar, circular and stre[t]ched. The radius of curvature of the mirror can be changed continuously by applying pressure or vacuum behind aluminized sheeth. A: Paxton T : ?
11. All body functions which relate to use of energy: Use of CO., swaet, ECG, breathing to be converted into sound. A: Childs T : ?
12. 10 - 12 FM transmitters and rec[ei]vers which can be used for audio as well as switching . Price about 50 dollars / piece. A : all T : all
13. Battery driven photocell with relay A : all T : ?
14. Powerpak. What is the maximum power which can be obtained during ten minutes from batteries and which weights less than 30 pounds? A : Paxton. D.Hay T : ? Cannot be liquid batteries.
15. Time compression and extension. The recording of an actual event can either be speeded up of slowed down and shown instantaneously, at the same time as the event occurs. Use of tv or film? A: Whitman, Childs, T: ?
16: Feedback. Use of feedback through speakers and mikes carried by people to create variable sound A: Rauschenberg. T: Coker and others.
17. Infrared tv. Find out what tv pickup tubes are available on the market. What frequencies do body and other objects emit? What infrared light sources are available? How strong? The room in which the action occurs should be "dark" to visible light. Forms of rebroadcast: snooperscopes, tv sets, Eidaphor. A: Rauschenberg T: Heilos and others
18. Instant heat and cold. Use of infrared sources and liquid air. A: Whitman and others T : ?
19. Low frequency transmission loops, simple and with low definition. Each of the spectators to carry a receiver. A : some T : ?
20. Debbie Hay wants to be able to approach two objects (comb and hair, knife and fork / and connect a sound source (tape recorder) . In how many ways could such a switch be made? A : D.Hay T : ?
21. Fahlström and Rauschenberg want to float, suspended in air. A: Rauschenberg Fahlström T: Hailos
This list does not contain suggestions from [C]age or Tudor. They are out of town and will be back shortly.

2nd list Feb 20,1966
22. Doppler sonar. Display of velocity of moving objects. A. Lucinda Childs T: Coker.
23. Change frequency of heart beat - transform up or down. Use of filter. A: Fahlström T:?
24. Transform words. (Frequency, amplitude, filter) A: Paxton T: ?
25. Control objects at distance A : Fahlström
26. One or more floating forms following man that moves. A : Fahlström
27. Activate objects at distance with vortex gun, heat, light beam. A: Fahlström.
28. Photocells sensitive to light on movie or tv screen, A : Fahlström.
29. Suspension in air by 30 m3 of helium or rocket belt. A Fahlström
30. Balloons coming out of hat. Like thought balloons. A Fahlström
31. Clouds. A Fahlström
32. Display on large screen of image under microscope. A: Fahlström.
33. Write on wall with laser beam? Fluorescent material? A: Fahlström.

3rd list March 1,1966 (following 5th meeting )
34. It appears possible that impulses from flexing of muscles can be used to trigger switches (in connection with proposed wireless system for instance). Suggestion by Jim Mc Gee. T. Coker A. ?
35. Use of vocoder to transform voice sounds. Application in Debbies dance where the sound of combing ones hair will be heard as doves. There will be a taping session in which we will have a[c]cess to the vocoder. T. Coker A ? (Fahlström)
36. Red laser-light reflected back and forth across floor. Smoke to make light visible. T. Klüver. A Debbie
37. Changing colors. Needs moisture and acid. Change from colorless situation to color. Should be investigated. T. Winslow A (many)
38. Variation of 37. Fahlström wants to have blood [poisoning?] appear on arm by itself. Start dye reaction at certain time. T. Winslow. A Fahlström. Arm slowly turning blue.
39. Vacuum forming of plastics sheets. Heat polystyrene to boiling water? T. Winslow A Paxton. Use of mold.
40. Vinyl acetates such as Lucite return to original shape when heated to 100 ° C. Should get samples of Lucite. How large does it come.
41. In general inter[est] in materials which change phase (from solid to liquid or liquid to gas) at room temperature or close to it.
42. Light pipes made of Lucite. T ? A. Whitman.
43. Light sensitive chemical which changes color (or from colorless to color) in presence of light. Not ultraviolet. This should happen in controlled area. A. Rauschenberg.
44. Temperature and pressure sensitive colors. Color cha[n]ge with pressure. Live fabrics. A Rauschenberg.
45. Lenses and prisms made of Lucite. Large lenses - two surfaces with water or ether liquid with high index of refraction in between. Make enormous telescope. Variable focal length lenses of large size. T. Hodges Winslow and others. A. Whitman and others.
46. Silicones. From GE in Waterford. Transparent silicones. How large volume? Could lenses be made? Get samples and info.
47. Lucite in acetone- get bubbles for Fahlströms thoughtballons. Nr 30.
48. Decomposition. Large structure that crumbles. Sugar. Collapse» Rubber frozen in liquid air will break like glass. Something that melts at room temperature. Rubber frozen with water inside. Chair that thus collapses after sometime. T. ? A Fahlström.
49. Concentrated, strong, battery-driven lights. A . Debbie.
50. Use of magnetic fields in connection with low friction surface. Objects moving on low friction surface (teflon) (grafite etc). Use of large electromagnets in general. A Lucinda, Fahlström etc.
51. Holy smokes. very light stable smokes. Thin wall bubbles. Try.
52. Nitrous Iodine. Cracks and pops on the floor when you walk on it. Very dangerous. A Rauschenberg Get.
53. Something that grows. Sponge under pressure (when dried) will grow and swell. It increases in size. A Fahlström.
54. Suassage [sausage ?] containing polyurethane in mouth. A Fahlström. Try.
55. Suction cups in the ceiling.
56.Hollow fiber or tube in which gas or liquid changes color. A Steve and Debbie.
57. Cars controlled at a distance. A. Debbie.

4th list March 8th, 1966. After 5th and 6th meetings.
58. Moving sound source to be adapted to wireless system. A Paxton and others. T Coker
59. Nowhere sound. Use of time delay in general. A Rauschenberg T Coker
60. A great amount of miniature surplus tape recorders. Have these adapted. A Paxton T McGee
61. Home tv projection system. Small screens. Cheep. A Whitman and others T Heilos and others.
62. Movie-tape-movie transfer system for color to manipulate colors locally on film. Design Coker. A Whitman.
63. Using TV tape for mixing of sound and image in superimposition economically ( black and white ) A Rauschenberg T Heilos
64. Printing of tape manually - without tape recorders. A . Rauschenberg
65. Audio tape cartridges. A Paxton
66. Investigate color tv tape-projection system. A Whitman T Heilos and others.

NEW PROJECTS
67. smoke to come out of costume at different points, different color.A. Whitman
68, snowfall that doesn't fall A. Fahlström
69. Strong continuous or intermittent light to light up a room. A. Rauschenberg, Whitman, [F]ahlström
70. Heilos and Trossolo are looking into different types of projector schemes and microprojectors

762.title: 9 Evenings catalogue (page 6)
762.ref_bibliographic: 9 evenings : theatre and engineering. Edited by Pontus Hultén and Frank Königsberg. [New York] : Experiments in Art and Technology : The Foundation for Contemporary Performance Arts, [1966]. [12] p.

732.title: Remarks by Oyvind Fahlstrom, 9 Evenings: Theater and Engineering: pressbriefing. September 29, 1966.
732.ref_bibliographic: Press package for 9 evenings : theatre and engineering. New York : Ruder and Finn, September 29, 1966.
732.text:
In my piece, "Kisses Sweeter Than Wine," I approach the new technology on several levels. Chemicals developed by the new technology permit me to use elements formerly not possible—an object gradually changing color, "snow bubbles" rising from the ground, people enveloped by "clouds." By utilizing our internal broadcasting system, I can have pillows sing out while they are bounced on the floor or thrown in the air. By utilizing our remote control system, I can have an actor pursued by an airborne object or direct the same object to approach floating targets.
On another level, my piece deals with machine-like qualities in people: robot-like people capable of memorizing enormous amounts of data or of making multidigit calculations in their heads (as found in psychiatric literature); the risk of putting "robots" (narrow minds) in situations for which they are not "programmed"— i.e., crisis situations—and machines getting out of control.
Juxtaposed with this are glimpses of everyday events and characters of the world of today. Bob Hope and Mao Tse Tung appear in New York City street demonstrations, for example. For this we will use films of an actual demonstration along with tapes of the reactions of the people who see it. Tape and film become a part of the piece. New York, China, Indonesia, the bottom of the sea, space, the world of the future (as seen in a science fiction movie)—all are interwoven into a triptych of slide, movie, and television screens. There is no explanation. The spectator draws conclusions or not, as he chooses. I think of it as initiation rites for a new medium, Total Theater.

37.title: Klüver on the performance of Kisses Sweeter than Wine
37.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
37.text: Oyvind Fahls[t]röm's Kisses Sweeter than Wine was a complex, poetic theater performance incorporating live actors, elaborate props, and a triptych of slide, movie and television projection screens. Oyvind used a pillow that "could sing out while it was bounced on the floor," a remote-controlled mylar missile circling the Armory, and snowflakes that fell upward. Characters included Jedadiah Buxton and other idiot savants who were "capable of memorizing enormous amounts of data or of making multi-digit calculations in their head; "a girl in a plastic swimming pool of Jello, Chinese Sparrows under attack, and Space Girl, dressed in silver, who descended in a winch hoist from the ceiling. Performers in white dress shirts gather around her as she holds up the head of then President Lyndon B. Johnson.

735.title: Kluver on the conception of 9 Evenings
735.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy ; Martin, Julie, « Working with Rauschenberg », in Walter Hopps and Susan Davidson (eds). Robert Rauschenberg : a retrospective, New York : Guggenheim Museum Publications, 1997, p. 310-327.
735.text: At the first meeting between the artists and the engineers, on January 14, 1966, I told the artists that they could ask for anything they wanted, and I asked the engineers to respond with suggestions on how to accomplish these ideas, if they could be realized at all. (Several of the artists wanted to float in the air.) These meetings lasted through March, and we gathered seventy artists' requests. Then one engineer was assigned to each artist depending on the artist's project and the engineer's field of expertise. Other engineers worked on sound and control equipment and systems that would be used by all the performers.

18.name: E.A.T. Meeting at the Central Plaza Hotel, New York

39.title: E.A.T. Meeting at the Central Plaza Hotel_2003_Klüver_Holding
39.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
39.text: 9 Evenings generated a great interest in using new technology among the artists in New York, Robert Whitman, Fred Waldhauer, Robert Rauschenberg, and I decided to form Experiments in Art and Technology as a not-for-profit service organization for artists, engineers, scientists and industry, to promote artists' access to the new technology they wanted for their work. On November 30, 1966, we called a meeting at the Central Plaza Hotel on lower Broadway in New York to determine the amount of interest the artists had in this idea. Three hundred artists came to the meeting, and we collected eighty immediate requests for technical help. We realized that our first task was to interest more engineers in working with artists.

41.title: Klüver on the Technical Service Program
41.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
41.text: The idea of the one-to-one collaboration between individual artists and engineers or scientists was the basis of E.A.T. These collaborations made it possible for artists to pursue ideas that required the use of new technology, and the work could develop in directions that neither the artist or the engineer could have foreseen. We also believed that these collaborations could lead technology in directions more positive for the needs, desires, and pleasures of the individual. We developed the Technical Services Program, whose principal activity was to match artists who had technical problems or projects with engineers or scientists who could work with them. Over the years E.A.T. has helped thousands of artists who approached us for technical assistance. In 1967 Fred Waldhauer and L.J. Robinson collaborated with Rauschenberg on his large interactive sculpture Soundings. In this photograph Robinson, center, talks with Rauschenberg, to the right, during the installation of Soundings at the Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam.

46.title: Klüver on the Participation to the Annual meeting of IEEE in 1967
46.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
46.text: [...] In March 1967 we took a booth at the annual meeting of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) where artists made the case for engineers getting involved. In this photograph artists Tom Gormley and Hans Haacke, far right, are talking to an engineer. [...]

phases.description:
Technical Service 
Experiment in Art and Technology Program
1966-1973

42.title: Klüver describing the work Soundings
42.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
42.text: In a silent space Soundings is a mirror, eight feet high and thirty-six feet long. Behind the partially mirrorized front layer are two layers of plexiglass with images of wooden chairs silkscreened on them. Different lights behind the sheets of plexiglass are triggered by sounds in the room so that sets of lights go on, and illuminated images of chairs are seen through the mirror. Technically, Soundings works by having the sound signal from microphones hung in front of the panels split into four frequency bands, chosen to correspond to the pitch of different human voices. The signal from each frequency band controls a set of thirty-six 150-watt spotlights. and the brightness of the lights varies in intensity based on the volume of the sound. Thus, one frequency band activates nine lights throughout the piece; and soft sounds will produce a low light level.

43.title: Klüver on the E.A.T. Press Conference and Exhibition
43.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
43.text: With the help of Theodore Kheel, we organized a press conference at Bob Rauschenberg's building on October 10, 1967, to formally launch E.A.T. It was accompanied by a one-day exhibition of works of art incorporating technology. Representatives from industry, labor, government, and the academic and technical communities, including John Pierce of Bell Laboratories, and Senator Jacob Javits, expressed support for E.A.T. at the press conference. Press coverage exceeded our expectations, including this above-the-fold article in The New York Times.

397.title: Press Conference for E.A.T.
397.ref_bibliographic: Press conference for E.A.T.. New York : Experiments in Art and Technology, [October 1967]. Set of 13 elements. Press kit. Includes press releases, speeches, biographies of board members of E.A.T. and an artist's statement.
397.text:
PRESS CONFERENCE FOR E.A.T.

The press conference will take place at Robert Rauschenberg's studios, 381 Lafayette Street, New York City, on October 10 at 4:00 p.m. It is held jointly by the American Foundation on Automation and Employment and Experiments in Art and Technology.

Purpose:
1. To acquaint the technical and industrial community with E.A.T. s program and objectives.
2. To gain support for E.A.T. from industries, labor unions and individuals.
3. To announce an agreement whereby E.A.T. will receive assistance and headquarters space in Automation House from the American Foundation on Automation and Employment.

Invited are:
	50 labor union officials
	100 scientists and engineers
	100 industrial leaders
	30 artists
	175 representatives from technical press
	75 representatives from other press, television and radio
	25 museum curators
	30 leaders from technical institutions
	15 politicians

	The program will include statements by Theodore Kheel, Robert Rauschenberg and Billy Klüver. In addition, statements will be given by Messrs. Ralph Gross, Robert Morris, Herman Kenin, Senator Jacob K. Javits, Dr. John Pierce and Dr. Warren Brodey in support of our aims.

[Press Conference For E.A.T. - 2]

	Fifteen works resulting from collaborations between artists and engineers will be exhibited during the conference.
	A projection television system will provide direct visual contact between the different floors in the building.
	The press and members of the technical, industrial and labor communities will be given a press package containing:
		Program from "9 Evenings"
		Reporter Magazine
		Photos of collaborations
		E.A.T. Newsletters
		E.A.T. Brochure
		Brochure from American Foundation on Automation and Employment
		Reprints from Spectrum, Art Forum, Fortune
		Press release and attachments including lists of Supporting Members and Patrons of E.A.T. and excerpts from speeches

	Other data such as short biographies of members of the board of E.A.T. and technical description of the art world will be available on request.

398.title: Remarks by Billy Klüver at the E.A.T. Press Conference
398.ref_bibliographic: Press conference for E.A.T.. New York : Experiments in Art and Technology, [October 1967]. Set of 13 elements. Press kit. Includes press releases, speeches, biographies of board members of E.A.T. and an artist's statement.
398.text:
REMARKS BY BILLY KLÜVER
President
Experiments in Art and Technology
New York, New York

Experiments in Art and Technology is not organized for the benefit of the artist.

Experiments in Art and Technology in a real sense is a revolutionary process to catalyze the individual's responsibility for the shaping of the new technology. We can no longer claim innocence for the human and social consequences resulting from technological change. We are, in all respects, responsible for the technology that will form our environment tomorrow. This responsibility implies the search for a technology directed towards pleasure and enjoyment. It implies an awareness of the distinction between functional and ecological aspects of technology. It implies that the inherent authority of a medium is recognized so that exploration rather than education can be emphasized. It implies that we expand and enrich technology in a conscious way. it implies the elimination of the distinction between work and leisure.

E.A.T. will stimulate this awareness within industry, labor, the technical community, politics and the arts by developing an effective method of collaboration between artists and engineers. The artist functions autonomously. His constraints are physical. His subject matter is the relation of the human being to the world. The engineer works within a group. His work is bounded by economic consideration, existing investments in equipment and regulatory standards. The raison d'etre of E.A.T. is that the collaboration may yield a work which is neither the preconception of the engineer nor the artist but a result of the human interaction between their two areas.

The manifestations of the artist-engineer interaction will become known through professional channels such as articles in technical journals, technical conferences and the formation of professional groups for Engineering in Art. Our alliance with the American Foundation on Automation and Employment will considerably expand E.A.T. 's dialogue with labor and industry. In the Foundation's building on East 68th Street, we will be able to make use of the latest technical equipment for performances and exhibitions.

The collaborative projects will explore new and relevant uses of technology, they will give the artist and the engineer a new awareness and insight, and they will require the positive involvement of industrial leadership, labor and politics. This interaction will generate a fusing of specializations from which a new responsibility will emerge.

We are asking all of you here from the press, industry, politics, labor, the arts and the technical community to recognize and share in this responsibility which forms the base of E.A. T. and to lend your authority and sympathy in support of our enterprise.

399.title: Remarks by Herman D. Kenin at the E.A.T. Press Conference
399.ref_bibliographic: Press conference for E.A.T.. New York : Experiments in Art and Technology, [October 1967]. Set of 13 elements. Press kit. Includes press releases, speeches, biographies of board members of E.A.T. and an artist's statement.
399.text:
REMARKS BY HERMAN D. KENIN
President
American Federation of Musicians

It has been said that "a people can never be fully civilized until the economy is the servant of the peoples culture and not the master. " Today, with the formation of E.A.T. , we affirm once again that the knowledge of the scientist can and must be wedded in the effort of enriching and ennobling the life of Man. The skills of the engineer and scientist are meant for more than supporting an endless flow of gadgetry; the talents of actor, musician and painter must have a greater place in the scheme of our society than that of helping to sell soap, tail fins and hair pins. When these men and women are not assisted in their efforts to make their fullest contribution, then not only is their dignity as human beings diminished but the worth of our civilization is seriously lessened as well.
	E.A.T. will offer such assistance and because it does, it has my whole-hearted support and interest.
	I am here today representing the council of AFL-CIO Unions For SPACE. The Council is a new organization, younger, in fact, than E.A.T. It comprises 18 international unions representing many hundreds of thousands of professional employees throughout our land. These people are teachers, librarians, engineers, nurses, actors, dancers, singers and musicians. They are technicians and artists who will benefit from the work of E.A.T. , and they are also the audience and patrons who will enjoy the products of E.A.T. 's efforts.
	As practitioners in the arts and sciences, the membership of our constituent unions are concerned about the growing chasm between the disciplines as compartmentilizations and specializations become increasingly the rule in our organization of industries and the economy. As engineers, scientists, and artists, the members of AFL-CIO unions are concerned by the growing impersonalization of their work and by the frustrations they face in attempting to employ their knowledge and talents in making what they might consider a valid contribution to our civilization.
	As audiences and consumers, the membership of our unions are concerned that the products they buy, the entertainment they see, the environment in which they find themselves during the growing period of time they can spend away from their work place are so unfulfilling and unrepresentative of the best of which our society is capable.
	In our council we will bring together many dedicated professionals. We will concern ourselves not only with their working environment so that they can make their fullest contributions in their professions, but, also, with the quality of society to which they are asked to contribute their knowledge and talents. The work of E. A. T. will have an impact in both areas. Those who are employed as engineers and artists — the many hundreds of thousands who are represented in our council — welcome the opportunity to work with E.A.T.

400.title: Remarks by John Pierce at the E.A.T. Press Conference
400.ref_bibliographic: Press conference for E.A.T.. New York : Experiments in Art and Technology, [October 1967]. Set of 13 elements. Press kit. Includes press releases, speeches, biographies of board members of E.A.T. and an artist's statement.
400.text:
REMARKS BY JOHN R. PIERCE
Executive Director
Bell Telephone Laboratories
Murray Hill, New Jersey

	Technology is the source of the material well-being of our age. Man cannot live without art. Sometimes it seems that our culture and our lives are becoming fragmented. I am happy that dedicated and talented people are bringing art and technology together through experimentation, which is a common ground to both.
	Billy Klüver, Robert Rauschenberg and their colleagues have succeeded surprisingly in arousing interest among capable men in a variety of fields. They have established an organization and have found gratifying financial support for making a promising start.
	This bold new venture deserves whatever help people can give it. Surely, art cannot safely ignore or reject such a powerful force as technology. And, technology should not be without art. Technology is a tool which we should use toward social and creative ends.
	Bridging the gap between art and technology is not easy. Backgrounds, knowledge and expectations are different. If they are to succeed, artists must learn to use the possible, and technologists must reach out for the impossible. E.A.T. is providing a mechanism and avenue for mutual understanding and cooperation. It is up to artists, technologists and those who appreciate and support their efforts to see that E.A.T. succeeds.

401.title: Excerpts from Remarks by Ralph C. Gross at the E.A.T. Press Conference
401.ref_bibliographic: Press conference for E.A.T.. New York : Experiments in Art and Technology, [October 1967]. Set of 13 elements. Press kit. Includes press releases, speeches, biographies of board members of E.A.T. and an artist's statement.
401.text:
EXCERPTS FROM REMARKS BY RALPH C. GROSS
President
Commerce and Industry Association

	Along with its obligation to be a profit maker for its owners, the modern business corporation has an obligation to be a good citizen in the community. As a basic part of this obligation, the corporation must examine carefully its responsibility to support the arts. In the past ten years, business has recognized its debt as a social institution by increasing steadily its support of education, health and welfare organizations.
	Unfortunately, however, business has not generally accepted the arts as a proper area for its support. A National Industrial Conference Board Survey showed that American corporations in 1965 allocated less than three-fifths of each contributed dollar to the arts, for a grand total of just under 25 million dollars. Such major firms as IBM, Chase Manhattan Bank, S.C. Johnson & Son, Hallmark Cards, Inland Steel and several others have already provided outstanding leadership in supporting the visual and performing arts — but not enough corporations have followed their leadership.
	In a major speech to the NICB last year, Mr. David Rockefeller proposed that we establish a Council on Business and the Arts to stimulate corporate financial contributions to the arts. This would parallel the job being done for business aid to education by the Council for Financial Aid to Education Organization several years ago. I understand that Mr. Rockefeller has developed over the past few weeks and that there will be an announcement on a council in support of the arts very shortly. I urge our business corporations to give full support to this project.

402.title: Remarks by Warren Brodey at the E.A.T. Press Conference
402.ref_bibliographic: Press conference for E.A.T.. New York : Experiments in Art and Technology, [October 1967]. Set of 13 elements. Press kit. Includes press releases, speeches, biographies of board members of E.A.T. and an artist's statement.
402.text:
REMARKS BY WARREN BRODEY*
Director of M.I.T. Science Camp

	The first industrial revolution averaged the people; if you are willing to be like the many: dress alike, eat pre-prepared foods, life is made simpler. If you are famous or poor, you are allowed individual expression. You must deserve to make it. You must fill in the blanks if your individual existence is to be recognized. There is a limit to the number of blanks that can be handled by the system. Personal creativeness is interpreted as angry, or, rendered meaningless by the complications one must face to make it work. It is drained by complications.
	In the days when the controls of our society had to be simplified; when mass transportation could allow only limited variation if it were to be available, when design of products for the many meant they must all be alike —- to be cheap … in those times, man had to be averaged. But today, the many -- both people and products are in a traffic jam.
	The new technology provides an implication sensed by the many as they are bombarded by proud news of technological adventures: individuals can learn to play with technology. Individuals who are not mechanically inclined can design their our experiences by using the new variability that industry could provide if there were enough demands to make this economically feasible. But demand develops only as it is shown that there is something new to be demanded. The computer-assisted factory begins to provide large number productions with versatility in products and a man-machine relation more like that of the small shop.
	There is a new potential for living in a personalized environment if we merely can think our way out of the mass production mentality and into the immense choice and fun that industry's new talents and technology can make available. Imagine having many, many forms of transportation designed to different uses, personal tastes and esthetic styles.
	It is the artist who has the capacity to create this variability and to use and to make relevant what is outside the "accepted systems. " He can point out relationships that were not seen before. The artist can create the surprises that foreshadow great new cultural inventions to match our technical advances. But like the technologist, the artist must unlearn his obsolescence and intensely sense the relevance of the new technology as a source of raw material.
	It is by using the language and media of technology that the artist will help us to understand the technology with which we live. Artistry and industry together can help create a people-oriented technology. In the joint execution of this search, each hints insights to the other and there becomes a sense of fresh existence to be experienced. I believe people will want in. They will want the participation in invention that makes technology friendly. They will want to swim in the stream that joins traditional engineering and art. Simply bridging the gap between these formal disciplines is not the same as getting people into the action.
        Neither individuals, nor companies, nor groups of artists can afford to go too far off the beaten track to often. The cost of modern experimentation without a clear demand is too high. Experiments in Art and Technology has achieved a most exciting way to use new versatility and to show what can be done.

*This is the personal statement by the author, and, in no way necessarily represents the view of any institute he may be affiliated with.

403.title: Remarks by Robert Morris at the E.A.T. Press Conference
403.ref_bibliographic: Press conference for E.A.T.. New York : Experiments in Art and Technology, [October 1967]. Set of 13 elements. Press kit. Includes press releases, speeches, biographies of board members of E.A.T. and an artist's statement.
403.text:
REMARKS BY ROBERT MORRIS
Artist

My relation to E. A.T. has been an external one. I have known some of the people who have been most intimately involved with its development, but I myself have been outside it. I have participated in its projects only indirectly. So what speculations or reflections I can make are necessarily those of an observer.

First I should say something about my own particular experience with technology. It is the development of my own work, sculpture, in relation to industry that enables me to say anything in particular about the relationship. And, my experience and the generalization I can make may not be at all relevant to those who have worked directly with E.A.T. In the beginning, I merely intended to use industry to implement certain ideas I had which were fairly clear in my own mind. I knew what I wanted and it was simply a matter of finding someone to build it. This approach changed in proportion to what I found out about how things got made. It became less and less a matter of being in a studio thinking of things, making the plans and sending them off to the fabricator. More and more it became a matter of incorporating methods and materials I had found out about in the process of being related to particular fabricators. The process of working became more direct and also more complex — involving as it would not only the ever increasing acquisition of technical information but also the development of a social and executive sense which had not been necessary when I made the work myself in the studio. Working became a very extended situation of making appointments, visiting factories and gathering information. The more I found out and the more people I met who were interested in helping, the less it seemed necessary to plan everything either precisely or completely in advance. More work got made easier by leaving certain problems open for others to work out. I began accepting solutions suggested by others which showed up in the finished work in very specific ways — and in ways which I had not preconceived. More possibilities occur[r]ed. In short, less, not more, control was becoming desirable. The process of making art began to get ever so slightly corporate.

Remarks by Robert Morris - 2

What is interesting to me about E.A. T. is that it seems to be a pretty maximum resource for a much more extended kind of corporate making. This is just a speculation, and maybe it will turn out to be relevant. "Dialogue" between the artist and engineer is talked about, but, for the most part, what I have seen has had the traditional individualistic orientation with the artist in control demanding that the product be the projection of his images. The Nine Evenings seemed like this, except for some interesting mistakes. I think that I myself still adhere to the values of individualistic art and maintain a fairly tight control of the end product in spite of some developments away from this. Most artists I know work this way. Possibly it is the way most will continue to work, but I think this type product control is being questioned by younger people. It is also true that most periods of high individualistic art are politically unstable, even corrupt, and sometimes philosophically stagnet as well —- the Renaissance or now would be an example. It is obvious that these things are not going unnoticed by younger people. I think the broader awareness and more extended involvement in social, political as well as artistic action indicates a less professionalistic, less specialist, less product-oriented tendency. Possibly these people will be able to utilize the facilities E.A.T. offers for a more extended way of working which involves the cooperation and initiative of many. But if this is true, I do not know what is possible in these new terms. It would be boring to try to predict its nature. It would seem that getting many unlikely things tried would be more relevant than demanding particular successes.

I hope E.A.T. can maintain and develop roots in many extended processes and connect to many diverse people. By being open, available and diverse, it will be a means that has not existed before. Out of such means, things we cannot predict should develop.

541.title: Lieberman on Oracle in the Exhibition of the E.A.T. Press Conference
541.ref_bibliographic: Lieberman, Henry. «Art and science proclaim alliance in avant-garde loft». The New York Times. (Oct. 11, 1967). P. 49.
541.text:
Rauschenberg's 'Oracle'

	Another sculptural construction was a sound-emitting assembly consisting of a tire, truck door, window frame, bathtub and air vent. This is Mr. Rauschenberg's "Oracle."
	Five radios are used, with the tuning dial of-each being rotated by motor. Thus, each radio picks up snatches of the broadcasts of all the local radio stations. To eliminate wiring from assembly components to the central pickup point, signals from the radios are relayed to the components by small FM transmitters.
	Last year an artist-engineer collaboration called "Nine Evenings: Theater and Engineering" left the art critics bewildered. A few visitors at the Lafayette Street show also looked with puzzlement on "Oracle." But the show sponsors emphasized that it was the idea of collaboration, and not a specific art work, that counts most.

44.title: Klüver on the E.A.T. Lecture-Demonstrations in Spring 1968
44.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
44.text: In the spring of 1968, E.A.T. organized a series of thirty lecture demonstrations by engineers and scientists for artists, held at the E.A.T. loft at 9 East 16th Street. The lectures covered such technical subjects as lasers and holography; computer generated sound and images; color theory; paper; television; and new HexcelTM materials. Speakers came from academic, industrial and government laboratories such as, Bell Laboratories, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, National Bureau of Standards, Eastman-Kodak, Columbia University, IBM, and Union Camp Company. In this photograph, Herwig Kogelnik, who did some of the fundamental work on lasers at Bell Laboratories in Murray Hill, N.J., gives a lecture on lasers and holography.

45.title: Klüver on the E.A.T. Local Groups
45.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
45.text:
E.A.T. Local Groups began to spring up spontaneously as artists and engineers in areas outside New York contacted us wanting to set up artist-engineer collaborations to work with the new technology. We encouraged people to start Local Groups and gave them information and advice. By 1968 there were 28 E.A.T. Local Groups active in the U.S. and Canada, 4 in Europe and one in South America. In June 1968 we held an international conference at the loft in New York for E.A.T. representatives to meet and discuss ideas for organization and activities in their areas.
We also went on speaking tours to colleges and universities and visited Local Group meetings. In this photograph, I am speaking to a group in Toronto. Behind me is a projection of the first technical requests from the artists for 9 EVENINGS.

775.title: Norma Loewen on E.A.T. and IEEE
775.ref_bibliographic: Loewen, Norma. “Experiments in Art and Technology: A Descriptive History of the Organization”. New York University, 1975.
775.text:
It was assumed that E.A.T.'s technical services should be handled by engineers and modeled after the practices of technical societies. This was in part to remain open to any artist regardless of his fame or aesthetic preference and to be regarded as a professional  engineering society. [1]
With these ends in mind, E.A.T. aimed to establish contacts with the American Physical Society, Engineers Joint Council, Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE), and other technical societies. They were contacted for E.A.T.'s own membership, use of their membership lists for direct mailings to prospective technical members, or the publication of articles on E.A.T. and artist/engineer projects.
In December 1966, Billy Kluver had begun plans to form an "Engineering for Art Group" [2] within the IEEE, a technical society with membership divided geographically into regions and technically into groups. It was hoped that the group would encourage having artists relate to society through a specific profession, that engineers would work on projects as challenging and difficult as their "normal" engineering problems, that the engineers' work would remain professional as defined by the technical society to be useful to artists, and that their technical contributions would be professionally recognized, this being considered essential to establish their role in collaboration.
Given encouragement from the IEEE, which at first found the idea "very freshing," Klüver outlined the rationale for forming the group before the New Technical and Scientific Activities Committee of the IEEE on March 21, 1967.
Kluver argued that the intellectual community, unlike the technical community, was aware of the artists' "intense but unsatisfied desire to use technology as a material"; that the capacity of technology was greater than what people were willing to recognize and, unlike pre-television times, one could now ask "what should the next mass media look like?"; that engineers had "become responsible for the character of our technical environment"; and that "to help make the technical environment of the future more varied, imaginative on a different level of human activity," engineers needed the interaction which artists were  proposing. If the engineer were rational and the artist irrational, their collaboration would suggest new uses of technology and eventually lead to a new kind of technology.
The group was to perform three functions as given in Kluver's talk. First, it would provide focus outside the art community on specific technical problems and feedback of artists' problems into an engineering vocabulary. Second, It would deal not only with artists' technical problems but human problems resulting from artist/engineer relationships and make the engineer aware of the artist's language. Third, it would publish its transactions.
In concluding his talk, Kluver suggested the IEEE was facing "an historical decision." It did "not look like much on the surface" but could become "a challenge for the IEEE to bring the two cultures together again."
The IEEE considered the situation atypical and suggested forming a subgroup rather than a full-fledged professional group. They asked what the group's functions would be, what financial and other support would be required, how leadership would be selected and reviewed, what the membership qualifications would be for non-engineers, and what assurance could be given that the group be centered on electronics and electrical engineers and that their contributions be maintained at a professional level.
Reference to the group's formation appeared throughout the 1967 issues of E.A.T. News. One of the persons asked to assist in forming the group was Cyril M. Harris of Columbia University.

1. Kluver, "Report to the Board," May 25, 1967, and E.A.T. News. June 1, 1967, p.4.
2. The group was also called "Engineering in Art" and "Art in Engineering" in E.A.T. News. June 1, 1967, pp.3 and 14. The following statements about the group are from Kluver's notes and correspondence with Richard M. Emberson, director of technical services, et al. at the IEEE, December 1966-April 1967.

385.title: About the donators for the E.A.T. Competition Awards
385.ref_bibliographic: [Press package for “The machine as seen at the end of the mechanical age”]. New York : Experiments in Art and Technology ; New York : The Museum of Modern Art, November 11, 1968. Set of 15 elements. Press kit. Includes press releases, one postcard and one program.
385.text:
Winners of the $3,000 first prize were Harris Hyman and Ralph Martel, who collaborated with artist Jean Dupuy to construct a sculpture of dust. Frank Turner was awarded a $1,000 second prize for his contribution to Wen-Ying Tsai's cybernetic sculpture of stainless steel rods and strobe lights; Niels 0. Young also won a second prize of $1,000 for his role in making Fakir in 3/4 Time, mechanical fountain, with his artist wife Lucy Jackson Young.
	The first prize was awarded by P. L. Siemiller, Co-chairman of the American Foundation on Automation and Employment, which donated the prize money. Mr. Siemiller is also President of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers (AFL-CIO).
	The two second prizes were donated by the McCrory Corporation and Richard Brandt, President, on behalf of the Trans-Lux Corporation.

386.title: Keneas' article on E.A.T. Competition
386.ref_bibliographic: Keneas, Alexander. "Museum Unites Art and Science". The New York Times. (Nov. 12, 1968), p. [?]
386.text:
MUSEUM UNITES ART AND SCIENCE

3 Works by Men From Both Fields Honored at Modern
By ALEXANDER KENEAS

	The marriage of art and technology, which has hot always been a happy one, received encouragement yesterday from three model couples at the Museum of Modern Art.
	Prefatory to an exhibition opening at the museum Nov. 27, three works that exemplify "the most inventive use of new technology," and made by artists working closely with engineers, were awarded prizes—$3,000 as first prize and $1,000 each as second prizes.,
	The works will be included in the museum exhibition, "The Machine as Seen at the End of the Mechanical Age.")
	After a brief news conference at which artists, scientists and representatives of industry and labor expressed hopes for further collaboration, the winners were allowed to perform.
	"Heart Beats Dust which took first prize, began the demonstration. Acoustic, vibrations passing through a latex membrane in a' black, windowed cube activated particles of red dust that swirled in the rays of a small Kleiglight. The source of the vibrations was a taped recording of heartbeats.
	One of the engineers of "Dust,"' Ralph Martel, then rigged up a stethoscope to provide the vibrations and, testing his own beat, which thumped noticeably louder, than the taped beats, said "first prize" smilingly.
	After stethoscoped spectators took their turn at making the dust dance, the first of the two second-prize winners, the lights still dim for maximum visual effect, was set in action.
	"Cybernetic Sculpture," groupings of vibrating stainless steel rods illuminated by strobe lights whose flashes respond to the variations of sounds created by the audience, drew laughs when the oscillations gave the illusion of burlesque gyrations.
	Enthusiasm for the third work, "Fakir in 3/4 Time," was perhaps the strongest. A motor-driven loop of textile tape, which like the loop of a lariat remains rigid in motion, soared like a Brancusi bird, twisted into a moebius band and wheeled into an ellipse, as it was manipulated by its - engineer, Niels O. Young. Mr. Young's children were on hand to jump through some of the loop formations.
	Also on hand was Theodore W. Kheel, the labor lawyer and multimedia mediator who heads the American Foundation on Automation and Employment, donor of the first prize.
	Mr. Kneel emphasized that the prizes were for the engineers involved, and not the artists, in the three works.
	They are Harris Hyman and Mr. Martel for "Dust"; Frank T. Turner for "Cybernetic Sculpture" and Mr. Young - for "Fakir."
	The competition was arranged by Experiments in Art and Technology, which is dedicated to preserving and strengthening the marriage.

367.text:
THE NEW YORK TIMES, SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 12,1967

EXPERIMENTS IN ART AND TECHNOLOGY ANNOUNCES A COMPETITION FOR ENGINEERS AND ARTISTS AND REQUESTS SUBMISSION OF WORKS OF ART MADE IN COLLABORATION TO DE SELECTED FOR AN EXHIBITION AT THE MUSEUM OF MODERN ART, NEW YORK CITY

The Museum of Modern Art, New York, has asked Experiments in Art and Technology to collaborate on a section dedicated to new technology in art as an extension of a major exhibition entitled THE MACHINE, to be held in the fall of 1968 and directed by K. G. P. Hulten, Director of Moderna Museet, Stockholm. The main body of the exhibition will be an historical survey of works of art commenting on the machine and the mechanical world.
Works to be considered for inclusion in the exhibition should be submitted by June 1, 1968 to Experiments in Art and Technology.
Experiments in Art and Technology is established to develop an effective collaboration between engineer and artist. The raison d'etre of Experiments in Art and Technology is the possibility of a work which is not the preconception of either the engineer or the artist but which is the result of the exploration of the human interaction between them. To encourage this aim in the works to be considered for the exhibition, Experiments in Art and Technology announces a competition for the best contribution by an engineer to a work of art produced in collaboration with an artist. The project may be initiated by either an artist or an engineer.
Experiments in Art and Technology will grant a first-place award of $3,000 and two second-place awards of $1,000 each to the engineer for his technical contribution to the collaboration. The jury will consist, of scientists and engineers from the technical community who are not necessarily familiar with contemporary art. The jury will not be informed about the names of the collaborating engineers. The awards will be for the most inventive use of new technology as it evolves through the collaboration of artist and engineer.
Final selection of the works to be shown at the Museum of Modern Art will be made by Mr. Hulten in consultation with the Jury.
Experiments in Art and Technology will help interested engineers and artists to establish contact. Engineers or artists who find the competition and the exhibition of interest should contact Experiments in Art and Technology at 9 East 16th Street, New York, New York, 10003. The Exhibition is international.

368.title: Press release for E.A.T. Competition
368.ref_bibliographic: [Competition for the best contribution by an engineer to a work of art]. — New York : Experiments in Art and Technology, November 5, 1967. — [2] p. — Press release.

For Release
Sunday, November 5, 1967

For Further Information Contact:
Miss Sue Hartnett
Experiments in Art and Technology, Inc. 9 East 16th Street
New York, N. Y. 10003 Telephone: 242-5014
