Works of art selected will be included in a major exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, New York City, entitled THE MACHINE, to be held in the fall of 1968 and directed by K.G.P. Hulten, Director of Moderna Museet, Stockholm. The main body of the exhibition will be an historical survey of works of art commenting on the machine and the mechanical world. The exhibition will be international.
	The Museum of Modern Art has asked Experiments in Art and Technology to collaborate on a section in the exhibition dedicated to new technology in art. Works to be considered for inclusion in the section on technology in art should be submitted by June 1, 1968 to Experiments in Art and Technology, Inc., 9 East 16th Street, New York, N. Y. 10003.
	The jury will consist of scientists and engineers from the technical community who are not necessarily familiar with contemporary art. The jury will not be informed about the names of the collaborating engineers. The awards will be for the most inventive use of new technology as it evolves through the collaboration of artist and engineer.
	Final selection of the works to be shown at the Museum of Modern Art will be made by Mr. Hulten in consultation with the jury.
	Experiments in Art and Technology was established to develop an effective collaboration between engineer and artist The raison d'etre of Experiments in Art and Technology is the possibility of a work which is not the preconception of either the engineer or the artist but which is the result of the exploration of the human interaction between them. The competition is intended to encourage this aim in the works to be considered for the exhibition.

369.title: Further information about the Competition and the request for submission of works of art in connection with the exhibition "The Machine" at the Museum of Modern Art, New York
369.ref_bibliographic: Further information about the competition and the request for the submission of works of art in connection with the exhibition "The machine" at the Museum of Modern Art, New York. – New York : Experiments in Art and Technology, [November 12, 1967]. – [2] p. – Application form. Published in Some More Beginnings : an exhibition of submitted works involving technical materials and processes. New York : E.A.T., 1968, p. 7.
369.text:
FURTHER INFORMATION ABOUT THE COMPETITION AND THE REQUEST FOR SUBMISSION OF WORKS OF ART IN CONNECTION WITH THE EXHIBITION "THE MACHINE" AT THE MUSEUM OF MODERN ART, NEW YORK.

REASONS FOR E.A.T. INVOLVEMENT

To stimulate professional scientists and engineers to collaborate with contemporary artists.
To bring the realization over to the technical community of the massive interest among contemporary artists in the new technology.
To promote the value and significance of the technical contribution to a work of art in the technical and art communities.
To increase the access by artists to the latest technology.

THE EXHIBITION

"The Museum of Modern Art, New York, has asked Experiments in Art and Technology to collaborate on a section dedicated to new technology in art as an extension of a major exhibition entitled THE MACHINE, to be held in the fall of I968 and directed by K.G.P. Hulten, Director of Moderna Museet, Stockholm. The main body of the exhibition will be an historical survey of works of art commenting on the machine and the mechanical world. Works to be considered for inclusion in the exhibition should be submitted by June 1, I968 to Experiments in Art and Technology."

The number of works involving the new technology selected for the exhibition will be approximately ten. They must be of a "medium size" to fit into the space at the Museum of Modern Art. Since physical size is in many cases an inaccurate measurement, applicants are advised to use their own judgment.

The works submitted can result out of a collaboration between artist and engineer or be made by either alone. They must, however, incorporate the use of new technology such as the use of computers, new materials, electronics, and structural engineering. The section dedicated to the new technology comprises contemporary works of art and does not form part of the main theme of the exhibition which is "an historical survey of works of art commenting on THE MACHINE and the mechanical world".

All artists and engineers who would like to submit works to the exhibition should fill out the enclosed form as soon as possible and mail it to Experiments in Art and Technology, 9 East 16th Street, New York, New York 10003.

The procedure for viewing the works will be worked out during the spring of I968, and artists and engineers will be advised accordingly. No works should be brought or sent to E.A.T. before this time.

A catalog of submitted works with brief descriptions will be published.

THE COMPETITION

In connection with the request for submission or works to THE MACHINE exhibition, E.A.T. "announces a competition for the best contribution by an engineer to a work of art produced in collaboration with an artist. The project may be initiated by either an artist or an engineer. Experiments in Art and Technology will grant a first-place award of $3,000 and two second-place awards of $1,000 each to the engineer for his technical contribution to the collaboration. The jury will consist of scientists and engineers from the technical community who are not necessarily familiar with contemporary art. The jury will not be informed about the names of the collaborating engineers. The awards will be for the most inventive use of new technology as it evolves through the collaboration of artist and engineer".

Commercial products, display signs, architectural models, discotheque lighting, technical equipment and other objects which cannot be recognized as works of art by those "familiar with the field" are excluded from the Competition.

The jury will be made familiar with various aspects of the collaboration between an artist and an engineer such as the different working environment for the engineer in his collaboration with an artist. The jury will not be given any esthetic advise and will be instructed to disregard esthetic preferences. The jury's decision must be unanimous and it is binding.

E.A.T. will not ask for detailed information about proposed projects. Any such information offered to facilitate finding a partner will be kept in confidence.

To enable artists and engineers to meet and discuss projects, informal meetings will be held every Sunday, 2:00 to 5:00 p.m. at 9 East loth Street.

Further clarifications will be mailed to participants if necessary.

Please contact E.A.T. headquarters if you have any further questions, telephone 212 242-8803.

370.title: Final instructions for E.A.T. competition
370.ref_bibliographic: Final instructions for E.A.T. competition and M.O.M.A. exhibition. New York : [Experiments in Art and Technology], [May 1968]. [3] p. Form.
370.text:
To qualify for the E.A.T. Competition "for the best contribution by an engineer to a work of art produced in collaboration with an artist," works must be the result of a collaboration between an artist and an engineer or groups of artists and engineers. All works submitted by June 1, 1968, will be considered for the M.O.M.A. Exhibition, but only collaborative works will be considered for the E.A.T. Competition.

Deadline for submission of entries to both the E.A.T. Competition and the M.O.M.A. Exhibition is June 1, 1968.
Works must be completed and available for viewing by that date.

INSTRUCTIONS FOR E.A.T COMPETITION

On or before June 1, the following information must be sent to E.A.T., 9-East 16th Street, New York, New York, 10003:

	a. Detailed technical report by the engineer, describing his contribution to the collaboration. This may include technical drawings or diagrams.
	b. Photographs, slides, or—if desired—8mm or 16mm film of the work.
	c. The enclosed information blank should be filled out completely and sent in with the above material. The name of the engineer should not appear on any other material submitted. Jury members will not know the names of the collaborating engineers.

Do not send or bring works to E.A.T. You will be contacted to arrange date, time and place for viewing. Because of the wide geographical spread of the entries, and limited time, several local viewing centers will be set up—for example New York, Chicago, Los Angeles, and others if necessary. Participants in the competition will be advised when and where their work will be seen. All shipping costs required must be paid by the collaborators and not by E.A.T.

While there is no restriction on size, weight, or medium of entries to the E.A.T. Competition, our original designation of "medium size" was to suggest that works should be transportable and easily exhibited.

Commercial products, display signs, architectural models, discotheque lighting, technical equipment, and other objects which cannot be recognized as works of art by those "familiar with the field" are not eligible for the Competition. Engineers or artists involved in more than one collaborative project may submit all their projects to the Competition. The names of the Competition jurors will remain anonymous until final selections are made.

371.title: Jurors' background
371.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
371.text:
JURORS

JAMES M. BROWNLOW, IBM RESEARCH LABORATORIES. BORN 1920; B.S. IN GLASS TECHNOLOGY FROM ALFRED UNIVERSITY, 1943; M.S. IN CERAMICS FROM MASSACHUSETTS INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY, 1948; JOINED IBM, 1952; IBM FELLOW, 1967; INTEREST: MAGNETIC MATE- RIALS FOR COMPUTER MEMORY.

MICHAEL D. GOLDER, CELANESE PLASTICS COMPANY. BORN 1943; B.S. IN CHEMICAL ENGINEERING FROM PRATT INSTITUTE, IN 1965; M.S. IN CHEMICAL ENGINEERING FROM UNIVERSITY OF CINCINNATI, 1968; JOINED PLASTICS RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT CENTER OF CELANESE PLASTICS, 1962; ACADEMIC INTERESTS: DYNAMICS OF CHEMICAL REACTORS; BIOCHEMICAL ENGINEERING.

CYRIL M. HARRIS IS PROFESSOR OF ELECTRICAL ENGINEERING AND ARCHITECTURE A T COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY . AFTER RECEIVING THE Ph.D. DEGREE IN PHYSICS FROM M.I.T. HE JOINED THE TECHNICAL STAFF OF THE BELL* TELEPHONE LABORATORIES. SUBSEQUENTLY HE WAS FUL* BRIGHT LECTURER AT THE TECHNICAL UNIVERSITY OF DELFT IN THE NETHERLANDS AND, LATER, VISITING PROFESSOR AT THE UNIVERSITY OF TOKYO. DR. HARRIS IS PAST PRESIDENT AND A FELLOW OF THE ACOUSTICAL SOCIETY OF AMERICA AND A FELLOW OF THE INSTITUTE OF ELECTRICAL AND ELECTRONIC ENGINEERS AND OF THE AUDIO ENGINEERING SOCIETY. HE WAS ACOUSTICAL CONSULTANT FOR THE RECENTLY COMPLETED POWELL SYMPHONY HALL IN ST. LOUIS AND THE METROPOLITAN OPERA HOUSE IN NEW YORK. HE IS THE ACOUSTICAL CONSULTANT FOR THE JOHN F. KENNEDY CENTER FOR THE PERFORMING ARTS NOW UNDER CONSTRUCTION IN WASHINGTON, D.C.

JOHN W. PAN, BELL TELEPHONE LABORATORIES. BORN 1933 IN NEW YORK, SPENT CHILDHOOD IN CHINA; B.S. IN ELECTRICAL ENGINEERING FROM UNIVERSITY OF CINCINNATI, 1955; PH.D. IN ELECTRICAL COMMUNICATIONS FROM MASSACHUSETTS INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY, 1962; JOINED BELL TELEPHONE LABORATORIES, 1955; INTEREST: DIGITAL TRANSMISSION SYSTEM.

WILLIAM G. ROSEN, NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION. BORN 1921; B.S. IN PHYSICS FROM UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS, 1943; UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCE, PRIVATE TO FIRST LIEUTENANT, 1943-1946; M.S. IN PHYSICS FROM UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS, 1947; PH.D. IN MATHEMATICS FROM UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS, 1954; INSTRUCTOR AND ASSISTANT PROFESSOR, DEPARTMENT OF MATHEMATICS, UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND, 1954-1961; JOINED NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION, 1961; CURRENTLY SPECIAL ASSISTANT TO THE DIRECTOR OF THE NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION AND EXECUTIVE SECRE- TARY OF THE COMMITTEE ON ACADEMIC SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING OF THE FEDERAL COUNCIL FOR SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY; INTEREST: SCIENCE AND PUBLIC POLICY.

372.title: Instructions to the jury for the Competition
372.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
372.text:
INSTRUCTIONS TO THE JURY FOR THE COMPETITION

"THE AWARDS WILL BE FOR THE MOST INVENTIVE USE OF NEW TECHNOLOGY AS IT EVOLVES THROUGH THE COLLABORATION OF THE ARTIST AND ENGINEER."

THE JURY MEMBERS HAVE NOT BEEN CHOSEN FOR THEIR KNOWLEDGE OR THEIR INTEREST IN CONTEMPORARY ART. THE WORKS SHOULD BE JUDGED PRIMARILY ON TWO CRITERIA:

	FIRST, HOW INVENTIVE AND IMAGINATIVE IS THE USE OF TECHNOLOGY?

	SECOND, TO WHAT EXTENT HAVE THE ENGINEER AND THE ARTIST COLLABORATED SUCCESSFULLY?

THE JURY MEMBERS WILL MEET ONLY WITH THE ARTISTS AND WILL NOT BE TOLD WHO THE ENGINEER IS OR WHERE HE WORKS. ALL THE WORKS SEEN BY THE JURY HAVE BEEN CLASSIFIED AS WORKS OF ART. THE JURY IS FREE TO APPLY AESTHETIC CONSIDERATION TO THE CHOICE BUT SHOULD VERBALIZE SUCH CONSIDERATIONS IN THE FINAL JUDGEMENT.

THE JURY'S DECISION IS BINDING AND THE NAMES OF THE JURY MEMBERS WILL BE MADE PUBLIC. THE JURY'S DECISION MUST BE UNANIMOUS. A BRIEF STATEMENT BY THE JURY SHOULD ACCOMPANY THE AWARDS.

373.title: Statement by the Jury of E.A.T. Competition
373.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
373.text:
STATEMENT BY THE JURY

IN EACH OF THE WINNING ENTRIES A SPECTRUM OF TECHNOLOGY WAS USED WITH GREAT IMPACT ON THE ART FORMS. EVIDENT IS THE REALIZATION THAT NEITHER THE ARTIST NOR THE ENGINEER ALONE COULD HAVE ACHIEVED THE RESULTS. INTERACTION MUST HAVE PRECEDED INNOVATION. GOING BEYOND A DEMONSTRATION OF ART AND TECHNOLOGY, THE ENGINEER AND ARTIST TOGETHER HAVE CREATED MORE THAN A WELL-EXECUTED REALIZATION OF FANTASY. THE UNEXPECTED AND EXTRAORDINARY, WHICH ONE EXPERIENCES ON VIEWING THESE PIECES, RESULT FROM INVENTIVENESS AND IMAGINATION, STIMULATED NOT BY THE BRUTE FORCE OF TECHNICAL COMPLEXITY BUT BY PROBING INTO THE WORKINGS OF NATURAL LAWS.

374.title: Winners of the E.A.T. Competition
374.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
374.text:
THE FIRST-PRIZE WINNERS IN THE E.A.T. [COMPETITION] ARE HARRIS HYMAN AND RALPH MARTEL FOR THEIR WORK ON NO. 30 HEART BEATS DUST.

THE TWO SECOND-PRIZE WINNERS ARE: FRANK T. TURNER FOR HIS CONTRIBUTION TO NO. 120 CYBERNETIC SCULPTURE AND NIELS O. YOUNG FOR HIS WORK ON NO. 137 FAKIR IN 3/4 TIME.

47.title: Klüver on the request for proposals for E.A.T. Competition
47.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
47.text:
Again to stimulate interest in the technical community, E.A.T., in November 1967, announced a competition for the best contribution by an engineer to a work of art made in collaboration with an artist. The prize was to be given to the engineer, and the judges were all engineers.
Some of the works were to be selected by Pontus Hultén for his exhibition, "The Machine," at the Museum of Modern Art in 1968. E.A.T. offered to find partners for all engineers and artists who wanted to enter the competition.

The E.A.T. competition generated more than 140 submissions from all over the world, and we decided to show all these works.  […]

472.name: The American Foundation for Automation and Employment

388.title: E.A.T. to All Participants in Some More Beginnings
388.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
388.text:
TO ALL PARTICIPANTS IN E.A.T. EXHIBITION

The E.A.T. exhibition, SOME MORE BEGINNINGS, at the Brooklyn Museum will open November 24, with a public opening November 26. You will receive separate information and invitation to the opening night. During the show, November 26-January 5, we may have an attendance as large as 100,000 persons. The exhibition includes 139 works, one work by each artist or collaborating artist and engineer.

For those who submitted more than one work, from the works we have chosen___________________.
Please fill in the information for this work on the enclosed forms. If you prefer to exhibit another of your entries, please contact us so that the proper description label can be made, although the above work is represented in the catalogue.

Delivery 
We would like to receive all works November 4,5, and 6. Deliveries to the loading dock at the Museum can be made during the hours of 9,00 a.m.-11,00 a.m. and 1,00 p.m.-3,30 p.m. If you cannot deliver your works at these times, please call Amy Martin at E.A.T. for further information on what to do. All works must be addressed or marked: 
E.A.T. Exhibition
The Brooklyn Museum
188 Eastern Parkway Brooklyn, New Kork 11238
There will be a telephone at the exhibition, the number: 638-9835

Shipping 
As the most reliable method for snipping, the Museum suggest you send your work by air freight, consigned to Emery Air Freight in New York City. Railway Express should be avoided because of long delays. United Parcel Service is also efficient, If your work is within their 50-pound, 108-inch (width and girth combined) limit. All works must arrive prepaid, and you must inform the shipping company of the times for delivery at the Museum.

Personal Deliveries 
If you want to deliver the work yourself, it can be brought directly to the 5th floor, west wing, at the Museum or to the Museum's loading dock. Personal deliveries to the loading dock must be made November 4, 5 or 6 between the hours of 9,00-11,00 a.m. and 1,00-3:30 p.m. If this is not possible, call Amy Martin at E.A.T. If you would like to rent a truck to deliver your work and are interested in sharing rental expenses with another exhibitor in your area, contact E.A.T. for their names.

Maintenance 
Enclose with your work complete maintenance instructions, including power requirements if excessive, circuit diagrams, instructions for repair procedures, and information about special problems, and replacement parts. We cannot keep works in the show which have broken down. Any work which fails during the exhibition will be withdrawn if our maintenance engineers cannot fix it or the exhibitor does not arrange to make the necessary repair.

I. Photographs 
Unless E.A.T. is notified in writing to the contrary, it is understood that your loaned object may be photographed for reproduction for publicity purposes connected with the exhibition, that slides may be made and used by E.A.T. for educational purposes, and that the object, or photographs, may be used for films or television programs connected with the exhibition.

II. Sales 
If the work either at the Museum of Modern Art or at The Brooklyn Museum is for sale, it is understood that 15% of the sale price shall revert to E.A.T. as a contribution to defray the cost of the exhibition, an 10% of duplicate works of the piece exhibited.

III. Insurance 
It is understood and agreed that E.A.T. is providing space for exhibiting loaned property as an [accommodation] to the lender. The Lender hereby releasee E.A.T. and the Brooklyn Museum from any liability in connection with the loaned property, Including but not limited to, liability from damages and loss, from fire and theft, vandalism, and the Lender understands that E.A.T. and the Museum have no responsibility to insure the loaned property. The Lender has entire responsibility for maintaining insurance on the loaned property from nail to nail. Neither the Museum nor E.A.T. shall be responsible for providing [information] to the Lender's [insurers], for any errors or deficiencies in such information, of for lapse of coverage.

IV. Term of Loan 
The dates of the exhibition are November 24, 1968 to January 5, 1969 and may be extended.

V. Maintenance 
It is understood that any loaned object will upon mechanical or electronic failure, be withdrawn from the exhibition by E.A.T. If the exhibition engineers are unable to repair the failure and upon notification, the artist does not arrange repair. It is also understood that repairs and adjustment of equipment by engineers provided by E.A.T. are authorized by the Lender unless E.A.T. is notified in writing to the contrary. Replacement parts must be provided by the Lender If he is requested to do so.

VI. Shipping 
It is understood that all shipping costs will be paid by the exhibitor.

VII. Loan Agreement 
Filling In and signing the Loan Agreement form will indicate that the exhibitor understands and agrees to all the conditions of loan as here stated.

391.title: Klüver's acknowledgments in the catalogue Some More Beginnings
391.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
391.text:
I WOULD LIKE TO THANK THE ARTISTS AND ENGINEERS FOR THEIR CONTRIBUTION TO THE EXHIBITION: MOST IMPORTANT, THEIR WORKS, BUT ALSO THEIR INTEREST, COOPERATION AND, AS LISTED BELOW, ACTUAL HELP ON INSTALLATION AND OPERA TIONS.

IN THEIR UNFAMILIAR ROLE AS MEMBERS OF A JURY THE FIVE SCIENTISTS, JAMES BROWNLOW, MICHAEL GOLDER, CYRIL HARRIS, JOHN PAN, AND WILLIAM ROSEN, GAVE GENEROUSLY OF THEIR TIME AND KNOWLEDGE IN JUDGING THE COMPETITION. THE PRIZES WERE DONATED BY THE AMERICAN FOUNDATION ON AUTOMATION AND EMPLOYMENT, FIRST PRIZE; AND MCCRORY CORPORATION AND TRANS-LUX CORPORATION, SECOND PRIZES.

I WOULD LIKE TO EXPRESS MY APPRECIATION TO THOMAS BUECHNER, DIRECTOR OF THE BROOKLYN MUSEUM, AND BATES LOWRY, DIRECTOR OF THE MUSEUM OF MODERN ART, FOR MAKING THIS COLLABORATIVE VENTURE POSSIBLE.

STAFF MEMBERS OF THE MUSEUM OF MODERN ART HAVE GIVEN CONTINUING SUPPORT, ADVICE AND HELP, IN PARTICULAR WILDER GREEN, JENNIFER LICHT, ELIZABETH SHAW, JEAN EDITH WEIFFENBACH AND JOAN WEIGGINS.

THE COOPERATION AND ASSISTANCE WHICH THE STAFF OF THE BROOKLYN MUSEUM SO FREELY SHOWED US, MADE THE INSTALLATION BOTH EFFICIENT AND PLEASANT. I SHOULD LIKE TO THANK IN PARTICULAR: DAVID SALTONSTALL, ASSISTANT DIRECTOR; FLORENCE BELLER, SECRETARY TO THE DIRECTOR AND ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT MRS. BARBARA LASALLE, REGISTRAR; SALLY MCHALE, ASSISTANT REGISTRAR; ALPHONSUS GRANT, CHIEF OF SECURITY; ROBERT HAYDEN, SUPERINTENDANT; DONELSON HOOPES, CURATOR OF PAINTINGS AND SCULPTURE; CHARLES SMITH, SUPERVISING CLERK; PETER JANNACE, CUSTODIAN; LEO MURPHY, MUSEUM MAINTAINER; DOMINIC BLASI, PREPARATOR, DEPARTMENT OF PAINTING AND SCULPTURE.

LLOYD KREUZER AND TED WOLFF VOLUNTEERED TIME FOR TECHNICAL SUPERVISION OF THE INSTALLATION AND MAINTENANCE OF THE EXHIBITION. CARPENTRY WAS DONE BY HARRY COHEN AND JOKER NEWTON AND RIGGING BY JAY BELL. OTHER HELP WAS GIVEN BY MARIANNE BARCELLONA, ADRIENNE BORDES, BERNARD KAHN, BOB BRENNAN, ARTURO CUETARA, SCOT GARDINER, MICHAEL GOLDBERG, BARRY GREEN, DOLORES HOMES, ALEXANDER KASUBA, MICHAEL KlRBY, GISELLE MAUER, STEVE PAXTON, MICHAEL ROBBINS, WILLIAM SCHWARZ, BOB SPIEGEL AND BECKY YOUNG.

TECHNICAL DESCRIPTIONS FOR THE CATALOGUE WERE COMPILED FROM MATERIAL SUBMITTED WITH ASSISTANCE FROM TED WOLFF. THE COMPUTER PROCESSED IMAGES ON THE COVER ARE BY MANFRED SCHROEDER WITH PROGRAMMING BY LORINDA CHERRY. LAURIE GLASGOW AND BETTY HUMPHREYS OF REDMOND PRESS DID THE LAYOUT. JIM NORRIS OF ECONOTYPE SET THE TYPE. SUSAN BROCKMAN COMPILED MA TERIAL ON THE WORKS SUBSTITUTED FOR THE EXHIBITION.

MEL BOCHNER SUPERVISED THE PRODUCTION OF THE SILK-SCREEN POSTERS BY MANFRED SCHROEDER, AND LEON HARMON AND KENNETH KNOWLTON. TOM GORMLEY DESIGNED AND SUPERVISED THE PRODUCTION OF PUBLICITY POSTERS. JOHN BRUNDO OF BANTAM PRESS GAVE VALUABLE ADVICE AND HELP THROUGHOUT.

MY SPECIAL THANKS GO TO JEAN DUPUY, HARRIS HYMAN, AND RALPH MARTEL; RICHARD FRAENKEL AND JEFFERY RASKIN; LEON HARMON AND KENNETH KNOWLTON; ROBIN PARKINSON AND ERIC MARTIN; LILLIAN SCHWARTZ AND PER BIORN; WEN-YING TSAI AND FRANK TURNER; NIELS AND LUCY YOUNG, FOR DUPLICATING THEIR WORKS SO THEY COULD BE SHOWN IN BOTH EXHIBITIONS.

SEYMOUR SCHWEBER DONATED THE BUTTONS SHOWING THE COMPUTER PROCESSED IMAGE OF AN EYE. 

WITT WITTNEBERT MADE THE LIGHT BOXES FOR THE TITLES.

MY KIND THANKS TO MARION JAVITS FOR ARRANGING THE OPENING OF SOME MORE BEGINNINGS.

THEODORE KHEEL, ROBERT RAUSCHENBERG AND FRED WALDHAUER PROVIDED UNFAILING ADVICE AND SUPPORT WHEN IT WAS MOST NEEDED THROUGHOUT THIS PROJECT. PONTUS HULTEN HAS GIVEN FREELY OF HIS TIME FOR ADVICE AND HELP IN ALL PHASES OF THE MAKING OF THE CATALOGUE AND THE INSTALLATION OF THE EXHIBITION.

FRED WALDHAUER PROVIDED UNFAILING ADVICE AND SUPPORT WHEN IT WAS MOST NEEDED THROUGHOUT THIS PROJECT. PONTUS HULTEN HAS GIVEN FREELY OF HIS TIME FOR ADVICE AND HELP IN ALL PHASES OF THE MAKING OF THE CATALOGUE AND THE INSTALLATION OF THE EXHIBITION.

E.A.T. STAFF MEMBERS HAVE WITH GREAT ENERGY CARRIED OUT ALL ASPECTS OF THIS PROJECT: CLAUDIO BADAL, SUSAN EDGERTON, JEAN-JACQUES ERLICHMAN, RALPH FLYNN, SUSAN HARTNETT, FRANCIS MASON, AMY MARTIN, JULIE MARTIN, TERRY MARTIN, SUSAN MUNSHOWER, ROSE PETROCK, PETER POOLE, AND TAMARA VIDOS.

BILLY KLÜVER NOVEMBER 16,1968

236.title: Norma Loewen on the Installation of the Exhibition Some More Beginnings
236.ref_bibliographic: Loewen, Norma. “Experiments in Art and Technology: A Descriptive History of the Organization”. New York University, 1975.
236.text: Amy Martin became the competition coordinator. Installation, mostly by those submitting works and by other volunteers, took three weeks. Two of the prize-winning works, "Heart Beats Dust" and "Fakir in 3/4 Time," and four other entries selected for "The Machine" were duplicated by the artists and engineers to permit showing at both museums.

234.title: Klüver's thanks in the catalog of the Exhibition Some More Beginnings
234.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.

235.title: Norma Loewen on the Design of the Exhibition Some More Beginnings
235.ref_bibliographic: Loewen, Norma. “Experiments in Art and Technology: A Descriptive History of the Organization”. New York University, 1975.
235.text:
Works submitted to E.A.T. for the competition and "The Machine" exhibition were thought to represent energy, naive joy, and a direct use of a wide-range of new technology. More interested in the energy than in questioning what was or was not art, and in a spirit of advocacy, E.A.T. decided to show all the works at an exhibition concurrent with "The Machine."
	The exhibition's title, "Some More Beginnings," came from discussions at Robert Rauschenberg's place. Knowing that the New York art community was always anxious to label such events, E.A.T. did not want the exhibition "to seem to be the answer to what E.A.T. was," as Francis Mason recalls, but "some more beginnings of what could come."
	Having considered various places in Manhattan—the Marlboro Gerson Gallery, the Union Carbide show room, the old General Motors Building, and Automation House (still in renovation)—and liking the idea of a show in Brooklyn, E.A.T. made arrangements with Thomas Buechner, director of the Brooklyn Museum, for use of the museum's West Gallery and Sculpture Court.

48.text: The E.A.T. competition generated more than 140 submissions from all over the world, and we decided to show all these works. "Some More Beginnings: Experiments in Art and Technology," which was the first major art and technology exhibition, opened at the Brooklyn Museum in November 1968. In this photo Peter Poole demonstrates Fakir in 3/4 Time by Niels and Lucy Young, which won a prize in the E.A.T. competition. On the same principle as a lariat, a loop of cotton ribbon held by vacuum to a rotating axle, moves 100 mph along itself, forming a standing stationary shape in space.

272.title: Lindgren on Breer's Float
272.ref_bibliographic: Nilo Lindgren, "Into Collaboration" in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin, and Barbara Rose (eds). Pavilion. New York: E.P. Dutton, 1972, pp. 3-59.
272.text: Gradually, elements that had persisted from the very beginning were fitted together. Bob Breer's floats, now to move almost imperceptibly on a terrace hovering on the edge of the Fog, echoed the theme of the whole Pavilion: they moved subtly, mysteriously and evocatively, emitting sounds and emanating a life of their own. Large white domes, changing the space they move in, the floats relate in shape and color to the white dome.

266.title: Lindgren on Breer's initial ideas
266.ref_bibliographic: Nilo Lindgren, "Into Collaboration" in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin, and Barbara Rose (eds). Pavilion. New York: E.P. Dutton, 1972, pp. 3-59.
266.text:
Robert Breer, the first artist to become involved with the Pavilion, makes motorized sculpture; pure forms that move about quietly and mysteriously. He calls them "floats" or, with some self irony, "automobiles" since his father was the celebrated designer of the Chrysler Airflow. He is also a well-known filmmaker. In his film work, Breer aims for "very intense activity in a small area" to force the viewer into visual concentration and he has steered away from multi projection and multimedia works which he believes overwhelm the senses. According to Breer, the usual result of multimedia is scattered razzle-dazzle without articulation and form. This taste for a subtle, quiet experience was shared by the other artists in the Pavilion Project. It is mainly for this reason the Pavilion was not planned as a multimedia work. Although its elements have been drawn from different technologies, the aim of the collaboration was to evoke a flow of unmistakable experience. 
Breer first heard of the Osaka Pavilion Project from one of his neighbors, David Thomas, who was Vice-President of Pepsi-Cola International in charge of marketing and distribution. Thomas had been asked to handle the project after it had already been initiated in Japan by Alan Pottasch, then President of Pepsi-Cola, Japan. Pepsi had secured the space for a pavilion through a clever business stratagem. The executives in Japan had gathered and given information to the Expo Authorities on how to sell food and drinks at a world's fair, and, as Thomas relates, "more or less as a quid pro quo, the Japanese fair authorities gave us space for a pavilion." 
Alan Pottasch then proceeded to contract with the Takenaka Komuten Construction firm in Japan to build a pavilion. A faceted dome was selected for the site, the work of Japanese architect Tadashi Doi, resident architect of the 360-year-old Japanese construction firm. The whole project was somehow to become self-liquidating on the basis that Pepsi might gain the concession for beverages for the entire Expo. The Pavilion was to serve as the headquarters for Pepsi operations in the Kansai area. The public part of the Pavilion was to be nothing more than a shell, a set of bleachers, and a bandstand. Since the real market for Pepsi's product is youth, Pottasch planned a worldwide rock contest, with the winning contestants being flown in free by an international airline. The Pavilion theme was to be "World Without Boundary." There was also to be a half-hour high-quality film, perhaps on sports, to be shown on six screens simultaneously. When New York heard of the scheme, which was already underway independently in Japan, they felt it would interfere with Pottasch's distribution work, and handed the assignment to David Thomas, advising him that he had a budget of $250,000 to make the film. 
But when Thomas became involved, in February, 1968, he questioned the idea of an international rock contest because he could find no one who was interested in it. Also, the Pavilion, he discovered, was acoustically the worst design imaginable for a live rock group because they would not be able to hear themselves playing. He was strongly in favor of doing something "modern." 
He bought a book on underground movies and sent it off to Alan Pottasch in Tokyo. Then he consulted his neighbor, Robert Breer. 
Breer, at that point, had no interest whatsoever in becoming involved either with sports films or commercial companies; Japan seemed far away and unrelated to his own work. Nevertheless, they discussed the project. Breer gave Thomas a list of filmers and other people to see. 
For six months Thomas was kept out of the project. During this time, there had been negotiations with Walt Disney, which evaporated when Disney began talking about budgets of several million dollars. Essentially, "the whole matter went dead until August 1968," when the project once again came back to Thomas. Now it was six months later, a loss of time that Thomas argues was crucial, and that contributed to the agonies of the later development. 
Time was tight and a decision had to be made by mid-December when the representatives of the company from the Far East would be coming to the New York headquarters to make plans and to set budgets that had to be amortized over the next several years. 
Thomas was very sympathetic to the new youth movements and their music, but he felt something more was needed. Although he claims he knows nothing about art, he had absorbed a feeling for art and for the Far East from his father who had written a classic work on the art of China and Japan, as well as from his own experience in the East.
"We would be very smart," he argued with himself, "instead of going the gimmick route, to do something genuinely prestigious; to create a piece of contemporary art, one very much in keeping with an avant-garde group, but one also understandable by the people in Japan." Armed with this new art idea, Thomas once again went to see Breer. 
Breer had been unreceptive to Thomas out of alarm at getting artistically involved with a large commercial company whose taste he imagined would be very conventional. He was also unenthusiastic because, as he said, "I could see that a world's fair meant gaudy' displays, and I just had a lot of resistance to that." A couple of times in the past, Breer had become involved in commercial filmmaking projects, and each experience had been bitter. "I couldn't live up to their demands," he said with a trace of tension in his voice, "and each time something broke inside me; what I turned out was always bad." When he finally did get involved in the Pepsi project, he was still uneasy. "Oh, Christ, yes!" he exclaimed, "Uneasiness is an understatement." 
Despite his initial hesitation, Breer began to think for the first---time that there might, after all, be some legitimate connection between his work and Expo '70. As he says, a "simpleminded bell rang in my head." In college, Breer, who had been raised as a Catholic, found himself interested in Zen. He liked the idea that there might be a real reason to do something in Japan. He thought: "Perhaps it's possible to get a corner of the Pavilion, or a reserved area nearby, for a garden of floats, which the Japanese would associate with the rocks in the Japanese temple gardens, which may appear to move if the viewer assumes the proper state of concentration." 
Excited by the philosophical implications, Breer now pursued the idea with David Thomas. As the possible scale of the project dawned on him, it grew more exciting. He made rough sketches of a dome (he hadn't yet seen the design of the actual dome), and proposed several arrangements for his floats. In one, the visitors were to go over a moat in which the floats moved about. In another, he thought of suspended tea gardens over a sea of floats. At this stage, the proposals were for works outside the dome, or in a space adjacent to it. Breer conceived of them as a quiet antidote to the rock-and-roll racket he believed would prevail inside. 
Thomas encouraged his neighbor to think about the Pavilion interior. So Breer went further with the drawings, conceiving of his floats inside, platform size. One would contain a rock-music group and would move about the vast floor. Another float would hold the lighting, playing effects off the inside of the faceted dome. "But," he said, "I was discarding clichés as quickly as they came up." 
Bob Breer had become seriously interested in the Pepsi project, and, with the continuing encouragement of Thomas, he began to conceive of possibilities besides his floats. At that time, the soft drink company was still concentrating on the idea of rock bands and live performances; but the physical environment of the interior and exterior was still wide open. 
At this point Breer reached out to Billy Kluver, President of Experiments in Art and Technology, a new organization formed in 1966 in the aftermath of the first large artist-and-engineer collaboration experiment in New York, 9 Evenings: Theatre and Engineering. What 9 Evenings began in New York was thus continued \ outside Osaka, half a world away geographically. Indeed, a number of the artists and engineers who participated in the 9 Evenings have also worked on the Expo Pavilion, including Japanese composer Toshi Ichiyanagi and artist Fujiko Nakaya. 
A friend of the artists involved in 9 Evenings, Breer provided production assistance and appeared in several pieces. Before then, Breer had been "leery" of the artist-engineer collaboration, although he found the open-ended approach employed by Kluver exciting. 
When Breer suggested to David Thomas that the Pepsi company bring in EAT. (about which they knew practically nothing) to coordinate the project, it was because he felt that through E.A.T. artists could cope with the commercial establishment without getting broken. EAT. could act as a buffer behind which they could operate more freely and more effectively in their own style. 
Said Breer, "I couldn't deal with these company people. I couldn't speak their language." 
Robert Whitman, another artist involved in 9 Evenings who was drawn into the Pepsi project, shares Breer's conviction. "With EAT.," he said, "artists have for the first time had access to professionals on their own level in other worlds. This is a funny thing. Any artist, whether or not he had anything to do with EAT., has professional status and is suddenly more respectable. It's taken a lot of years of work." 
Despite this favorable billing, there was a real question at that time as to whether or not E.A.T. should, or could, become involved in the Pepsi Pavilion Project. 
In this atmosphere of doubt, Kluver and Breer talked it over.

51.title: Klüver on the exhibition of Floats
51.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
51.text: [...] And on the plaza, seven of Robert Breer's Floats, six-foot high white sculptures, moved around slowly at less than 2 feet per minute, emitting sound.

276.title: Nilo Lindgren on the design and production of the Floats
276.ref_bibliographic: Nilo Lindgren, "Into Collaboration" in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin, and Barbara Rose (eds). Pavilion. New York: E.P. Dutton, 1972, pp. 3-59.
276.text:
The project that started the whole Pavilion collaboration going, of course, was Bob Breer's floats. John Ryde, a mechanical and electrical engineer with many years experience, became Breer's engineering collaborator. He was interested in the float project because of the engineering and logistics problems involved where and how it could be done. Breer's earlier floats had been relatively lightweight, designed for indoor use, and run by small motors and flashlight batteries. A different approach was needed. Ryde's solution was to borrow the technology of the golf cart. The floats were made with a heavy steel frame, four heavy-duty storage batteries, a third-horsepower motor, and so on. "What the float really is," John Ryde said, "is an electric automobile that goes about a foot a minute." The visitor will have to look very closely, probably down at the skirt of the float, to get the immediate sensation of its movement. Breer and Ryde experimented with different speeds, finding that some went too fast and some too slow, before they arrived at the just detectable speed for the size and mass of their floats. In order to silence the motor, Ryde had the armature rewound to reduce motor speed to about 300 rpm. 
Breer and Ryde had to foresee the problems that could occur in anticipation of the trouble that seven, free-moving, eight hundred pound objects could get into. "We had to consider all surfaces of the Pavilion environment as possible targets for the floats. They touched everything within range-including intrepid Japanese children who got in between three floats to see what would happen," Breer related. Several safety systems were installed, and Ryde observed that ultimately if all systems failed, the wheels would slip enough to keep the traction power down. 
Breer debated whether there should be sound in his floats, and tentatively suggested that sounds from the Pavilion be transmitted to the floats. This idea was dropped when Larry Owens reported that broadcast transmission was not permitted on the Expo site. Then Breer decided to install identical twenty-minute loop tapes of sound in each float: sawing, Mack truck driving away, three people discussing a beautiful view, a dawn chorus. To compose the tapes, he surrounded himself with tape recorders and played all the tapes out of sync to approximate the effect to be created by the floats as they moved about the terrace, coming together and moving apart.

56.title: Klüver on Light Frame
56.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
56.text:
[...] Four tall triangular towers held the lights for Myers' Light Frame sculpture. 
[...] At night Frosty Myers' Light Frame sculpture created a tilted rectangle of light around the Pavilion cutting through the Cloud on the dome. Four triangular poles of different heights, were set in a square 130 feet apart at each corner of the Pavilion plaza. At the top of each pole were two 500-watt, high intensity xenon lights, each light directed toward the light of the neighboring tower, creating a narrow beam of light between each tower to form the rectangle of light.

265.title: Lindgren on Myers' initial ideas
265.ref_bibliographic: Nilo Lindgren, "Into Collaboration" in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin, and Barbara Rose (eds). Pavilion. New York: E.P. Dutton, 1972, pp. 3-59.
265.text:
Sculptor Forrest Myers, the youngest of the four artists, had been making gigantic light sculptures with searchlights about the time EAT. became involved in the project. "Just the scale of his work," Breer reflected in retrospect, "sounded natural. I felt it was real outdoor stuff." 
For his own part, Myers (or "Frosty," as everyone knows him) was attracted to the outside of the Pavilion. He soon realized that the greatest number of fair visitors would experience these pavilions only from the outside and never get to go in. Lines are too long, time is short, the fair is large. However, millions would see the Pavilion from the outside-a rare opportunity for an environmental light sculptor.

278.title: Nilo Lindgren on the design and production of the Light Frame
278.ref_bibliographic: Nilo Lindgren, "Into Collaboration" in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin, and Barbara Rose (eds). Pavilion. New York: E.P. Dutton, 1972, pp. 3-59.
278.text: When Frosty Myers described his idea for the light frame during the first trip to Japan, David Tudor suggested shining two well-focused spotlights directly toward each other. A quick test carried out at Toshiba Electric Co. showed this was a good solution. Frosty Myers began working with Larry Silverstein of Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute who travelled to Japan and researched various lighting systems. The system was finally realized by Boris Sojka in California, a lighting and optics engineer who works for Pichel Industries. The company makes special high-intensity light sources and had perfected a process for making a parabolic mirror reflector for such lights. When Myers first saw these lights, the issue was nearly settled. Said Sojka, "We spoke the same language, we both understood the direction we were going in, and we just worked out."

269.title: Lindgren on a general meeting at the E.A.T. loft on November 10, 1968
269.ref_bibliographic: Nilo Lindgren, "Into Collaboration" in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin, and Barbara Rose (eds). Pavilion. New York: E.P. Dutton, 1972, pp. 3-59.
269.text:
Kluver called for a general meeting at the E.A.T. loft on November 10, and he made a point of asking Rauschenberg to be there. 
The meeting proved, as Kluver expected, to be an important turning point. Rauschenberg suggested that since most of them were plastic artists-painters and sculptors-they should shift their approach to include elements that appealed to all the senses rather than just the visual, that is, elements that would create what people would feel as an "invisible" environment. Everyone had ideas, and long lists of these were drawn up on the spot. 
The basic idea of the "invisible environment" had taken hold, and at the end of the meeting Kluver said, "OK, you guys have two weeks to come up with a design or there won't be a pavilion." The artists decided they would meet alone. 
Two days later, Whitman, Myers, Breer, and Pearce held their first intensive design session. At Whitman's house, they worked and created paper models on Whitman's mirror-top table. Within two weeks the basic design was realized, which remained essentially unchanged throughout the project. 
In thrashing out their ideas, the artists became increasingly committed to true, non-competitive collaboration, discarding ideas, triggering new ideas in each other, and acting as catalysts for each other. In his original plan, for instance, Frosty Myers had a square grid of radio loops on a flat floor (the sound loops consciously borrowed from the dancer Steve Paxton who had used them in 9 Evenings). Onto this elaborate square, the group proposed rear-screen projections so that a visitor could walk out over clouds, over fire, over living creatures like magnified newts and fish. Eventually, however, all types of visual projections were abandoned by mutual agreement, because visitors in most fair situations are battered by projections and from their experience, Breer and Whitman decided it was not a strong enough thing to sacrifice the amount of time and money to research and develop it against other things they wanted to do. "Then," said Myers, "Bob Whitman came up with the idea of pitching the floor so that the whole floor was related to the optics of the dome." 
Gradually, as Myers suggested, the floor kept getting scaled down. At first the floor was made to vibrate, to hum, to change color, but then it moved toward a more passive and subtle form, each section having a different texture, each texture being related to different sounds over the radio loops. Different smells were also considered, and abandoned. It was remembered that Mike Todd's son had spent several million dollars for movie "smellies" and hadn't solved the technical problems. Said Myers, "It just ends up being a garbage can." 
"When we really hit on something we knew would work," Frosty reflected, "it got very exciting. Like we all knew, that was it-especially when one of us injected an idea that was good to start with, and then watched the other two help improve the thing, transform it, tune it up into something. Without their help, you could never have gotten to that point. That was really good! Also, some of the ideas were delegated. For instance, some of our ideas were taken over by one of us to specialize in. Other ideas were given to other artists who got involved later on."

270.title: Lindgren on the Fog and Light Frame
270.ref_bibliographic: Nilo Lindgren, "Into Collaboration" in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin, and Barbara Rose (eds). Pavilion. New York: E.P. Dutton, 1972, pp. 3-59.
270.text:
The idea of the Fog to shroud the dome was discussed for some time. No one knew whether or not it was actually possible to make a fog, but the idea persisted and survived. Once the fog idea emerged, it immediately suggested two other ideas to Myers, both having to do with the interaction of light and fog. One was for the four towers with lights, the tallest being a hundred feet, and the others grading down at fifteen-foot levels-eighty-five feet, seventy feet, and fifty-five feet-so that the lights set at right angles formed a tilted square. This frame of light was to surround the Pavilion and shine through the Fog; from a distance, a visitor would see a skewed rectangle, and as he approached he would see it as a square framing the Pavilion. As he walked under it "he would feel he had entered something, sort of a fourth-dimensional fence or gate." Myers' other idea was for the Suntrak sculpture, which was to track the sun continually and throw a reflection of it into the Fog during the day. 
When the Fog was proposed, Pearce realized it made sense because it would be seen from across the fair grounds. If the Pavilion had been crowded down among many of the others, the Fog "would have been meaningless." Likewise, he saw the light frame, forming a slanted square of light framing the outside of the Pavilion, as a special kind of sculptural announcement. Down in the bowl, crowded in, it would have been "an interesting piece of sculpture, but a waste of money."

584.title: Fog Sculpture for Pepsi Pavilion, 1970, Expo '70, Osaka, Japan. Photo Fujiko Nakaya
584.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.

268.title: Lindgren on the initial ideas of Fog and Mirror
268.ref_bibliographic: Nilo Lindgren, "Into Collaboration" in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin, and Barbara Rose (eds). Pavilion. New York: E.P. Dutton, 1972, pp. 3-59.
268.text: From the beginning, everyone involved felt somewhat dissatisfied with the faceted dome. In retrospect, however, its existence as a negative "given" may have been the constraint that gave birth to the two most remarkable features of the Pavilion-the Mirror and the Fog. These two obscure the dome shape from the inside and the outside. Both Fog and Mirror are mysterious and evocative: both contribute to the "visual richness" that all the artists were interested in.

269.title: Lindgren on a general meeting at the E.A.T. loft on November 10, 1968
269.ref_bibliographic: Nilo Lindgren, "Into Collaboration" in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin, and Barbara Rose (eds). Pavilion. New York: E.P. Dutton, 1972, pp. 3-59.

270.title: Lindgren on the Fog and Light Frame
270.ref_bibliographic: Nilo Lindgren, "Into Collaboration" in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin, and Barbara Rose (eds). Pavilion. New York: E.P. Dutton, 1972, pp. 3-59.

The idea of the Fog to shroud the dome was discussed for some time. No one knew whether or not it was actually possible to make a fog, but the idea persisted and survived.
