53.title: Klüver on design and production of the Fog
53.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
53.text:
The original four artists wanted to cover the dome, which had been decided on before we became involved, with a cloud and asked Japanese artist Fujiko Nakaya to create it. We had already rejected chemical means of producing fog: carbon dioxide for environmental reasons and urea for public relations ones. Nakaya found cloud physicist Tom Mee in Pasadena, who designed a nozzle system for her. Water under pressure of 500 psi is pushed through an orifice 10 mil in diameter and hits a small pin which breaks the water into droplets tiny enough to remain suspended in air. [...]
Nakaya designed a cloud control system to monitor the humidity and wind; different groups of nozzles were activated to produce more or less volume of cloud as the weather conditions demanded.

54.title: Klüver on the operation and exhibition of Fog
54.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
54.text:
[…] Outside the Pavilion, the dome, which had been decided on before we came into the project, was covered by a water vapor cloud sculpture, by Fujiko Nakaya.
[…] The system for the Pavilion consisted of 2,520 jet-spray nozzles organized in 10-foot strands of plastic pipe with one nozzle every foot, placed in the ridges and valleys on the top section of the roof. The system could generate a 6-foot thick 150-foot diameter area of low-hanging cloud. This required 41 tons of water per hour, and we had to build a small reservoir to continually feed the system. Nakaya took this photograph the first day she had the cloud system turned on full. The Expo fire brigade showed up, but much to their relief found only what they called 'water smoke.'
[…] A view of the Pavilion from the back with the cloud sculpture fully on and one of the towers for Myers' Light Frame sculpture.

1044.name: State University of New York at Albany (SUNI)

49.title: Pepsi-Cola Pavilion_2003_Klüver on the Clam Room design and exhibition
49.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
49.text: The sloping floor and ceiling of the Clam Room was designed by Robert Whitman to provide a transition between the outside of the Pavilion and the Mirror Dome upstairs. It was dark, with some light coming from the glass ceiling which was the center part of the floor of the Mirror Dome. [...] This is a view of the Clam Room looking toward the entrance tunnel.

50.title: Klüver on the exhibition of the Laser Deflection System
50.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
50.text: [...] A sound-activated laser deflection system showered the floor and visitors with moving patterns of laser light 10 feet across. Lowell Cross designed the system which split the beam from a krypton laser into four colors, and sent each color beam to sets of mirrors mounted at right angles and vibrating up to 500 cycles per second to create the patterns. [...].

275.title: Nilo Lindgren on the design and production of the Laser Deflection System
275.ref_bibliographic: Nilo Lindgren, "Into Collaboration" in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin, and Barbara Rose (eds). Pavilion. New York: E.P. Dutton, 1972, pp. 3-59.
275.text:
Another electronic composer at the Pavilion took a strikingly different direction, although also under David Tudor's lead. One of Tudor's early ideas was to have a shower of laser light whose output would be modified by sounds-creating "visual sound." The sound-modulated laser shower was at first to be in the dome, but when it became evident that its effects would be washed out by the ambient light, the laser was moved to the underground Clam Room. Tudor suggested Lowell Cross to design the laser system. Cross had collaborated with Tudor for some time in making images from sound material using color television sets. Tudor and Cross had then worked on finding the means of making the projection of such television displays large enough for concert audiences. 
When Cross heard from Tudor that there was interest in having a laser in the Pavilion, and a krypton laser became available through the Coherent Radiation Laboratories, he began to pursue this idea for achieving specific visual effects using vibrating mirrors. With the krypton laser, one can get a four-color output. By designing four sets of mirrors to deflect each of these beams, and by causing sound signals to vibrate these mirror systems, it became possible to get a four-color, visual, live output for the sounds fed into the system. 
Cross related his concern with translating sound into vision, "I decided that one of the great problems with electronic music is that it has very little visual information of any real interest. In contrast, a traditional concert is a very social visual experience. There is all the ritual of the conductor in white tie and tails coming out, and everyone in the audience knows what it looks like when sound is produced on almost any kind of musical instrument. Through this experience, a listener to a phonograph recording at home knows what is happening visually as he listens." There is no equally rich equivalent for the sounds produced electronically by deadlooking boxes of equipment. So Cross decided it was worthwhile, through electronics, to make a correlation between what one hears and what one sees. 
Dr. Carson Jeffries became Cross's collaborator on the sound-to-visual transformation. An experimental physicist at the University of California, Berkeley, Jeffries is also a superb mechanical designer as well as a sculptor. It was Jeffries who built the micrometer control system on the light-beam galvanometers that deflect laser beams. 
Of their collaboration, Carson Jeffries said: "I believe this is a collaboration not between a physicist and a musician, but between two artists-Lowell's background in electronics is very good and my background in sculpture is good, so we are working together as artists." 
Asked what he thinks makes a successful collaboration, Cross answered: "I just think it takes the ability to get things finished. A real effort and drive on the part of the collaborators to see a thing through to the end and make it work. David Tudor, Carson Jeffries, and I were all highly motivated in this."

57.title: Pepsi-Cola Pavilion_2003_Klüver on the Mirror operation and exhibition
57.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
57.text:
[…] Climbing the stairs, they came into the Mirror Dome, which was Bob Whitman's idea. It was a 90 foot diameter 210-degree spherical mirror made of aluminized mylar in which the real image of the floor and the visitors on it hung upside down in space over the their heads. 
[...] The spherical mirror in the Pepsi Pavilion, showing the real image of the floor and the visitors hanging upside down in space over their heads. This optical effect resembles that of a hologram. Because of the size of our mirror, a spectator looking at the real image of a person could walk around that image and see it from ail sides. The effect was spectacular.
Our architect John Pearce devised an ingenious way the mylar mirror could be held up inside an air-tight spherical cage. A slight vacuum of less than 1/1000 of an atmosphere in the space between the cage and the mirror was sufficient to hold up the mirror. There was no need for cumbersome air locks.
[...]
This photograph of Ritty Burchfield with a flag is the first formal photograph taken in the mirror and was used for publicity in Japan. Remy Charlip used this flag and other large pieces of colored cloth for a performance in the Mirror on opening day of the Pavilion. The space in the mirror was gentle and poetic, rich and always changing. It was quite complex in spite of its simplicity. Every day we discovered new and complicated optical effects.

39. This photograph is printed upside down to demonstrate the real image effect in the mirror. We can clearly see the real image of the backs of two men (one wearing a white hat); and the fronts of the same two men standing on the floor, their arms raised, pointing toward their images. Visitors became very excited when they recognized themselves and their friends in the mirror.

268.title: Lindgren on the initial ideas of Fog and Mirror
268.ref_bibliographic: Nilo Lindgren, "Into Collaboration" in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin, and Barbara Rose (eds). Pavilion. New York: E.P. Dutton, 1972, pp. 3-59.
268.text: From the beginning, everyone involved felt somewhat dissatisfied with the faceted dome. In retrospect, however, its existence as a negative "given" may have been the constraint that gave birth to the two most remarkable features of the Pavilion-the Mirror and the Fog. These two obscure the dome shape from the inside and the outside. Both Fog and Mirror are mysterious and evocative: both contribute to the "visual richness" that all the artists were interested in.

60.title: Pepsi-Cola Pavilion_2003_Klüver on the Opening day
60.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
60.text:
We took this photograph on March 15, the opening day of Expo '70, as everyone climb[e]d onto the entrance tunnel for a group port[rai]t.
1. Franny Breer, 2. David Tudor, 3. Julie Martin, 4. Calvin Tomkins, 5. Jackie Serwer, 6. Robert Whitman (partially obscured), 7. Ardison Phillips, 8. Fujilko Nakaya, 9. Frosty Myers, 10. Dore Weiner, 11.
Sachiko Tamai, 12. John Ryde, 13. Carla Harrison, 14. Gordon Garmire, 15. Robert Breer, 16. Lori Van't Slot, 17. Harry Harper, 18. Billy Klüver, 19.  Remy Charlip, 20. Babara Rose, 21. Lowell Van't Slot, 22. Howard
Chesney, 23. Fred Waldhauer, 24. Eric Saarinen, 25. Larry Owens, 26. Peter Poole, 27. John Pearce, 28. Maja Klüver, 29. Olga Klüver, 30. Tom Mee, 31. Elsa Garmire, 32. Sig Stenlund.
About three million people visited the Pavilion during the course of Expo '70. Ardison Phillips calculated that the average visitor spent 23 minutes in the Pavilion, longer than any other pavilion. As a matter of fact, we once saw a Japanese family sitting on the astroturf peacefully having their lunch.

264.title: Lindgren on Tudor's initial ideas
264.ref_bibliographic: Nilo Lindgren, "Into Collaboration" in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin, and Barbara Rose (eds). Pavilion. New York: E.P. Dutton, 1972, pp. 3-59.
264.text: The inner space as a sound space? This fell naturally to composer David Tudor, whose work "Bandoneon!" at 9 Evenings made extraordinary use of the acoustics of the Armory. He has worked for many years with Merce Cunningham's dance group, for whom he recently composed the score for Rainforest. Tudor was responsible for the conception of the interior of the dome as a sound environment that would surround and move around the visitors. It was also he who conceived of the sound system as an "instrument" so that the sound would not be fixed in advance but would result from the visiting artists playing it.

267.title: Lindgren on Tudor's initial ideas (sound system)
267.ref_bibliographic: Nilo Lindgren, "Into Collaboration" in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin, and Barbara Rose (eds). Pavilion. New York: E.P. Dutton, 1972, pp. 3-59.
267.text:
In talking with the artists, it becomes obvious that each in his own way was struggling to wrap his own conceptions around what was already given, or supposedly given. Following this process, we get insights into how these artists thought of themselves and of their functions. For instance, Tudor was probably most influenced in his thinking and feeling by the presence of the rock groups. When he first heard from Breer about the project, Tudor decided simply "Not to say 'no,' but to keep it open." Tudor understood the situation was to create an environment for rock groups, that is, for live performances. This idea came through to him with "great force." "My immediate reaction," Tudor related, "was that I wasn't interested as a composer, but that I could serve by thinking of myself more like a performer. I tried to imagine what I would consider an interesting environment if I were a rock performer." 
 
As soon as he realized the space was to be a dome, Tudor related, he became "involved" with the idea of moving sound, especially for rock groups. "One thing about rock groups," he explained, "is that they all have the same density of sound, and I felt there ought to be some means of creating an unpredictable space relationship that would vary the source of the sound. That is, the rock group wouldn't be able at first to figure out how they are actuating such movement." 
His first plan was to spot the sound so that it would not come from all points at once, and to make a program that would interface between a performer and the feedback of his sound, so that the controllable modification would introduce new relationships between the performer and his experience of his work. 
The dome space as given was too small to allow the possibilities of sound differentiation that would be available in a larger space. From this point of view, the rock groups made no sense. The other artists, too, for their own reasons, were struggling around them. They were all tired of rock, and began to toy with the idea of submitting a completely fresh proposal. "Somehow," Tudor remembered, "we never made that decision, it arose naturally. As we defined more and more details of the interior, it became its own space, with its own characteristics, and finally it became clear that rock groups were inappropriate." 
In defining "differentiation of sound space," David Tudor described the fundamental concept behind the sound system of the Pavilion. "You see, for me," he said, "sound space is more physical; I can almost touch it." "I kept the sound movement," he said, "because the idea was still in my head; I thought it would be intriguing to experience sound that moved very quickly. The sound moving from speaker to speaker moves so quickly that it destroys the shape of the sound wave. There will be a point at which the speed is so great that the original sound will be destroyed. My interest is in going beyond that point and seeing what speed itself will create; to see what kinds of sound material will not require faithful reproduction or will act as a new sound generator. We've never heard that."

274.title: Nilo Lindgren on the design and production of the Sound System
274.ref_bibliographic: Nilo Lindgren, "Into Collaboration" in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin, and Barbara Rose (eds). Pavilion. New York: E.P. Dutton, 1972, pp. 3-59.
274.text:
The sound-modifier system was proposed by composer David Tudor. When the time came to think about equipment for the sound system, Tudor brought Gordon Mumma into the project. Mumma suggested a system that would modify the pitch (frequency), the loudness, and the color (formants) of each of the eight channels of the sound system, so as to give the "player" a more flexible instrument. 
Mumma, originally a French-horn player and a pianist, said that although he still plays conventional instruments, his primary interest for the past decade has been in electronic music. In effect, he now builds his own instruments, seeing little difference between this development and the time when musical instruments were developed through mechanical means. "It's just that the technology today is electronics rather than mechanics." 
At the outset of his involvement with the Pavilion sound system, Mumma made what is essentially a philosophical decision about the direction he would take. He said, "I didn't want to generate sound, or make sound; I didn't want to make a toy instrument. Instead, I wanted to make an environmental control system for sound." 
Just about the time Mumma started to implement ideas for the system, he came across a new small solid-state circuit (called a "gate-controlled amplifier") of a special kind. "I had," he said, "an idea that it could be used for some things the manufacturer hadn't really thought of, and in the course of about four weeks, I filled a notebook with various things I was able to do with it. All of them, interestingly, fit the possibilities I had in mind for the sound-modifier console. This single integrated circuit not only generated more efficient ways of working, but new ideas as well" 
Mumma's final system was ready by late February, 1970. It then had to be interfaced with the system designed by Tudor-and the engineer, Larry Owens. 
The interfacing of these system parts required the closest degree of collaboration between Mumma and Owens. Said Mumma: "I had to be able to take the sound signals they were producing, and had to give them signals they could use after the sound-modifier processing. We collaborated in the greatest of detail. Otherwise, I was able to carry forward my work on the modifier autonomously." 
Because there are eight channels of sound that can undergo modification, and twelve controls for each channel, Mumma's control console contains a total of ninety-six controls in all. This, he notes, is the same order of magnitude of combinations as one has with a large organ. Although ninety-six controls may seem like a large number to cope with, Mumma feels that a person with practice can, in an hour or so, get a good idea of possible configurations and then be able to treat it as a performing instrument.

59.title: Klüver on the Sound System
59.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
59.text: David Tudor designed the sound system as an "instrument" with 32 input channels and 37 speakers arranged in a rhombic grid on the surface of the dome behind the mirror. Sound could be moved at varying speeds around or across the dome, or it could be shifted abruptly from any one speaker to another, creating point sources of sound. Both the lighting system, designed by artist Tony Martin, and the sound system could be pre-programed or controlled in real time from a console at one side of the Dome.

280.title: Nilo Lindgren on the design and production of the Sound System (2)
280.ref_bibliographic: Nilo Lindgren, "Into Collaboration" in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin, and Barbara Rose (eds). Pavilion. New York: E.P. Dutton, 1972, pp. 3-59.
280.text:
Toward the Sound System 

As engineering consultant in the early conceptualizing meetings on the project, Waldhauer listened to David Tudor's ideas and identified the character of the engineering problems in order to identify the technical problems involved. During the first trip to Japan, Tudor described sounds that would move around and over the top of the dome, so that the listener would have the impression that the sound was somehow embodied in a vehicle that was flying around him at varying speeds, from so slow that the motion would be just barely noticeable, to so fast that again the ear would not be able to detect motion. Waldhauer's first suggestion was to space loudspeakers in a grid around the dome and to interconnect them in such a way that a given sound could be commutated between the loudspeakers using a joystick or handle that could be moved around by the performer. Apparent movement of the sound source would correspond to the position or movement of the joystick. This idea would have been workable except that Tudor asked for twenty sound channels, all capable of moving independently around the dome. Waldhauer felt that a twenty-joystick system was beyond the capability of even a shoeless performer, so that some sort of programming or automation would be needed. 
There the matter rested for two months until March 10, when Waldhauer invited Larry Owens to a meeting with Tudor, and John Pan. Owens is a member of the technical staff with the Digital Techniques Department at the Bell Telephone Laboratories in New Jersey where he works on special-purpose digital machines and on signal processing. He had also participated in a few collaborative projects with artists that involved the electronic switching of sounds in an audio system, and, therefore, seemed to be well suited to solve the technical problems that Tudor's sound system presented. The engineers saw the problem of moving the sounds as David wanted as essentially a switching problem and John Pan proposed a system similar to TASI, a switching system used to increase the efficiency of transatlantic submarine cable telephone transmission. The TASI system switches many trunks or telephone line inputs at each end of a cable onto a smaller number of transmission channels of a cable by filling up empty spaces. Voice-actuated switches at each end switch a trunk away from a channel when a trunk user is momentarily silent. This kind of system would switch the many different sound inputs through the originally proposed twenty channels onto sixty speakers. Instead of voice actuation the switching was to be controlled by a programming system that Pan and Owens proposed at this meeting. 
Choices made early in the development of the digital switching system (in particular the punch-paper tape programmer) made it impossible to handle the number of channels Tudor wanted. Owens traded off the number of channels for the physical realizability of his system. The channels were reduced from twenty to sixteen, and finally to eight. At this point, the reduction of channels removed the original objections to analogue control by joysticks, but the design of the system using digital control was too far advanced to introduce this change. 
Larry Owens agreed to design the schematics, components, and layouts for the audio system. The design was to be on paper with Owens building nothing. 

In April, Kluver asked Owens to be part of the group of engineers who were going to Japan to meet with the Takenaka people on technical aspects of the Pavilion. 
They went, Owens recalled, with the idea of transferring the actual development of the systems to their Japanese colleagues. 
The American artists and engineers overestimated the degree to which the Japanese would be willing to collaborate on designing and building components. From the first meeting at the offices of the Takenaka Komuten, in Osaka, the Japanese wanted finished drawings, schematics, equipment specifications, and wiring diagrams. 
By their last day of meetings, Kluver asked Owens to be the engineering coordinator for the many separate projects. There were hundreds of practical questions to be dealt with: who was to be responsible for each piece of equipment; what it was to look like; who was to make the specifications; who was to decide which cost estimates were reasonable; what kind of gear could be brought over from the United States and what was its compatibility with equipment made in Japan; and how would they tie together or interface the various systems? The final system had to be integrated into a single controllable package. 
Until then, John Pearce, the coordinating architect, had been acting as project manager, but now, Owens and Pearce together made the day-to-day architectural and technical decisions, balancing out the needs among all the collaborators-artists, engineers, architects, the Pepsi people, and the Japanese. Owens and Pearce complemented each other's strengths and together they made an effective team. 

Although Tudor and Waldhauer had decided in the first meeting in Tokyo that the amplifiers, loudspeakers, the tape recorders-the things you can buy off the shelf-would be bought and installed in Japan, it was now determined by the group that the console had to be built in the United States, since there was too little time to transfer design information to the Japanese. 
In normal engineering programs for equipment manufacture, the usual procedure is to make preliminary designs, test them on rough models to determine design feasibility, then build a prototype or first real model, and test it extensively to eliminate design flaws (usually called "debugging"). But Owens decided that he would not have time to build a prototype, but would have to go from designs on paper directly to the final model. 
When Owens returned to the United States in April, 1969, from the first of his many trips, he began the detailed design of the control console for the sound and light systems. He asked two technicians, Per Biorn (who had collaborated on 9 Evenings) and Peter Kubik, to implement his designs. Later on, Skip Savard and Lowell Van't Slot, who designed a crowd-counting system, were added to the team. 
The audio control system was to be completed by early January, 1970, and coordinated with the sound-modifier system being developed separately by Gordon Mumma. As things went, the system was not ready for debugging until the control console was installed in the Pavilion in late February. The debugging process was never to be completed.


If the case of the Fog illustrates successful collaboration, the history of the sound system points up the problems. Calvin Tomkins' section describes some of the things that went awry in the final days and hours before the Pavilion opened on March 15, 1970, but the basic problems developed much earlier. 
Although a complete analysis of the interactions and decisions that led to difficulties in the evolution of the sound system is not possible here, it is worthwhile comparing some of the judgments of the leading participants. 
Fred Waldhauer has commented that this form of collaboration is a very fragile process. "But," he said, "there are two roads to go: find engineers who are willing to change, to take risks and to take the responsibility for the implications of collaboration with an artist, or institute hierarchy. We have always chosen to do the former. There is no question that Larry did a mammoth job for so young a man, but in the case of the sound system he was not able to sacrifice some of his engineering baggage to make his collaboration on the sound system go." 
Owens talked about the pressures of the collaboration on him. He found, of course, that it was a real learning process, because "the artist" he said is a person who "doesn't really want to make up his mind six or eight months in advance, and, yet, in a project of this magnitude, the technology demands such decisions in order "to meet schedules." Owens went on, "occasionally, we've made unilateral decisions. The environmental concept as originally envisioned has altered, partly due to engineering decisions. The artist is much more vague than the engineer, so you are not making decisions based on facts. Sometimes you are making decisions based on the absence of facts! What the engineer does in this case is to invent facts, make a decision, implement the decision, and then come back to the artist and say 'Is this what you meant?' " One of the problems, he feels, is that the artist does not know what engineering is, and then furthermore, "The artist doesn't visualize things in terms of words. The artist deals with things." 
David Tudor felt that Owens' attitude that the artist cannot participate in the engineering, precluded artistic alternatives in a situation with pressing deadlines. "At the beginning, one lays down the things one wants to work with," Tudor said, "then the engineering becomes an interpretation of this. If you then can't go inside the engineering problems and are never allowed to offer an alternative along the engineering road, the thing takes the engineer's shape. It was a one-way street, and my original ideas were leaving one by one. Of course there were strict time considerations and delays and delays, but Larry wanted, above all, to present me with a finished product, and warded off all 'meddling.' 
"The number of channels cost me more heartache than anything else," Tudor continued, "My conception of numbers was real. Like with a juggler, three balls are different from four balls, and the difference is so extreme it goes all the way down the line. In January, 1969, I asked for twenty channels, in the system I was presented with it finally stopped being reduced at eight. Numbers were different in Larry's thinking and there was no translation possible."

277.title: Nilo Lindgren on the design and production of the Interior Light System
277.ref_bibliographic: Nilo Lindgren, "Into Collaboration" in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin, and Barbara Rose (eds). Pavilion. New York: E.P. Dutton, 1972, pp. 3-59.
277.text:
Robert Whitman asked artist Tony Martin to design the interior light system. Martin's approach was to design lighting to "render perceivable the basic visual dynamics of the real and virtual images," and to explore the "permutations of the combined reflections as a changeable and natural, though unusual, space for people to enjoy and do things in." He travelled to the site in Japan and consulted with Boris Sojka and Elsa Garmire on the West Coast. In addition to a series of fixed and moving spotlights in the top of the dome, he devised a central interior light that illuminated upward and moved vertically through the focal point of the Mirror to the top of the Mirror dome. He described the effect this light produced: "Light from this source will reflect downward from the dome and illuminate a circular to donut shape in variable diameters on the peopled floor. For general real-imaging of floor activity it will create a convex image in midspace of the area which is illuminated." 
Although he saw color as a "natural result of reflected clothing and floor elements and activity," he added gel combines to the movable spotlights. All the light functions-intensity, movement, color -were programmable. Martin wanted to make it possible for a performer to combine "spontaneous action and tuning of the dome's visual events with the packaged programming of them using audio tape (multichannel, on/off, intensity, and time control as well as straight audio-signal intensity control) and/or papertape digital control of these functions."

55.title: Klüver on the Pepsi Pavilion Interior Light
55.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
55.text: Both the lighting system, designed by artist Tony Martin, and the sound system could be pre-programed or controlled in real time from a console at one side of the Dome.

37.name: Pepsi Pavilion Floor and Sound Loop System

52.title: Pepsi-Cola Pavilion_2003_Klüver on the Floor and Sound Loop System exhibition
52.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
52.text: […] The floor was divided into 10 areas made up of different materials, such as astroturf, rough wood, slate, tile, and asphalt. Through handsets, visitors could hear different sounds while standing on each different floor material: on the tile floor, horses hooves and shattering glass; on the astroturf, ducks, frogs, cicadas and lions roaring. These sounds were transmitted to the handset from wire loops embedded in the floor section.

269.title: Lindgren on a general meeting at the E.A.T. loft on November 10, 1968
269.ref_bibliographic: Nilo Lindgren, "Into Collaboration" in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin, and Barbara Rose (eds). Pavilion. New York: E.P. Dutton, 1972, pp. 3-59.
269.text:
Kluver called for a general meeting at the E.A.T. loft on November 10, and he made a point of asking Rauschenberg to be there. 
The meeting proved, as Kluver expected, to be an important turning point. Rauschenberg suggested that since most of them were plastic artists-painters and sculptors-they should shift their approach to include elements that appealed to all the senses rather than just the visual, that is, elements that would create what people would feel as an "invisible" environment. Everyone had ideas, and long lists of these were drawn up on the spot. 
The basic idea of the "invisible environment" had taken hold, and at the end of the meeting Kluver said, "OK, you guys have two weeks to come up with a design or there won't be a pavilion." The artists decided they would meet alone. 
Two days later, Whitman, Myers, Breer, and Pearce held their first intensive design session. At Whitman's house, they worked and created paper models on Whitman's mirror-top table. Within two weeks the basic design was realized, which remained essentially unchanged throughout the project. 
In thrashing out their ideas, the artists became increasingly committed to true, non-competitive collaboration, discarding ideas, triggering new ideas in each other, and acting as catalysts for each other. In his original plan, for instance, Frosty Myers had a square grid of radio loops on a flat floor (the sound loops consciously borrowed from the dancer Steve Paxton who had used them in 9 Evenings). Onto this elaborate square, the group proposed rear-screen projections so that a visitor could walk out over clouds, over fire, over living creatures like magnified newts and fish. Eventually, however, all types of visual projections were abandoned by mutual agreement, because visitors in most fair situations are battered by projections and from their experience, Breer and Whitman decided it was not a strong enough thing to sacrifice the amount of time and money to research and develop it against other things they wanted to do. "Then," said Myers, "Bob Whitman came up with the idea of pitching the floor so that the whole floor was related to the optics of the dome." 
Gradually, as Myers suggested, the floor kept getting scaled down. At first the floor was made to vibrate, to hum, to change color, but then it moved toward a more passive and subtle form, each section having a different texture, each texture being related to different sounds over the radio loops. Different smells were also considered, and abandoned. It was remembered that Mike Todd's son had spent several million dollars for movie "smellies" and hadn't solved the technical problems. Said Myers, "It just ends up being a garbage can." 
"When we really hit on something we knew would work," Frosty reflected, "it got very exciting. Like we all knew, that was it-especially when one of us injected an idea that was good to start with, and then watched the other two help improve the thing, transform it, tune it up into something. Without their help, you could never have gotten to that point. That was really good! Also, some of the ideas were delegated. For instance, some of our ideas were taken over by one of us to specialize in. Other ideas were given to other artists who got involved later on."

354.title: Opening spectacular
354.ref_bibliographic: Live programming : Pepsi pavilion : Expo 70. — New York : [Experiments in Art and Technology], [November 26, 1969]. — [9] p. — Projects description.
354.text:
LIVE -PROGRAMMING: PEPSI PAVILION, EXPO '70    	11/26/1969

"OPENING SPECTACULAR"

This program will include highlights from proposals which have already been submitted.

The program is in 8 sections (see below). Transition from one section to the next will be instantaneous and dramatic.

A poet will write a description, both artistic and technical, about what is taking place. This will be heard over the loop system, e.g. "It is now Spring ... streams full from melting snows ..." The sound of water gurgling and rushing will come over the sound system. To create the impression of actual passage of water, different speakers will transmit different water sounds.
Technical information on how this is done will be given over the loop-system.

PROGRAM OUTLINE

1. Spring : Remy Charlip. The dome is green. Sounds of water rushing, birds, rain.
2. Summer: Alan Kaprow. The dome is golden. Sounds of the beach, children playing, farm machinery.
3. Autumn: Jerome Robbins. The dome is red/russet. Sounds of birds migrating, wild geese, a harvest festival.
4. Winter: La Monte Young. The dome is blue-white. Sounds of cold winds, breaking ice.
5. Earth : John Hassell, sound-modification composer. Sounds of earthquakes, an avalanche, body-sounds, heartbeats.
6. Air: Terry Riley, wind-instruments composer. Sounds of air, wind, jet-plane.
7. Fire: Ann Halprin. Temperamental violence. Sounds of fire. Flames in the dome.
8. Water: Whale People. The dome is blue/green - dim, under-water. Sounds of water dripping, songs of whales.

355.title: Compilation of Broad Ideas and Specific Suggestions for Programming
355.ref_bibliographic: Live programming : Pepsi pavilion : Expo 70. — New York : [Experiments in Art and Technology], [November 26, 1969]. — [9] p. — Projects description.
355.text:
E.A.T.
November 25, 1969

Compilation of Broad Ideas and Specific Suggestions for Programming

1. Re-enact clas[s]ical Japanese legends and dramas in dome environment.
2. Use sound system to program traditional and contemporary Japanese poetry: use lights and other sounds in addition to reading poems to create moods of haiku poetry.
3. Use sound and light system of the Pavilion to create patterns anal[o]gous to and derived from Fibonacci "spiral" sequences of sunflowers and sunburst motion of cathode ray tube.
4. Activity oriented use of dancers, tumblers, and circus performers.
5. Environment can be made gentle and lyrical, associated with nature sounds and environments—in a forest, under the sea— or it can be made violent and turbulent— thunderstorms, earthquakes, volcanos erupting.
6. Use a large flexible mirror surface on the floor, photo cells, and reflect light through the focal point to make the pavilion a light machine activated by the visitors.
7. Visitors rearrange shapes made of plastic or cloth, moving them to different positions on the floor.
8. Spectator games using handsets, light beams, sonar devices, echo-location devices, and sound and light reflective shields.
9. With telephone lines hooked to each of the thirty-seven speakers visitors to Expo can pick up a phone and call the pavilion within certain hours to recite their favorite poem or sing a song.
10. Floor loops can be used to broadcast news from all over the world in different languages
11. Taking of photographs in the pavilion
12. Using movement of sound on speakers to simulate whales swimming closer and closer singing to each other. By moving sound rapidly to top of dome, the leap of a humpback whale will be created. Use of lights, dimming movement, will simulate descent into the sea. Telephone calls will be heard from people interested in whales.
13. Large over-sized puppets will be held up by helium ballo[o]ns or long sticks inside in form of large people, large hand, full-scale whale, etc.
14. Group costumes many people wear special costu[me] simultaneously (for school groups especially) red circle, rainbow, concentric circle, weaving pattern, sea or cate[r]pillar, dragon or hill.
15. Pick up words and phrases of visitors and keeping them intelligible, switch them from speaker to speaker.
16. Using fibre-optics and handsets to create planetarium and floating solar system.
17. Performers wearing special costumes and carrying mirrored shields will reflect sound and light.
18. Articulate characteristic frequencies of the dome by recirculating sounds of speech through several cycles of being played and re-recorded in the dome, so that bell-like tones remain.
19. Large round 'keyboard' in the center of the floor that visitors step on to activate dome functions.
20. Demonstration for school children of physical properties of dome and sound in spherical shape using the loop system.
21. A sine-wave generator will be used to make standing wave forms in the dome. The sound will vary in volume throughout the space, and visitors will hear according to their position on the floor. The resonant frequencies of the dome will be used.
22. Light-weight aluminum mobiles will be hung on which lights of the pavilion will play.
23. Programs incorporating such events as flashes from xenon lights, simulated sunrise with seagulls, rocket ship take-off with rising winch light, watery and biological sounds, a thunderstorm, streamers, wind machine, flames, lights on poles, flashbulbs.
24. A low-power laser beam direct vertically up a descending stream of water from a siphon under the winch.
25. Use of tape delay system to produce multiple echoes.
26. A neon show: neon figures and shapes that move inside the mirror; vertical neon light from top to focal point; horizontal rotating light.
27. Rate of movement of sound and light will vary and correspond to the density of the visitors in the dome.

Note: These ideas have been copyrighted by the artists and are the property of the artists.

357.title: Job Descriptions for Live Programming
357.ref_bibliographic: Live programming : Pepsi pavilion : Expo 70. — New York : [Experiments in Art and Technology], [November 26, 1969]. — [9] p. — Projects description.
357.text:
E.A.T.
November 25, 1969

JOB DESCRIPTIONS

ENGINEER:

Maintenance: interior lights, taperecorders, sound system, gas laser, floats (mechanical and tape recorders), fog, sun-track resetting, maintain mirror, etc.

Interface with the artists: teach him the operation of the console, advise on technical implementation of his program in the system

Test functioning of equipment and systems: periodic resetting of pavilion to zero state

Assistant engineers report to the Engineer.


PROGRAM MANAGER:

Responsible for starting the Pavilion each day.

Supervise that prog[r]ams are planned and executed. Supervise props budget and acquisitions and construction. Hires extra performers if needed (high school kids, etc.) Works with coordinating artist of the week who reports to him.

Prepares daily schedules of people and programs. Keeps daily log of activities, photos etc.

Responsible for state and looks of Pavilion; reports breakdowns to engineer.

Interface with Pepsi management of the Pavilion.

Handles VIP along with engineer, artists and Pepsi management.

The Tape librarian, pavilion assistant, and logistics person report to him


COORDINATING ARTIST:

Coordinate and plan his week. Pull other artists together for the weeks activities.

Responsible for procuring, constructing props or special equipment for his week

Supervise making of punch paper tapes, sound tapes

Physically get programs ready, running programs, performances

Assist with VTPs

After hours: testing programs, testing equipment, learning console, making practice runs of programs


TAPE LIBRARIAN:

Transfer artists' programs onto punch paper tape

Splice and prepare audio tapes

Store and keep track of paper-tape programs and audio tapes


LOGISTICS:

In charge of travel, housing, shipping of equipment and props

Procurement of materials for props and other special arrangements

Those appearing were Remy Charlip, Lowell Cross, Jacquelyn Farrell and Harry Harper (following through a proposal first submitted by Lisa Forbes and Roger Payne), Takumi Hijikata, Anthony Martin, Rikuro Miyai, Pauline Oliveros and Lynn Lonidier, and David Tudor.

341.title: Live Programming for the Pepsi Pavilion: Request for Proposals, October 15, 1969
341.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, Julie Martin, and Barbara Rose (eds). Pavilion. New York: E.P. Dutton, 1972. 346 p.
341.text:
Live Programming for the Pepsi Pavilion: Request for Proposals
October 15, 1969

1. Programmers

	Twenty-tour programmers will be chosen, half from Japan and half from the United States and Europe. Each programmer will stay for a period of three, four, or five weeks at the Pavilion. At any given time during the twenty-six weeks of Expo, at least four programmers will be in residence to program the Pavilion. The residencies of the programmers will be staggered by one week to smooth over the break in the schedule when a new programmer takes over (Figure 1). The programming will change every week due to the addition of a new programmer. The four programmers will decide, in collaboration, on the total program for the weeks that they work together. The collaborative nature of the programming means that adjustments may take place in the submitted proposals in accordance with the opinions of the programmers working together.
	Each programmer will be asked to introduce and inform the new programmer who will succeed him. Each programmer will also be asked to coordinate the programming for one week. This will be the last or the next-to-last week of his stay. When he receives notice of the acceptance of his proposal, each programmer will be told who his three collaborating programmers will be during the week when he is coordinator. He should contact them as far in
advance of his coordination week as possible. 
	

2. General Nature of Programming

	We want the visitors to be responsible for their own experiences-to have choices. The Pavilion and the programming will provide for this.
	We feel that the program for one day should be a homogeneous continuum. Changes should be introduced gradually and radical, overall changes occur only after a considerably longer period than the average visiting time, The homogeneous nature of the programming will allow any visitor to come in at any time in the cycle without feeling that he is interrupting something that has a beginning and an end (Figure 2). The stay of the average visitor cannot be very long, but we should like some people to be able to stay longer if they feel like it. A reasonable assumption is that 1,500 people will walk through the Pavilion every hour. A visit will
probably range from ten to thirty minutes.
	To aid the programmers, a graph in the control room will plot the number of people in the Pavilion at any given time. A given section of the programming may be shortened or lengthened by manual controls. This will add flexibility in affecting the length of stay of the visitors.
	The two major programmable elements, the spherical Mirror and the overall sound system, discussed below, and the floor segments with their sound-loop system can all be activated together, or one or the other emphasized at any one time (Figure 3).
	Due to the slope of the floor, visitors will obscure each other's direct view of anything taking place at floor level. Performances or activities on the floor cannot be seen directly by the majority of the visitors. Any performances or activities will be reflected in the mirror and in this way be seen by the visitor as a reflection, as real or virtual images.
	Objects and people can be placed in space above the heads of the spectators either supported by scaffolding or other support structures from the floor, or through bouncing off mats - e.g. tumblers.
Weights of up to 44 pounds can be hung from the ceiling if they do not swing. No people can be suspended from the ceiling.

3. Important considerations

	It will be the responsibility of the Programmers to develop a program which will get people to leave the Pavilion. In order to make all proposals comparable, they must assume a 15-minute visiting time.

4. The Sound System

	The thirty-seven speakers comprising the output channels for the sound system, are placed on a rhombic grid in the dome behind the mirror. (Figure 4) There are three categories of extremes of sound reproduction:
a) The line sound; a sound is switched at a rapid rate from speaker to speaker in any desired pattern. Switching time from speaker to speaker is approximately one-tenth of a second. The amount of time a sound stays on any one speaker is programmable.
b) Point sound; a sound is heard from one speaker in the dome. Point sound can be shifted to any other speaker in the dome.
c) Immersion, or environmental, sound; this effect is much like standing in a wood, or on a street, where sounds come from all directions. This will require multiple recordings of sounds.

	The sound system has 8 input channels fed by tape recorders, microphones and telephone lines. Any one of the 8 input channels can be switched to any one of - or any combination of - the output channels. Each input channel can be programmed to pass through stages of sound modification: AM, FM, PM, envelope shaping etc. (Figure 5)
	The programming is done on hard-wired programming cards. A large number of these cards will be available with standard switching patterns. However, it will be possible for each Programmer to make up his own cards at the Pavilion.
	Tapes are now being collected of non-copyrighted sounds : sounds of brain waves, heart beats, earthquakes, the earth, fish,animals; factory and street sounds etc. The sounds are continuously repeated. (See Appendix 1)
	Anyone who wishes further specific details about the sound system should contact Larry Owens, David Tudor, Toshi Ichyanagi, or Gordon Mumma, through Peter Poole.

5. Handsets and Loops in the floor

	Each visitor is given a handset in the entrance tunnel. The handset has a magnetic pickup, an amplifier and a speaker. Audio-fed loops under the various floor sections transmit sounds to the handset. A list of typical sounds is attached. These sounds can be programmed from the Control Room.
	At the opposite end of the handset, a lightbulb is turned on by a sixty cycle-per-second signal through the loops. The light can only be turned on for a total of three minutes in every fifteen- minute period. The audio can be on for any length of time. After each fifteen-minute period, the batteries have to be recharged. (Figure 6)

6. Light System

Basically there are four areas of visual possibilities in the Dome:

a) Lighting individual groups of people and things, with programmable intensity, color and duration, so that they produce images in the mirror-whether real images in space, or virtual images appearing behind the reflective surface.
b) Lighting larger areas, and especially peripheral areas in the Dome, with preset spots programmed for sequence, duration etc. 
c) Throwing beams from two high intensity sources on the equator level, through space, bouncing lines of light around the dome, illuminating small areas, things, people etc.
d) Activating the mirror with an interior 3 kilowatt source which is moveable vertically through the focal point, the center of the hemisphere.

	These four areas can be used separately, or combined by the programmer who can manipulate all the functions of the light apparatus on the Control Console.

	There are three holes at the seven-metre-diameter level of the Mirror, where lights are placed. Each hole contains three lights: two one-kilowatt spots with fourteen-inch reflectors. These light areas approximately eight feet in diameter, generally in a concentric plot, i.e. six lit areas around the center. Plus one auto-color, auto- iris, 1-kilowatt spotlight. This spotlight impinges on a plane
mirror approximately one half x one meter large. The mirror is located two and eight-tenths meters from the front of the spotlight and in a housing that can pan and tilt. The limit of the pan movement is 240 degrees. The tilt movement has no limit.
	There are two holes located at about ten feet from the floor on opposite sides of the Dome. Through each hole shines the seventy-five-watt pole-mounted Xenon, a high-intensity small diameter, spot beam.
	At the center of the dome is a hemispherical housing, which is hanging from a winch, and which contains three one-kilowatt bulbs. The housing can move from one meter off the floor, to two meters from the top of the Dome.
	All of the lights are programmable except the two seventy-five-watt xenons, which have on-off control only. The entire system can be controlled from the console and/or from a punched-paper tape machine.

7. The Mirror

	The optical properties of the Mirror are described in an enclosed article by Elsa Garmire. If you have any questions about various effects to be obtained, you can contact her. It is still possible to see a good approximation of the mirror in Los Angeles, where a full-scale model has been erected for experimentation. Contact Peter Poole.

8. Style

	We should like the experiences to "tend towards the real" rather than the philosophical. We are not interested in political or social comment, instructional performances, statements, etc. We are anxious that professional people - e.g. sports people, snake handlers, fashion people - participate as much as possible. We are interested in participation by the visitors.

9. Schedules, Expenses, and Deadlines

	We would prefer it if the Resident Programmers remained in Osaka for a month. Three weeks is the acceptable minimum. Programmers will be paid five hundred dollars a week. They are asked to arrive in Osaka three to five days before their programming period is due to begin, so as to become familiar with procedures and equipment. They will not be paid for these days. We would appreciate it if you could give some indication of the times when you will definitely not be able to go to Japan. Travel and accommodation will be provided for Programmers and their wives, but food costs will not be covered.
	The following schedule has been set up for selection of programmers:
	Monday, November 17: No more programming proposals will be accepted after this date. It would help considerably if you would include an estimate of the probable cost of your program, or information on the availability of special materials.
	Monday, December 22: You will be notified as to whether your proposal has been accepted and given your residence period. You will also be told the names of your collaborating programmers and the nature of their proposals.
	Everyone who submits a proposal will be advised about the progress and content of the Live Programming.
	Peter Poole is coordinating the collection of sound tapes and the organization of the programming. He can be reached at: E.A.T., 235 Park Avenue South, New York, N.Y. 10003; telephone- 677-3750. Please contact him if you have any questions. A telephone list of all people involved in the project is also enclosed for your convenience.

344.title: Project description of Live Programming in the Pepsi Pavilion
344.ref_bibliographic: Live programming at the Pepsi Pavilion. – [June 10, 1969]. – [3] p. – Archives documents. – Project description.

345.title: First published description of the live programming
345.ref_bibliographic: E.A.T. proceedings. – No. 8 (Mar. 25, 1969). – New York : Experiments in Art and Technology, 1969. – [17] p. – Issue title : «Description of the Pepsi pavilion for the Japan world exhibition 1970 Osaka».
345.text: Live performances of theatre, music, dance, and childrens' programs will be held in the Pavilion. The performers can make full use of the technical equipment and unique properties of the dome.

58.title: Klüver on the Pepsi Pavilion Programming
58.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
58.text: […] The artists wanted to create a Pavilion where the vis[i]tors could explore the envi[ro]nment and create their own experience. The artists also conceived of the Pavilion as a performance space, continuously programmed by visiting American and Japanese artists throughout the six months of Expo '70.

347.title: Coordinators - Live Programming
347.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, Julie Martin, and Barbara Rose (eds). Pavilion. New York: E.P. Dutton, 1972. 346 p.
347.text:
Coordinators - Live Programming

Toshi Ichiyanagi
Peter Poole
David Tudor
Robert Whitman

346.title: Live Programming in World Without Boundaries
346.ref_bibliographic: World without boundaries. — New York : PepsiCo International, 1970. — [11] p. — Leaflet.
346.text: Twenty-six invited programmers, all from the arts, sciences and other similar professions, rotate in teams of four, composing the light and sound experiences. The live programming is experimental in nature and takes full advantage of the unique technical equipment and other properties of the dome. The programs created by the resident artists will become a remarkable document of the six-month life of the Pavilion.

350.title: Tomkins on the design of Live Programming
350.ref_bibliographic: Tomkins, Calvin. – «Outside art». – Pavilion. – Edited by Billy Klüver, Julie Martin and Barbara Rose. – New York : E. P. Dutton, 1972. – P. 105-172.
350.text: While the hardware for the project was being designed and built, Klüver and Whitman spent a lot of time thinking about what Klüver called its software--the events that would take place inside the Pavilion. The original idea of a rock-music discothèque had been superseded by the concept of an automated "environment," with sound and lighting and other effects programmed in advance. By the spring of 1969, though, the infinite range of possibilities offered by the sound system, the lights, and the optical marvels of the Mirror led Klüver, Whitman, and Tudor to decide that automation would be too limiting. Only if this unique theatrical space was made available to other artists as well, they felt, could that range of possibilities be tapped. Live programming would mean, of course, a substantial increase in the operating budget something in the neighborhood, Klüver thought, of a hundred thousand dollars. Pottasch agreed with the new idea in principle, but he did not quite see the need for inviting as many artists as Klüver had in mind-at least twelve Americans and an equal number of Japanese, each of whom would spend four weeks at the Pavilion during Expo's six-month run. Why not just get four good artists, Pottasch suggested, and let them come up with a basic program that could then be repeated several times a day? Klüver said that nobody could tell who was going to make the best program until he had actually made a program, because nothing like the Mirror dome had ever existed before. The situation was open-ended, and this, as Klüver kept trying to tell Pepsi, was what it was all about. The process of artists working in the Pavilion was what interested E.A.T., more than guaranteed results. It was this kind of argument that drove some of the Pepsi executives up the wall.

351.title: Tomkins on the curation of Live Programming
351.ref_bibliographic: Tomkins, Calvin. – «Outside art». – Pavilion. – Edited by Billy Klüver, Julie Martin and Barbara Rose. – New York : E. P. Dutton, 1972. – P. 105-172.
351.text: As usual, E.A.T got Its way. A tentative live-programming budget of a hundred thousand dollars was approved-although no contract was signed. Whitman and Peter Poole, a young British geographer who joined E.A.T. in 1967, began lining up American artists on the basis of proposals submitted for programs fifteen minutes long; Miss Nakaya and Toshi Ichiyanagi, a Japanese composer, did the same for Japanese artists. Proposals involving formal dramatic presentations or performances were discouraged. The New York group wanted to have the Mirror dome used as a generalized theatrical space, in which the spectator himself would participate as much as possible. Some spectators might pass through with hardly a pause; others might stay there for hours. The best programs of all, everyone said, would undoubtedly come toward the end of the fair, by which time all concerned would have passed on what they had learned about the Mirror and the sound and light systems. To Pepsi, it all seemed a long way from traveling troubadours and singing dolls. The Pepsi public-relations department was having a terrible time thinking up a name for the Pavilion. Someone hit on the word "Sensosphere" to suggest the kind of total sensory experience visitors would have there; the name stuck for several weeks, until it was discovered that in Japanese "senso" means "war."

61.title: Klüver on the Anand Project
61.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
61.text: Vikram Sarabhai, head of the Indian Atomic Energy Commission, asked E.A.T. to develop methods for creating instructional programming for television to be used for the ATS-F Satellite which was going to be placed over India. We assembled a group of specialists in engineering, education and television, as well as an artist, Robert Whitman. The group went to India in December 1969 and worked at the Anand Dairy Cooperative in Gujurat State to produce programs for the women who raise buffalo for milk production. We proposed using 1/2" video equipment to gather material from the villages which would be used as visual research notes when the final instructional programs would be made for broadcast over the satellite. Our proposal, with its emphasis on local input was adopted and became  the  basis for the programming in what is now known as the SITE television satellite project. I consider this project to be E.A.T.'s most significant contribution.

629.title: Buffle, Anand Project. Photographer Peter Poole. Courtesy E.A.T.
629.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.

62.title: Klüver on the American Artists in India
62.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
62.text: With support from Porter MacCray of the JDR III Fund, E.A.T. organized	a project for open-ended cultural exchange, called American Artists in India. In 1970 and 1971 we sent nine artists to India for one month each to travel, study, teach or work on their own or on collaborative projects with Indian artists, as they chose. The artists documented their stay through drawings, photographs sound recordings or film. Artists who participated in the project were choreographers Trisha Brown, Steve Paxton, and Yvonne Rainer: composers Lowell Cross, Terry Riley, and LaMonte Young; and visual artists Jared Bark, Jeffrey Lew, Kate Redi[c]ker, and Marian Zazeela. In this photograph, Bark, with his hand on his head, talks with students at the National Institute of Design in Ahmedabad, with whom he worked.

554.name: The John D. Rockefeller III Fund

63.title: Children and Communication_2003_Klüver on the project
63.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
63.text: For the project Children and Communication, we linked one uptown and one downtown space in Manhattan with 14 dedicated telephone lines. The terminal equipment on these lines included facsimile machines, electro-writers, telex machines and telephones. Robert Whitman designed environments where the children could freely access all the equipment. For four months, in 1971 more than 500 children visited the two locations. They enthusiastically typed or hand-wrote messages, sent pictures and talked to children at the other location, children from other areas of the city they would not normally meet.

570.name: We Care, a community group in Harlem

64.title: Telex: Q&A_2003_Klüver on the project
64.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
64.text:
E.A.T. developed an international communications project called Utopia: Q&A, as a contribution to Pontus Hultén's exhibition on the Paris Commune, "Utopia and Visions: 1871-1981." We linked four public spaces by telex: Automation House in New York, Moderna Museet in Stockholm, the National Institute of Design in Ahmedabad, India, and a Xerox exhibition space at the Sony building in Tokyo. Visitors were invited to ask people in other countries questions about 1981, ten years into the future. The questions from each site were sent to ail other sites and anyone, expert or layman, could answer the questions about the future.
This photograph shows the large public environment at the Tokyo telex site organized by Fujiko Nakaya (center), Hakudo Kobayashi (left), and Yuji Morioka (riqht), where people could come and read the telexes from ail over the world and then send their own questions or answers, and have their pictures taken for the project poster, which she printed at the end of the exhibition.

472.name: The American Foundation for Automation and Employment

65.title: Island Eye Island Ear_2003_Klüver on the project
65.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
65.text: David Tudor proposed a collaborative concert, "Island Eye Island Ear," to use sound and visual elements to reveal the nature on an island. Parabolic antennas would create sound beams of natural sounds recorded earlier by Tudor on the island for people to walk through. In 1973 we traveled to Knavelskar in the Swedish Archipelago and made this map of the plans for Tudor's antennas, Fujiko Nakaya's fog sculpture areas, Jacqueline Matisse Monnier's kites, and Margaretha Asberg's dancers.

44.name: Interactive Display System for the Plaza

555.title: Project Description of the Interactive Display System for the Plaza and Façade for Centre Pompidou
555.ref_bibliographic: Interactive display system for the plaza and façade for Centre Beaubourg, Paris. New York : Experiments in Art and Technology, February 13, 1974. [3] p.
555.text:
INTERACTIVE DISPLAY SYSTEM FOR THE PLAZA AND FACADE FOR CENTRE BEAUBOURG, PARIS

Submitted by:
Experiments in Art and Technology 
39 West 53rd Street
New York, New York 10019 
February 13, 1974

The following are three proposals for an Interactive Display System for the Plaza and Facade for Centre Beaubourg.

1. GAMES 
A number of terminals would be placed on the Plaza: terminals would be tables of the size of a normal chess board and placed at such a height that people could stand by them. By activating squares or areas on the boards with a "stylus", lights would light up on the facade. These are some of the possible games.

a. Tic-Tac-Toe - A Tic-Tac-Toe matrix would light up on the facade; as the players touch the squares on the terminal surface, crosses or circles appear within the corresponding squares on the facade. Even though Tic-Tac-Toe is a solved game, it still has wide appeal.

b. Chess - A chess game would be very complex but it might be possible to work out the system for a visual display of a game. In the 8" x 8" square display board on the facade, neon symbols would be placed corresponding to "king", "queen", "knight" etc.

c. Checkers - Played on an 8" x 8" square board, it requires only one symbol in each square (an "X" or an "0"). In addition, the display system would provide for the "king" which can move anywhere on the board and each side you have a "king".

d. Ping-Pong - A simulated game of Ping-Pong similar to those now produced on television display systems.

e. Hobo Chess - Played on an open grid of squares with "X's" and "O's", where the object is to get five in a row.

f. Simulated Horse Racing - This would be programmed from the control tower where approximately five horses would move the length of the building. Some form of control of the race could be devised. The betting information would be displayed on the top of the building.

g. A Maze - Pre-programmed mazes would light up on the facade and the player
would have a certain amount of time to work through it with a stylus.

h. Catch The Moving Light - Lights would be programmed to move across the facade. Players would attempt to "catch" the light by touching it with a stylus when it is on.

The signals triggering the lights would be low-voltage running in ducts to the corresponding areas on the light display board, where a relay in and a simple electronic circuitry would switch on the lights.
The system should be designed in such a way that games can be changed.


2. THE PLAZA
Step switches on the Plaza would be located underneath, and as people move around on the Plaza, lights would be turned on tracing their path. Again, a low-voltage system would be used to switch on and off the lights. The possibility of overriding certain areas with pre-programmed patterns of "dance" performers on the Plaza could be designed.

3. DRAWING Light sources would be evenly distributed over the facade. The same type of terminals would be used as for the games, except that the terminal boards may have as many as 200 squares. Using a stylus, people would write their names, draw figures, etc. on the facade. This could also include the possibility of programming the display on the facade.

413.name: Musée national d'art moderne / Centre de création industrielle

592.title: George Delanay and Billy Klüver at the fog control mechanism, in Billy Klüver's garden, 1981. Photo : Fujiko Nakaya
592.ref_bibliographic: George Delanay and Billy Klüver at the fog control mechanism, in Billy Klüver's garden in Berkeley Heights, New Jersey, in preparation for the performance of Opal Loop at Brooklyn Academy Music, 1981. Photo : Fujiko Nakaya

25.title: Klüver on the design and production of Opal Loop in 1980
25.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
25.text: In 1980 Trisha Brown asked Fujiko Nakaya to make a set for a new dance, Opal Loop. Fujiko designed a system for making a stage of fog for the dance, the volume and movement of the fog were controlled by turning sets of nozzles off and on to create convection currents. [...]  We built a replica of the Brooklyn stage in my backyard and tested the fog system before moving into the theater. Since the dancers could not dance on a wet marley floor, we rented a large gas-driven heat blower, used in football stadium dugouts, and put it underneath the stage to raise the temperature of the floor so the fog droplets evaporated immediately, keeping the floor dry.

26.title: Klüver on the performance of Opal Loop
26.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
26.text: The dance was first performed in an old DC power station on Crosby Street in Manhattan. Later Trisha included Opal Loop in her program at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. [...] In this photo, Trisha Brown, far left, and her dancers perform Opal Loop.

591.title: Billy Klüver walks in front of the full size model of the stage at Brooklyn Academy Music built in his garden, 1981. Photo: Julie Martin
591.ref_bibliographic: Billy Klüver walks in front of the full size model of the stage at Brooklyn Academy Music built in his garden, 1981. Photo: Julie Martin

24.title: Klüver on the design and production of Astral Convertible in 1989
24.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
24.text: In 1989 Trisha Brown asked Bob Rauschenberg for a set for her dance Astral Convertible, to be performed in an outdoor space. Rauschenberg and I discussed the project, and I brought engineer Per Biorn into the collaboration. We designed and Biorn built open towers on wheels in which battery-powered motorcycle headlights on the towers face photocells on other towers so that the lights, and sound from tape recorders also located on the towers, are turned off and on as the dancers move among the towers.

22.title: Klüver on the design and production of Friends and Neighbors
22.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
22.text: Artists continue to approach E.A.T. for technical assistance. One of the most recent matchings we made was for Irina Nakhova, a Russian artist who works in New York. Nakhova wanted sculptures that reacted to the presence of viewers. I put her in touch with Per Biorn, who designed and built circuits in which sound was triggered by touch. They were built into the sculptures in the piece [...].

23.title: Klüver on the exhibition of Friends and Neighbors in 1994
23.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
23.text: [Circuits in which sound was triggered by touch] were built into the sculptures in the piece in this photograph, Friends and Neighbors, shown first at Hartford College for Women, then in Denmark in 1994, and later at the Cranbrook Museum of Art in Michigan. Nakhova dressed clothes dummies with old thrift store overcoats on which she had painted images of classical sculptures. When viewers approached and touched the coats, the sculptures sounded off with pre-recorded loud cries or insulting or angry comments. Nakhova has collaborated with other engineers on sculptures that inflate and change shape when viewers come close to them.

21.title: Klüver on the conception and production of the 9 Evenings Film Preservation
21.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
21.text: In 1996 E.A.T. began a film restoration and presentation project, using archival 16 mm film and reel-to-reel tape recordings that I had arranged to be shot and recorded during the 9 Evenings. The material was transferred to video. Swedish filmmaker Barbro Schultz Lundestam is editing the material to present each artists' original work as fully as possible. The videos will also include a documentary section of still photographs, artists' notes, and interviews with artists and engineers. The photograph above was taken from the screen of a television monitor during the editing of Öyvind Fahlström's work. Kisses Sweeter Than Wine, and shows characters Fahlström called 'Chinese Sparrows' swinging from long swings attached to the ceiling of the Armory.

40.title: E.A.T. Publications_2003_Klüver_Editing & Publishing
40.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
40.text: In January 1967 we began to publish a newsletter that reported on our efforts to structure E.A.T. and on the activities we were organizing to bring artists and engineers together. A year later, we split it into two publications: E.A. T. Operations and Information providing practical news about resources and procedures for member engineers and artists, and TECHNE, a newspaper with articles on collaborations and projects between artists and engineers using the new technology.

40.title: E.A.T. Publications_2003_Klüver_Editing & Publishing
40.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
