phases.description: Dates uncorrect (a little bit before and after)

441.title: Description of of Studies in Perception I, II and III
441.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
441.text:
49. HARMON
A 35MM TRANSPARENCY OF A PHOTO IS SCANNED BY A FLYING-SPOT SCANNER, AND THE RESULTANT ELECTRICAL SIGNALS ARE CONVERTED INTO NUMERICAL REPRESENTATION ON MAGNETIC TAPE.

THE FIRST STEP TAKEN BY THE COMPUTER IS TO FRAGMENT THE PICTURE INTO ROWS AND FRAGMENTS PER ROW, AND THE AVERAGE BRIGHTNESS LEVEL OF EACH FRAGMENT IS COMPUTED. THE BRIGHTNESS LEVELS ARE ENCODED, AND THE PICTURE IS NOW REPRESENTED BY NUMBERS, EACH OF WHICH REPRESENTS A SMALL AREA HAVING ONE POSSIBLE BRIGHTNESS VALUE.

INSTEAD OF RANDOMLY SPRINKLING BLACK DOTS IN THE PROPORTION CALLED FOR BY ANY GIVEN BRIGHTNESS LEVEL, THE DOTS ARE ORGANIZED INTO MICROPATTERNS (E.G. A CAT, AN UMBRELLA) WHICH CAN BE SEEN AT CLOSE RANGE. FOR EACH BRIGHTNESS LEVEL, THE COMPUTER MAKES A RANDOM CHOICE AMONG THE PREDETERMINED SET OF MICROPATTERNS WHICH FITS THAT LEVEL. THE PICTURE IS PRODUCED ON FRAMES OF MICROFILM BY A MICROFILM PRINTER AND THEN PHOTOGRAPHED.

140.title: Catalogue Entry of Studies in Perception I, II and III
140.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
140.text: 49. LEON D. HARMON AMERICAN, BORN 1922. KENNETH C. KNOWLTON AMERICAN, BORN 1930.; COMPUTER PROGRAM RESEARCH, BELL TELEPHONE LABORATORIES. STUDIES IN PERCEPTION I, II, AND III 1967. COMPUTER PROCESSED PHOTOGRAPHIC PRINTS; 2 1/2" X 2' X 3' CATEGORY: A.3

art: electronically, photographically or holographically generated images

270.title: Lindgren on the Fog and Light Frame
270.ref_bibliographic: Nilo Lindgren, "Into Collaboration" in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin, and Barbara Rose (eds). Pavilion. New York: E.P. Dutton, 1972, pp. 3-59.
270.text:
The idea of the Fog to shroud the dome was discussed for some time. No one knew whether or not it was actually possible to make a fog, but the idea persisted and survived. Once the fog idea emerged, it immediately suggested two other ideas to Myers, both having to do with the interaction of light and fog. One was for the four towers with lights, the tallest being a hundred feet, and the others grading down at fifteen-foot levels-eighty-five feet, seventy feet, and fifty-five feet-so that the lights set at right angles formed a tilted square. This frame of light was to surround the Pavilion and shine through the Fog; from a distance, a visitor would see a skewed rectangle, and as he approached he would see it as a square framing the Pavilion. As he walked under it "he would feel he had entered something, sort of a fourth-dimensional fence or gate." Myers' other idea was for the Suntrak sculpture, which was to track the sun continually and throw a reflection of it into the Fog during the day. 
When the Fog was proposed, Pearce realized it made sense because it would be seen from across the fair grounds. If the Pavilion had been crowded down among many of the others, the Fog "would have been meaningless." Likewise, he saw the light frame, forming a slanted square of light framing the outside of the Pavilion, as a special kind of sculptural announcement. Down in the bowl, crowded in, it would have been "an interesting piece of sculpture, but a waste of money."

279.title: Nilo Lindgren on the design and production of the Suntrack
279.ref_bibliographic: Nilo Lindgren, "Into Collaboration" in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin, and Barbara Rose (eds). Pavilion. New York: E.P. Dutton, 1972, pp. 3-59.
279.text: For his other light sculpture, Myers consulted with Robert Wilson of Bell Laboratories at Holmdel, New Jersey, who had designed a sun-tracking device which operated in the microwave region. For mechanical design and realization of the sculpture, he turned to an East Coast inventor and engineer, Niels Young of Cambridge, Massachusetts, who had won second prize in E.A.T.'s contest the year before for a technological-artistic collaboration. "Technologically," Young declared, "there is no significant problem involved. It's just a matter of making the structural base strong enough to withstand high winds." Myers needed to find a shape for his sculpture that Young could properly design in engineering terms. The two thrashed over many shapes and forms together and argued over the need for one or two mirrors. They spent one whole day making small models until both were satisfied. Although Young had reservations about the seriousness of the sculpture project Myers' enthusiasm, he says, won him over.

57.name: Lowell Cross and Nora Cross Residence in India

62.title: Klüver on the American Artists in India
62.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
62.text: With support from Porter MacCray of the JDR III Fund, E.A.T. organized	a project for open-ended cultural exchange, called American Artists in India. In 1970 and 1971 we sent nine artists to India for one month each to travel, study, teach or work on their own or on collaborative projects with Indian artists, as they chose. The artists documented their stay through drawings, photographs sound recordings or film. Artists who participated in the project were choreographers Trisha Brown, Steve Paxton, and Yvonne Rainer: composers Lowell Cross, Terry Riley, and LaMonte Young; and visual artists Jared Bark, Jeffrey Lew, Kate Redi[c]ker, and Marian Zazeela. In this photograph, Bark, with his hand on his head, talks with students at the National Institute of Design in Ahmedabad, with whom he worked.

560.title: Communique of Projects Outside Art

561.title: Poster of Projects Outside Art
561.ref_bibliographic: Projects outside art. New York : Experiments in Art and Technology, [1969]. N. p.

562.title: Press release of Projects Outside Art
562.ref_bibliographic: Projects outside art : an exhibition of realizable projects in the environment. New York : Experiments in Art and Technology, [March 15, 1970]. [1] p.

563.title: Selection of Four Areas (Projects Outside Art)
563.ref_bibliographic: Projects outside art : an exhibition of realizable projects in the environment. New York : Experiments in Art and Technology, [March 15, 1970]. [1] p.
563.text:
Projects Outside Art

The exhibition will be divided into four areas:

I. "Roof" garden
To construct gardens in city environments at minimum cost using new methods such as hydroponics.

II. Three complete display terminals with access to existing visual programs at Bell Telephone Laboratories, General Electric, M.I.T.

III.Recreation
Innovative approaches to recreation within specific environments.

IV. Children and Communication
Techniques for establishing communication with children in learning, play or other situation.

June 12, 1970

564.title: Letter to Roger Ferragallo
564.ref_bibliographic: Appendix on the roof garden project. New York : Experiments in Art and Technology, [July 1970]. [1] p. Memorandum accompanying the letter entitled «Letter to Roger Ferragallo».
564.text:
Roger Ferragallo,							                                                             — July 1, 1970 
Tell Project Director
Larey College
1001 Third Avenue
Oakland, California

Dear Mr. Ferragallo:

A selection committee made up of Dr. William Lambert, Professor of Psychology, Sir George Williams University, Montreal; John W. Pan, Supervisor of Digital Techniques and Systems Studies, Bell Telephone Laboratories, Holmdel, New Jersey; and Nicholas Quennell, Architect, in conjunction with E.A.T. staff, have chosen four areas in which the exhibition, PROJECTS OUTSIDE ART, will concentrate.

1. A Vegetable Roof Garden to be planted on top of Automation House. This project will be undertaken in collaboration with the Environmental Research Laboratory in Tuscon, Arizona. Peter Poole will be coordinating the Garden project.

2. A display related to the Garden on the roof demonstrating how plants grow and more precisely, how plants can be made to grow in a city environment. We also plan to translate by electronic means the growth of the plants on the roof as part of the exhibit.

3. Recreation and Play: this project is still in the planning stage and will be handled by E.A.T./Los Angeles. Ardison Phillips will be coordinator.

4. Children and Communication is a project which will set up an environment where children will be able to interact with various kinds of communication equipment. Robert Whitman will be coordinator.

You are invited to participate in any one of the above projects. If you are interested, please contact us as soon as possible and let us know how much time you would be able to devote and what the nature of your contribution might be.

We are planning to publish all the proposals in full or in part submitted for PROJECTS OUTSIDE ART independent of and with no reference to the exhibition. If you wish your proposal to be included, sign the enclosed release form and return it to me.

We look forward to hearing from you. 

Sincerely,

Jacquelyn D. Serwer Exhibition Coordinator

472.name: The American Foundation for Automation and Employment

553.title: Communique of E.A.T. on the Esthetics Symposium
553.ref_bibliographic: Esthetics : a symposium sponsored by E.A.T.. New York : Experiments in Art and Technology, June 10, 1970. [1] p. Communique.
553.text:
ESTHETICS
A Symposium Sponsored by E.A.T.
Automation House
October 31, 1970 10:00 A.M.-9:00 P.M.

As the commitment to the conscious development of the environment increases, there is a greater need for experimental open-ended projects to develop procedures and prototypes for action in this area. These projects require collaboration among individuals from different professions and institutions.

Through our involvement in such projects, we have become increasingly aware of the importance of esthetics in these situations. Many of the important decisions that have to be made are esthetic decisions. Many of the most disruptive and difficult conflicts that arise in these open-ended, multi-disciplinary working situations can be traced to personal or professional esthetic biases. These esthetic commitments are usually hidden, unacknowledged or disguised as something else (economic, political, technical, cultural, psychological, etc.)

We would like the symposium to focus on these problems. The purpose of the symposium is to establish the validity of making esthetic decisions within these situations; to articulate the particular esthetic commitments of different professions; and to explore means for arriving at esthetic decisions and resolving esthetic conflicts (procedures, organizational forms, etc.).

571.title: Loewen on the Esthetics Symposium
571.ref_bibliographic: Loewen, Norma. “Experiments in Art and Technology: A Descriptive History of the Organization”. New York University, 1975.
571.text:
In plans developed by June 1970, the symposium was to focus on problems created by decisions in realizing collaborative, experimental projects that could be traced to the aesthetic commitments of individuals and institutions.
	At this time, the symposium was scheduled for October 31, 1970, as an all-day event with participation by about six leaders in the arts, social sciences, and sciences. Among the symposium participants suggested or invited were Chester Bowles, John Cage, Noam Chomsky, Kenneth Clark, Richard Feynmann, Harold Howe, Lane Kirkland, Jack Masey, Alva Myrdahl, Ernest Rothkopf, Vikram Sarabhai, Meyer Schapiro, Kenzo Tange, George Wald, Alvin Weinberg, and Jerome Wiesner.
	Persons interested in these problems and a general, paying audience would be invited to cone. Papers prepared by the participants would be distributed before the symposium to co-participants and people planning to come. Proceedings would be taped, published, and made available for distribution to schools and libraries.
	The symposium and conference was variously budgeted from $12,635 to $25,000. The latter included the publication and distribution of proceedings. Funds were requested from the National Science Foundation in January 1970 and the New York State Council on the Arts in July 1970. The funds were not granted and the symposium did not take place.

551.title: Grant Application for Esthetic Symposium
551.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Garden Party », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 157-162
551.text:
PROJECTS OUTSIDE ART

ESTHETICS SYMPOSIUM

In October of this year, Experiments in Art and Technology will hold an exhibition of realizable projects in the environment called PROJECTS OUTSIDE ART. The exhibition will be held at Automation House, 49 East 68th Street, New York City. The projects presented in the exhibition will be the result of collaboration among artists, engineers, scientists and other professionals organized into teams.
Announcements asking for project proposals were sent to art schools, engineering schools and research laboratories as well as our members. (See attached announcement). On the basis of 116 proposals received, four subject areas were chosen: a roof vegetable greenhouse (to be carried out in collaboration with Environment Research Lab, University of Arizona); visual display of how to create city agriculture; children and communication; recreation and play (to be carried out by E.A.T./L.A.).
In conjunction with the exhibition we are planning to hold on October 31 an all day symposium, "Esthetics". Through our involvement in experimental, collaborative situations, we have become increasingly aware of the significance of esthetics in these situations. Many of the important decisions that have to be made are esthetic decisions. Many of the most disruptive and difficult conflicts that arise in these open-ended, multidisciplinary working situations can be traced to personal or professional esthetic biases. These esthetic commitments are usually hidden, unacknowledged or disguised as something else (economic, political, technical, cultural, psychological, etc.).

	The symposium will focus on these problems. The purpose of the symposium will be:

	To establish the validity of making esthetic decisions within these situations.

	To articulate the particular esthetic commitments of different professions.

	To explore means for arriving at esthetic decisions and resolving esthetic conflicts 	(procedures, organizational forms, etc.)

We will invite the following people to participate in the Symposium: Chester Bowles, John Cage, Noam Chomsky, Kenneth Clark, Lane Kirkland, Alva Myrdahl, Ernest Rothkopf, Vikram Sarabhai, Meyer Shapiro, Kenzo Tange, and Jerome Weisner. In addition, there will be a group of invited guests, individuals who are particularly interested in these questions, [page 2] as well as a general audience. We will ask the participants to prepare an article or statement to be distributed before- hand to the co-participants and to the people planning to attend the Symposium. The proceedings of the Symposium will be published.

We have received a grant of $25,000 from the National Endowment for the Arts for the exhibition.

Submitted to: New York State Council on the Arts
July 15, 1970

454.name: New York State Council on the Arts

568.title: Loewen on the First Project Description of Recreation and Play
568.ref_bibliographic: Loewen, Norma. “Experiments in Art and Technology: A Descriptive History of the Organization”. New York University, 1975.
568.text:
The initial group for "Recreation and Play" in Los Angeles included Jim Anderson, John Braun, Douglas Campbell, John Forkner, Jim Gilbert, Helen Goodwin, Newton Harrison, Allan Kaprow, and Ardison Phillips. It was brought to E.A.T.'s attention that the members of the group had not necessarily dealt with the subject of recreation and play in their individual proposals and that they did not share a common background, concern, or personal affinity.

	In the summer of 1970, the group was considering kinds of recreational activities that existed or could happen within a mobile cubic mile and ways to demonstrate these.(1)
	E.A.T. had envisioned looking at department stores, shopping centers, markets, and county fairs to find the attributes of pure recreation not having status, health, or other values attached as in traditional recreational facilities. As a basis for understanding the project, Robert Whitman, who was personally committed to "Projects Outside Art," saw the essential properties of pure recreation to be accessibility, freedom to participate in a socially approved activity on a personal basis for oneself, and "some transcendent quality, magic, mystery, fantasy dreams,"
	It seems to me something very interesting could come about if the President of Macy's would announce that Macy's primary business is recreation, not selling things.(2)

(1) Their project was briefly described in E.A.T. L.A.: Survey (Los Angeles), No. 5, Summer 1970, p. 3
(2) Robert Whitman's telex to John Forkner and letter to the Los Angeles group, September 25, 1970.

569.title: Loewen on the Second Project Description of Recreation and Play
569.ref_bibliographic: Loewen, Norma. “Experiments in Art and Technology: A Descriptive History of the Organization”. New York University, 1975.
569.text:
By November 1970, the Los Angeles group had proposed a second project—the "development of a transition orientation for the city dweller in Los Angeles so that he can fully experience the recreational effects of the countryside."(1) The group apparently fell apart.

(1) Recreation and Play, proposal submitted by E.A.T. Los Angeles to E.A.T. in New York, November 1, 1970.

570.title: Loewen on the Third Project Description of Recreation and Play
570.ref_bibliographic: Loewen, Norma. “Experiments in Art and Technology: A Descriptive History of the Organization”. New York University, 1975.
570.text:
By April 1971, a third project was proposed by another group in Los Angeles including John Casbarian, Leonard Cottrell, Craig Hodgetts, and Stephen West, all of the California Institute of the Arts, School of Design, and Ardison Phillips and Ruth Baker of E.A.T. Los Angeles. Evidently, none had initially submitted individual proposals for "Projects Outside Art."
	For the exhibition, now planned to open in May 1971, the group proposed "Contact Sports: Technology as a Medium for Social Exchange":

	an experimental environment in which the visitor is both creator and object of a series of video and photocopied images. The visitors interact with themselves and not the technology itself. (1)

	Visitors would move through three "video space fields" identified by specified colors and be able to coordinate their movements by watching television monitors. The images created would be projected on a screen after a three-minute delay. A poster machine would allow visitors to push a button and receive a poster of the same images after a five-minute delay.
	The necessary equipment for the project included thirty-eight color video monitors, three color video cameras and projectors, and a color copier. The direct interconnections between the video and print equipment were seen as a demonstration of a marriage between the television and printing industries. Manufacturers in both fields would need to loan some of the equipment which was considered expensive for purchase or rental. The group considered other items basic to set up a permanent video center, at Automation House.
	E.A.T. in New York found the group's plans too grandiose on the whole and particularly too expensive to be realized for "Projects Outside Art." Aesthetically, the plans also seemed outside the boundary conditions E.A.T. had set up. The project remained unrealized for the exhibition, as did the "Projects Outside Art" exhibition itself.

(1) Proposal submitted by the group to E.A.T, in New York, n.d.

566.title: Short Description of Recreation in E.A.T./L.A. survey. No 5 (Summer 1970)
566.ref_bibliographic: E.A.T./L.A. survey. No. 5 (Summer 1970). Hollywood : Experiments in Art and Technology, Los Angeles, 1970. 14 p.
566.text: Recreation: The Los Angeles collaboration includes Jim Anderson, John Braun, Doug Campbell, John Forkner, Jim Gilbert, Helen Goodwin, Newton Harrison, Allan Kaprow, and Ardison Phillips. This group is working on the basic concept of the kinds of recreation which exist within a cubic mile and the methods and means by which these recreation can be demonstrated, utilizing the state-of-the-art technology.

567.title: Project Description of Recreation and Play
567.ref_bibliographic: Recreation and play. Hollywood : Experiments in Art and Technology, Los Angeles, November 1, 1970. [4] p.
567.text:
RECREATION AND PLAY

Submitted by:
Experiments in Art and Technology 16 80 North Vine Street Hollywood, California 90028
November 1, 1970

Every rural and wilderness area relates to every urban area as a recreational reservoir. In the Los Angeles area such a reservoir is the Owens Valley.

The orientation necessary for urban dwellers to make the transition from urban to rural activity from the point of view of recreational potential is poorly understood. When the urban dweller goes to rural recreation areas, he often takes with him the habits and attitudes common to his urban lifestyle which are incompatible to the wilderness. Furthermore, when the urban dweller returns to the city, he often fails to see relationships or analogies between the two experiences or ways of life.

The development of a transition orientation for the city dweller in Los Angeles so that he can fully experience the recreational effects of the countryside is the goal of this project. The intent of this proposal is to describe the possibilities for informing and orienting an urban population about the utilization of rural recreation.

Contrary to the facility-bound concept of professional recreation wherein adult "recreators" supervise the interaction of others, in this project, recreators acting also as investigators, will be roving co-participants, confining themselves to a limited geographic neighborhood.

In this case, Owens Valley, a 20 mile radius of Bishop, California has been selected, and an initial probe will survey the area shown on the accompanying map for its natural benefits, ecological history and recreational potential. A study has already been made of its wind, water and solar conditions (Ralph Knowles, Cultural Heritage Grant). Knowles'study will be helpful, but a complete and intense survey will begin November 6 to compile bibliographic information in the form of charts, maps, graphs, video tapes, booklets, infrared photographs and other appropriate media. The investigation will be divided between Owens Valley and Los Angeles.

There will be six roving recreator-leaders plus one administrator who will define what information is to be gathered, i.e. visuals, sounds, statistics, questions and answers. In essence these roving recreators will serve as the nucleus of this study. Information gathering will be done in the same manner as a successful experiment conducted in Santa Barbara:

	In the Santa Barbara experience, we went into the community unfamiliar with its people or places. We chose to "discover" the recreational potential by befriending three ten-year-old boys. We exchanged tools with them for the day (our tape-recorders for their innertubes) and this immediately made these tools recreactional. We proceeded to explore, guide, and be guided, to follow the natural patterns suggested by those who live there.

A preliminary stage of the project will be to survey adults in a geographic location in Los Angeles predominantly inhabited by persons under thirty years of age. These individuals will be asked about their recreational habits within their urban environment. This information will then be coordinated with ideas to develop Owens Valley as a rural recreational facility for this type of urban dweller.

The information will be compiled in three forms:

	Visual: film, cassette, videotape

	Sound: real sounds of Owens Valley, short tape conversations and interviews

	Graphic interpretation: including booklet to describe method by which urban dwellers can orient themselves to rural recreation.

The suggested display in Automation House would include a brief history of the project, including, perhaps, the initial propos ls submitted and subsequent ideas and the final project. Photographs, soundtapes, and written material; documentation of the initial experience at Santa Barbara with photos, movies, and sound tapes; an orientation pamphlet to Owens Valley including density maps, infrared photography, history, photographs, along with the showing of video tapes of selected geographical locations in Owens Valley and Los Angeles.

This information that is compiled can be distributed in three ways :

	Home : an individual in his own environment would be advised of recreational locations and necessary facilities needed for transition.

	Mobil campers: information can be played on car cassettes en route to the recreational areas.

	Audio-visual centers: demonstrations of potential recreation uses and providing orientation for arriving recreationers.

The roving recreators include:

	Jim Anderson, Director of Social and Cultural Affairs, L.A. County Department of Parks and Recreation

	John Braun, Professor of Fine Arts, University of Southern California

	Doug Campbell, Architect, University of California, Berkeley

	John Forkner, Optics Engineer, Philco-Ford 

	Jim Gilbert, Architect

	Ardison Phillips, Administrator-E.A.T. 

	Michael Plesset, Jet Propulsion Laboratory

Initial contacts have been made with chemists, civil engineers and closed space systems scientists.

phases.description: Third Conception: 'Contact Sports: Technology as a Medium for Social Exchange'

594.title: Sketch of two Greenhouses
594.ref_bibliographic: City agriculture. New York : Experiments in Art and Technology, September 3, 1970. [4] p.

595.title: Project Description of City Agriculture
595.ref_bibliographic: City agriculture. New York : Experiments in Art and Technology, September 3, 1970. [4] p.
595.text:
CITY AGRICULTURE

Experiments in Art and Technology 235 Park Avenue South 
New York, New York 10003
September 3, 1970

EXPERIMENTAL PROJECT IN CITY AGRICULTURE

This is a proposal to apply existing technology and expertise to create closed-environment systems that would make it feasible to undertake city agriculture on a wide scale. The project will include a prototype rooftop vegetable garden and a manual to instruct other groups in methods of constructing and maintaining similar gardens.

The garden will be built and maintained by Experiments in Art and Technology in collaboration with the Environmental Research Laboratory of the university of Arizona. Under a grant from The Rockefeller Foundation, the Environmental Research Laboratory has developed a pilot project in which an integrated closed-environment system for power-water-food production can yield fresh vegetables in arid coastline areas. Research facilities are operated in Tuscon and Puerto Peñasco, Mexico. The Environmental Research Laboratory will make its horticultural and technical experience and resources available to the project.

Seedlings will be grown in the nurseries of the Department of Agricultural Engineering at Rutgers University; and the New York Horticultural Society will act in an advisory capacity, and publicize the project through their channels.

The experimental garden will consist of two greenhouses whose walls are double-skin inflated plastic, as indicated in the enclosed sketch. The circular dome structure will be a self-contained unit; the half-cylinder structure can be joined to identical modules to make longer greenhouses. These greenhouses will be light enough to comply with the usual roof weight regulation for New York City, and will be mounted on wheels so that they can be moved about the roof to take advantage of changing sunlight conditions.

Each greenhouse will have a climate control system which will filter and regulate the temperature and flow of air. For this project two different types of climates will be simulated. The greenhouse with the cooler climate will grow tomatoes, lettuce and radishes; the other will have aubergine, cucumber and melon. The feeding system will be an adaptation of the system developed by the Environmental Research Laboratory for growing plants in the desert; nutrients in solution will be periodically fed into the soil medium., a mixture of vermiculite and peat moss.

It is estimated that each greenhouse will provide enough vegetables for a family of four. In another measure of output from such a system, it was calculated that if a rooftop garden were devoted exclusively to tomatoes, it could produce one tomato per person per day for all the inhabitants of the building.

This experimental garden is intended to serve as a prototype for city agriculture which can be repeated elsewhere in the city. The structures are being designed to be easily mass-produced, and the design is suitable for installation on any roof in New York City. The climate control and nutrient feeding systems can be adjusted to simulate a variety of climatic regimes in which corresponding groups of plants can be grown. Thus, the. system can be productive under a wide variety of conditions, the only limiting factor being the amount of sunlight available.

During the time the garden is operating on the roof of Automation House, we will encourage other groups to initiate their own gardens and provide them with the technical assistance they may need.

Oliver Selfridge of Massachusetts Institute of Technology will compile a manual which will describe the construction, maintenance and horticultural methods used in the experimental garden and prescribe means for the general application of these techniques for city agriculture. Specific topics will include: assessing the suitability of your location for a rooftop garden and varieties of possible climatic and nutrient combinations to grow a wide variety of fruits and vegetables.

596.title: Report by Norma Loewen on A Vegatable Roof Garden
596.ref_bibliographic: Loewen, Norma. “Experiments in Art and Technology: A Descriptive History of the Organization”. New York University, 1975.
596.text:
A Vegetable Roof Garden

	The purpose of the roof garden project, also called a demonstration project in city agriculture, was:
	To apply existing technology and expertise to create closed- environment systems that would make it feasible to undertake city agriculture on a wide scale. (1)
	The project was initiated by E.A.T. with the Environmental Research Laboratory (ERL), a unit of the Institute of Atmospheric Physics, University of Arizona. EEL, with research facilities in Tucson, Arizona, and Puerto Peñasco, Sonora, Mexico, had been conducting experiments with greenhouses and other means to economically provide power-water-food systems for desert areas since the early 1960s.
	Those involved in the project through ERL were Carl N. Hodges, director of ERL; Merle H. Jensen, horticultural consultant; Chip Lockwood, business and funding consultant; Mahmoud M. Shabandar, architectural consultant; and David H. Pollock, Shabandar's architectural associate. Neither ERL nor the individuals involved appeared to have earlier submitted proposals for "Projects Outside Art."
	Preliminary work on the project was begun about July 1970, following Peter Poole's meeting with ERL at their research facilities. Upon discussing the boundaries of the project, it was agreed that E.A.T. would collect information about the existing conditions, materials, equipment, and funding sources. ERL would prepare a set of preliminary design drawings to define the architectural and engineering scope of the work and to permit cost estimates from manufacturers.
	E.A.T.'s initial idea for a project in hydroponics, as the project was announced by E.A.T. Los Angeles, (2) was soon preempted by practical considerations. Having an entire roof cover supported by the walls of the building rather than the roof was pursued until about September 1970, when it was decided to have smaller, environmentally controlled units because of fire regulations in New York. The units were to be designed for easy mass production and installation on any roof in New York City.
	As developed in the drawings prepared by Mahmoud Shabandar and David Pollock, two lightweight greenhouses would be made of metal skeletons on wheels covered with double-skin inflated plastic. One would be a self-contained circular dome structure and one a half-cylinder dome that might be joined to identical units for making longer greenhouses. Each would simulate a different climate : the one having lettuce, tomatoes, and radishes, the other having aubergine, cucumber, and melon.
	Environmental control units, using mechanical and electrical systems, would be highly sensitive and flexible to regulate the temperature and flow of air. The air would be filtered, heated, cooled, and circulated. Nutrients in solution would periodically be fed into the soil. Ideally, a variety of fruits, vegetables, herbs, or flowers could thus be grown in the same units at different times, in many sites, and all year. "The only limiting factor" was considered to be the amount of available sunlight. (3)
	After evaluating the preliminary design, E.A.T. planned to select and invite additional persons, including artists, to participate in plans for the exhibition at Automation House. They apparently would help determine the final selection and layout of plants. If wanting to assure the optimum use of the units and growth of plants, their choices would need to be based on recommendations, if not necessities, of the established parameters and conditions.
	The first documented suggestion as to how artists might participate could be inferred from Mahmoud Shabandar's suggestion for audio and visual effects, e.g., the plastic enclosures might be colored, painted, or inflated with colored gases. (4)
	In plans as of September 1970, the College of Architecture at Rutgers State university, in cooperation with Merle Jensen, was to grow seedlings in the nurseries of the university's Department of Horticulture and Forestry. The university's Department of Agricultural Engineering was to assist in constructing and installing equipment in the greenhouses. The New York Horticultural Society was to function as an advisor and publicize the project through their channels. Oliver Selfridge at MIT was to compile a manual describing various aspects of the project for others interested in initiating and developing their own rooftop gardens.
	In plans as of December 1970, EEL would be completely responsible for the architectural, technical, and horticultural design aspects of the greenhouses. They would also assume fund raising for these activities except for the architects' expenses and fees. E.A.T. and the American Foundation on Automation and Employment would be jointly responsible to raise funds covering the architects' fees and expenses and to generally administer the project.
	Arrangements would be made to have the project promoted in New York by the mayor's office, city agencies, television programs, and New York magazine. During the time of the garden's operation atop Automation House, groups would be encouraged to initiate their own gardens and given technical assistance through E.A.T. Annual New York City roof garden competitions might be held. The gardens were to be a source of recreation, instruction, and achievement.
	The experience gained from the prototype might also be applicable to greenhouses for commercial, educational, and other functions on the roofs of prisons, schools, hospitals, office buildings, and apartment houses. Among the possibilities E.A.T. considered were greenhouses in Chinatown, to grow vegetables not cultivated in New York; Rockefeller Plaza, to use the various levels of roofs and terraces as suggested by Julius Haber of RCA; and Westbeth, to provide artists in the housing complex with a fresh vegetable garden.
	As another "spin-off," E.A.T.'s term used in drafting general policy statements for projects, the model greenhouses would be suited for continuing experiments. Agencies concerned with the environment might sample and analyze pollutants in the air for research relating air pollution to plant growth and yield, which was of interest to the United States Department of Agriculture.(5) Plants tolerant of pollutants and low light levels might be identified, thereby further promoting possibilities for less elaborate control systems or for fresh air gardens. The project would hopefully stimulate an extensive practice of agriculture in the city.
	Basic research and design for the greenhouse units, more or less completed by about the end of January 1971, had taken longer than initally scheduled for exhibition purposes and seemed to cost more than was desired. The actual cost of having the system built and installed was estimated close to $30,000, which was called "extremely high" in comparison to the square feet of growing area.(6)
	Among the potential sponsors contacted by E.A.T. between September 1970 and April 1971 were Mrs. Albert Lasker of the Richmond Foundation, Alice M. Kaplan of the J. M. Kaplan Fund, Stewart R. Mott of the Philanthropy Office, Frederick L. Bissinger of the Allied Chemical Foundation, and others including the New York Botanical Garden, W. Atlee Burpee Company, Trane Company, and G. T. Schjeldahl Company.
	Earlier in the project, Allied Chemical had offered to supply Aclar as a covering material. material. Generally, however, attempts to acquire funds or donations of materials and equipment had been unsuccessful both  by E.A.T. and ERL. 
	ERL's only positive result in fund raising had been through their association with Aqua-Chem Corporation, which had a small subsidiary firm called Environmental Farms in Tucson. Aqua-Chem had developed an experimental, controlled environmental unit called "Envirodome," a packaged structure for use throughout the world, which heretofore had been unknown to E.A.T. It was not clear whether the units were only on paper, whether one or more had been constructed to date, or whether they were already being mass-produced. In any event, Aqua-Chem offered to sell E.A.T. a unit for $6,000, which ERL considered reasonable.
	With assistance for installation of the unit at Automation House from the Coca-Cola Company, the parent company of Aqua-Chem, ERL suggested they might experiment with high carbon dioxide concentration and low light levels to grow bib lettuce, a specialty crop fetching a premium price.
	Billy Klüver and Julie Martin recall that the greenhouse alternative came suddenly and unexpectedly, that purchase of the unit for the Automation House exhibition was approved by Theodore Kheel, that a contract was made but later canceled by Aqua-Chem, and that such units were later sold at Abercrombie and Fitch.(7)
	The plans for the project remained on paper in the form of correspondence, drawings, and proposals. The fourth project announced for "Projects Outside Art," a display relating to the garden, was not begun.


(1) "Projects Outside Art: City Agriculture," E.A.T.'s proposal/ report, September 1, 1970, p. 1
(2) E.A.T. L.A.: Survey, No.5, Summer 1970, p.3.
(3) "Projects Outside Art: City Agriculture," p.2. 
(4) Shabandar's letter to Billy Klüver, July 9, 1970.
(5) Letter from Howard E. Heggestad, Agricultural Research Service, United States Department of Agriculture, February 26, 1971, in reply to Peter Poole's letter of inquiry, February 17, 1971
(6) Carl N. Hodges' letter to Billy Klüver, April 1, 1971.
(7) Interview, New York City, September 4 and 5, 1973. Klüver's and Martin's recollections hereafter given in this chapter are from the same source.

565.title: Appendix to the Roof Garden Project
565.ref_bibliographic: Appendix on the roof garden project. New York : Experiments in Art and Technology, [July 1970]. [1] p. Memorandum accompanying the letter entitled «Letter to Roger Ferragallo».
565.text:
APPENDIX ON THE ROOF GARDEN PROJECT

We have been in contact with Carl N. Hodges and his group of architects, horticulturalists and research scientists at the Environmental Research Laboratory in Tuscon, Arizona. They have submitted a preliminary proposal to us in which the greenhouse techniques they have developed will be used to grow vegetables in a city environment.

So far we have established the following boundaries for the the project:

1. The garden should be relatively cheap, easy to plant and feasible in the city environment.

2. It should be all-season and covered by a polyethelene tent-like structure.

3. It should produce at least tomatoes, cucumbers and egg-plants. Other plants may be added as the group working on the project decides.

The major task of the Garden project team will be to build the garden.

Although we will try to have meetings before these dates, we would like the people who wish to work on the display aspects of the project to begin work around August 1. Those people who wish to work on the garden will be needed about September 1.

384.title: E.A.T. Competition Awards
384.ref_bibliographic: [Press package for “The machine as seen at the end of the mechanical age”]. New York : Experiments in Art and Technology ; New York : The Museum of Modern Art, November 11, 1968. Set of 15 elements. Press kit. Includes press releases, one postcard and one program.
384.text:
EXPERIMENTS IN ART AND TECHNOLOGY, INC. 
9 East 16 Street, New York, N. Y.

THE MUSEUM OF MODERN ART
11 West 53 Street, New York, N. Y.

The names of the American engineers who were awarded prizes in the international competition arranged by Experiments in Art and Technology in connection with The Museum of Modern Art exhibition, The Machine as Seen at the End of the Mechanical Age, were announced November 11 at a press conference-demonstration at the Museum. Purpose of the competition, launched a year ago, was to find the most inventive contribution by an engineer to a work of art produced in collaboration with an artist.
	Winners of the $3,000 first prize were Harris Hyman and Ralph Martel, who collaborated with artist Jean Dupuy to construct a sculpture of dust. Frank Turner was awarded a $1,000 second prize for his contribution to Wen-Ying Tsai's cybernetic sculpture of stainless steel rods and strobe lights; Niels 0. Young also won a second prize of $1,000 for his role in making Fakir in 3/4 Time, mechanical fountain, with his artist wife Lucy Jackson Young.
	The first prize was awarded by P. L. Siemiller, Co-chairman of the American Foundation on Automation and Employment, which donated the prize money. Mr. Siemiller is also President of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers (AFL-CIO).
	The two second prizes were donated by the McCrory Corporation and Richard Brandt, President, on behalf of the Trans-Lux Corporation.
	The prizewinning works are included in The Museum of Modern Art exhibition on view from November 27 through February 9. At the same time, all the entries in the E.A.T. competition are being shown in an exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum, Some More Beginnings, opening November 26.
	In Heart Beats Dust, first prizewinner, the essential material is red dust lying on a stretched rubber membrane enclosed in a glass-faced cube. The dust is activated by acoustic vibrations produced by the rhythm of heart beats and made visible by a light beam of high intensity. "Like many works of recent years, Heart Beats Dust manifests a new form of cooperation with nature," according to Pontus Hultén, Guest Director of The Museum of Modern Art exhibition. "A sensitive collaboration between natural forces within and outside the human body has here been achieved." Hyman and Martel received special technical advice from Charles Coster and Robert Maziarz of North American Phillips, Incorporated, and Rodney F. Kaiser of Kliegl Brothers.
	Fakir in 3/4 Time is a mechanical fountain. Its creators, Lucy Jackson Young and her husband, Niels 0. Young, engineer, point out that it is the first machine to do the Indian rope trick. Based on the same principle as that of the lariat, in which the motion of a loop of cord along its own length causes it to become rigid, the cord in Fakir in 3/4 Time, instead of being swung at the end of a tether, is gobbled in and spewed out again by means of an electric motor and sheave, at the rate of 100 miles an hour.
	The Cybernetic Sculpture, created by artist and engineer Wen-Ying Tsai, is based on the principle of the harmonic motion in a "standing wave" produced by a vibrating rod. Multiple stainless steel units, each more than nine feet high, with a 20 inch diameter at the base, are grouped together. The visual effect when in motion is continually modulated by high frequency stroboscopic lights. The lights react to sound, such as that of a voice or the clapping of hands. The sense of contact with the sculpture that the viewer obtains is due to the subtlety of the work's reaction; the response of the trembling rods seems a direct translation of his voice. "The technical solution that produces this illusionistic feat is at once so discreet and so efficient that it strikes us as perfect," Mr. Hultén says.
	The winning works were selected from more than 150 submissions from artists in nine countries. The jury consisted of five scientists and engineers who were not necessarily knowledgeable about contemporary art. The jurors were unfamiliar with the participating engineers. They were: James M. Brownlow, International Business Machines Research Laboratories; Michael D. Golder, Plastic Research and Development Center, Celanese Plastics Company; Cyril M. Harris, Professor of Electrical Engineering and Architecture, Columbia University; John W. Pan, Bell Telephone Laboratories; and William G.Rosen, Special Assistant to the Director, National Science Foundation, and Executive Secretary of the Committee on Academic Sciences and Engineering of the Federal Council for Science and Technology. 
	In making the awards for the most inventive use of new technology as it evolves through the collaboration of artist and engineer, the jurors were asked to base their judgements on these criteria: First, how inventive and imaginative is the use of technology? Second, to what extent have the engineer and artist collaborated successfully?
	In making their decision, the jurors issued the following statement:
In each of the winning entries a spectrum of technology was used with great impact on the art forms. Evident is the realization that neither the artist nor the engineer alone could have achieved the results. Interaction must have preceded innovation. Going beyond a demonstration of technical prowess or an intricate orchestration of art and technology, the engineer and artist together have created more than a well-executed realization of fantasy. The unexpected and extraordinary, which one experiences on viewing these pieces, result from inventiveness and imagination, stimulated not by the brute force of technical complexity but by probing into the workings of natural laws.

	In addition to the prizewinning engineers and the artists, others present at the conference were: Theodore W. Kheel, President of the American Foundation on Automation and Employment; Richard Brandt, President of Trans-Lux Corporation; Meshulam Ricklis, President of the McCrory Corporation; Bates Lowry, Director of The Museum of Modern Art; G. Pontus Hultén, Director of Moderna Museet in Stockholm and Guest Director of The Museum of Modern Art's exhibition; Dr. Billy Klüver, President of E.A.T.; and Robert Rauschenberg, Chairman of the Board, E.A.T.
	Representatives of labor and industry, who were invited, included Lane Kirkland, assistant to George Meany, President of the Central Labor Council (AFL-CIO); Ralph Gross, President of the Commerce and Industry Association; Edward Swayduck, President of Local One Amalgamated Lithographers of America; Seymour Schweber of Schweber Electronics; and At[h]elstan [Spilhaus], The Franklin Institute, Philadelphia.
	Experiments in Art and Technology (E.A.T.), an international organization, was established in 1967 to develop an effective collaboration between engineers and artists. [The] aim of the non-profit organization is to encourage new work which is not the preconception either the engineer or the artist but which is the result of their joint explorations.

Additional information available from Elizabeth Shaw, Director, Department of Public Information, The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53 Street, New York, N.Y. I00I9. 245-3200

421.title: Description of Heart Beats Dust
421.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
421.text:
30. DUPUY
THE DUST IS LITHOL RUBINE, A BRILLIANT RED PIGMENT OF LOW SPECIFIC GRAVITY, CHOSEN FOR ITS ABILITY TO REMAIN SUSPENDED IN AIR FOR LONG PERIODS.

THE THRUST IS ACHIEVED BY A 12-MINUTE CYCLE CONTINUOUS LOOP TAPE RECORDING THE HEARTBEATS PLAYED THROUGH A 15'' COAXIAL SPEAKER MOUNTED DIRECTLY UNDER A TIGHTLY STRETCHED RUBBER MEMBRANE ON WHICH THE PIGMENTS SITS. IN ORDER TO GET MAXIMUM BASE RESPONSE, THE TAPE IS PLAYED AT 1/2 NORMAL SPEED.

THE LIGHT SOURCE IS A 250 WATT QUARTZ ELEMENT WITH SHUTTERS AND A LENS TO GIVE INTENSE LIGHT WITH SHARP EDGES.

375.title: Hulten's Description of Heart Beats Dust
375.ref_bibliographic: Hultén, K[arl] G[unnar] Pontus. The machine as seen at the end of the mechanical age. New York : The Museum of Modern Art, 1968. 216 p.
375.text:
Jean Dupuy
French, born 1925 (artist)
Ralph Martel
American, born 1935 (engineer)
Heart Beat Dust. 1968
Dust, plywood, glass, light, electronic equipment, 
7’ high x 2’ wide x 2’ deep (including active cube, 2’ on each side)

The essential material of this sculpture is dust, enclosed in a glass-faced cube and made visible by a light beam of high intensity. The dust is activated by acoustic vibrations produced by the rhythm of heart beats. As an artist, Dupuy worked with polyethylene plastic, which by generating static electricity attracts and retains dust. While seeking a means to avoid this, he had the idea of utilizing the dust itself as a medium.
Like many works of recent years, Heart Beats Dust manifests a new form of cooperation with nature. A sensitive collaboration between natural forces within and outside the human body has here been achieved.
An earlier use of dust as an artistic medium was by Marcel Duchamp. While he was working on the Large
Glass (see pages 80—81), after having left it untouched for a long time he found it covered with dust and decided to let some of it be the material for the sieves above the chocolate grinder. He fixed the dust in that area with varnish. In 1920, Man Ray took a famous photograph of this Breeding of Dust (Elevage de Poussiere).

48.title: Klüver on the exhibition Some More Beginnings
48.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy, « The Story of E.A.T.: Experiments in Art and Technology, 1960 – 2001 », in Billy Klüver, Julie Martin (eds.). E.A.T. - The Story of Experiments in Art and Technology, Tokyo, NTT InterCommunication Center, 2003, p. 17-72.
48.text: The E.A.T. competition generated more than 140 submissions from all over the world, and we decided to show all these works. "Some More Beginnings: Experiments in Art and Technology," which was the first major art and technology exhibition, opened at the Brooklyn Museum in November 1968. In this photo Peter Poole demonstrates Fakir in 3/4 Time by Niels and Lucy Young, which won a prize in the E.A.T. competition. On the same principle as a lariat, a loop of cotton ribbon held by vacuum to a rotating axle, moves 100 mph along itself, forming a standing stationary shape in space.

383.title: Hulten's Description of Fakir in 3/4 Time
383.ref_bibliographic: Hultén, K[arl] G[unnar] Pontus. The machine as seen at the end of the mechanical age. New York : The Museum of Modern Art, 1968. 216 p.
383.text:
Lucy Jackson Young. American, born 1930 (artist)
Niels 0. Young. American, born 1930 (engineer) 
Fakir in 3/4 Time 1968
Base : aluminum, plastic and motors, approximately 30” high by 25” wide x 16 deep ; fountain effect : textile cord or tape, adjusting from 4 to 40’ above base

The creators of this mechanical fountain point out that it is the first machine to do the Indian rope trick. The basic principle by which a loop of otherwise limp cord could be coaxed into apparent rigidity and made to stand up was discovered only a couple of years ago. It is the same principle as that of the lariat, in which the motion of a loop of cord along its own length causes it to become rigid. In Fakir in 3/4 Time, the cord, instead of being swung at the end of a tether, is gobbled in and spewed out again by means of an electric motor and sheave, at the rate of 100 miles per hour. Because of its speed, the stream of cord resists deflection until it reaches the end of its loop, when it has to turn about and return to the machine. The head operates by means of a vacuum capstan.
Fakir in 3/4 Time has the elegance of a very simple solution. The choreography of this mechanical fountain is manually adjustable, but theoretically it could be programmed in a way similar to Arm (opposite).

230.title: Catalogue Entry of Fakir in 3/4
230.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
230.text: 137. LUCY J. YOUNG AMERICAN, BORN 1930. NEILS O. YOUNG AMERICAN, BORN 1929; PHYSICIST, INSTRUMENT DEVELOPMENT, VICE PRESIDENT, BLOCK ENGINEERING, INCORPORATED. SECOND PRIZE E.A.T. COMPETITION. FAKIR IN 3/4 TIME 1968. TEXTILE TAPE, ALUMINUM, PLASTIC, VARIABLE SPEED MOTOR; BASE 25" X 16" X 30", HEIGHT 4' TO 40', ADJUSTABLE FROM BASE CATEGORY: C.2

528.title: Description of Fakir in 3/4
528.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
528.text:
137. YOUNG
THE PRINCIPLE IS THE SAME AS THAT OF THE LARIAT. IN THE LARIAT, A LOOP OF CORD REMAINS RIGID, AND CAN EVEN BOUNCE OFF OBSTRUCTIONS, BECAUSE OF THE MOTION OF THE CORD ALONG ITSELF. HERE, INSTEAD OF BEING SWUNG AT THE END OF A TETHER, THE LOOP IS PROPELLED ALONG ITSELF AT 100 M.P.H. BY MEANS OF AN ELECTRIC MOTOR AND SHEAVE.

THE HEAD CONTAINS A 1/2 HP 10,000 RPM UNIVERSAL MOTOR FOR DRIVING THE LOOP BY MEANS OF A VACUUM CAPSTAN SIMILAR TO THOSE USED ON COMPUTER TAPE DECKS. THE HEAD ALSO CONTAINS AN ALTITUDE AND AZIMUTH GEAR MOTOR FOR POINTING THE CORD STREAM. A NUMBER OF SLIP RINGS PRESERVE NECESSARY ELECTRICAL CONNECTIONS, AND THE HEAD ITSELF ACTS AS A SEALED PLENUM KEPT AT A PRESSURE BELOW ATMOSPHERIC. OUTSIDE AIR THUS PRESSES AGAINST THE CORD MATERIAL ON THE SHEAVE, TRAVELS THROUGH THE PERFORATED SHEAVE, THROUGH THE HEAD, AND IS PUMPED OUT THROUGH THE NECK OF THE HEAD AT 100 M.P.H.

THE CONTROL UNIT PUMPS AIR FROM THE HEAD BY MEANS OF A SPIRAL BLOWER AND SUPPLIES POWER TO THE DRIVE MOTOR THROUGH A VARIABLE TRANS FORMER. THE ALTITUDE AND AZIMUTH MOTORS ARE ALSO SUPPLIED POWER SO THAT THEY CAN ASSUME ANY SPEED, FROM FULL FORWARD TO FULL REVERSE.

Page 15-16
Edward Adams American, born 1921. Nicholas Zettlemoyer, American born 1944; Graduate Associate, Pennsylvania State University. Michael Strumpf Israeli, born 1936; Graduate Associate Pennsylvania State University. Sound Structure 1968. Aluminium, motor; 13 1/2'' x 2 1/2'' Category C.1.2.

Page 25-26
Double tubes -an outer tube supported by a pivot near the top of a flexible inner tube- produce sound when the outer tube is tilted on the pivot by the wind, striking the inner tube. To produce sound indoors, a floating base with spring supports has been added, with vertical motion produced by a reciprocating cam mounted on a low-speed electric motor. Frequency and magnitude of movement is controlled by a potentiometer.

THE SHADOW THROWN BY THE WHITE LIGHT APPEARS IN THE COLOR OF THE LIGHT ACCEPTS THE COMPLEMENTARY COLORS OF THE COLORED LIGHTS, WHILE THE SHADOW OF THE COLORED LIGHT ACCEPTS THE COMPLEMENTARY COLORS OF ITS SOURCE. 376.title: Hulten's Description of E.L.L.I.
376.ref_bibliographic: Hultén, K[arl] G[unnar] Pontus. The machine as seen at the end of the mechanical age. New York : The Museum of Modern Art, 1968. 216 p.
376.text:
John William Anthes. American, born 1946 (artist)
Tracy S. Kinsel. American, born 1930 (engineer)
ELLI. 1968
Helium-neon laser, mirrors, target, loudspeakers, electronic and electrical devices, 51" high x 26" wide x 26" deep 

In recent years, there have been many projects that utilized lasers light. The interest of ELLI (Electronic Laser Light Image) is that it presents a three-dimensional light image that responds to information given to it. “The viewer can have dialogue with image (extension of ELLI’s soul)… the image has dialog with surroundings”. There are alternative methods of operation. In one, the music from a magnetic tape generates the audio signals that control the images ; in the other, the observer controls the light images by depressing keys on the keyboard of an electric organ. The images produced can be either stationary or in motion; by forming “chords”, one can make them increasingly complex.
The completely dematerialized sculpture that Gabo predicted as a further step beyond his Standing Wave of 1920 has here been achieved.

97.title: Catalogue Entry of E.L.L.I.

97.text: 5. JOHN ANTHES AMERICAN, BORN 1945. TRACY S. KINSEL AMERICAN, BORN 1930; LASER COMMUNICATIONS, BELL TELEPHONE LABORATORIES. E.L.L.I. (ELECTRONIC LASER LIGHT IMAGE) 1968. LASER, ELECTRONIC ORGAN, FM RADIO RECEIVER MIRRORS, ELECTRONICS; 51"X26"X26" CATEGORY: C.1.2.4

533.title: Description of E.L.L.I.
533.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
533.text:
5. ANTHES
THE LIGHT SOURCE IS A SMALL, LOW-POWER HELIUM-NEON LASER (THE HIGH-POWER DENSITY OF WHICH PROVIDES A BRIGHTER BEAM THAT COULD BE ACHIEVED WITH A NON-COHERENT LIGHT SOURCE). THE LASER BEAM PASSES THROUGH AN X-Y DEFLECTOR, UNDER THE CONTROL OF 2 ELECTRICAL SIGNALS, WHICH PRODUCES MOVEMENT IN 2 ORTHOGONAL DIRECTIONS INDEPENDENTLY. THE DEFLECTED BEAM IS PROJECTED ONTO A ROTATING SCREEN. THE TIME THAT THE BEAM IS SWEPT INTO A REGION OF THE SCREEN DETERMINES THE SPATIAL LOCATION OF THE IMAGE IN THE DIRECTION ALONG THE LIGHT BEAM. THUS, A THREE-DIMENSIONAL OPTICAL IMAGE IS CONSTRUCTED, USING AUDIO SIGNALS (AN FM RECEIVER AND A HAMMOND ORGAN) TO CREATE AND CONTROL THE IMAGE.

GOLDMAN AMERICAN, BORN 1920; METEOROLOGIST, ASSOCIATE DIRECTOR OF RESEARCH, INSTITUTE FOR STORM RESEARCH. STORMFLOW 1967. 535.title: Description of Stormflow
535.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
535.text:
8. BARNSTONE
THE MODEL REPRESENTS THE AIR FLOW IN SEVERE THUNDERSTORMS. THE WARM, MOIST AIR OF THE LOWEST LEVELS (RED STREAMLINES) IS CHANNELED INTO THE STORM BY A COMBINATION OF THE STORM MOTION, THE LOW-LEVEL AMBIENT AIR FLOW, AND THE SUCTION OF THIS AIR UPWARD INSIDE THE STORM. THIS AIR IS BUOYED UPWARD AND THEN HITS THE TOP OF THE TROPOSPHERE, THE TROPOPAUSE, WHERE IT SPREADS AND IS CHANNELED OUT OF THE STORM BY HIGH-SPEED AMBIENT AIR ASSOCIATED WITH THE JET STREAM. JUST ABOVE THE CHANNEL OF INFLOWING MOIST AIR IS A LAYER OF VERY DRY AMBIENT AIR THAT MOVES AROUND THE STORM (YELLOW STREAMLINES). SOME OF THIS AIR IS DRAWN INTO THE STORM BY THE ACTION OF RAINFALL INSIDE THE STORM. THE AIR DRAWN INTO THE STORM (BLUE STREAMLINES) IS COOLED BY EVAPORATION OF THE RAINDROPS FALLING THROUGHOUT AND FORCED DOWNWARD AND AROUND THE CENTER OF UPWARD-MOVING WARM, MOIST AIR. THIS AIR SPREADS AS IT HITS THE GROUND BELOW AND IS LEFT BY THE MOVING STORM.

536.title: Description of Interaffection
536.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
536.text:
9. BAS-COHAIN
A LUCITE BOX, SUSPENDED BY WIRE, IS HALF-FILLED WITH AN OPTICALLY ACTIVE LIQUID (A CONCENTRATED CARBOHYDRATE SOLUTION IN WATER) ON WHICH FLOATS A LIGHT OIL. ON THE REAR OF THE BOX IS MOUNTED A SOLID PIECE OF "POLAROID" MATERIAL; ON THE FRONT, CUT-OUT PATTERNS OF POLARIZING SHEETS. LIGHT TRAVELING THROUGH THE OPTICALLY ACTIVE SOLUTION HAS ITS PLANE OF POLARIZATION ROTATED. WHEN THE BOX IS PUSHED, THE WAVE MOTION PRODUCED INTERACTS WITH AND CHANGES THE FRONT PATTERN. THE OIL LAYER SERVES TO INTENSIFY THE WAVE MOTION.

101.title: On Homage to Windmill Exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum (cat. SMB)
101.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
101.text:
Merry Bean American, born 1920. William S. Bean American, born 1920; Electric engineer, U.S. Air Force Systems Program. Homage to the Windmill 1968. Wood, plastic, electronics, electric lights; 25"x20"x20" Category: C.1.2.4. [p.64]

10. Bean
Constructed of the 20 Plastic rods radiating from a collar that curves around 2 sides of a moire-covered tetrahedron and a rotating edgelit clear plastic sunburst, there are 5 distinct actions, controlled by foot switches operated by viewers: rods light up in sequence from 1 to 20, or in reverse; all the rods are lighted and blink slowly; the sunburst rotates clockwise or counter-clockwise. An input circuit periodically samples the rapidily changing patterns of sensor signals and duplicates the sample in an input register. The latter is a set of bistable device each corresponding to a switch. The state of these devices remains constant for the duration of the interval (corresponding to 20 pulses) and determines the action of the operating network. The operating network is basically a double-decade counter consisting of flip-flop storage elements and a balanced decoding matrix. [p.27-28]

539.title: Description of Encounter
539.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
539.text:
12. BERG
TWO OBJECTS ARE CONSTRUCTED OF ALUMINIUM-CLAD HORSESHOE MAGNETS, ALUMINUM RODS, AND STAINLESS STEEL CYLINDERS. THE OBJETS BOB UP AND DOWN, WHEN GENTLY DEPRESSED, OR ARE SUSPENDED IN MID AIR BY THE FORCE OF INTERACTION WITH A THIRD MAGNET IMBEDDED IN THE BASE. THE MAGNETIC FORCES BETWEEN THE TWO MAGNETS PREVENT THEM FROM MOVING INDEPENDENTLY. WHEN BOTH MAGNETS ARE DEPRESSED AND RELEASED, THEY BOB UP AND DOWN SYNCHRONOUSLY. IF ONLY ONE IS DEPRESSED, THE BOBBING ACTION PASSES BACK AND FORTH FROM ONE TO THE OTHER. THE ACTION IS ENERVATED IN ABOUT TWO MINUTES BECAUSE OF VISCOUS DRAG OF AIR AND FRICTION OF THE BALL BEARINGS AT THE PIVOT POINTS.

OTANO AMERICAN, BORN 1933; COMMUNICATION AND NAVIGATION INSTRUMENTATION, VICE PRESIDENT, INTERNATIONAL TECHNOLOGY, INCORPORATED. RICHARD E. MARTIN AMERICAN, BORN 1930; ENGINEERING DRAFTSMAN, EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT, INTERNATIONAL TECHNOLOGY INCORPORATED. WHAT MAKES IT TICK? I TICK YOU TICK WE TICK LIGHT-TIC MAGNE-TIC PLAS-TIC TRIP-TYCH (A TOY MACHINE) 1968. TAPE RECORDER, PHOTOGRAPHS, ELASTOMERIC SHEETING, ACRYLIC, ELECTRIC LIGHTS, STEEL, MOTORS, SOLID STAGE MODULES, MAGNETS, ALUMINUM, PLEXIGLAS; 3 PANELS, EACH 8' X 2' CATEGORY C.1.2.4.

404.title: Description of About What makes it tick? I Tick You Tick We Tick Light-Tic Magne-Tic Plas-Tic Trip-Tych (A Toy Machine)
404.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
404.text:
14. BERMUDEZ
THIS WORK CONSISTS OF 3 PANELS 2' WIDE AND 8' HIGH SET IN A TRIANGULAR-SHAPED BASE.

ON SIDE A (CONDUCTIVE ELASTOMERIC SHEETING), AN ENLARGED PHOTOGRAPH OF A STILL LIFE ON THE GRASS IS MOUNTED AT THE TOP IS A PINK FLUORESCENT ACRYLIC BUBBLE 18" IN DIAMETER. THIS CONTAINS 2 MORE ACRYLIC BUBBLES OF DIFFERENT SIZES WHICH ARE LIGHTED FROM THE BACK AT A PROGRAMMED RATE, PRODUCING COLORED LIGHT ON THE INSIDE SURFACE OF THE LARGER BUBBLE. THE MOVABLE "PUSH-LITE" FLOWER SHAPE FORMS ARE MADE OF ACRYLIC AND STYRENE, EACH COVERING AN INCANDESCENT LAMP WITH A DIODE IN SERIES WITH THE LAMP AND A COAXIAL MALE CONNECTOR. THE "PUSH-LITE" FLOWERS CAN BE MOVED ABOUT THE FACE OF THE PANEL; THEIR POSITIONS DETERMINE WHICH OF 2 DIFFERENT SOLID STATE MODULES (METRONOME OR BIRD CALL) WILL BE ACTIVATED IN ADDITION TO THE LIGHT.

SIDE B CONSISTS BASICALLY OF THE SAME MATERIAL AS SIDE A, EXCEPT THAT THE BUBBLE AT THE TOP IS OF BLUE PLEXIGLAS NO. 2061 AND CONTAINS PROGRAMMED FLASHING LIGHTS. A "PUSH-LITE" ON THE FACE OF A PHOTOGRAPHED CLOCK ACTIVATES A BELL RING.

ON BOTH SIDES A AND B, MOVEMENT OF THE "PUSH-LITE" FLOWERS PRODUCES STEADY OR ELECTRONICALLY PROGRAMMED FLASHING LIGHTS.

ON SIDE C (AN ANODIZED BLACK 1/16" ALUMINUM SHEET), FOUR 7/8' STEEL BALLS ARE MOVED BY 4 ALNICO PERMANENT MAGNETS FROM RADAR MAGNETRONS WHICH ARE MOUNTED ON 4 SEPARATE SYNCHRONOUS MOTORS OF DIFFERENTS SPEEDS. ACRYLIC RODS AT TOP AND BOTTOM CONDUCT LIGHT FROM MIDGET INCANDESCENT LAMPS, AT THE BOTTOM A TAPE SWITCH MATE ACTIVATES A SOLID STATE ELECTRONIC SIREN MODULE.

ENCLOSED BY THE 3 PANELS, A PRESET TIMER CONTROLS A CONTINUOUS TAPE CARTRIDGE RECORDER WHICH PLAYS A CHILD'S NARRATION. THE TIMER IS ACTIVATED BY INITIAL MOVEMENT OF THE "PUSH-LITE" FLOWERS.

15. BORDES
IN ORDER TO ACHIEVE A MIRROR REFLECTION BETWEEN THE PAINTED SURFACES OF THIS PLEXIGLAS CONSTRUCTION, THE TECHNIQUE OF THIN FILM DEPOSITIONS OF V ARIOUS ELEMENTS IS USED. V ARIOUS SALTS AND MINERALS-CHROME, ALUMINUM, NICKEL, SILVER, OR GOLD-ARE EVAPORATED ONTO THE SURFACES IN A HIGH VACUUM CHAMBER. DEPOSITIONS ARE MEASURED BY A DENSITOMETER TO ENSURE THA T THE PROPER THICKNESS HAS BEEN ACHIEVED.

408.title: Description of Analog Carving Machine
408.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
408.text:
17 BUSH
THIS MACHINE SCULPTS WOOD AUTOMATICALLY. THE ARTIST CONSTRUCTS A METAL FRAME OR SKELETON OF THE DESIRED FINAL FORM. THE SKELETON IS IMMERSED IN A TANK OF WATER. VOLTAGE IS APPLIED BETWEEN THE METAL FRAME AND THE TANK, CREATING A FAMILY OF INVISIBLE CONSTANT VOLTAGE SURFACES IN THE WATER. A PROBE ATTACHED TO A SERVO MOTOR TRACES OUT ONE OF THESE SURFACES; THE SERVO SYSTEM IN TURN OPERATES A CUTTER POSITIONED OVER A WORKTABLE HOLDING A BLOCK OF WOOD. AS TANK AND TABLE ROTATE SYNCHRONOUSLY, THE CONSTANT-VOLTAGE SURFACE IS TRANSLATED ONTO THE WOOD. THE INITIAL SURFACE TRACED BY PROBE AND CUTTER IS CLOSE TO THE TANK WALL; SUCCESSIVE CUTS AT GRADATED VOLT AGE READINGS REMOVE FURTHER LAYERS OF WOOD UNTIL THE FINISHED SCULPTURE IS ACHIEVED.

THE MACHINE IS BUILT FROM SCRAPS OF METAL, PARTS OF JUNKED AUTOMOBILES, AN OLD HI-FI AMPLIFIER. SEVERAL ELECTRIC MOTORS, AND A GALVANIZED GARBAGE CAN.

409.title: Description of Sound Mobile
409.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
409.text:
18. CASSEN-STERN
THE WORK TRANSLATES LIGHT INTO SOUND. EACH HANGING SPHERE HAS ITS OWN TONE. 15 DIFFERENT TONES ARE TRIGGERED EITHER BY STROBE, PROJECTED IMAGES, OR FLASHLIGHTS WHICH PARTICIPANTS CAN PLAY ON THE SPHERES. EACH SPHERE CONTAINS THE OSCILLATOR AND PHOTOCELL. WHEN SUPPLIED WITH A LOW DC VOLTAGE, THE CIRCUIT OSCILLATES AT A FIXED FREQUENCY. THE PHOTOCELL IS IN SERIES WITH THE OSCILLATOR, AND WHEN LIGHT HITS THE FACE OF THE CELL, THE FIXED FREQUENCY SIGNAL PASSES THROUGH THE AMPLIFIER AND SPEAKER SYSTEM AND IS HEARD BY THE VIEWERS.

413.title: Description of Free Forms
413.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
413.text:
22. COSTA.
MOVEMENT IS ACCOMPLISHED BY PULSING AN ELECTRO-MAGNET NEAR THE NATURAL FREQUENCY OF OSCILLATION OF A MOVING MASS SYSTEM. THE MAGNET ATTRACTS A STEEL COUNTERWEIGHT. PULSING THE ELECTROMAGNET IS ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH THE USE OF A SOLID STATE SUB-TIMER WHICH IS ACTIVATED BY AN ELECTROMECHANICAL MASTER TIMER EVERY MINUTE AND A HALF. THE ELECTRONIC CIRCUIT ENERGIZES THE MAGNET FOR ONE SECOND EVERY SIXTH SECOND. AFTER SIX PERIODS, THE ELECTROMECHANICAL TIMER SHUTS OFF THE ELECTRONIC TIMER, ALLOWING THE MOVING MASS SYSTEM TO COME TO REST, AFTER WHICH THE PULSING BEGINS AGAIN.

414.title: Description of Kinetic Pressure Painting
414.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
414.text:
23. CUETARA
PRESSURE APPLIED TO THIS PLEXIGLAS BLOCK BY MEANS OF A HYDRAULIC AUTOMOBILE JACK CREATES STRESSES OF SEVERAL THOUSAND POUNDS PER SQUARE INCH, FORCING A DOUBLE REFRACTION WHICH CAN BE OBSERVED THROUGH LARGE POLARIZERS. THE MOTOR-DRIVEN JACK, DURING A TWO-MINUTE "ON" CYCLE, INDUCES A PHOTOELASTIC STRESS PATTERN AT EIGHT SECOND INTERVALS. PATTERNS VARY FROM CYCLE TO CYCLE BECAUSE PUMP ACTION AND VALVE RELEASE ARE NOT SYNCHRONIZED. DURING THE TWO-MINUTE "OFF" CYCLE, THE BLOCK WILL EITHER BE CLEAR OR WILL CONTAIN THE LAST PATTERN, DEPENDING ON THE POSITION OF THE RELEASE VALVE WHEN THE MAIN SWITCH IS DEACTIVATED.

419.title: Description of The Human Voice
419.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
419.text:
28. DOWNEY
THE HUMAN VOICE CONSISTS OF 3 UNIITS, EACH CONTAINING A BISTABLE SWITCH, A RADIO INTERCOM, A MICROPHONE, AND EITHER A TAPE RECORDER OR A RADIO.

COMMUNICATION BETWEEN BOXES IS ACCOMPLISHED WITH RADIO INTERCOMS, CONSISTING OF A RADIO TRANSMITTER WHICH PRODUCES SIGNALS FOR TRANSMISSION TO THE OTHER INTERCOMS. THE RADIO SIGNALS ARE CAPACITIVELY COUPLED TO THE AC POWER LINE, WHICH SERVES AS A TRANSMISSION LINE. THE STATE OF EACH INTERCOM (TRANSMIT OR RECEIVE) AND OTHER COMPONENTS ARE DETERMINED BY A BISTABLE SWITCH CONNECTED TO A TRANSDUCER. THE SWITCH IS ACTIVATED BY PRODUCING A SHARP NOISE ABOVE THE TRANSDUCER.

THE SWITCHES OPERATE RELAYS WHICH TURN ON OR OFF COMPONENTS WITHIN THE UNITS OF THE SCULPTURE. RELAY FUNCTIONS INCLUDE SWITCHING THE SPEAKER TO OPERATE AS A MICROPHONE, TURNING THE RADIO PORTION ON OR OFF, AND CONNECTING OR DISCONNECTING THE RADIO TRANSMISSION LINE.

377.title: Hulten's Description of Picture-Frame
377.ref_bibliographic: Hultén, K[arl] G[unnar] Pontus. The machine as seen at the end of the mechanical age. New York : The Museum of Modern Art, 1968. 216 p.
377.text:
Richard Fraenkel. American, born 1923 (artist)
Jeffrey Raskin. American, born 1945 (engineer)
Picture-Frame. 1968
Ink drawing on paper embossed frame, 12 ¼ x 14 ½ 

Studies in Perception, I was produced by scanning a photograph with a machine similar to a TV camera and converting the electrical signals into numerical representations on a tape. The computer analyzed the image into levels of brightness, but instead of using randomly sprinkled dots to produce values of light and dark, the dots were organized into small patterns, visible at close view but imperceptible at a greater distance. 
Picture-Frame was made by computation analysis of the relief molding of an old picture frame; the resultant tape was then run through a pen-and-ink arrangement on a computer to carry the design into the picture area. As Fred Waldhauer of E.A.T. remarked, with reference to the frame being preliminary to the picture: "This is probably what the computer would do, if it could think."

428.title: Description of Picture Frame
428.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
428.text:
37. FRAENKEL
THE THREE-DIMENSIONAL DESIGN EMBOSSED ON THE PICTURE FRAME WAS REPRODUCED TWO-DIMENSIONALLY ON A CALCOMP DIGITAL INCREMENTAL PLOTTER DRIVEN BY AN IBM 1401. THE CALCULATIONS WERE PERFORMED ON AN IBM 360/67. THE PROGRAM THAT PRODUCED THE PICTURE WAS WRITTEN IN FORTRAN IV AND USES THE QUICK-DRAW GRAPHICS SYSTEM. THIS GRAPHICS SYSTEM ALLOWED A SMALL UNIT OF THE DESIGN TO BE DEFINED IN TERMS OF/SHORT LINE SEGMENTS. THIS SMALL PORTION WAS THEN ROTATED, REFLECTED, AND TRANSLATED TO MAKE UP A BASIC DIAMOND-SHAPED UNIT. A NUMBER OF THESE UNITS FORMED A ROW, AND THEN A DOUBLE ROW WAS DEFINED. THIS DOUBLE ROW WAS STEPPED ACROSS REPEATEDLY TO MAKE THE FINAL PICTURE.

434.title: Description of Ice Table and Steam
434.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
434.text:
44. HAACKE
A REFRIGERATION UNIT IS HOUSED IN A STAINLESS STEEL BOX TOPPED BY A FREEZING PLATE. MOISTURE FROM THE ENVIRONMENT IS ATTRACTED BY THE COLD PLATE WHERE IT CONDENSES AND FREEZES, GRADUALLY BUILDING UP A THICK ICE LAYER. INCREASES IN TEMPERATURE CAN MAKE SOME OF THE ICE MELT INTO A RECEPTACLE INSIDE THE BOX.


A STAINLESS-STEEL COVERED BOX WITH A REMOVABLE LID SERVES AS A CONTAINER FOR 14 GALLONS OF WATER. THE INSIDE IS DIVIDED BY COPPER WALLS AND FLOORS INTO A LARGE WATER RESERVOIR, A SMALL HEATING UNIT AND A COMPARTMENT HOUSING THE ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT, SUCH AS OUTLETS OF IMMERSION HEATING ELEMENT, THERMOSTAT, AND ELECTRIC WATER LEVEL CONTROL. APPROXIMATELY 1 GALLON OF WATER IS CONTINUOUSLY BEING KEPT CLOSE TO BOILING IN THE SMALL HEATING COMPARTMENT BY A 1200 WATT IMMERSION HEATER. THROUGH A HOLE IN THE CENTER OF THE LID, THE STEAM CONTINUOUSLY ESCAPES INTO THE ENVIRONMENT.

POSITIONED IN THE SAME ROOM, ICE TABLE FEEDS ON STEAM.

438.title: Description of of Sound Sculpture [Hamouda]
438.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
438.text:
46. HAMOUDA
A VERTICAL TUBE IS SUSPENDED FROM A STANDING ARCH. THE TUBE HAS A LARGE SLOT IN FRONT THROUGH WHICH CAN BE SEEN PIANO AND BASS STRINGS STRUNG LENTH WISE AROUND THE INSIDE PERIMETER OF THE CYLINDER. STRINGS STRUNG LENGTHWISE AROUND THE INSIDE PERIMETER OF THE CYLINDER ELECTRIC MOTORS INSIDE TOP AND BOTTOM OF THE CYLINDER-DRIVE IN OPPOSITE DIRECTIONS VERTICAL AXLE JOINED AT THE CENTER BY A BEARING SLEEVE. FROM THESE REVOLVING AXES SHORT ARMS PROTRUDE, FROM WHICH ARE HUNG FREE-SWINGING WEIGHTS. ALSO FROM THE BOTTOM AXIS INTERRUPTING BARS PROJECT. TOP WEIGHTS ARE MOVED IN ONE DIRECTION AND ENCOUNTER INTERRUPTING BARS MOVING IN THE OPPOSITE DIRECTION. UPON RELEASE, THEY SWING THROUGH THE INNER SPACE OF THE SCULPTURE, RANDOMLY STRIKING STRINGS OR THE CYLINDER, WHICH ACTS AS A SOUNDING BOARD. ALTHOUGH THE PERCUSSIVE SOUNDS NEVER REPEAT THEMSELVES, AN AVERAGE TONAL PATTERN EMERGES.

441.title: Description of of Studies in Perception I, II and III
441.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
441.text:
49. HARMON
A 35MM TRANSPARENCY OF A PHOTO IS SCANNED BY A FLYING-SPOT SCANNER, AND THE RESULTANT ELECTRICAL SIGNALS ARE CONVERTED INTO NUMERICAL REPRESENTATION ON MAGNETIC TAPE.

THE FIRST STEP TAKEN BY THE COMPUTER IS TO FRAGMENT THE PICTURE INTO ROWS AND FRAGMENTS PER ROW, AND THE AVERAGE BRIGHTNESS LEVEL OF EACH FRAGMENT IS COMPUTED. THE BRIGHTNESS LEVELS ARE ENCODED, AND THE PICTURE IS NOW REPRESENTED BY NUMBERS, EACH OF WHICH REPRESENTS A SMALL AREA HAVING ONE POSSIBLE BRIGHTNESS VALUE.

INSTEAD OF RANDOMLY SPRINKLING BLACK DOTS IN THE PROPORTION CALLED FOR BY ANY GIVEN BRIGHTNESS LEVEL, THE DOTS ARE ORGANIZED INTO MICROPATTERNS (E.G. A CAT, AN UMBRELLA) WHICH CAN BE SEEN AT CLOSE RANGE. FOR EACH BRIGHTNESS LEVEL, THE COMPUTER MAKES A RANDOM CHOICE AMONG THE PREDETERMINED SET OF MICROPATTERNS WHICH FITS THAT LEVEL. THE PICTURE IS PRODUCED ON FRAMES OF MICROFILM BY A MICROFILM PRINTER AND THEN PHOTOGRAPHED.

442.title: Description of Arm
442.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
442.text:
50. HARRIS
THE CONSTRUCTION IS COMPOSED OF 5 ELEMENTS, EACH CAPABLE OF INDEPENDENT MOVEMENT. EACH ELEMENT IS A RECTILINEAR BOX CONTAINING AN ELECTRIC MOTOR  FOR ROTATING THE ELEMENT IMMEDIATELY ABOVE IT,  CONTROLLED IN SPEED AND POSITION BY A MASTER MOTOR IN THE BASE. THE MOVEMENT IS CHOREOGRAPHED BY A CONTROL TRACK WHICH COMMANDS THE MASTER MOTOR IN SPEED AND POSITION, AND THE AMPLIFYING "SLAVE" MOTORS IN THE LINKS OF THE ARM RESPOND IN SPEED AND POSITION TO THE MASTER.

INSTRUCTIONS ARE CONVEYED BY SYNCHRO TRANSMITTING MOTORS, WHICH "READ" THE CONTROL CHART AND ARE LINKED BY WIRES TO A SERVO MOTOR WITHIN EACH ARM ELEMENT. THE CONTROL CHART IS A ROLLING RIBBON OF 12" WIDE PLASTIC INTO WHICH GROVES ARE ENGRAVED. A LIGHT STYLUS RIDES IN THE GROOVES TRANSLATING ITS WAVE MOTION INTO LINEAR MOTION AND THEN INTO ROTATION BY MEANS OF A RACK AND PINION MECHANISM.

379.title: Hulten's Description of Arm
379.ref_bibliographic: Hultén, K[arl] G[unnar] Pontus. The machine as seen at the end of the mechanical age. New York : The Museum of Modern Art, 1968. 216 p.
379.text:
Hilary Harris. American, born 1929 (artist)
James Macaulay. Scottish, born 1923 (engineer)
Arm. 1967—1968
Anodyzed aluminum, aluminum alloy, motors, electronic equipment, 55" high (including base and 5 elements) x 21" wide x 16" deep; maximum radius of arm, 55"

Arm is born out of a collaboration between an artist and an engineer who have been working together for many years, mostly in animated and documentary films. Film is, of course, a medium in which there is a constant, natural, and for the most part unproblematic collaboration between artists and engineers, who jointly develop an increasingly refined technique.
All of Hilary Harris’ earlier work — which has included dance, still photography, sculpture, and film — has concentrated on movement as its underlying theme. In Arm, a highly advanced mechanical technology is used in combination with electronics to create a nonfigurative choreography. Each of the five articulated elements is capable of independent movement. The motor within each one is controlled by a master motor in the base, and this in turn reacts to instructions, programmed by the choreographer, which are read continuously by the mobile as it performs.
