444.title: Description of Loop Box
444.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
444.text:
52. HASSELL
A LOOP OF MAGNETIC TAPE WINDS IN AN ASCENDING SPIRAL FROM AN ENTRANCE POINT IN THE FLOOR OF A BOX MADE OF ONE WAY GLASS. THE TAPE IS A LOOP CONTAINING RANDOM DISTRIBUTION OF FRAGMENTS OF 6 ASCENDING GLISSANDI RECORDED WITH A SINE TONE GENERATOR, INTERSPERSED WITH VARIOUS LENGTHS OF UNMAGNETIZED TAPE. EACH PIECE OF TAPE WHICH HOLDS SOUND IS ASSIGNED ONE OF 6 FLUORESCENT COLORS AND BECOMES A LIGHT SOURCE ITSELF BY BEING CAUSED TO FLUORESCE BY 4 ULTRAVIOLET LIGHT TUBES MOUNTED IN THE TOP OF THE BOX. TAPE WITHOUT SOUND IS BLACK. AS EACH PIECE OF SOUND COMES TO ONE OF THE 6 TAPE HEADS, THE SOUND IS HEARD ON ONE OF 6 EXTERNAL SPEAKERS. IN THE BASE OF THE BOX ARE CONTROLS FOR VOLUME AND REVERBERATION WHICH CAN BE CONTROLLED BY THE VÎEWER.

146.text: 53. MIKE HINGE NEW ZEALANDER; BORN 0000. 2,000 LIGHT YEARS FROM HOME 1968. ALUMINUM, SYNCHRONOUS MOTORS, CAM TIMERS, WOOD, ELECTRIC LIGHTS, 24"X24"X14" CATEGORY: C.1.2

445.title: Description of 2,000 Light Years from Home
445.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
445.text:
53. HINGE
THE PIECE CONSISTS OF A NUMBER OF PERFORATED DISCS ROTATED BY SYNCHRONOUS MOTORS. THE MAJOR DISCS ARE 13 1/2" IN DIAMETER, SPACED 1 1/2" APART, AND ARE POWERED BY 10 DIFFERENT MOTORS OF VARIOUS SLOW SPEEDS. THE SECOND SET OF DISCS IS MOUNTED BELOW AS A REFLECTOR FOR THE FIRST SET. THE DISCS ARE ILLUMINATED FROM BELOW BY COLORED THERMAL FLASHING D-26 BULBS MOUNTED ON A 2' SQUARE WITH HOLES PUNCHED FOR WIRING AND VENTILATION.

20 SURROUNDING DISCS ARE ROTATED BY 20 MOTORS AND ARE SEQUENTIALLY ILLUMINATED BY COLORED BULBS ON A 12 HOUR CYCLE.

446.title: Description of Orbiter
446.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
446.text:
54. HOENER
A SMALL SPHERE MOVES IN A NUMBER OF LOOPS ABOUT THE CENTER OF THE SCULPTURE, PASSING THROUGH THE TUNNEL IN THE LARGE SPHERE AFTER EACH LOOP. A COMPLETE CYCLE OF 13 DISTINCT LOOPS IS MADE IN A PERIOD OF ABOUT 2 MINUTES, WITH THE LOOP POSITION CONTINUALLY SHIFTING IN INCREMENTS OF APPROXIMATELY 110 DEGREES. BOTH THE LARGE AND SMALL SPHERES ROTATE ABOUT THEIR OWN AXES. EACH TIME THE SMALL SPHERE EMERGES FROM THE TUNNEL, IT HAS ROTATED APPROXIMATELY 20 DEGREES. ALL MOTIONS ARE SYNCHRONIZED USING PRECISION GEARING AND MINIATURE ROLLER CHAIN DRIVES.

148.text: 55. INTERSYSTEMS CANADIANS. AUDIOHYDROKINETIC PRESENTATION 1967. ACRYLIC, FLUORESCENT GLYCOL LIQUIDS, 2 TAPE MACHINES, CROSS-OVER FILTER NETWORK, 12 LOUDSPEAKERS, 35 WATT AMPLIFIER, 2 HYDRAULIC AND 3 PNEUMATIC SYSTEMS, TIMING CONTROL DEVICE, 25 CENTS COINBOX; 12' X 6' X 4' CATEGORY: C.1.2.4

447.title: Description of Audiohydrokinetic presentation
447.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
447.text:
55. INTERSYSTEMS
THREE 3/4" PLATE RECTILINEAR AND TWO 3/8" WALL CYLINDRICAL ACRYLIC COLUMNS ARE FILLED WITH FLUORESCENT LIQUIDS-RED, ORANGE, GREEN, YELLOW, AND BLUE (ALL NON-FLAMMABLE, NON-EXPLOSIVE, NONCORROSIVE, AND RESISTANT TO FREEZING). THE PIECE ALSO CONSISTS OF 2 HYDRAULIC AND 3 PNEUMATIC SYSTEMS, A MASTER TIMING DEVICE, 2 SEPARATE LIGHT SYSTEMS (ONE CONSISTING OF EIGHT 4' ULTRAVIOLET LAMPS CONSTANTLY ON; THE OTHER, OF THREE 8' FLUORESCENT TUBES ARE MADE TO FLASH IRREGULARLY BY THE MASTER PROGRAMMER). TWO PHILLIPS SM 9900 CONTINUOUS PLAYBACK TAPE MACHINES, AND A COIN BOX.

TWO TAPES OF DIFFERENT LENGTHS IN DIFFERENT PROGRAMS ARE HEARD SIMULTANEOUSLY SO THAT THE MUSIC IS VIRTUALLY NEVER REPEATED. THIS IS AMPLIFIED BY A PHILLIPS 35 WATT POWER AMPLIFIER PLAYED THROUGH 12 PHILLIPS LOUDSPEAKERS WITH A FILTER CROSSOVER NETWORK.

56. ISOBE
THIS STRUCTURE CONSISTS OF AN ASSEMBLAGE OF CYLINDRICALLY SHAPED DOUBLE-SKIN STRETCHED MEMBRANES EXPANDED BY AIR PRESSURE. AIR PRESSURE IS AUTOMATICALLY CONTROLLED BY ENVIRONMENT WITH DIFFERENTIAL PRESSURE SWITCH AND MANOMETER, AND SERVES AS SOLE SUPPORT OF THE STRUCTURE AS WELL AS DEFINING ITS SHAPE.

450.title: Description of Hole-diaphragm structures (program 3.8.14.)
450.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
450.text:
58. JAEGER
A MULTIPLE "CAMERA OBSCURA" PRINCIPLE IS USED TO GENERATE PATTERNS OF SUPERIMPOSED HOLES WHICH HAVE BEEN DRILLED INTO DISCS. LIGHT IS PROJECTED THROUGH THE HOLES AS THE DISCS ROTATE, AND THE RESULTING MOVING BEAMS OF LIGHT STRIKE A PHOTOGRAPHIC PLATE TO RECORD THE OVERALL PATTERN. THE PATTERNS CAN BE VARIED BY CHANGING HOLE SHAPE HOLE LAYOUT, DISC ANGLE, AND DISC SEPARATION.

452.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
452.text:
60. KAHN
AN EGG-BEATER IS CLAMPED, WITH A FLUORESCENT LUCITE STRIP, ONTO A FLUORESCENT ACRYLIC-PAINTED WOOD BASE. THE TINES OF THE EGG-BEATER AND THE ADDITIONAL COMPONENTS (PAPER CUPS, A SPINDLE, STRIPS OF MODEL MAKERS' BASS WOOD, STRIPS OF FLUORESCENT LUCITE) ARE ALSO PAINTED WITH FLUORESCENT ACRYLIC PAINTS IN VARIOUS COLORS. THESE ARE INSERTED IN THE DEVICE, WHICH IS ILLUMINATED BY ULTRAVIOLET LIGHT, AND THE SPEED OF ROTATION IS CONTROLLED WITH AN SCR CIRCUIT.

454.title: Description of Astrological Clock
454.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
454.text:
62. KASOUNDRA
THIS CLOCK IS ThE REPRESENTATION OF THE HOROSCOPE AND TIME IN THE DIMENSION OF THE CIRCLE. WHERE NINE IS ON THE FACE OF THE CLOCK IS THE FIRST HOUSE, AND GOING COUNTER-CLOCKWISE ON THE ASTRO-CLOCK, TEN IS THE LAST HOUSE. EACH HOUSE HAS THIRTY DEGREES OF SPACE WITHIN IT-OR SIXTY MINUTES. AS THE CLOCK HANDS MOVE, THE DISTANCES BEtWEEN THE HANDS ARE OPPOSITION, CONJUNCTION, SEXTILE, SEMI-SEXTILE, ETC. THESE ARE ALL DEGREES OF 360 DEGREES WHICH TELL THE ASTROLOGER HOW THE NADIAL CHART LIES WITH THE NATIVE AT BIRTH OR FOR THE READING OF A PROGRESSED CHART, ETC.

455.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
455.text:
63. KASUBA
A SHEET OF PLEXIGLAS RELIEF IS ILLUMINATED BY A MOVING LIGHT TRAVELING IN A FIXED PATTERN. THE LIGHT, OBSTRUCTED AT THE EDGES OF THE PLEXIGLAS PRODUCES MOVING SHADOWS AND APPARENT MOVEMENT OF THE SCULPTURE.

456.title: Description of Psychescope: Integration
456.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
456.text:
64. KLAUBER
4 ACRYLIC DISCS ARE SUPPORTED ON 2 PIVOT WHEELS AND SEPARATED BY 4 NYLON WASHERS. THE DISCS CAN BE REMOVED BY LIFTING THEM UPWARD, ALLOWING EASY CHANGE OF IMAGES. ALL 4 DISCS HAVE 275 SPUR TEETH CUT ON THEIR PERIMETERS, BY WHICH THEY ARE ROTATED. THE DISCS REVOLVE AT FIXED SPEEDS AND IN 2 DIRECTIONS. THE SPROCKET RATIO CAN BE CHANGED TO VARY THE SPEED OF THE DISCS.

157.title: Catalogue Entry of Psychescope: Integration
157.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
157.text: 64. GEORGE KLAUBER AMERICAN, BORN 1923. GUILLAUME SEBASTIAN VOS AMERICAN, BORN 1946. PSYCHESCOPE: INTEGRATION 1968. METAL, PLASTIC, WOOD, FILM, MOTOR; 34" X 34" X 10" CATEGORY: A.1.2

457.title: Description of Forms/Sounds
457.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
457.text:
65. KNOWLES
FIXED FREQUENCY SOUNDS FROM A LOUDSPEAKER ARE PRODUCED IN PRESELECTED GROUPS ALTERNATING WITH SILENCE PERIODS. THE SOUNDS ARE MATHEMATICALLY RELATED TO THE HEIGHTS OF THE COLUMNS: THE FREQUENCIES IN INVERSE PROPORTION. THE SOUNDING TIME DIRECTLY PROPORTIONAL, RANGING FROM 1 TO 9 SECONDS. BOTH GROUPS OF SOUNDS AND SILENCES ARE CHOSEN RANDOMLY.

THE SYSTEM USES 9 FEEDBACK OSCILLATORS WITH TWINTEE [SIC] FREQUENCY DETERMINING NETWORKS AND SINUSOIDAL OUTPUTS. THE TIMERS ARE RC NETWORKS. EACH POWER STAGE HAS A POWER CAPACITY OF 4 WATTS. THE RANDOM SELECTORS ARE SIMILAR, BEING THREE-STAGE BINARY COUNTERS DRIVEN BY 1 Mc/s CLOCKS USING DE CODING LOGIC TO SELECT GROUPS OF SOUNDS. FOR THE SILENCE TIMER, THE SELECTED COUNTERPOSITION WAS STEPPED BY A ONE SECOND CLOCK TO ACHIEVE THE TIME INTERVAL.

THE SEQUENCE OF EVENTS IS AS FOLLOWS:
A) SOUNDS ARE SWITCHED OFF BY THE INDIVIDUAL TIMERS, AND DURING THIS TIME THE SILENCE PERIOD IS SELECTED.
B) THIS IS THE SILENCE PERIOD. IN WHICH THE NEXT GROUP OF SOUNDS IS SELECTED AND THE TIMERS ARE RESET.
C) SOUNDS START TOGETHER.

459.text:
67. KRUGMAN
RODS, BALLS, AND OTHER SHAPES ARE ATTACHED AT DIFFERENT LEVELS TO 7 MOTORS MOUNTED ECCENTRICALLY ON A PLYWOOD BOARD WHICH ARE PROGRAMMED TO MOVE IN A RANDOM MANNER. THIS ASSEMBLY IS COVERED BY A PINK BEDSHEET AND A SHEET OF TRANSPARENT PLASTIC. VACUUM CLEANER MOTORS SUCK IN AND RELEASE THE FABRIC, AND A SWITCHING SYSTEM OPERATES LIGHTS AND A SHAKING AND RAISING MOTION.

162.text: 69. NORMAN LARKIN AMERICAN, BORN 0000. JEAN-JACQUES RIVARD XXXXXXXXXX, BORN 0000. JOHN BIMSHAS AMERICAN, BORN 0000; MECHANICAL DESIGN, MIT INSTRUMENTATION LAB. INERTIAL NAVIGATION SYSTEM 1968. AIR BRUSH ON ILLUSTRATION BOARD; 36 1/2" X 31 3/16" CATEGORY: A

461.title: Description of Inertial Navigation System
461.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
461.text:
69. LARKIN
THE PURPOSE OF THIS INERTIAL NAVIGATION PERSPECTIVE CROSS-SECTION DRAWING IS TO DESCRIBE TO THE SPONSORING AGENCY'S PERSONNEL THE DETAILED INTRICACIES AND FUNCTION OF THE SYSTEM.

THE DRAWING WAS CREATED BY THE ARTISTS FROM PRELIMINARY TECHNICAL DRAWINGS, SKETCHES, AND VERBAL INSTRUCTIONS FROM THE ENGINEER. THE FUNCTION AND INTERRELATION OF COMPONENT PARTS AND THE RELATIVE IMPORTANCE OF VARIOUS FEATURES WERE INITIALLY EXPLAINED TO THE ARTISTS. SINCE THE FINISHED PERSPECTIVE WAS TO BE USED PRIMARILY FOR TECHNICAL DISCUSSIONS, IT WAS VERY IMPORTANT THAT ALL THE DETAILS BE TECHNICALLY ACCURATE.

THE COLORING SCHEME IS IMPORTANT FOR TECHNICAL REASONS: COLOR INDICATES THE CONSTRUCTION MATERIAL, MOTOR LAMINATIONS, GLASS, SYNTHETIC MATERIALS AND FINISHES.

473.title: Description of Cosmos
473.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
473.text:
81. MAUER
THE TOP FIGURE IS ATTACHED TO A PIVOTED ALUMINUM MOUNTING PLATE FREE TO ROTATE AROUND ONE VERTICAL AXIS. A CIRCULAR FOLLOWER IS ATTACHED TO THE MOUNTING PLATE. A GROOVED PLATE (STATIONARY) IS POSITIONED APPROXIMATELY 1" BELOW THE MOUNTING PLATE. THE FOLLOWER ON THE MOUNTING PLATE DURING 1 CYCLE IS MAINTAINED IN HORIZONTAL POSITION. DURING THE FOLLOWING CYCLE, THE FOLLOWER IS SWITCHED ONTO A CAMMED CIRCULAR SURFACE, CAUSING THE TOP FIGURE TO TILT APPROXIMATELY 15 DEGREES FROM THE HORIZONTAL.

THE ENTIRE MECHANISM ASSEMBLY IS POSITIONED ON A PEDESTAL. THE PEDESTAL CONSISTS OF A STEEL CYLINDER INTO WHICH A GEAR REDUCTION MOTOR IS MOUNTED. THE MOTOR-DRIVEN SPIRAL LUCITE COLUMN, ATTACHED TO THE MOUNTING PLATE AND HOUSED IN LUCITE TUBING IS ANCHORED TO THE MOTOR HOUSING AND TO THE STATIONARY CAM PLATE. A TRANSPARENT PLASTIC DOME WHICH CONTAINS THE ENTIRE MOTOR HOUSING AND IS CEMENTED TO THE TUBING. LIGHTING IS INTRODUCED INTO THE SPIRAL COLUMN.

476.title: Description of Capacitance Audio Brek
476.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
476.text:
84. MILLONZI
THE "FLOW-NEON" UNIT PROVIDES CONTROLLED FLOW OF A DISCHARGE IN A GLASS TUBE. THE EXCITATION OF THE DISCHARGE IS OBTAINED BY AN R-F FIELD OF VARYING STRENGTH. A CONTINUOUS GROUND MUST BE PROVIDED ALONG THE GLASS TUBE, HERE IN THE FORM OF THIN METALLIC TAPE. THE RATE OF FLOW OF THE DISCHARGE IS DETERMINED BY THE RATE OF CHANGE OF THE R-F FIELD STRENGTH. THREE FLOW-NEON UNITS ARE USED, ONE FOR EACH OF THREE NEON SHAPES.

ONE GLASS SHAPE REMAINS FULLY ILLUMINATED AT ALL TIMES. THE OTHER 3 ARE PROGRAMMED TO FLOW AT VARIOUS WRITING AND CYCLE SPEEDS AND TIMES. THE ELECTRONIC SOUNDS ARE GENERATED BY A CONTINUOUS LOOP TAPE AND AUGMENTED BY THE RANDOM PATTERN CREATED BY TINY FLUORESCENT BULBS IN THE CONNING TOWER.

477.title: Description of Worlds
477.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
477.text:
85. MILLS
A BAND IS MOVED BY AN ELECTRIC MOTOR DRAWN PULLEY ARRANGEMENT AT A UNIFORM SPEED ALONG THE PERIPHERY OF EACH OF THE 3 FRAMES, IMPARTING VARYING ROTATIONAL SPEEDS TO THE ROLLERS. THE X-Y POSITION OF ANY ONE ROLLER WITHIN THE FRAME AND ITS DIRECTION OF ROTATION WILL BE DETERMINED BY THE COMBINATION OF FORCES APPLIED BY ALL CONTIGUOUS ROLLERS. SMALL MAGNETS IMBEDDED IN THE BOTTOM OF THE WOODEN ROLLERS HOLD THEM TO THE VERTICAL STEEL SURFACE.

180.title: Catalogue Entry of Explosive Creations
180.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
180.text: 86. VERNER MOLIN SWEDISH, BORN 1907. BO HALL SWEDISH, BORN 0000; HEAD OF CONSULTING DEPARTMENT NITRO NOBEL AB, STOCKHOLM. EXPLOSIVE CREATIONS 1968. BLASTED ENGRAVING ON COPPER CATEGORY: E

478.title: Description of Explosive Creations
478.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
478.text:
86. MOLIN
ENERGIES OF UP TO ONE MILLION HORSEPOWER, LASTING ONE MICROSECOND, ARE SCREENED, MASKED, AND DIRECTED, USING A WIDE VARIETY OF SUBSTANCES LAID UPON THE COPPER PLATE IN THE DESIRED PATTERNS. THIS IS THEN COVERED WITH A PLEXIGLAS SHEET, OVER WHICH IS LAID A LAYER OF EXPLOSIVE CHARGE WHICH IS DETONATED BY A BLASTING CAP. DURING THE BLASTING, THE SUBSTANCES ARE BROKEN THROUGH AND PASS DIFFERENT ENERGY LEVELS. WHICH RESULTS IN THE PRESERVATION, IN ETCHED FORM, OF THE ORIGINAL PATTERN. THE RESISTANT MATERIALS PLACED ON THE COPPER PLATE ARE VARIED AND CONSIST OF HEMATITE, IRON ORE, DUST, HAIR, GREASE, AND SAND.

181.title: Catalogue Entry of Yahweh 13
181.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
181.text: 87. RALPH K. MORRILL AMERICAN, BORN 1939. NORTON WISE AMERICAN, BORN 1940; ASSISTANT PROFESSOR OF PHYSICS, AUBURN UNIVERSITY. YAHWEH 13 1968. ALUMINUM, BICYCLE WHEELS, MOTOR, BATTERY, TAPE RECORDERS, LOUDSPEAKER, AMPLIFIER, ELECTRIC LIGHTS; 26" X 26" X 48" (MOVES IN 14' CIRCUMFERENCE) CATEGORY: C.1.2.4

479.title: Description of Yahweh 13
479.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
479.text:
87.
LIGHTS AND MOTION ARE SOUND ACTIVATED, THE CONSTRUCTION, WHEN ACTIVATED, MOVES WITH RHYTHMIC SWAY IN A SLOW, REGULAR CIRCLE. IN ORDER TO READ THE WORDS WRITTEN ON THE INNER DRUM, A PARTICIPANT IS FORCED TO WALK BACKWARD IN THE CIRCLE. LIGHT SHINE IN HIS EYES, AND ANYTHING SAID IS RECORDED FOR 3 SECONDS AND PLAYED BACK GREATLY AMPLIFIED WITH INTERJECTED LAUGHTER AND COMMENTS.

TAPE RECORDERS, ELECTRONIC CONTROLS, BATTERY CHARGER, SPEAKERS, AND LIGHTS ARE MOUNTED ON DISCS BETWEEN 2 BICYCLE WHEELS OF UNEQUAL SIZE, AN INITIAL AUDIO SIGNAL FROM THE MICROPHONE TRIGGER AN SCR WHICH TURNS ON THE MOTOR, SPOTLIGHT AND TAPE RECORDER 1. THESE OPERATE FOR 1 MINUTE AFTER WHICH ANOTHER AUDIO SIGNAL IS REQUIRED TO CONTINUE OPERATION. DURING THIS PERIOD, THE TAPE RECORDER RESPONSE IS ON 6-SECOND CYCLE. RECORDER 1 RECORDS FOR 3 SECONDS AND PLAYS, GREATLY AMPLIFIED, FOR 3. RESPONSES ARE PROGRAMMED AT RANDOM INTERVALS ON TAPE 2, AND THESE, WHEN THEY APPEAR, PREEMPT THE TAPE FEEDBACK ON 1. THIS RECORD FEEDBACK CYCLE CONTINUES AS LONG AS THE AUDIO PICK-UP SYSTEM DETECTS SOUNDS.

483.text:
91. PALYKA
THE PROGRAM WAS RUN "ON LINE" ON A SYSTEM OF 2 INTERRELATED BENDIX G-20'S AND 3 PHILCO CATHODE RAY TUBES. THE PROGRAM PRODUCES IMAGES AND SEQUENCES ON WHICH CHANGES CAN BE MADE AND FED BACK INTO THE COMPUTER, PRODUCING NEW IMAGES AND SEQUENCES. THE PROGRAM IS RUN SEVERAL TIMES UNTIL A DESIRED IMAGE IS OBTAINED. THIS PROCESS WAS CONTINUED UNTIL THE FILM WAS COMPLETED.

187.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
187.text: 94. GIANFRANCO PENNISI ITALIAN, BORN 1922. WOOD-ENGRAVING MACHINE 1966. METALLIC STYLUS, WOOD, POLYETHYLENE, ELECTRONICS, SODIUM CITRATE CATEGORY: E

486.title: Description of Wood-engraving machine
486.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
486.text:
94. PENNISSI
THE ENGRAVED MATERIAL IS PLYWOOD, TREATED WITH AN AQUEOUS SOLUTION OF PARTIALLY CONDUCTIVE SODIUM CITRATE. A HIGH-FREQUENCY, HIGH-VOLTAGE GENERATOR IS COUPLED TO AN INSULATED POINTED METALLIC STYLUS. HIGH-FREQUENCY ENERGY IS TRANSFERRED FROM THE TIP OF THE STYLUS TO THE CONDUCTIVE WOOD AND RESULTS IN AN ARC WHICH ENGRAVES THE SURFACE WITHOUT THE APPLICATION OF PRESSURE. THE SPEED OF ENGRAVING IS APPROXIMATELY 4-7 MM/SEC.

THE HIGH-FREQUENCY ENERGY IS GENERATED USING A 100 KHZ OSCILLATOR COUPLED TO A COIL CONSISTING OF 1,200 TURNS OF COPPER WIRE, WHICH GENERATES 35,000 VOLTS. THIS VOLTAGE IS RECTIFIED AND FED TO THE STYLUS. 

TWO STYLI MAY BE USED: AN ENGRAVING STYLUS HELD IN THE RIGHT HAND AN AUXILIARY STYLUS IN THE LEFT. THE LATTER IS USED FOR FINISHING AND FOLLOWS THE ENGRAVING STYLUS AT A DISTANCE OF 5-6 MM. FINER ENGRAVING CAN BE MADE BY REDUCING THE HIGH-FREQUENCY POWER.

99. RICHTER

THE BASE CONTAINS A MOTOR, WHICH ROTATES THE SCULPTURE. IT IS ILLUMINATED BY A COLLIMATED PROJECTION LAMP WITH MASK AND LENS SYSTEM, WHICH IS PLACED TO ONE SIDE.

193.text: 100. RAYMOND RING AMERICAN, BORN 1945. JOEL KATZEN AMERICAN, BORN 1945; COMPUTER AND INFORMATION SCIENCE, UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA. ALAN HAYES AMERICAN, BORN 1945; COMPUTER ANALYST, UNH. MOVIE PDP-8 1968. 16MM FILM, MAGNETICALLY STRIPPED FOR SOUND CATEGORY: A.3

492.title: Description of Movie PDP-8
492.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
492.text:
100. RING
THE PRINCIPAL PART OF THIS MOVIE WAS PRODUCED THROUGH THE USE OF DIGITAL EQUIPMENT CORPORATION PDP-8 DIGITAL COMPUTER AND DEC-338 DISPLAY UNIT. THE DEC-338 DISPLAY UNIT IS A CRT UNIT (CATHODE RAY TUBE) WITH A SQUARE DISPLAY AREA OF 1024 x 1024 RASTERS. WHEN THE DEC-338 IS CONNECTED TO THE PDP-8, LINES CAN BE DRAWN ON THE DISPLAY AREA THROUGH THE USE OF A LIGHT PEN, AND THESE LINES CAN BE MANIPULATED BY A PUSH-BUTTON PANEL.

ALL SEQUENCES, EXCEPT FOR THE LAST ONE, ARE BASED ON THE VISUAL MANIPULATIONS OF THE LETTERS M O V I E : ROTATIONS, HORIZONTAL AND VERTICAL EXPANSIONS AND CONTRACTIONS. INCREASES AND DECREASES IN INTENSITY, REMOVAL OF ACTUAL SEGMENTS OF THE IMAGE, AND THE CHANGING OF ANGLES.

THE LAST FOUR SECONDS OF THE FILM WERE PRODUCED WITH AN IBM-7040 DIGITAL COMPUTER AND A STROMBERG CARLSON SC-4020 FILM RECORDER, A SMALL SPECIAL-PURPOSE DIGITAL COMPUTER WHICH CAN PRODUCE 16MM FILM.

101. ROCHON
THIE REPEATING 5-MINUTE CYCLE OF FLASHING LIGHTS IS CONTROLLED BY A PUNCHED TAPE PROGRAMMER. IT USES 61 LOAD CIRCUITS ON THE PUNCHED TAPE: A SYNCHRONOUS DRIVE MOTOR PROVIDES A READING SPEED OF 15 LINES PER SECOND.

THE "MAKE BEFORE BREAK" ACTION OF THE READERS ALLOWS FOR THE SWITCH CLOSURE TO REMAIN CONSTANT AS LONG AS THE CHANNEL IS PUNCHED WITH SUCCESSIVE HOLES.

196.text: 103. BELA SANDOR HUNGARIAN, BORN 1935. THE RIEMANNS 1968. CEMENT, POLYURETHANE FOAM; 39" X 12" X 12" CATEGORY: C

495.title: Description of the Riemanns
495.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
495.text:
103. SANDOR
A THREE-DIMENSIONAL FIGURE IS FORMED FROM ONE PIECE OF TWO-DIMENSIONAL MATERIAL WITHOUT GLUING AND JOINING IN ANY WAY.

TO SHAPE THE BASE MATERIAL, A FLAT STRIP OF SOFT POLYURETHANE FOAM IS SLIT AND BRAIDED, ALTHOUGH THE CONTINUITY OF THE MATERIAL IMPOSES CONSIDERABLE GEOMETRIC RESTRICTIONS.

THE SOFT POLYURETHANE SERVES AS THE MOLD FOR THE RIGID STRUCTURE. THE BRAIDED FOAM PIECE IS IMPREGNATED WITTH A CEMENT SOLUTION, WHICH SOLIDIFIES IN A CELLULAR CONFIGURATION. THIS MATERIAL IS THE REINFORCING SUBSTRATE ON WHICH A THIN LAYER OF CEMENT IS BUILT.

496.title: Description of Gyrokinetic Number 11
496.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
496.text:
104. SCALA
GYROKINETIC NUMBER 11 IS SEVEN FEET HIGH AND WEIGHS ABOUT 150 LBS. IT IS COMPOSED OF 150 FEET OF STEEL BARS, 1/16" X 3/4", BENT BY THE ARTIST AND RIVETED WITH STEEL PRESSURE RIVETS. EACH ASSEMBLY IS HELI-ARC WELDED TO A CENTRAL SHAFT OF THREE TELESCOPING STEEL TUBES. FOUR SEPARATE ASSEMBLIES ARE CONNECTED TO THE CENTRAL SHAFTS BY GEARS. THE THREE SHAFTS ARE HELD IN PLACE IN THE BASE OF THE SCULPTURE BY PILLOW BLOCKS. ON EACH SHAFT IS AN 8" PULLEY CONNECTED BY V-BELT TO A 3" PULLEY WHICH IS ON A SHAFT WITH A STEEL GEAR WHICH CONNECTS TO A WORM GEAR ON THE MOTOR. THE SCULPTURE IS POWERED BY THREE MOTORS. THE SPEED OF THE MOTORS IS REDUCED BY THE GEAR AND PULLEY ARRANGEMENT. THE PROGRAM OF THE SCULPTURE IS WORKED OUT WITH A REPEATING CYCLE TIMER. THE TIMER IS HOMEMADE AND IS POWERED WITH A GEAR MOTOR. THE PROGRAM GOES THROUGH A 30-MINUTE CYCLE BEFORE ANY REPITITION TAKES PLACE.

197.title: Catalogue Entry of Gyrokinetic Number 11
197.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
197.text: 104. JOSEPH SCALA AMERICAN, BORN 1940. GYROKINETIC NUMBER 11, 1968. STEEL, MOTOR, ELECTRIC LIGHTS, PROGRAMMED TIMER; 7' X 5' X 3' CATEGORY: C.1.2

497.title: Description of Eye
497.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
497.text:
105. SCHROEDER
THIS PHOTOGRAPH OF AN EYE IS PRODUCED BY PROGRAMMING A GE-645 COMPUTER IN FORTRAN IV TO PRODUCE A DIGITAL TAPE FOR THE STROMBERG-CARLSON 4020 DIGITAL PLOTTER. THE LATTER, A SPECIAL-PURPOSE DIGITAL COMPUTER, DECODES THIS TAPE TO PRODUCE THE FINAL
PICTURE ON 35mm MICROFILM. ON A MICROSCOPIC SCALE, EACH PICTURE IS A COMPOSITE OF ONE MILLION MULTIPLELY EXPOSED POINTS ON THE FACE OF A CATHODE RAY TUBE.

THIS PHOTOGRAPH IS COMPOSED OF "A PICTURE IS WORTH A THOUSAND WORDS." EACH SYMBOL IS EXPOSED IN THE MICROFILM PROCESS UP TO 40 TIMES ACCORDING TO THE BRIGHTNESS LEVEL OF THE ORIGINAL PHOTOGRAPH OF THE EYE.

198.text: 105. MANFRED R. SCHROEDER AMERICAN, BORN 1931. SUSAN HANAUER AMERICAN, BORN 1943; PROGRAMMER, BELL TELEPHONE LABORATORIES. EYE 1968. COMPUTER GENERATED  PHOTOGRAPH; 24" X 24" CATEGORY: A.3

498.title: Description of Portal
498.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
498.text:
106. SCHULTZ
VIEWED DIRECTLY THROUGH THE 5 1/2" CIRCULAR HOLE, EACH LIGHT BULB IS REFLECTED AND RE-REFLECTED INTO A STRING OF SMALL POINTS OF LIGHT THAT RECEDE INTO THE DISTANCE. AN OPTICAL INTERFERENCE FILTER AT THE FRONT CAUSES THE COLOR OF THE IMAGES TO CHANGE FROM BLUE FOR THE CLOSEST TO GREEN FOR THE MORE DISTANT AND FROM BLUE TO PURPLE AND FINALLY TO RED AS THE VIEWER MOVES TO THE SIDE.

THE BULBS TURN ON AND OFF IN A SEEMINGLY RANDOM SEQUENCE WITH A GENERAL COUNTER-CLOCKWISE MOVEMENT. THE BULBS ARE DRIVEN BY 8 MONOSTABLE MULTIVIBRATORS. WHEN ONE OF THE MULTIVIBRATORS TURNS OFF, IT TURNS ON ONE OR TWO OTHERS. A TRAIN OF PULSES THAT IS CONSTANTLY CHANGING IS THUS PROPAGATED AROUND THE RING OF MULTIVIBRATORS. THE TIME THAT A GIVEN BULB REMAINS ON IS CONSTANT, BUT THE TIME IT REMAINS OFF IS ALWAYS CHANGING.

199.text: 106. BOB SCHULTZ AMERICAN, BORN 1943. PORTAL 1968. OPTICAL INTERFERENCE FILTER, CIRCULAR POLARIZER, SUB-MINIATURE ELECTRIC LIGHT BULBS, ELECTRONICS, ACRYLIC, WOOD; 17" X 17 X 7 " CATEGORY: B.1.2.4

200.title: Catalogue Entry of Dream of Love
200.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
200.text: 107. IRA W. SCHWARTZ AMERICAN, BORN 1922. SY WASSYNG AMERICAN, BORN 1919; DESIGN ENGINEER, SCHWARTZ-WASSYNG, INCORPORATED. CHARLES A. VANCE AMERICAN, BORN 1918; VICE PRESIDENT, SAMINEX EXPORT. DREAM OF LOVE 1968. TIMER-RELAY SYSTEM, SPROCKET CHAIN, MOTOR, ELECTRIC LIGHTS, METAL "MIRROR," PAINTED PANELS; 8' X 8' X 2' CATEGORY: C.1.2

499.title: Description of Dream of Love
499.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
499.text:
107. I. SCHWARTZ
A RIGID FRAME SUPPORT 3 ROWS OF 12 VERTICAL PANELS. THE FRONT AND BACK ROW OF PANELS ARE MIRRORED. THE CENTER ROW HAS 2 NUDES PAINTED BACK TO BACK, AND ALL 3 ROWS TURN ON A VERTICAL AXIS. THESE NUDES ARE REFLECTED IN MIRRORED PANELS-DISSEMBLED AND REJOINED AS THE 3 PANELS TURN IN OPPOSING DIRECTIONS. THERE ARE TWO TIMING DEVICES WHICH STOP THE PAINTINGS AND THE FRONT PANEL OF MIRRORS AT SPECIFIC INTERVALS.

EACH PANEL IS PIVOTED BOTH TOP AND BOTTOM. BOTTOM AXIS ENTENDS THROUGH THE FRAME WITH A SPROCKET FIXED AT THE LOWER END. EACH ROW IS SYNCHRONIZED TO ROTATE THROUGH A SPROCKET CHAIN DRIVEN BY A MOTOR.

A TIMER/RELAY SYSTEM IS EMPLOYED TO VARY THE TIME SEQUENCE OF EACH ROW.

504.title: Description of Eclipse
504.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
504.text:
112. SIMON
THIS PROCESS INVOLVES THE APPLICATION OF HIGH-VOLTAGE PARTICLE ACCELERATORS AND THE SPARK DISCHARGE PHENOMENA WHICH RESULTS FROM IRRADIATION OF CERTAIN PLASTICS.

WHEN MONOENERGETIC ELECTRONS STOP IN A POLYMER, A NEGATIVE SPACE CHARGE BUILDS UP IN A PLANE PERPENDICULAR TO THE INCIDENT BEAM. THE DEPTH OF PENETRATION IS RELATED TO THE ACCELERATOR VOLTAGE. AFTER IRRADIATION, THE SPACE CHARGE CONCENTRATION CAN BE DISCHARGED BY PASSING A SHARP METAL OBJECT IN CLOSE PROXIMITY TO THE ELECTRON PLANE. THE DISCHARGE PRODUCES A PERMANENT AND CHARACTERISTIC PATTERN CALLED A "LICHTENBERG FIGURE"-PROBABLY A RESULT OF A DEPOLYMERIZATION OF THE POLYMER. THE UNIQUE CRAZING IN THE CASE OF A CLEAR PLASTIC IS COMPOSED OF SMALL CAVITIES AND HOLLOW CHANNELS. WHEN END-LIGHTED, THE PATTERNS ARE ACCENTUATED BY THE INTERNAL REFLECTION IN THE FIGURE.

IT IS POSSIBLE TO CONTROL THE POSITION OF THE DISCHARGE BY SHIELDING REGIONS OF THE PLASTIC MATERIAL WHERE NO DISCHARGE IS DESIRED. CONTROL OF THE VOLTAGE DETERMINES THE DEPTH OF THE DISCHARGE, AND BY COLORING THE BACK OF THE PLASTIC MATERIALS AND USING LIGHTING, THE ARTIST WAS ABLE TO ACHIEVE THIS EFFECT. COLOR IS APPLIED WITH STANDARD ACRYLIC PAINTS.

506.title: Description of Duchamp and Computer Descending a Staircase
506.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
506.text:
114. SPIVAK
THE PRESENTATION CONSISTS OF BLACK AND WHITE HALFTONE TRANSPARENCIES PROJECTED THROUGH COLOR FILTERS. THE SUPERIMPOSED PROJECTIONS PRODUCE A MULTIHUED ABSTRACT "PAINTING." THE SLIDES WERE PRODUCED BY UTILIZING A COMPUTER AND A MICROFILM RECORDER. THE DIFFERENT GREY SCALE VALUES OF THE ADJOINING SQUARES IN EACH OF THE SLIDES WERE CHOSEN RANDOMLY BY THE COMPUTER, USING A PROBABILISTIC DETERMINATION FOR EACH OF THE 10 DIFFERENT GREY SCALE VALUES. WHEN SLIDES ARE ILLUMINATED UNDER VARYING INTENSITIES MANY COLORS APPEAR.

508.title: Description of X = e^λt
508.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
508.text:
118. TAFRA
FIBER OPTIC LIGHT GUIDES CONDUCT LIGHT FROM A HIGH-INTENSITY SOURCE IN THE BASE THROUGH A FIBER BUNDLE WHICH HAS BEEN SEPARATED. SOME FIBERS HAVE BEEN ABRADED TO ENABLE LIGHT PASSAGE AT LATERAL POINTS ALONG THEM. THE LIGHT SOURCE IS A 150 WATT PRE FOCUSED PROJECTION LAMP SEPARATED FROM THE MAIN FIBER TRUNK BY A 5" DIAMETER HEAT-ABSORBING CONDENSER LENS WHICH WORKS WITH THE COOLING FAN TO PREVENT HEAT DAMAGE TO THE FIBERS.

210.title: Catalogue Entry of Black Video 2
210.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
210.text: 117. ALDO TAMBELLINI AMERICAN, BORN 1930. KENNETH WISE AMERICAN, BORN 1945; ELECTRONICS ENGINEER, OPERATIONS MANAGER, VIDEOFLIGHT. BLACK VIDEO 2 1968. 2 TELEVISION MONITORS, VIDEO RECORDER, VIDEO TAPE, CONTROL BOX, AUDIO OSCILLATOR, MICROPHONE; 12 1/2" X 27" X 19 1/2" CATEGORY: C.1.3.4

509.title: Description of Black Video 2
509.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
509.text:
117. TAMBELLINI
THE VISUAL INFORMATION ON THE TV MONITORS COMES FROM AN ELECTRONICALLY MADE VIDEO TAPE WHICH CAN VARY IN LENGTH FROM ONE HOUR TO FIVE MINUTES. WAVE SHAPES MOVE AT A VERY HIGH SPEED; AT TIMES THE VISUAL PATTERNS OF A VOICE BECOME VISIBLE. IN MAKING THE VIDEO TAPE, THE CATHODE RAY EQUIPMENT WAS PUSHED TO A MAXIMUM INTENSITY OF LIGHT.

THE AUDIO INFORMATION IS A RESULT OF SEVERAL IMPROVISATIONAL SECTIONS, SUCH AS SOUND PRODUCED BY NEON LIGHTS OR BY AN AUDIO GENERATOR. A SPECIAL CONTROL BOX IS ATTACHED TO ONE MONITOR AND ALLOWS MANIPULATION OF THE EXISTING TAPED IMAGE. THE IMAGE CAN BE SWITCHED FROM POSITIVE TO NEGATIVE AND INVERTED; LIGHT INTENSITY AND SIZE CAN BE CHANGED; OTHER MODULATIONS CAN BE ACHIEVED BY USING AN AUDIO OSCILLATOR. SOUNDS IN THE ROOM ALSO MODIFY THE IMAGE THROUGH A MICROPHONE ATTACHED TO THE CONTROL BOX.

art: electronically, photographically or holographically generated images

211.title: Catalogue Entry of Cinecube no. 1
211.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
211.text: 118. TANIA AMERICAN, BORN 1924. DANIEL J. SMOLEY AMERICAN, BORN 1944. CINECUBE NO. 1 1968. CANVAS, WOOD, PLASTICS, FILM PROJECTOR, FILM, MOTOR, SCREENS, MIRRORS; 8' CUBE CATEGORY: C.1.2.3

510.title: Description of Cinecube no. 1
510.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
510.text:
118. TANIA
THIS PIECE IS AN 8' CUBE, MODULAR IN DESIGN. IN THE CENTER OF THE LARGE CUBE IS A 3' CUBE, CONSTRUCTED FOR REAR PROJECTION OF MOVIES. ALL SURFACES OTHER THAN THE PROJECTION SCREENS ARE OPAQUE.

4 VIEWS OF THE SAME SUBJECT ARE SHOWN SIMULTANEOUSLY AND IN SYNCHRONIZATION, A DIFFERENT VIEW VISI8LE ON EACH WALL OF THE 3' CUBE.

A SINGLE PROJECTOR RUNS A COMPOSITE FILM MADE UP OF INDIVIDUAL FRAMES OF THE 4 VIEWS AND WORKS ON A TIME A MULTIPLEX PRINCIPLE. TO PROJECT THE COMPOSITE FILM, IT IS NECESSARY TO FILM 4 VIEWS OF THE SUBJECT AT HIGH SPEED (64 FRAMES/SECOND) AND THEN SPLIT THE SUCCESSIVE VIEWS OPTICALLY SO THAT EACH SCREEN RECEIVES THE FRAMES IT REQUIRES (16 FRAMES/SECOND). THE COMPOSITE FILM IS RUN ON A 16MM BAIA VIEWER WHICH HAS BEEN MOTORIZED TO A SPEED OF 64 FRAMES/SECOND WITH A SYNCHRONOUS MOTOR. THE RESULTING IMAGES ARE REFLECTED TO THE APPROPRIATE SCREEN THROUGH THE USE OF A SYNCHRONIZED. ROTATING 5 FRONT SURFACE MIRROR. THE ENTIRE PROGRAM IS A FILM LOOP THAT IS WOUND AUTOMATICALLY ON A SINGLE REEL WITH A CENTER TAKE-OFF AND A PERIPHERY REWIND.

art: electronically, photographically or holographically generated images

384.title: E.A.T. Competition Awards
384.ref_bibliographic: [Press package for “The machine as seen at the end of the mechanical age”]. New York : Experiments in Art and Technology ; New York : The Museum of Modern Art, November 11, 1968. Set of 15 elements. Press kit. Includes press releases, one postcard and one program.
384.text:
EXPERIMENTS IN ART AND TECHNOLOGY, INC. 
9 East 16 Street, New York, N. Y.

THE MUSEUM OF MODERN ART
11 West 53 Street, New York, N. Y.

The names of the American engineers who were awarded prizes in the international competition arranged by Experiments in Art and Technology in connection with The Museum of Modern Art exhibition, The Machine as Seen at the End of the Mechanical Age, were announced November 11 at a press conference-demonstration at the Museum. Purpose of the competition, launched a year ago, was to find the most inventive contribution by an engineer to a work of art produced in collaboration with an artist.
	Winners of the $3,000 first prize were Harris Hyman and Ralph Martel, who collaborated with artist Jean Dupuy to construct a sculpture of dust. Frank Turner was awarded a $1,000 second prize for his contribution to Wen-Ying Tsai's cybernetic sculpture of stainless steel rods and strobe lights; Niels 0. Young also won a second prize of $1,000 for his role in making Fakir in 3/4 Time, mechanical fountain, with his artist wife Lucy Jackson Young.
	The first prize was awarded by P. L. Siemiller, Co-chairman of the American Foundation on Automation and Employment, which donated the prize money. Mr. Siemiller is also President of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers (AFL-CIO).
	The two second prizes were donated by the McCrory Corporation and Richard Brandt, President, on behalf of the Trans-Lux Corporation.
	The prizewinning works are included in The Museum of Modern Art exhibition on view from November 27 through February 9. At the same time, all the entries in the E.A.T. competition are being shown in an exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum, Some More Beginnings, opening November 26.
	In Heart Beats Dust, first prizewinner, the essential material is red dust lying on a stretched rubber membrane enclosed in a glass-faced cube. The dust is activated by acoustic vibrations produced by the rhythm of heart beats and made visible by a light beam of high intensity. "Like many works of recent years, Heart Beats Dust manifests a new form of cooperation with nature," according to Pontus Hultén, Guest Director of The Museum of Modern Art exhibition. "A sensitive collaboration between natural forces within and outside the human body has here been achieved." Hyman and Martel received special technical advice from Charles Coster and Robert Maziarz of North American Phillips, Incorporated, and Rodney F. Kaiser of Kliegl Brothers.
	Fakir in 3/4 Time is a mechanical fountain. Its creators, Lucy Jackson Young and her husband, Niels 0. Young, engineer, point out that it is the first machine to do the Indian rope trick. Based on the same principle as that of the lariat, in which the motion of a loop of cord along its own length causes it to become rigid, the cord in Fakir in 3/4 Time, instead of being swung at the end of a tether, is gobbled in and spewed out again by means of an electric motor and sheave, at the rate of 100 miles an hour.
	The Cybernetic Sculpture, created by artist and engineer Wen-Ying Tsai, is based on the principle of the harmonic motion in a "standing wave" produced by a vibrating rod. Multiple stainless steel units, each more than nine feet high, with a 20 inch diameter at the base, are grouped together. The visual effect when in motion is continually modulated by high frequency stroboscopic lights. The lights react to sound, such as that of a voice or the clapping of hands. The sense of contact with the sculpture that the viewer obtains is due to the subtlety of the work's reaction; the response of the trembling rods seems a direct translation of his voice. "The technical solution that produces this illusionistic feat is at once so discreet and so efficient that it strikes us as perfect," Mr. Hultén says.
	The winning works were selected from more than 150 submissions from artists in nine countries. The jury consisted of five scientists and engineers who were not necessarily knowledgeable about contemporary art. The jurors were unfamiliar with the participating engineers. They were: James M. Brownlow, International Business Machines Research Laboratories; Michael D. Golder, Plastic Research and Development Center, Celanese Plastics Company; Cyril M. Harris, Professor of Electrical Engineering and Architecture, Columbia University; John W. Pan, Bell Telephone Laboratories; and William G.Rosen, Special Assistant to the Director, National Science Foundation, and Executive Secretary of the Committee on Academic Sciences and Engineering of the Federal Council for Science and Technology. 
	In making the awards for the most inventive use of new technology as it evolves through the collaboration of artist and engineer, the jurors were asked to base their judgements on these criteria: First, how inventive and imaginative is the use of technology? Second, to what extent have the engineer and artist collaborated successfully?
	In making their decision, the jurors issued the following statement:
In each of the winning entries a spectrum of technology was used with great impact on the art forms. Evident is the realization that neither the artist nor the engineer alone could have achieved the results. Interaction must have preceded innovation. Going beyond a demonstration of technical prowess or an intricate orchestration of art and technology, the engineer and artist together have created more than a well-executed realization of fantasy. The unexpected and extraordinary, which one experiences on viewing these pieces, result from inventiveness and imagination, stimulated not by the brute force of technical complexity but by probing into the workings of natural laws.

	In addition to the prizewinning engineers and the artists, others present at the conference were: Theodore W. Kheel, President of the American Foundation on Automation and Employment; Richard Brandt, President of Trans-Lux Corporation; Meshulam Ricklis, President of the McCrory Corporation; Bates Lowry, Director of The Museum of Modern Art; G. Pontus Hultén, Director of Moderna Museet in Stockholm and Guest Director of The Museum of Modern Art's exhibition; Dr. Billy Klüver, President of E.A.T.; and Robert Rauschenberg, Chairman of the Board, E.A.T.
	Representatives of labor and industry, who were invited, included Lane Kirkland, assistant to George Meany, President of the Central Labor Council (AFL-CIO); Ralph Gross, President of the Commerce and Industry Association; Edward Swayduck, President of Local One Amalgamated Lithographers of America; Seymour Schweber of Schweber Electronics; and At[h]elstan [Spilhaus], The Franklin Institute, Philadelphia.
	Experiments in Art and Technology (E.A.T.), an international organization, was established in 1967 to develop an effective collaboration between engineers and artists. [The] aim of the non-profit organization is to encourage new work which is not the preconception either the engineer or the artist but which is the result of their joint explorations.

Additional information available from Elizabeth Shaw, Director, Department of Public Information, The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53 Street, New York, N.Y. I00I9. 245-3200

512.title: Description of of Cybernetic Sculpture
512.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
512.text:
120. TSAI
VERTICAL STAINLESS-STEEL RODS ARE VIBRATING AT AN UNVARYING RATE OF 30 CPS, ILLUMINATED BY STROBE LIGHTS WHOSE FLASH RATE IS CONTROLLED BY SOUNDS IN THE ENVIRONMENT. IN A STATE OF SYNCHRONIZATION, WITH THE LIGHTS AND THE RODS AT 30 CPS THE RODS APPEAR TO BE STILL, IN THE SHAPE OF A HARMONIC CURVE. ANY SOUND VARIES THE STROBE LIGHTS VOLTAGE-CONTROLLED TRIGGER OSCILLATOR WHICH CHANGES THE RATE OF FLASHING. THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN THE VIBRATION RATE AND THE FLASH RATE PRODUCES THE ILLUSION OF MOTION IN THE RODS THE GREATER THE DEVIATION BETWEEN THE TWO FREQUENCIES, THE GREATER THE APPARENT MOTION OF THE RODS.

STAINLESS STEEL, STROBOSCOPIC UNITS, VOLTAGE-CONTROLLED OSCILLATOR, MOTORS; 8 UNITS, EACH 9'4" X 20" DIAMETER HOWARD WISE GALLERY, NEW YORK CITY CATEGORY: C.1.2.4

382.title: Hulten's Description of Cybernetic Sculpture
382.ref_bibliographic: Hultén, K[arl] G[unnar] Pontus. The machine as seen at the end of the mechanical age. New York : The Museum of Modern Art, 1968. 216 p.
382.text:
Wen-Ying Tsai. American, born China, 1928 (artist and engineer) 
Frank T. Turner. American, born 1911 (engineer)
Cybernetic Sculpture. 1968
Multiple stainless steel units, each 9'4" high X 20" diameter at base; oscillator, stroboscopic lights, electronic equipment

This sculpture is based on the principle of the harmonic motion in a "standing wave" produced by a vibrating rod — the same idea that Gabo explored earlier (see page 106). Here, several units are grouped together. Their visual effect when in motion is continually modulated by high-frequency stroboscopic lights. The lights react to sound, such as that of a voice or the clapping of hands. The sense of contact with the sculpture that the viewer obtains is due to the subtlety of the work's reaction; the response of the trembling rods seems a direct translation of his voice. 
The technical solution that produces this illusionistic feat is at once so discreet and so efficient that it strikes us as perfect.

516.title: Description of U-2
516.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
516.text:
124. U.S.C.O.
THIS IS A STRUCTURE DISPLAYING SUPERIMPOSED ANTIQUE GLASS-NEGATIVES OF NUDE STARLETS OF THE 1920'S BACKED UP BY FOUR 12" SHOWCASE LAMPS, PULSING IN A PROGRAM, AND AN ANTIQUE WOODEN SCREW TURNING AT A PRACTICALLY IMPERCEPTIBLE SPEED AND REVERSING, RISING OUT OF THE CENTER OF THE PIECE. THE CIRCUITRY EXPOSED BELOW CONSISTS OF A PROGRAM WIRED INTO A STEPPING SWITCH, WHICH DISPLAYS EITHER 2 DIAGONAL PAIRS OF A THIRD SELECTION OF ALL 4 BULBS, TIMED BY A UNIJUNCTION CIRCUIT FIRING A TRIAC. THE UNIJUNCTION OSCILLATOR BEATS AGAINST LINE FREQUENCY, PRODUCING A PULSE IN THE 4 BULBS. 3 PULSING RATES CAN BE PROGRAMMED AND POTENTIOMETER ADJUSTED. THE STEPPER ALSO PROGRAMS MOTOR REVERSAL, TURNING THE CENTRAL SCREW.

POEMFIELD NO. 1, MAN AND HIS WORLD, COLLIDEOSCOPE, POEMFIELD NO. 2 1967. 19-MINUTE 16MM COMPUTER-GENERATED BLACK AND WHITE FILM, COLOR FILM CATEGORY: A.3

517.title: Description of Poemfield no. 1, Man and His World, Collideoscope, Poemfield no. 2
517.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
517.text:
125. VANDERBEEK
THE COMPUTER LANGUAGE DEVELOPED BY THE ENGINEER FOR THESE 16MM COMPUTER-GENERATED FILMS TREATS PICTURES AS MOSAICS OF SPOTS, ACTUALLY RECTANGULAR ARRAYS 252 x 184, EACH ELEMENT OF WHICH IS REPRESENTED WITHIN THE COMPUTER BY A NUMBER FROM 0 TO 7, WHICH INDICATES LIGHT INTENSITY AT THAT POINT. PICTURES ARE BUILT AND MODIFIED WITHIN THE COMPUTER BY APPROPRIATE MANIPULATION OF THESE NUMBERS, AND AT THE DESIRED TIMES ARE USED TO DIRECT THE MICROFILM RECORDED IN DISPLAYING THE ENTIRE ARRAY OF 46,368 SPOTS IN ORDER TO EXPOSE ONE FRAME OF FILM. (ACTUALLY, THESE SPOTS ARE GENERATED BY TYPING TINY LETTERS, USING THE 4020 CHARACTRON TUBE IN THE TYPEWRITER MODE, DIFFERENT CHARACTERS BEING USED FOR DIFFERENT INTENSITIES ACCORDING TO THEIR OVERALL GREY LEVEL.) THE PROGRAMMER USES TWO LEVELS OF LANGUAGE: AT THE LOWEST AND MOST DETAILED LEVEL OF CONTROL, HE DIRECTS SCANNERS TO CRAWL ABOUT THE TWO-DIMENSIONAL ARRAY, READING NUMBERS THEY 'RE SITTING ON AND OPTIONALLY WRITING NEW NUMBERS INTO THESE POSITIONS. ON THE HIGHER LEVEL, THE SYSTEM IS INSTRUCTED TO DRAW LINES, ARCS, ETC. OPERATIONS CAN BE INVOKED COVERING ENTIRE AREAS WITH ANY CINEMATIC INSTRUCTION.

521.title: Description of Untitled [Walther]
521.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
521.text:
129. WALTHER
THE FLOWER BUDS ON THIS DRAWING WERE CREATED BY SHOOTING MICROCAPSULES OF OIL PAINT ONTO A CANVAS PANEL. THE OIL-CONTAINING CAPSULES WERE PRODUCED UTILIZING THE PROCESS OF MICROENCAPSULATION. THE CAPSULE IS DRY, FREE FLOWING, AND APPEARS TO BE SOLID BUT IS APPROXIMATELY 90% LIQUID. THE LIQUID CAN BE RELEASED BY APPLYING PRESSURE TO RUPTURE THE HARD WALL MATERIAL.

THE ABILITY TO MAKE A POLYMER GO IN AND OUT OF SOLUTION IS THE KEY TO THE TECHNIQUE OF MICROENCAPSULATION. THE FIRST STEP WAS TO PRODUCE A SOLUTION OF THE WALL MATERIAL, IN THIS CASE A WATER-SOLUBLE GELATIN. THE LIQUID TO BE ENCAPSULATED WAS ARTIST OIL DISSOLVED IN TURPENTINE. THIS IMMISCIBLE LIQUID WAS ADDED THE WATERGELATIN SOLUTION AND AGITATED UNTIL THE DESIRED SIZE DROPLETS WERE FORMED. AT THIS POINT THE CHARACTERISTICS OF THE POLYMER SOLUTIONS-WERE ALTERED BY CHANGING THE pH FOR SOLUTION TO BRING ABOUT PHASE SEPARATION OF THE WALL MATERIAL. AS THE POLYMER COMES OUT OF SOLUTION, IT WRAPS AROUND THE OIL DROPLET. THE CAPSULES ARE THEN REMOVED FROM THE SOLUTION, AND THE WATER IS REMOVED FROM THE GELATIN WALL BY DRYING. 

THE SHOOTING OF THE CAPSULES WAS DONE BY PLACING THEM IN A TUBE AND RELEASING 80 PSI AIR BEHIND THE CAPSULE.

GRANDMAISON AMERICAN, BORN 0000; ELECTRICAL ENGINEER, INTERNATIONAL MARKETING MANAGER, SEMI-CONDUCTOR DIVISION, SPRAGUE ELECTRIC COMPANY. FIRST TIGHTEN UP ON THE DRUMS 1968. PERSPEX, SHEETING, NEON LIGHTS, ELECTRONICS; 2'5" X 2' X 1' CATEGORY: C.1.4

523.title: Description of First Tighten Up on the Drums
523.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
523.text:
132. WHITE
A PERSPEX PANEL CONTAINS HEXAGONALLY ARRANGED NEON LIGHTS. WHICH FLASH IN A REPEATING SEQUENCE, MOVING RHYTHMICALLY ACROSS THE PANEL. THE RHYTHM WILL BE IMPOSED ON AN OTHERWISE UNIFORMLY SHIFTING PATTERN BY VARIATIONS IN THE SHIFT VELOCITY HAVING ITS OWN DEFINITE AXIS. THE PIECE PRESENTS A SUPERFICIALLY CONFUSING MOSAIC OF FLASHING LIGHTS, WHICH IN TIME IS PERCEIVED AS A SET OF INTERACTING PATTERNS.

THE LIGHTS ARE ELECTRONICALLY CONTROLLED USING SPRAGUE US-0913 SHIFT REGISTER MICROCIRCUITS CONNECTED IN CHAINS WHICH TRANSFER A PULSE AT A RATE PROPORTIONAL TO THE PULSE REPETITION RATE. THE CHAINS ARE CONNECTED TO PULSE GENERATORS OF GRADUALLY VARYING FREQUENCY PRACTICING VARYING RATES OF SHIFT, WHICH ACCELERATE AND DECELERATE. PARALLEL CHAINS TRIGGER NEON LAMP DRIVER CIRCUITS TO CAUSE A BARRED PATTERN OF LIGHT TO MOVE ACROSS THE BOARD. THE DIFFERENTIAL TRIGGERING OF THE SHIFT REGISTERS BY THE VARIOUS PULSING CIRCUITS PRODUCES DISPLACEMENT OF THE PATTERNS, WHICH CAN BE CONTROLLED BY ADJUSTING THE VARIABLE PULSE GENERATORS.

THREE COMPLEXES OF CHAINS ARE EMPLOYED TO CONTROL SHIFTING IN INCREMENTS OF 120 DEGREES. THE COMPLEXES ARE ACTIVATED IN SEQUENCE BY A THREE-STAGE COUNTER.

241.name: You Grow In The Turquoise Kiva

226.title: Catalogue Entry of You Grow In The Turquoise Kiva

226.text: 133. IAIN WHITECROSS BRITISH, BORN 1936. THEODORE WOLFF AMERICAN, BORN 1940; BIOELECTRONICS, N.Y.U. MEDICAL CENTER. YOU GROW IN THE TURQUOISE KIVA 1968. ACRYLIC, MASONITE, MOTORS, INCANDESCENT LIGHTS, SOLID STATE LIGHT MODULATORS; 7'6" X 3'6' X 11" CATEGORY: B.1.2.4

524.title: Description of You Grow In The Turquoise Kiva
524.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
524.text:
133. WHITECROSS
ENVIRONMENTAL SOUNDS OF ALL KINDS ARE RECEIVED BY A FOUR INCH PM SPEAKER WHICH IS USED AS A MICROPHONE. THE SIGNAL FROM THE SPEAKER IS AMPLIFIED BY A SMALL PREAMP MODULE WHICH IS SUPPLIED FROM A 6 V REGULATED SUPPLY. THE SENSITIVITY OF THE SPEAKER AND OF THE OUTPUT IS CONTROLLED BY SEPARATE PENTENTIOMETERS. THE AMPLIFIED SIGNAL IS BOOSTED BY A 20 W POWER AMPLIFIER WITH A SELF CONTAINED 45 V SUPPLY, AND THE BOOSTED SIGNAL IS FED TO A THREE-CHANNEL MODULATOR. IN THE MODULATOR, THE SIGNAL IS SENT THROUGH THREE POTENTIOMETERS TO THREE INPUT TRANSFORMERS. THE OUT PUT OF THE TRANSFORMERS IS PARTIALLY FILTERED AND SENT TO PREBIAS THE TRIGGER DIODES OF 3 SCP IF A SIGNAL IS PRESENT, THE DIODES ARE PREBIASED AND FIRE EARLIER IN THE SCR CYCLE, THUS INCREASING THE POWER OUTPUT FROM THE SCR'S TO THE SCULPTURE'S LIGHTS. THE SCR'S ARE SUPPLIED BY A 10 A DIODE BRIDGE RECTIFIER AND ARE EQUIPPED WITH BACKGROUND CONTROLS AS WELL AS SENSITIVITY CONTROLS. THE MODULATED OUTPUT FROM THE 3 SCR CHANNELS GOES TO 3 LEDEX MOTOR-ROTATED WAFER SWITCHES WHICH CHANGE THE DESTINATION OF THE MODULATED POWER IN A PROGRAMMED CYCLE. EACH SCULPTURE UNIT HAS A SEPARATE SWITCH ROTATING AT A DIFFERENT SPEED TO SHUNT THE POWER TO ITS OWN SET OF BULBS. THIS PRODUCES AN INFINITE SET OF PERMUTATIONS OF POSITIONS AND INTENSITIES.

526.title: Description of Dark
526.ref_bibliographic: Some More Beginnings : an Exhibition of Submitted Works Involving Technical Materials and Processes. New York: E.A.T., 1968.
526.text:
135. WHITMAN
THE LIGHT SOURCE IS A HELIUM-NEON LASER, CAPABLE OF DELIVERING A VERY BRIGHT SPOT OF RED LIGHT, ABOUT 1/4" IN DIAMETER. FROM DISTANCES OF 8 TO 16 FEET. A LASER BEAM IS DIRECTED UPWARD, STRIKING A MIRROR POSITIONED AT 45 DEGREES WHICH ROTATES ABOUT A VERTICAL AXIS, CAUSING THE SPOT OF LIGHT TO SWEEP AROUND THE WALLS IN A HORIZONTAL PLANE. THE MIRROR IS ROTATED AT ABOUT 20 TO 30 REVOLUTIONS PER SECOND; THE MOTION IS NOT APPARENT TO THE OBSERVER (DUE TO THE PERSISTENCE OF VISION) AND THE LIGHT APPEARS TO BE A CONTINUOUS LINE.

TO ACHIEVE THE DRAWING AND ERASING, AN OPAQUE, RAMP-SHAPED MASK, WRAPPED INTO A CYLINDRICAL FORM ABOUT THE ROTATING MIRROR AND THEN CAUSED TO SLOWLY RISE (AND LATER TO FALL), RESULTS IN AN INCREASING (AND LATER A DECREASING) PORTION OF THE ROTATING BEAM TO BE INTERCEPTED. THUS, AS THE RAMP SLOWLY LOWERS, THE PORTION OF THE CIRCULAR LINE WHICH ESCAPES THE MASK AND IS SEEN ON THE WALL SLOWLY INCREASES AND THE LINE "GROWS AROUND THE WALLS," UNTIL THE CIRCLE IS COMPLETE (THAT IS. UNTIL THE OPAQUE MASK IS LOWERED COMPLETELY BENEATH THE ROTATING BEAM). THEN THE MASK REVERSES DIRECTION AND BEGINS TO RISE AND, IN SO DOING, "ERASES" THE LINE BACKWARD AROUND THE ROOM. THE CYCLE IS THEN REPEATED.

90. O'BRIEN
THE NUMERICAL RAW MATERIAL FOR A SERIES OF PAINTINGS WASR SOCIAL SECURITY NUMBERS, TELEPHONE NUMBERS MATHEMATICAL TABLES, AND RANDOM NUMBERS USING A STANDARD SQUARE "MATRIX" CANVAS FOR THE DESIGNS, A PARTICULAR COLOR WAS ASSIGNED TO EACH DIGIT, USING A COLOR SERIES BASED ON THE SPECTRUM! ZERO IS REPRESENTED BY WHITE, AND DECIMAL POINTS OR DIGIT SEPARATORS BY BLACK. ALTERNATE COLOR SYSTEMS WERE DEVISED BY USING A MONOCHROMATIC COLOR SCHEME. THE DIGIT 5 WAS REPRESENTED BY THE PURE COLOR, WITH FOUR DARKER TONES REPRESENTING 4. 3, 2, 1. FOUR LIGHTER TONES OF THE SAME COLOR WERE USED FOR 6, 7, 8, 9. THE COLOR AREA WAS MADE PROPORTIONAL IN SIZE TO THE SIZE OF THE DIGIT IT REPRESENTS.

251.name: Lowell Cross' proposal for Live Programming

361.title: Loewen on Live Programming
361.ref_bibliographic: Loewen, Norma. “Experiments in Art and Technology: A Descriptive History of the Organization”. New York University, 1975.
361.text: During the first five weeks of the pavilion's operation, programming was performed by 10 resident programmers, 8 from the United States, 2 from Japan. Those appearing were Remy Charlip, Lowell Cross, Jacquelyn Farrell and Harry Harper (following through a proposal first submitted by Lisa Forbes and Roger Payne), Takumi Hijikata, Anthony Martin, Rikuro Miyai, Pauline Oliveros and Lynn Lonidier, and David Tudor.

316.title: Lowell Cross' proposal for Live Programming
316.ref_bibliographic: «Proposals for Live Programming». – Pavilion. – Edited by Billy Klüver, Julie Martin and Barbara Rose. – New York : E. P. Dutton, 1972. – P. 285-320
316.text:
Lowell Cross

	I should like to use the crowd-control system to have an accurate account of the number of people going through the Pavilion and the rate at which they are going through it. I shall correlate
the rate of flow of people through the Pavilion with the rate of
visual and audio information in my program. If there are fewer visitors, I will slow down the rate of visible and audible information, thus encouraging people to remain in the Pavilion longer, because they will tend to walk until another event is presented. Thus, with fewer people there would be a subdued type of activity. As more
and more people come through the Pavilion, the rate of information
presented will be speeded up. The activities will be more intense, and people will get more in a shorter time and tend to move through faster. This means that no matter what the circumstance, how few or how many people are going through the Pavilion in a given length of time, they would receive approximately the same amount of information. I should like to automate this by hooking up the crowd-control counter with the Master Programmer, so that the rate of flow of visitors could control the rate at which the programmer was running the program.
	I want to make as much audio and visual interaction as possible,
using the ability of the lights to be programmed by the audio. 
	I shall program the laser deflection system, in addition to normal program tapes that are not beard but make visual patterns. I shall use the sounds in the Pavilion that can be picked up in the
Clam Room to operate the laser display. At other times the sounds
that will be in the normal laser program tapes will be heard in the
handsets of visitors entering the Clam Room, so they will be seeing what they are hearing.

317.title: Sandy Daley and Nicholas Quennell's Proposal for Live Programming
317.ref_bibliographic: «Proposals for Live Programming». – Pavilion. – Edited by Billy Klüver, Julie Martin and Barbara Rose. – New York : E. P. Dutton, 1972. – P. 285-320
317.text:
Sandy Daley and Nicholas Quennell

	This proposal attempts to use the Pavilion as a crude analogue for a more complex idea that we have been considering for some time. The aim is to have a number of people produce a single design. Using some form of feed-back system the group could respond to each other's contributions and produce a single unified result.
	The problem of group participation in the design process, whether it be six people around a conference table or sixty in a
community, is that of recording and visualizing the various individual
contributions so that a total product can emerge, rather than the accretion of a series of individual ideas.
	We would attempt setting up simple design problems (a park, a
restaurant, or simply an arrangement of arbitrary color or form). Visitors would be invited to pick up light-weight symbolic elements
representing such things as trees, walls, or tables. Working
within a limited number of fixed elements such as a street, lake, or
view, they would locate their elements by their own standards. The reflective capabilities of the dome would show all participants their own and everyone else's role in the total assemblage.

Revised Proposal
	
	A floating landscape will be created by visitors carrying photo
constructions of blossoming cherry trees. Sounds of dewdrops falling will be recorded on forty-eight tracks. Fresh air will be pumped into the Pavilion.

318.title: John Forkner's proposal for Live Programming
318.ref_bibliographic: «Proposals for Live Programming». – Pavilion. – Edited by Billy Klüver, Julie Martin and Barbara Rose. – New York : E. P. Dutton, 1972. – P. 285-320
318.text:
John Forkner:

Programming the Pavilion Dome as a Giant Light Machine

	General: There is an interesting possibility of transforming the entire Mirror dame into a giant light machine, The visual and audio effects produced would be under direct, live control of performers (and/or audience) moving over the surface of a large, flexible mirror located either in the Clam Room or on the main floor. The deflection of light generated by the performers' motions distorting the mirror would produce moving patterns of light passing over the audience on the main floor-visible to them on each other and also as imaged in the dome. In addition, the patterns of light would be sensed by a number of photodetectors placed around the dome floor, and the signals received would be used to produce or control sounds within the dome. Thus, both sound and light would be controlled by the performers, and the audience itself would in a sense be the screen for the projected light.

	Optics: The physical basis for generating the visual effects lies in the focusing properties of a spherical mirror. An intense light source would be placed halfway between the center of the spherical dome and the top (the infinity of focus), and under these conditions the dome would serve as a huge searchlight reflector creating a broad column of parallel light. This shaft of light would descend through the large glass window in the main floor and pass into the Clam Room. An area of the Clam Room floor equal to the size of the window would be covered by plastic mirror material supported on a flexible base (foam rubber or similar material). If undisturbed, this basically flat mirror would return the column of light back through the Clam Room ceiling window and onto the dome surface, where the dome would refocus the light again near the original source. After passing through this second focus, the light would then spread out over the entire floor of the dome. Any distortion of the flat mirror on the Clam Room floor such as produced by performers moving over the mirror surface -causes deviations in the arrival of light at the second focal point. Masks and/or colored filters or plastic diffraction gratings placed at this second focus would strongly modify the light as it reaches the dome floor, thereby producing organic patterns of light moving across the audience. Thus the system would function as a large, rather coarse Schlieren optical system, which magnifies the mirror distortions initiated by the performers.
	The same results could be effected with the flexible mirror located above the window in the main floor, however the possibility of involving both floors in the experience seems to be worth pursuing.
	Audio: A very close integration of the sound with the light patterns is possible by installing a number of light-sensing detectors in the dome floor area. The signals from these detectors could he used in several ways: (1) to generate sounds directly, e.g., through voltage-controlled oscillators (frequency of sound proportional to light intensity); (2) to control the local volume and hence the apparent direction of sounds centrally generated (either live or prerecorded, e.g., musicians strolling around flexible mirror producing "mirror-image" sound locations upstairs): (3) to control the permanently installed dome lighting (by suitable shielding of the detectors to discriminate the source of light). By using color filters on the detectors different sound qualities (pitch, timbre, etc.) could be triggered by the colors of the local areas of the moving light patterns.

	Performance (participation): The real-time control of light and
sound permitted by the proposed programming approach suggests various modes of performances: (1) Professional dancers, performing with or without visual feedback to the light patterns that they generate (the patterns on the main floor would be visible as images in the dome as seen through the Clam Room ceiling), visual feedback is easier if the dancers lie on the mirror and slide around its surface; (2) musicians performing with visual and audio feedback from dome (wearing earphones so audience in Clam Room does not hear light-pattern generated sounds in dome, but musicians do); (3) "performer-teachers" who give short series of movement/light/sound demonstrations to Clam Room audience and then invite participation.

322.title: Heavenly Passtime—Year 2000: Kaprow's Proposal for Live Programming
322.ref_bibliographic: «Proposals for Live Programming». – Pavilion. – Edited by Billy Klüver, Julie Martin and Barbara Rose. – New York : E. P. Dutton, 1972. – P. 285-320
322.text:
Allan Kaprow:

Heavenly Passtime—Year 2000

Sphere darkens. Three differently colored, intensely glowing balls of light move at random and at random velocities, over the surface of the sphere. Large dish-shaped mirrors, tilted at various angles, and placed throughout the floor area, reflect the images on the sphere, each other, and the people moving on the floor. A very low, throbbing sound fills the space in steady waves. A voice over the P.A. begins a continuing countdown of seconds: "Minus [p.296] 3, minus 2, minus 1, minus zero" {action begins) "plus 1, plus 2, plus 3, plus 4 ...," until conclusion.(1)
Visitors, equipped with light-beam guns, begin shooting at zero countdown. By aiming at a reflection of a light ball on any mirrored surface, they attempt to destroy the light balls. Direct hits result in huge flashes of light and terrific concussion noises.(2)
At the end of seven minutes of shooting, all sounds and light balls fade out and the houselights come up slowly. The announcer's voice now says (in successive languages perhaps): "Ladies and Gentlemen. You are (say) "Group 239. You have scored 46 direct hits, 122 near-misses. You are 89th on the power scale, since shooting began. Group 105, on May 13th at 1:15 p.m., achieved a record of 67 hits and only 32 near-misses. It is in control. We welcome you to try again." A big scoreboard, such as at ball parks, flashes the records as the visitors file out.(3)

1 It is suggested that balls of light be projected from glass floor in the center of the dome. Low-frequency throbbing sounds may be just above the audible range, but still within the palpable (gut) range. Dish mirrors on the floor may be made of wood with mylar surface.
2 Light-beam guns may be inexpensive, plastic toy flashlights fitted with lenses. The impulse-response system may be photocell type, located in or around projectors on floor. The light from guns pointed at light balls' virtual images will angle back to their sources and will activate the photocells located there to trigger, in turn, the explosion effect. Conversely, shots at so-called real images of the light balls, appearing on either the dishlike mirrors, or in real space, will produce no reaction. If desired, moments when some or all light balls will be "duds," even if directly shot, can be programmed into the switching system. These combined confusions should reduce the odds enough to prevent constant high scoring.
3 The scoreboard may be simply hooked into the traffic-flow computer provided.

323.title: Heavenly Passtime—Year 2000: Letter from Elsa Garmire to Peter Poole, December 12,1969
323.ref_bibliographic: «Proposals for Live Programming». – Pavilion. – Edited by Billy Klüver, Julie Martin and Barbara Rose. – New York : E. P. Dutton, 1972. – P. 285-320
323.text:
I spent the afternoon talking to Allan Kaprow. He has some good ideas about light games in the dome. I did some modifying of his ideas for technical reasons and we still don't have all the ramifications worked out, but the basic idea is sound technically and exciting. [p.297]
Our idea is to use roving light-globe sources, located above people's heads. On the side of the globes, facing the dome, would be photo- detectors. Only by "shooting" flashlights at the mirror, rather than the object, would a hit be recorded—or vice versa.
The only remaining technical question is how to propel the light sources. We've considered small "blimps," or suspending them on pulleys strung across from the three light holes. These would be no great weight and shouldn't pose any problem.
Sound system can be programmed to react to a hit, picked up by photodetector.
We also talked a great deal about what to do for the people waiting outside. He's got some very good ideas involving sound. Will there be, or could there be, speakers outside?

258.name: Something Like a Fifteen-Minute Solar Eclipse

324.title: Something Like a Fifteen-Minute Solar Eclipse: Kosugi's Proposal for Live Programming
324.ref_bibliographic: «Proposals for Live Programming». – Pavilion. – Edited by Billy Klüver, Julie Martin and Barbara Rose. – New York : E. P. Dutton, 1972. – P. 285-320
324.text:
Takehisa Kosugi: 
Something Like a Fifteen-Minute Solar Eclipse

This is a programming of light and sounds repeated every fifteen minutes. With partial participation of visitors to the performance, the programming will be altered at any time.
In one cycle of the process, the proposer is intending to let visitors experience an environmental event of light and sound effects that will occur in phenomena that change little by little—something like a fifteen-minute solar eclipse.
Following are the details of the programs. These programs will be carried on simultaneously, being influenced by one another, light by sounds and sounds by light.

Light Programming I: Facilitating lighting systems in the dome will be changing from brightness to darkness and again to bright- ness like the change of light in a solar eclipse. The time length of one cycle will be fifteen minutes.

Light Programming II: About seven turning lights will be installed in midair. Each, with different colors, light directions, or turning speed, throws a beam into the space.

Light Programming III: Seven visitors will put on, at will, light hats (with turning lights installed, light-weight and controlled by batteries) of different colored lights. In accordance with the visitors' [p.298] movements, sources of light will change freely. As the eclipse comes to its peak, a whirlpool of colored light appears in harmony with lighting effects produced by Light Programming II.

Light Programming IV: As a usual part of programming, lighting of the loop system will be programmed. At the highest point of eclipse, every light seems to shine like a star at night.

Sound Programming I: Music composed by various sounds, which will be picked up from the sound library (such as animal cries, movements, or sounds in our daily lives), will be heard through dome speakers and handsets held by visitors. When it is bright in the dome, the music will be performed as it is, but, as eclipse goes on, the music will be varied. Signals for variation are mainly those produced by Sound Programmings III and IV.

Sound Programming II: Electronic sounds produced by a combination of rf oscillators and receivers, will be played through dome speakers. These sounds will suggest to visitors something like birds' twittering, speeding cars, and other sounds made in our everyday life, and also those strange voices and sounds made by animals. Sometimes very peculiar sounds that have special effects, like sounds from cosmic space, will come through the speakers. Every sound will be tape-recorded stereophonically.

Sound Programming III: About seven CdS cell-controlled sound oscillator transmitters, which will be installed in a condition to react to lights programmed in Light Programming II, will work as a kind of multivibrator. Reacting to the brightness of light, sound frequency will change. Sounds from the speakers will have an effect as sounds themselves, and, at the same time, will be used as signals for sound variation from Sound Programming I.

Sound Programming IV: About seven CdS cell oscillators will be fitted up in hats (operated by batteries, with radio-wave transmitters installed) and will be put on by volunteer visitors. When the visitor with the hat on comes close to a visitor with a light hat of light programming, they will enjoy special effects of light and sound. The sounds in this system will not only be used as music itself, but as a carrier for sound variation, too.

326.title: Dome Works I: Anthony Martin's Proposal for Live Programming
326.ref_bibliographic: «Proposals for Live Programming». – Pavilion. – Edited by Billy Klüver, Julie Martin and Barbara Rose. – New York : E. P. Dutton, 1972. – P. 285-320
326.text:
Anthony Martin:
Dome Works I 
A combination of Water-Light Cycle, Silent Light, Cookery

This proposal is based on a fundamental cycle of one. Within the course of this involution-revolution are various, some optional, strata that are also cycles of activity with durations of one in fifteen minutes to a rapid vibratory beat.
Mode I. Water Cycle: A cloth siphon is rigged under a winch light so that there is a flow of waterdrops down through, or ending at, the focal point of the dome. At the center is placed a transparent receptacle containing one-half inch of water and between one foot and three feet in diameter. A low-power portable laser either argon or helium-neon, one milliwatt is directed upward through the drops and diffused at the top. A, b, and c superspots are directed obliquely into the dish at smallest iris aperture. Spots cross-fade in seven-second intervals.
Some of the results are: an overall reflection of wave forms created by the drops, an expansion and contraction of the drops' image—real image will ascend as it goes through focal length [signe???] and focal point.
Mode II. Vulgar Mode—Light-Cookery: A performer conducts light-cookery on floor, perhaps the berm area for optimum optical usefulness.
Apparatus: (1) reflective buckets, pots having various light sources in them; (2) liquid illuminate (luminol-alkaline-oxidizing solution, which is poured using transparent containers); (3) glow balls are thrown, juggled, rolled; (4) one xenon beam-light used with various reflectors and prisms; (5) one spot, its tilt function externalized through shielded cable and interfaced with photoresistor at end of loop, another spot, its pan mirror function externalized.
Total: four looped wires from console. These are activated by the cook and surrounding visitors using hand-set lights to illuminate the photocells. One ground loop in the performing area is used. This deploys two arcs: a three hundred sixty-degree vertical circular plane and a horizontal plane in the twenty-inch-diameter circumference. [p.302]
Mode III. System Mode: This is the automatic light-sound mode mainly of the vibratory and rotational light (weather) cycle.
Sound: (1) Singing mode. Continuous, melodious voice, very singular clear-tape or live. Like good pop, female or husky but clear! alto-soprano. One source rotates in spiral order on speakers from top to bottom ring and back, cyclic, the rate fluctuates from one to thirty-seven speakers per second. Movement then will change in its rate relationship to top-bottom cycle.
(2) Banging, crashing, thunder mode. Three channels are sound-modified and sent through all speakers, like Paul Bunyan or Toshiro Mifune crashing through a wood.
(3) Electric Bass, live or taped, interfaced with a photocell activated by lights in minutes one through five and twelve through fifteen of the cycle. Gong and finger cymbals are also photocell-gated.
Mode IV. Silent Mode: Basic Cycle Alternates: (1) cookery replaces water cycle; (2) water cycle replaces vibratory light cycle and cookery is placed in center of cycle; (3) no use of cookery; (4) pendulum lights.
The use of the Pavilion in this proposal will have a very wide dynamic range, especially the visual results of the cycle. The object is to have as much transmutation of the environment and as much observation and response of the visitors as possible in the basic cycle of fifteen minutes. It doesn't matter when people enter into the activity; there will be a transmutation of the space in any seven-to twenty-minute stay.

329.title: A-OK: Pauline Oliveros and Lynn Lonidier's Proposal for Live Programming
329.ref_bibliographic: «Proposals for Live Programming». – Pavilion. – Edited by Billy Klüver, Julie Martin and Barbara Rose. – New York : E. P. Dutton, 1972. – P. 285-320
329.text:
Pauline Oliveros and Lynn Lonidier:
A-OK

The audience is seated in a circle. Four loudspeakers are located in the four corners of the space in back of the audience. The speakers will receive material from a tape-delay system.

Entrances: 1. Accordionist to revolving platform in center of space. Four people will manually rotate the platform. First ring.
2. Violinists enter and form second ring, faces toward audience. They do not play while waiting.
3. Chorus enters and forms third ring, faces toward audience.
4. Conductors enter, each with his own, a 440 (or 220) tuning fork and form fourth ring. They face center. Chief conductor signals beginning. Resonate tuning forks on floor successively.

Beginning: Violinists, on cue from chief conductor, tune scordatura a e a e. Do not play anything other than necessary tuning notes. Continue to sound a's and e's. When chorus has entered (singing), begin repetitive patterns on a. Gradually add tremolo. Use single notes and/or double and triple steps. Mix in long-held
notes. After approximately ten minutes, "hoedowns" in A may begin. Watch for cues for your ring to make a revolution to the left or right. Chorus, on cue from chief conductor, begins to sound an a, 440 or 220. Use syllable "Ah," long tones. After approximately three minutes begin chants on a, try to follow your conductor. Any abstract syllables are permissible. After approximately 15 minutes, [p.305] individual melodic lines on a are permissible. Watch for cues for your ring to make a revolution to the left or right.

Conductors: Continue to resonate tuning forks until the violinists are in tune. On cue from chief conductor begin to sound an a, 440 or 220 or 110. Use syllable "Ah," long tones. When chief conductor introduces chorus, try to influence some of them to sing with you. After approximately three minutes, begin chants on a using abstract syllables. Influence your group. When all rings have their sound well established, the chief conductor may then try to induce his section of the audience to sing. Always keep the key of A. Watch for cues for your ring to make a revolution to the left or right.
One person in each ring is responsible for revolutions. Revolutions should start and stop and change directions during the course of the piece.

Accordion: Begin to play a 440 with right hand after tuning forks are sounding. When all groups are sounding, add left hand a. Make a continuous drone. Gradually add tremolos and octave registrations. Add e's. Make accents and occasional dissonances. Try to influence tempos. Pace yourself for twenty minutes. After approximately fifteen minutes, play melodic lines in the key of A. Always continue the drone. The piece is over when the accordionist stops playing. Exits will be in reverse order on cue from the chief conductor.

Tape-Delay System: Suspend microphones over center for optimum pickup of accordion. Use directional microphones. After about five minutes, introduce Channel A of tape recorder 2 gradually. At seven minutes, introduce Channel B of tape recorder 2. After ten minutes, introduce Channels A and B of tape recorder 1 and the feedback loops. Avoid sudden gains or losses. Do not let playback volume exceed performers' volume. Place supply reel on tape recorder 1 (recording) and take up reel on tape recorder 2. Recorders should be about twenty-one inches apart.

Lighting for A-OK: The Spectrum Circle: The spectrum circle utilizes all potential light sources passing through a spectrum of colors, or as many color changes as feasible. A complete color [306] change must occur gradually (about every two minutes) through such devices as rheostats and/or color wheels.
As the tuning forks begin sounding, ordinary house-lighting (white) gradates to yellow. The entire performance area, including [307] audience, is bathed in yellow, then green, to blue to purple to red to orange to yellow to white at end of performance.
As color changes occur, reflections from tiny mirrors mounted on the accordionist's platform will revolve around the performance space, off the walls, etc.
Outside the performance area, globe-shaped frosted-light sources could illuminate colors continuously running through the spectrum for the diversion of waiting visitors.
Other kinds of performing groups could form new circles within the piece. I.e., a circle of children, karate, theatre, etc. Perhaps violinists could come from the famous Suzuki school. Conductors can make any kind of kinetic action to induce performers to sing. The audience is gradually included.
All or part of the sound could be piped outside to waiting visitors.
The accordionist would be yours truly. Performance time: twelve to fifteen minutes ok.

365.title: Loewen on Oliveros' program for Live Programming
365.ref_bibliographic: Loewen, Norma. “Experiments in Art and Technology: A Descriptive History of the Organization”. New York University, 1975.
365.text: Oliveros had composed "Pep-Psi," which was heard as a recording of mantras performed by two Chinese girls. The hostesses were invited to sing with the recording and to direct visitors in exploring the sound properties of the dome space.
