330.title: Tape-Delay Feedback System: Terry Riley's Proposal for Live Programming
330.ref_bibliographic: «Proposals for Live Programming». – Pavilion. – Edited by Billy Klüver, Julie Martin and Barbara Rose. – New York : E. P. Dutton, 1972. – P. 285-320
330.text:
Terry Riley:
Tape-Delay Feedback System

This would be a tape system that could be used with electronic and prerecorded sound as well as with some kinds of live performance and sound sampling from within the Pavilion. The delay system could be set up in the following ways:
1. A number of tape recorders (2-4) are set up in a row so that the tape can be threaded from machine to machine passing over all the heads of all the machines. The outputs from machines 2, 3, and 4 are returned to a stereo output mixer; one output from the mixer is returned to the record mode of machine 1 to feed back in combination on the same channel with the other incoming information; the other output from the mixer goes directly on to the amplification and sound-modification stages along with the output of channel 1 of the first machine.
2. Instead of using all the tape recorders, it would be possible to mount a number of tape heads on a board to be placed between two tape recorders. The capstans and transports of the two machines would drive the tape across the tape heads, which are aligned to play back in ensemble with the two tape recorders. The tape heads are then fed into preamps and then into the mixer either to go directly to the amplification stages or to be fed back to tape recorder 1. With this system it is possible to get more flexibility in sound as the azimuth of the tape heads can be altered to reproduce a pure or a funky version of the original signal.
Each tape head could trigger a program sequence that could correspond to the time interval between tape heads so that the information could move around the speaker matrix in cyclical patterns relating to those being set up by the tape-head series. This system could be used in conjunction with any sound program: live, electronic or prerecorded. In relation to this system, a shorter-period delay system could be very effective in creating multiple spatial echo effects.
Set up five tape recorders recording at the following speeds: l5/u, 1%, 3%, 71/2 and 15 ips. Each tape recorder receives the same input source, which is also fed directly to an amplification stage. Outputs from all five tape recorders are fed to a mixer and [p.310] to five channels that can become delay periods to the original signal. By changing spatial relationships between speakers and delays, a myriad of echoes can be produced. To get periods in between the standard tape speeds, some of the recorders could be driven by oscillators or perhaps some variable-speed tape recorders could be obtained. I would use these tape-delay systems to create dense integrated networks of repeated patterns undergoing gradual change. In addition, I should like personally to perform some of my organ works designed especially for these systems. The overall sonic feeling in the dome would be one of subtle change within an essentially static framework of sound. The cost of the project would only be that of obtaining tape recorders or tape heads and preamplifiers and mixers.

332.title: Facts: Yuji Takahashi's Proposal for Live Programming
332.ref_bibliographic: «Proposals for Live Programming». – Pavilion. – Edited by Billy Klüver, Julie Martin and Barbara Rose. – New York : E. P. Dutton, 1972. – P. 285-320
332.text:
Facts: Artists today are obliged to make use of the cultural ruins: theatres, galleries, concert halls, buildings, streets, etc., which had their meanings once. The newborn places are mostly infected by conventions. The form that satisfies artistic necessity is still to be found.
	Meanwhile, the first task of artists would be to transform the given facts and give the same constituents a different meaning. At the same time, the composition will become more abstract and independent from the actual components.

334.title: Vision: Yuji Takahashi's Proposal for Live Programming
334.ref_bibliographic: «Proposals for Live Programming». – Pavilion. – Edited by Billy Klüver, Julie Martin and Barbara Rose. – New York : E. P. Dutton, 1972. – P. 285-320
334.text:
Vision: Without using any objects, create a labyrinth. The materials are lights and the spectators themselves. The lights scintillate rather than illuminate. Avoid stable images produced with light effects, only the afterimages count. Create a stochastic flow of the spectators using lights.
The distribution of lights is computed with a STLP1 program. The place should have strict nonhuman atmosphere.

336.title: Paper Events: Yoshiaki Tono's Proposal for Live Programming
336.ref_bibliographic: «Proposals for Live Programming». – Pavilion. – Edited by Billy Klüver, Julie Martin and Barbara Rose. – New York : E. P. Dutton, 1972. – P. 285-320
336.text:
Yoshiaki Tono:
Paper Events

This is a drama that would be performed by a group of graduates and undergraduates (Akira Koshlmizu, Katsuro Yoshida, Noriko Kon, Honda, and seven or eight others) from Tama College of Arts. The drama would be aimed at the involvement of human beings in two very contradictory worlds.
On the stage, a huge cube made of Japanese paper would be transformed into various forms in accordance with the direction and velocity of wind, humidity, gravity, and other physical properties of the changing environment. The paper storm would finally take over the stage, on which people are Involved in Paper Events. And, thus, the dialogue between paper and people would go on in various manners.
A conflicting drama, between the highly structured and artificial world of technology and the fierce and coarse world of nature, is expected to develop in the very technological space of the Pavilion.
Big straw ropes, thick hemp cloths, long chains, huge logs of wood, heavy rocks, and other things, which are very unsophisticated and crude materials, would also be employed to add a clear contrast to the environment.

272.name: Yoshio Tsukio's Proposal for Live Programming

337.title: Yoshio Tsukio's Proposal for Live Programming
337.ref_bibliographic: «Proposals for Live Programming». – Pavilion. – Edited by Billy Klüver, Julie Martin and Barbara Rose. – New York : E. P. Dutton, 1972. – P. 285-320
337.text:
Yoshio Tsukio

In order to encourage more active participation of the visitors, the following three types of devices are introduced. The direct expression of visitors is emphasized in real time.

1. Moving Mirror (two types, two of each or more): Introduce on the floor two types of movable, cast-acrylic mirror, convex and concave, one-meter diameter, mirrorized by aluminum vacuum-plating. The focal distance of these mirrors should be equal to that of the dome (f = 7.07 meters), thus even a slight change of position will change the image abruptly. By using a half-mirror effect, not only the reflective image but the effect of light transparency can be obtained depending on the angle of vision of visitors. Mirrors would be on movable platforms and visitors could move them around. By doing so, the real-and virtual-image effects of the Mirror dome will be emphasized and played up.

2. Thermo-Responsor (three or more): Several black balls coated with cholesteric liquid crystal would be hung from the ceil- ing at reachable distances for visitors. Cholesteric liquid crystal is sensitive to delicate changes of temperature in its surrounding air. It will change colors (high temperature to low temperature—purple, blue, green, yellow, orange, red, black) denoting in real time the condition inside the dome. For instance, if the dome is crowded and temperature inside the dome rises, or if a visitor breathes upon or touches it with a hand, the color will change in response.

3. Time Balloon (three types, three each or more): Prepare [p.315] chairs with built-in bellows connected by hose to balloons. Every time a visitor sits on it, the balloon swells. The balloons are of three types, adjusted to be blown full in fifteen minutes, twenty-four hours, or one month (duration of one programming period). The fifteen-minute-type and twenty-four-hour-type balloons are taken off the hose when they become full and set free to drift inside the dome space. Each day about thirty balloons will accumulate and little by little fill the dome, giving a homogeneous and continuous change to the space.

338.title: Yoshimura and Performers: Masanobu Yoshimura's Proposal for Live Programming
338.ref_bibliographic: «Proposals for Live Programming». – Pavilion. – Edited by Billy Klüver, Julie Martin and Barbara Rose. – New York : E. P. Dutton, 1972. – P. 285-320
338.text:
Masanobu Yoshimura:
"Yoshimura and Performers"

Cast: Masanobu Yoshimura, Onishi Kiyoji, Higuchi Seiichiro, Kobayashi Hakudo.

1. Program using chemical change and information of voices talking: Candles are made specially, and visitors grasp them. In the wicks of the candles several kinds of chemical substances that cause changes in flame color (i.e., sodium [Na]—yellow, cesium [Cs]—light blue, etc.) are put at different levels, and approximately eight changes in flame color occur during ten to twelve minutes burning. The dome is set up to reflect the flame color and the direction of colorful light. In the same manner, let the number and quality of visitors be information and the programming of the sound is done only by voices talking, and the sound movement is directed.

2. Program using bouncing balls: Spread mirror-film on the floor, let the whole dome become mirrorized. Bring in a silicone ball ejector. The light and sound (bouncing sound) program is controlled by silicone balls, which has high bouncing index. Visitors would participate in bouncing the balls. Bouncing gradually builds up to supersaturation condition. Simultaneously sumo wrestlers would perform on the trampoline.

3. Life in the capsule and in the space: Fantastic arena of space travel is produced by light and sound. Starlight, light stream of rockets in flight. Strobe light and other auxiliary lamps can be [p.316] used to produce a space event such as the collision of shooting stars. Sound should be documentary.
By the use of dry-Ice fog, a metamorphosis of light environment is produced. Sucking of fog by vacuum cleaner. Along with light and sound effect, heterogeneous space is created.
Projection of aged people on pneumatic object in midspace. Gradually, their ages retrogress and they become younger, returning to babies and to embryos in the end. The sound from the loops gradually changes over to a baby's cry.
The object in midair reveals itself entirely. It is a huge helium balloon in the shape of an embryo.
Between the legs of a giant woman object, performers and hostesses slide down a slide. Visitors would participate.

4. Measuring of the Mirror dome by trampoline and Zen priests' chorus: Players—students from local schools of athletics, and others, with rainbow suits on and beam-light electric torches in their hands—will jump on a trampoline. The movements of their real and virtual ¡mages will be reflected by the Mirror and reflecting beam-lights will involve visitors to the dome in the events.
In the center of the dome space, Zen priests will sit in religious meditation (zazen) and pray together in chorus. Smells and smoke of senko (incense stick) overspread the dome space.

Tape Sounds—(1) Number-counting in different languages (Japanese, English, French, German, Spanish, Russian, and so on). Voices in various languages will be heard from each channel of speakers with variations of loudness. (2) Flowing, running, and hissing sounds (concrete sounds plus electric sounds).

274.name: Sound Structure [La Monte Young, Marian Zazeela, and Robert Adler]

339.title: Sound Structure: La Monte Young and Marian Zazeela's Proposal for Live Programming
339.ref_bibliographic: «Proposals for Live Programming». – Pavilion. – Edited by Billy Klüver, Julie Martin and Barbara Rose. – New York : E. P. Dutton, 1972. – P. 285-320
339.text:
La Monte Young, Marian Zazeela, and Robert Adler

1. Sound Structure: La Monte Young and Marian Zazeela propose to make a special adaptation of their major work Map of 49's Dream The Two Systems of Eleven Sets of Galactic Intervals Ornamental Lightyears Tracery. This adaptation will utilize both the dome speakers and floor handsets. Sound sources will include sine-wave oscillators tuned to intervals, triads, and chords [p.317] selected from specific categories of The Two Systems of Eleven Categories 1:07:40 AM3X 67- .
Sine waves have the unique characteristic among sound-wave forms of having only one frequency component. All other sound- wave forms have more than one frequency component. When a continuous frequency is sounded in an enclosed space such as a room, the air in the room is arranged into high- and low-pressure areas. In the high-pressure areas the sound is louder, and in the low-pressure areas the sound is softer. Since a sine wave has only one frequency component, the pattern of high-and low-pressure areas is easy to locate in space. Further, concurrently sounding sine waves of different frequencies will provide an environment in which the loudness of each frequency will vary audibly at different points in the room, given sufficient amplification. This phenomenon can rarely be appreciated in most musical situations, and makes the listener's position and movement in space an integral part of the sound composition.
Additionally, if small, Robert Adler helium-filled balloons can be inflated to exactly the proper pressure, they will become neutrally buoyant and may be supported by the areas of greatest variation of molecular density or air pressure of the standing waves in the dome, that is, at the points where the sound is loudest, and creates visible patterns outlining these aspects of the standing waves.
The sine waves will be produced by all thirty-seven loudspeakers, and by the handsets, in various multichannel combinations, in such a way that frequencies on each individual set will combine with those on other sets, and with a drone frequency produced by the dome loudspeakers, to produce different preferred combinations from The Two Systems of Eleven Categories depending on the proximities of the different handsets.
The lights on the handsets will be controlled, and the controls tuned to pulse on and off at frequencies which may be represented as factors related to the sine waves by powers of two. By using the higher powers of two, and gauging the length of the on-pulse, it will be possible to make certain that a bulb does not use up more than its three-minute life-span within the maximum period it will be in use. [p.318]
Following the reflection motif already established in the mirrored dome, we will use a drone frequency at one of the simple harmonic resonances of the dome for some periods of the duration of the installation in order to obtain maximum sound reflectivity. Since The Two Systems of Eleven Categories uses only harmonically related frequencies we will determine a structure that best reinforces as many of the harmonic resonant frequencies of the dome as possible.
To realize Map of 49's Dream The Two Systems of Eleven Sets of Galactic Intervals Ornamental Lightyears Tracery, La Monte will bring his Moog synthesizer, and additional sine-wave generators and oscilloscopes. It would be helpful if the Pavilion could provide more highly stable, continuously variable-frequency sine-wave generators (with phase-lock and/or trigger-lock functions) and additional oscilloscopes, and if possible frequency counters capable of displaying ratio comparisons between two sine waves.
In addition to the sine-wave inputs, from time to time La Monte and Marian will sing live multichannel performances of sections of Map of 49's Dream The Two Systems of Eleven Sets of Galactic Intervals Ornamental Lightyears Tracery over the sine-wave drone and the harmonically related sine waves. Since Robert Adler has been chief engineer on the electronic and acoustical development of this work since the inception of The Tortoise, His Dreams and Journeys in 1964, he will be in charge of the technical setup of this aspect of the work.
Prerecorded tapes of our compositions will be a third source of inputs, some of which we will also be able to sing with.

340.title: Light Structure: La Monte Young, Marian Zazeela, and Robert Adler's Proposal for Live Programming
340.ref_bibliographic: «Proposals for Live Programming». – Pavilion. – Edited by Billy Klüver, Julie Martin and Barbara Rose. – New York : E. P. Dutton, 1972. – P. 285-320
340.text:
2. Light Structure: The two aspects which comprise the light works associated with Map of 49's Dream The Two Systems of Eleven Sets of Galactic Intervals Ornamental Lightyears Tracery will be uniquely demonstrated in the spherical Mirror dome.

a) The slide projections are made up of numerous black-and-white, negative and positive photographs of modular sections of several closely related designs. Each slide mount holds a photograph and a combination of colored gels. These design and color elements are combined into interlocking groups whose sequence, duration of appearance, and manipulation within the parameters [p.319] made available by the functions of the machines (i.e., focus, brilliance, color intensity) will be programmed to shift slowly in time. The machines are usually programmed in groups of three; they will be placed in triads around the perimeter of the dome and focused down onto the spectators, who will see the real images of the patterns on themselves reflected in the dome. Since the slides are symmetrical abstract designs, their real images will not appear inverted but will match the originals.
At other times the slides will be focused on the Dennis Johnson polytopic shapes and the Robert Adler balloon configurations, each of which will provide a different surface, and the possibility of other interesting effects.

b) Another work exploits the inherent properties of colored light mixtures combined with specific forms to produce a fluid, variable environment which appears to contain self-luminous colored bodies freely suspended in an atmosphere of continually moving calligraphic strokes. This will be created by the deployment of floating mobile sculptures hung in symmetrical arrangements from points on the dome, and illuminated by dichroic filtered light sources at angles necessary to cast multiple colored shadows of the mobiles down onto the floor and the heads of spectators. These patterns will in turn be reflected in the dome to create real images in space.
The mobiles will be cut out of light-weight aluminum sheet, painted white, and weigh only a few ounces. The slight air currents generated by the movement of people through the Pavilion will be sufficient to keep each mobile slowly shifting around its suspension axis, creating continually moving patterns of its shadows. Some lights will also be placed below the mobiles, and the shadows will be cast onto the balloon configurations and suspended polytopes. The mobiles will reflect the lights in such a way that spectators below will see brilliantly illuminated shapes slowly changing color as the suspended form moves and reflects a different dichroic source.
Dichroic filters can be obtained for three hundred-watt quartz spotlights, which will produce very intense, near-pure colors. They can be mounted about the perimeter of the floor area of the [p.320] dome and fixed in position so that only the on-off function need be controlled from the booth.

c) A third proposal for the lights provides a method for color-cod- ing the transitions of groups of people through the Pavilion. An estimate must be made of the maximum number of people who will go through the Pavilion each fifteen minutes. Each time the handset is returned to the entrance gate, the bulb color (or a plastic filter clipped onto a flashlight) is changed.
Thus, the gradual shift in colors will indicate the time it takes people to visit the Pavilion. A natural flow of color sequences will appear and be reflected in the dome. The color shift may even place a kind of psychological pressure on people to move on as they begin to notice they have the only turquoise light in a sea of blues. A possible color sequence would follow the spectral order, i.e., red, orange, yellow, yellow-green, green, turquoise, blue, violet. Probably eight different colors would be sufficient to cover the maximum time periods anyone might spend in the Pavilion, so that after two hours the color sequence would begin again.

352.title: Tomkins on the rehearsal of Charlip's Homage to Loie Fuller
352.ref_bibliographic: Tomkins, Calvin. – «Outside art». – Pavilion. – Edited by Billy Klüver, Julie Martin and Barbara Rose. – New York : E. P. Dutton, 1972. – P. 105-172.
352.text:
The programmer for this lead-off event was Remy Charlip, an artist, designer, and theatre director best known for his work in the field of children's theatre (he was a founder of the Paper Bag Players, in New York). Charlip had made up several large squares of bright-colored, very thin China silk, which the participants in his program (in this case, EAT. wives, girl friends, and female staff members) held by the corners and lifted, so as to make them billow and float. The reflections were colorful, but Martin and several others felt that they did not exploit the Mirror's extraordinary properties to best advantage. For the sound accompaniment to his piece (which he had decided to call Homage to Loie Fuller), Charlip had made a tape recording of his own breathing. Amplified over thirty-seven loudspeakers that were mounted in a rhomboid grid behind the mirror walls, it sounded very much like a man breathing into a tape recorder.
While Charlip rehearsed, the engineers continued to work on the sound system.

361.title: Loewen on Live Programming
361.ref_bibliographic: Loewen, Norma. “Experiments in Art and Technology: A Descriptive History of the Organization”. New York University, 1975.
361.text: During the first five weeks of the pavilion's operation, programming was performed by 10 resident programmers, 8 from the United States, 2 from Japan. Those appearing were Remy Charlip, Lowell Cross, Jacquelyn Farrell and Harry Harper (following through a proposal first submitted by Lisa Forbes and Roger Payne), Takumi Hijikata, Anthony Martin, Rikuro Miyai, Pauline Oliveros and Lynn Lonidier, and David Tudor.

354.title: Opening spectacular
354.ref_bibliographic: Live programming : Pepsi pavilion : Expo 70. — New York : [Experiments in Art and Technology], [November 26, 1969]. — [9] p. — Projects description.
354.text:
LIVE -PROGRAMMING: PEPSI PAVILION, EXPO '70    	11/26/1969

"OPENING SPECTACULAR"

This program will include highlights from proposals which have already been submitted.

The program is in 8 sections (see below). Transition from one section to the next will be instantaneous and dramatic.

A poet will write a description, both artistic and technical, about what is taking place. This will be heard over the loop system, e.g. "It is now Spring ... streams full from melting snows ..." The sound of water gurgling and rushing will come over the sound system. To create the impression of actual passage of water, different speakers will transmit different water sounds.
Technical information on how this is done will be given over the loop-system.

PROGRAM OUTLINE

1. Spring : Remy Charlip. The dome is green. Sounds of water rushing, birds, rain.
2. Summer: Alan Kaprow. The dome is golden. Sounds of the beach, children playing, farm machinery.
3. Autumn: Jerome Robbins. The dome is red/russet. Sounds of birds migrating, wild geese, a harvest festival.
4. Winter: La Monte Young. The dome is blue-white. Sounds of cold winds, breaking ice.
5. Earth : John Hassell, sound-modification composer. Sounds of earthquakes, an avalanche, body-sounds, heartbeats.
6. Air: Terry Riley, wind-instruments composer. Sounds of air, wind, jet-plane.
7. Fire: Ann Halprin. Temperamental violence. Sounds of fire. Flames in the dome.
8. Water: Whale People. The dome is blue/green - dim, under-water. Sounds of water dripping, songs of whales.

353.title: Tomkins on the the E.A.T. girls playing with Charlip's silk scarves (Pepsi Pavilion press preview )
353.ref_bibliographic: Tomkins, Calvin. – «Outside art». – Pavilion. – Edited by Billy Klüver, Julie Martin and Barbara Rose. – New York : E. P. Dutton, 1972. – P. 105-172.
353.text: In spite of these misfortunes, the press preview took place as scheduled, beginning at 1:30 p.m. on March 11. Owens, clinging for an hour to 8 rope ladder suspended through the winch-light opening, had patched the rip in the Mirror. The balloon was tight again, and was casting real and virtual images in profusion. The presence of a large number of people in the Mirror dome added a new element of animation, which greatly pleased Whitman and Breer. Half a dozen hostesses in bright-red maxicoats and red cloches had been stationed at intervals around the perimeter, and their reflections lent a festive note to the scene. The trouble was that very few of the visitors ever looked up into the Mirror. Handsets held to one ear, they walked around looking down at the variously textured floor sections, or else they watched the E.A.T. girls playing with Charlip's silk scarves.

360.title: Whale Experience: Lisa Forbes and Roger Payne's Proposal for Live Programming
360.ref_bibliographic: «Proposals for Live Programming». – Pavilion. – Edited by Billy Klüver, Julie Martin and Barbara Rose. – New York : E. P. Dutton, 1972. – P. 285-320
360.text:
Harry Harper and Jacquelyn Farrell:
Whale Experience (First submitted by Lisa Forbes and Roger Payne) [p.393]

1. Announcement over handsets saying that the world, especially as demonstrated in the Pavilion, is full of incredible sounds, many of which the listener has just heard; now we introduce a group of sounds that can be heard and experienced nowhere in the world outside the Pavilion. Before now these sounds have only been heard by whales at sea.

2. Sound: Pure sea, open ocean, immersion sound.
Lights: White, quite bright, ¡mage projected onto floor simulating the shimmer of light on water as seen from just below the surface; this is achieved by projecting light through clear container of agitated water.

3. Sound: Point sound, singing whale approaching gradually. Line sound possible, used to indicate slight variations in position of whale as he approaches more or less directly. Pure ocean sounds continue on all other speakers except the speakers where individual whales are introduced.
Lights: Begin gradual dimming, which should continue until darkness is very deep, about three-quarters through total whale program.

4. Sound: Second singing whale is introduced moving in a distant arc, then gradually moving closer.

5. Lights: Slightly before dome reaches maximum darkness, random flickering of hand-set lights begins. Individuals may conceive of having completed a descent in the ocean to the point known as the deep-scattering layer, which is inhabited by luminescent fish.

6. Sound: Use of line and point sound to simulate the following activities: whales swimming closer and closer, singing to each other; one of the whales arrives in the area first. By moving sound rapidly to top of dome, the leap of a humpback whale can be experienced. Sound is cut off suddenly at topmost speaker, followed by two to three seconds of open ocean immersion sound. The jump is concluded when massive tape-recorded sounds of whale reimmersing are splashed over topmost speakers. The first whale, having completed his leap, moves gradually away from the [p.394] area. The second whale moves closer and closer until his song is heard as a very loud total-immersion sound. After four to five seconds, the whale begins to depart from this area.

7. Sound: Aurally documents ascent.
Lights: As the second whale is departing, lights are programmed in reverse of the order described above so that a relatively rapid ascent through the water is simulated.

8. Program is completed when light and sea sounds simulate a return to the level just below the ocean's surface.

547.title: Norma Loewen on TV Dinner: Hommage to E.A.T. (food for thought)
547.ref_bibliographic: Loewen, Norma. “Experiments in Art and Technology: A Descriptive History of the Organization”. New York University, 1975.
547.text:
One of the first special projects was part of "Contemporary Voices in the Arts," a series of performances on college campuses upstate New York sponsored by the New York State Council on the Arts. The project concluded the series in New York City at the YM/YWHA on Ninety-second Street and Lexington Avenue, February 25, 1967. Called "Homage to E.A.T." or "TV Banner," it was an electronically amplified television dinner and panel discussion. The discussion at the dinner table included John Cage, Bobert Creeley, Merce Cunningham, Billy Klüver, Len Lye, Jack Tworkov, and Stan VanDerBeek. Sound switching, television projection, proportional control of projectors, and other technical elements were the work of Per Biorn, Ralph Flynn, Jim HcGee, Jim McGee, Jr., Leonard Bobinson, Bruce Robinson, Fred Waldhauer, and Dick Wolff.
A friend of E.A.T. at one of E.A.T.'s board meetings later said he had heard poor reviews of the event and cautioned E.A.T. to be careful of the caliber of their programs or they might be out of business before being established. (*)
Several persons recall that the event did bring together artists and engineers, which was new for some, but did not have anything new otherwise, technically or aesthetically. There were many technical difficulties with the equipment, which did not seem to bother some of the engineers. Some of the artists wondered why it didn't and why these difficulties had arisen since they had been successfully doing similar things by themselves in the past. When a projection screen happened to fall on the audience, as Jim McGee recalls, the angry audience stood up to yell and throw coins on stage until captured by John Cage (*). Cage had proceeded to play his "fish," a suspended piece of metal rapped to give unusual sounds, for which he received a standing ovation.

(*) Minutes of E.A.T.'s board meeting at Robert Rauschenberg's place, March 6, 1967.
(*) Telephone interview, December 4, 1973.

614.title: Matching procedures in 1968
614.ref_bibliographic: E.A.T. operations and information. No. 1 (Nov. 1, 1968). New York : Experiments in Art and Technology, 1968. 10 p.
614.text:
A.1. MATCHINGS
Matching procedures are currently being revised. The new matching procedure will be as follows: You will be sent the names, addresses, and occupations of up to three technical persons in your immediate area (unless you state that you are prepared to collaborate by mail if there is no one nearby). In some cases only one technical person may be available, or none at all, in which case the project will be kept on an open file and you will be notified.
Hopefully one of the technical persons will be able to collaborate with you. Contact them in your order of preference and discuss the possibilities of collaboration. The technical persons will not be notified about the project, so there is no need to contact the second or third if the first one leads to a working collaboration.
After making contact, could you mail back the E.A.T. Collaboration Information cards (an example is enclosed). This is the only way we can know whether or not a collaboration is taking place, and whether the technical persons whose names were sent are subsequently preoccupied with a collaboration or free to be introduced to someone else.
If, in the past, you submitted a proposal which was not matched, could you let us know whether it is still viable. If not, could you use the enclosed project proposal form either to describe it in its new form, or to describe any new project you might wish to submit for collaboration.

617.title: Cover of the Catalogue Robert Whitman Local Report
617.ref_bibliographic: Martin, Julie, ed., Robert Whitman Local Report. Berkely Heights, NJ and Easton PA, NJ: Experiments in Art and Technology, and Lafayette College Williams Center Art Gallery, 2007.

618.title: Project Description of Local Report
618.text:
Local Report is the latest in a series of communication media works that Robert Whitman has produced since 1972.

The basic structure of these works was for 30 people assigned to different parts of the city or calling area to call at five minute intervals and describe something they saw at the moment; these reports were then broadcast live. Whitman put the incoming calls directly on the air as they came in, his only intervention being to end the call when, as he puts it, “The caller has produced a coherent image.” Ninety calls over a thirty minute period produced the final work. The news reports capture the nature of a specific place and time, revealing it to audience and participants alike.

The first performance of this work was titled NEWS and took the form of a live broadcast program in New York City in which participants called in from pay phones; their reports were broadcast live over radio station WBAI. NEWS was performed in Houston, Texas, Minneapolis, Minnesota, and other cities over a two to three year period. Whitman remembers that when he first performed the piece, “Pay phones cost a dime.”

In subsequent performances of this work, Whitman used the latest technology available. In 2002 he worked with cell phones in Leeds, England; the cell phone calls were broadcast in real time on large speakers in a public square in the town. A recording of the resulting sound composition was made available by the sponsor, Lumens, on the internet at UBUweb.

Now in 2005, Whitman continues to explore the newest communication technology: The participants will use camera cell phones to transmit voice and video reports to the central performance site, where information will be played and projected. The reports will be simultaneously streamed live over this website.

While the technology has changed, what has remained constant in these works is that Whitman gets to know the area of the performance and works with local people in each location who know and love their town or area . Whitman uses their reports and descriptions to record and reveal the special nature of each place. Whitman creates with sound--and now with sound and images--a cultural map of a unique locality. Transformed by art, the local becomes universal.

Local Report is being performed in the summer of 2005 in available spaces at five shopping centers in the Northeastern United States. The legacy and promise of the project is to demonstrate not only the possibility of using such public spaces as venues for cultural events and programs, but also that the project can be replicated, that projects can be organized in which individuals -- from school children on up -- can get involved in seeing, describing and ultimately enjoying their own environments in new and more pleasurable ways.

How to run your own Local Report

625.title: Installation of Local Report at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, New York, December 6, 2005
625.ref_bibliographic: Martin, Julie, ed., Robert Whitman Local Report. Berkely Heights, NJ and Easton PA, NJ: Experiments in Art and Technology, and Lafayette College Williams Center Art Gallery, 2007.

626.title: How to create your own Local Report
626.ref_bibliographic: Martin, Julie, ed., Robert Whitman Local Report. Berkely Heights, NJ and Easton PA, NJ: Experiments in Art and Technology, and Lafayette College Williams Center Art Gallery, 2007.
626.text:
How to create your own Local Report

Introduction:

It is very much possible for anyone to run their own Local Report, and it does not take a large scale production in order to make it work. Give time, patience, and resourcefulness, a moderately tech-savvy producer could draw on the resources given here and set up the infrastructure for running Local Reports themselves. At a minimum, running a Local Report requires an internet connection, Voice-over-IP service, a decently capable computer and collaborators with video capable mobile phones (to be reporters). Running the Local Reports as documented in this book required a relatively complicated computer setup since there were many facets to the production. If you want to run your own Local Report, you need not include every aspect of the production in order to have a successful Local Report. For example, your Local Report could be played live on a screen and speakers, then recorded and posted to the website later. In that case, you would not need to set up the streaming infrastructure. Or, you could have the event only displayed live via streaming, in which case you would not need local playback and recording capabilities.

Overview:

The Whitman Local Report was run at 5 locations over the course of 2 months. At each location we had an internet connection, several laptops, a projector and of course 30 "reporters" with mobile phones. The reporters were sent out into the local area with the task of recording video in 20 second snippets which were sent back to the Local Report head-quarters and calling in live with a verbal report as well. At the head-quarters we sequenced the video as it came in and played the audio live when the caller called. We projected this all and played the audio on large speakers for anyone to come and watch. We also streamed it out onto the internet live so anyone anywhere could watch.

Below is a breakdown of the individual pieces that comprised the project presented with the intent to help you produce your own version of the Local Report.

Mobile phones:

For the Whitman Local Report (WLR) we used 30 Nokia 7610 phones. These phones support development using Java 2 Micro Edition (J2ME) and have additional capabilities for video and networking (MIDP 2.0 and MMAPI). Now-a-days these capabilities are common on many handsets and the application that was developed for WLR could be ported to a variety of other models. The basic requirements are a video camera, support for J2ME (with MIDP 2.0 and MMAPI) with video capture.

The source code for the WLR phone application is available online at: http://www.whitmanlocalreport.net/phone/source/

If you are interested in giving it a try before attempting to modify the source, the compiled application can be downloaded directly to your phone and tested by going to the following URL: http://www.whitmanlocalreport.net/phone/Whitman_Mobile_Video.jar

There is one caveat to trying this application out, it is that the sending of the video to the Local Report server requires a data connection through your mobile phone service provider (T-Mobile, Cingular, Verizon..) and use of this data connection might cost you extra depending on your service. You should check these costs before attempting to use the application.

The source for the application can be able to be compiled and installed as is but unless you make some minor modifications, it will upload the video to the Whitman Local Report Server instead of where you might want it to go. The upload URL (HTTP POST) is hard coded into the source.

To change the upload location in the Java source you will need to modify the following line in the WhitmanMVideo.java file and input the correct URL in place of the www.whitmanlocalreport.net/phone/up.php URL: HTTPPoster poster = new HTTPPoster("http://www.whitmanlocalreport.net/phone/up.php", "post.3gp", videoBytes);

If you try the application out without modifying the source, you should be able to find the video you upload by going to: http://www.whitmanlocalreport.net/videos/

Last, this application has a couple of features/bugs/items on the to do list. We welcome any modifications or contributions back to the source should you be interested in helping out. Ok, here is the list:

1: The status indication for uploads does not accurately indicate the progress of the file upload. This is unfortunately a limitation in the Java platform on mobile devices.

2: The videos are not saved on the device. There is an attempt to utilize a "record store" to do such but it's implementation is not complete and does not function correctly.

Again with the caveat, this application requires the use of a data connection on the phone from your mobile provider. If you do not have a plan to encompasses data use you will generally be paying a premium for the service. Second, video files are generally fairly large and can eat up your allowed data usage. In other words, BE CAREFUL with how you use this until you know what it will cost.

Video Reception:

The mobile phone application uses HTTP file upload capabilities to send the video to a web server on the internet. The following very basic (and very insecure) PHP script can be used to receive the video files sent from the phone:

<? $uploadfilename = time() . "_" . rand(1000,9999) . "_" . basename($_FILES['bytes']['name']); $uploaddir = '/xxxx/xxxx/xxxx/videos/'; $uploadfile = $uploaddir . $uploadfilename; if (move_uploaded_file($_FILES['bytes']['tmp_name'], $uploadfile)) { echo "Video Sent!"; } else { echo "Error: Video Not Sent!"; } ?>

In order to use the above script, you should put the code in a text file with the extension ".php". You should also change the line that starts with "$uploaddir" to point to the location you want the video files saved on your server. You will need a webserver that can run PHP scripts and this script will have to be placed somewhere that is web accessible (you probably want it in location that you are pointing to with the mobile phone application).

Video Playback Application:

Onsite at each location we had a laptop hooked up to a projector that ran an application to play back the videos full screen as they came in from the server. This application is actually two applications, the first is called "rsync", which is an application for synchronizing files across a network. Rsync was running on the server as a "daemon", meaning it was running as a service in the background. It was configured to share the videos read-only to any connection, so that we did not need to set passwords, but didn't have to worry about someone deleting or moving the files. Rsync then also ran on the video playback laptop to download the incoming videos from the server. It was set to run using "cron", an scheduling service which ran the rsync program every few minutes to download any new videos.

The second portion is a Java application that uses QuickTime for Java (which is bundled with QuickTime and iTunes) to playback the videos in sequence with controls for playing the next and previous videos. This application only plays 3gp videos but can be modified to play other QuickTime compatible formats fairly easily.

The source for this application can be downloaded here: http://www.whitmanlocalreport.net/video_player/

On-site Computer Setup:

At each location, we had an internet connection set up and ready to go when we got there. We then set up a small network of computers to run the show. One laptop was dedicated to managing the incoming calls and playing the audio from those calls. The next laptop was used for downloading the videos from the server playing them back. Both the audio and video were sent to another laptop that combined them into a stream and sent it to the streaming server. The audio/video signal was also sent to a local projector and PA system for live playback on-site.

Server Setup:

In addition to the collection of laptops that was used on-site, there was one remote server. The server, running the Debian operating system, was located at a colocation facility in Los Angeles. It provided a number of essential functions: website hosting with the Apache web server; phone call termination and call queue system using Asterisk phone system software; custom software for receiving videos send from the phones and relaying them to the laptops on location; and, the public streaming server, running Darwin Streaming Server, that delivered the audio/video stream for the world to experience.

Phone System (PBX/Asterisk):

The central part of the voice reports is the phone system built using Asterisk. It is essentially a call queue system like any business might have when you call their customer service number. Participants dial one of the phone numbers pre-programmed into the mobile phones. Asterisk answers, plays back some basic instructions, then moves on to the hold music, announcing the caller's position in the queue whenever the a call was answered. The first caller in the queue is transferred to the extension of the software phone running on the laptop on location. This software phone acts just like a phone in an office phone system does, it has an extension number that works only within that context. When the participant is next in the queue, Asterisk played them a prompt to get them prepared to deliver their report: "Get ready, your next! When the hold music stops you are live on the air!". After the current call is hung up, the next participant is prompted, asterisk sends the next call to the software phone on location. The software phone was configured to automatically answer as soon as possible, putting the audio immediately on the air. When the current report hits a good breaking point, hit the Esc key on the laptop running the software phone. Then the call is dropped and the next one picked up, starting this process again.

To setup your own queue system you will need an Asterisk server (http://www.asterisk.org) and Voice over IP (VoIP) service. You can find lots of help for setting up Asterisk help online, so this is just an outline of what needs doing. It is probably worthwhile to get a hosting provider to install and host Asterisk for you. Once you have Asterisk running and receiving calls from normal phones (mobile or otherwise), you can setup the call queue mechanism. All of the queues are set up in a file called "queues.conf". In this file you can set up the various automated announcements, the frequency of the announcements, and which extension receives the calls from the queue. All in all, the Local Report setup only required about 10 custom settings to get the call queue working.

Next, you will need to have a piece of software called a "soft-phone" to receive the calls as they come in. For this purpose we used software called Freshtel Firefly, but there are many solid options available now, depending on which operating system your computer is running. Essentially this software works just like a phone, receiving calls using VoIP instead of a normal phone line. We hooked this phone into Asterisk to be the phone that Asterisk directed the calls to once they were in the top of the queue. Again, the setup of this is out of the scope of this document but plenty of information for configuring soft-phones to work with Asterisk can be found online.

Last, Asterisk might be one of those portions of the system that we used for our setup that might be overkill for what you want to do. Many VoIP TSP (Telephony Service Providers) allow you to configure service with them to work directly with a soft-phone. Some might even allow you to setup a queue. We used Voicepulse for our service, they come highly recommended but the industry is changing quickly and it would behoove you to shop around a bit.

Mobile Phone Configuration:

The mobile phones that we used were configured so that they would be as easy to use as possible. We wanted to make it possible to have people with no mobile phone experience be able to fully participate in Local Report. Much of this configuration was centered around making the user need as few button clicks as possible in order to make their reports. In particular, we configured the two "soft keys" to open the two relevant applications for Local Report: the video application and the contacts (for calling in).

When a participant clicked on the soft key to launch the video application, the user needed only to keep clicking on that same soft key in order to choose all of the requisite options in order to record a video and upload it to the server. The first click launched the application, the second click started recording video, the third click stopped the recording, then the remaining clicks uploaded the video. When a participant clicked on the audio soft key, they were presented with four different phone numbers to dial, all of which dial the same phone system. The participant just clicked once more to dial a number, then followed the voice prompts of the phone system to do their audio report.

Making a Video Report:

First, the participant launched the video application as described above. This would open a preview window which they could use to set up the shot. Following that, a press to video soft key (the left button) started recording. Once recording started, the border around the video preview turned red, and a countdown from 20 starts, showing the remaining recording time. The participant could compose the video however they want to within the 20 second limit. When the countdown hit zero, the participant was prompted to upload the video, which was done by a couple clicks on the video soft key (allowing the application to access the network). Once the video uploaded was complete, the participant was notified on the phone, and the video was automatically played on-site and on the stream.

Making an Audio Report:

The Asterisk phone system answered the call, played a pre-recorded welcome, then placed the call in a hold queue, complete with hold music. As the call advanced in the queue, the phone system announced the call's position in the queue. When the call was up next, the participant heard a little pep talk, getting them ready to deliver their report. When the call was finally answered, the hold music stopped and the participant was immediately speaking live on location and the stream.

Conclusion

There are indeed many parts that make up the whole system that runs a Local Report, but each of the pieces is actually relatively simple in the grand scheme of things. Fortunately, there is a lot of good, free software like Asterisk, rsync, and J2ME that this whole system is built upon. Using the software that are provided on the whitmanlocalreport.net website, your own Local Report is that much closer to happening.

639.title: Foundation of E.A.T.
639.ref_bibliographic: Klüver, Billy ; Martin, Julie, « Working with Rauschenberg », in Walter Hopps and Susan Davidson (eds). Robert Rauschenberg : a retrospective, New York : Guggenheim Museum Publications, 1997, p. 310-327.
639.text: The origin of the name has its own story. We wanted something mundane like Foundation for Artists and Engineers. When our lawyer, Frank Konigsberg, came back from Albany, he informed the group that our preferences were either illegal or had been taken already, and that he had come up with and registered the name Experiments in Art and Technology. And that was that. Everybody—there must have been at least twenty of us—gasped at the word "experiments." As we saw it, an artwork is either finished or it isn't, and the public should not be subjected to incomprehensible scientific or technical experiments. But, anyway, the name has stuck, along with our insistence on keeping the periods between the initials.

648.title: Press Release of Mel Bochner, Singer Notes
648.ref_bibliographic: « Mel Bochner - Singer Notes ». MFC-Michèle Didier. URL: http://www.micheledidier.com/index.php/gb/mfc-exhibitions/mfc-archive/exhibition-mel-bochner-singer-notes.html.
648.text:
Exhibition from September 7 to novembre 17, 2017, curated by Michèle Didier and Sébastien Pluot
Opening on September 7, 2017 from 6pm to 9pm in the presence of Mel Bochner
Press release
Singer Notes is an important work by American artist Mel Bochner yet strangely it remains little-known. While encapsulating the germination of ideas which later proved to be fundamental in Bochner’s extremely influential work since the late 1960's, the Singer Notes have been generally unknown.
In 1968, Bochner replied to an open call organised by the already renowned “Experiments in Art and Technology” program. (Robert Rauschenberg and Billy Klüver initiated E.A.T. in 1966, when scientific optimism within American culture was at its climax.) Bochner was selected to partake in a residency at the Singer Laboratories in New Jersey. Between September and December 1968, he was to visit the labs three times a week. The Singer Notes are made up of notes and drawings which resulted from the conversations he held with scientists and engineers there. 
Although, in his application letter, the artist expressed his interest in a computerised “numerical photographic translation”, the residency actually consisted mainly of conversations and dialogical speculation. It was inspiring and instructive but Bochner remained sceptical with regards to the scientists’ positivist predicates. The Singer Notes, which were the primary outcome of such conversations, tackle several themes: how do scientists translate their research into more concrete applications? how do they design experiments? the nature of colour as a type of energy; the fundamental differences between the analog and the digital; how do scientists (and in a broader sense, people) know what they know? 
It was in this context that Bochner furthered his interest for intellectual research that he had developed as of 1964, while studying philosophy at Northwestern University in New York, reading the theories of Wittgenstein, Sartre and Heidegger. During the residency, his lack of a preconceived plan and his strong critical view on positivism led Bochner to formulate ideas for new works, as well as for projects which were to exist only conceptually. For example, texts written in the snow with heat-sensitive ink that would only be visible at a certain temperature then would disappear; or images created purely from algorithms, with no preliminary manmade drawings. The Singer Notes end on the first utterances of certain speculations which will later become one of Bochner’s most important works, the Measurement Series. 
While many of Mel Bochner’s works are included as iconic moments in the narrative of American postwar art, the Singer Notes haven’t seen the light of day for over fifty years. They have never been exhibited nor have they ever been published until now.
During a discussion with Sébastien Pluot in 2013, the artist spoke about this work. They then decided to record a further conversation as they looked through each page of notes. It is this transcription which is included in the second half of the recent Singer Notes, 1968 publication, while the first half of said publication comprises an exact copy of the Singer Notes themselves.
It was in 2015 that Mel Bochner and Sébastien Pluot proposed to Michèle Didier to publish the entirety of the Singer Notes alongside the conversation between Bochner and Pluot. They also suggested an exhibition, taking one of the last drawings of the Singer Notes as its starting point.
In the first room of the gallery, a facsimile of the original Singer Notes binder* is placed upon a pedestal, thus harking back to Bochner’s display of his historical 1966 piece entitled Working Drawings And Other Visible Things on Paper Not Necessarily Meant To Be Viewed as Art. This facsimile, published in three copies, is produced by mfc-michèle didier on the occasion of the exhibition.
In the second room, the artist installs Measurement Perimeter, this first Measurement Room, which has never been exhibited. A major work, which can be seen as the culmination of the experiments and research undertaken at Singer Labs.
This hitherto unseen exhibition will be shown for the first time in Paris at mfc-michèle didier gallery from september 8 to November 10, 2017. 
* MEL BOCHNER
  Singer Notes - (Binder)
Aluminium Binder.
Dimensions of the Binder: 303 x 291 x 70 mm.
Contains 47 looseleaves slipped in plastic folds.
Dimensions of the plastic folds: 280 × 215 mm.
Printed on Lessebo Design Natural 120 g.
Limited edition of 3 numbered and signed copies.
Produced and published in 2017 by mfc-michèle didier.

652.title: Singer Notes, 1968. A Conversation Between Mel Bochner and Sébastien Pluot
652.ref_bibliographic: Bochner, Mel, and Sébastien Pluot. Singer notes, 1968 - Mel Bochner. Bruxelles, Belgique: Michèle Didier, 2017.
652.text:
Mel Bochner |  Singer Notes is a group of notes, sketches and diagrams that were collected into a book. But they didn't begin that way. In the late sixties Bob Rauschenberg and Billy Klüver started a group called E.A.T. (Experiments in Art and Technology). Klüver was an engineer who worked at Bell Laboratories and had come up with the idea of working and doing projects with artists, mostly with Rauschenberg at that point. It's a long story but eventually Klüver left Bell Labs. He and Rauschenberg started their own collaborative project, E.A.T. that was in the optimistic spirit of the time, and guided by Rauschenberg's extraordinary generosity. Bob didn't monopolized the project for himself, but shared it with other artists, opening the possibilities of technology to a whole generation. There was the famous E.A.T. 9 Evenings as well as many smaller projects which E.A.T. either raised money to fund or collaborated on with others.
By the late sixties Singer Labs was engaged with a lot of different activities, many of them were very high-tech - research for the Government involving computers and other advanced technological stuff. Someone at Singer had the idea that they would like to have an artist working with them too. (Perhaps because they were in competition with Bell Labs, also located in New Jersey.) So they solicited E.A.T. with a proposition for an artist to work at Singer. A number of artist were invited to submit a proposal and - to make a long story short - mine was chosen.
I travelled out to Denville, New Jersey, three days a week, about an hour on the bus, and met with a rotating group of engineers, mathematicians and physicists. We sat around and talked all day; it was like a think tank. There was no set agenda, we talked about things that people were working on and essentially tried to find some kind of common ground. In other words, it began as a conversation to find something to have a conversation about, which had a nice circular logic to it.
Sébastien Pluot | Did this "circular logic" define the project that you wanted to do? Other artists seemed to be making more technical partnerships.
MB | Yes, most of the other artists who applied needed technical assistance for a precise physical artwork. Although I didn't have any specific project in mind, I did go in with one idea, that somehow through manipulating numbers, as I had done in drawings, the computer could translate them into photographic images. But the programmers said it would take longer to write the program than it would for me to do it by hand. So that idea went nowhere.
SB | In the project you submitted to E.A.T. you are talking about "numerical photographic translations."
MB | 1968 was still the early days of computers. They were almost impossible to get access to, but I thought it might somehow be possible to use them in my work. At that time computers were not "user friendly," you had to be able to translate everything into the computer's language, Fortran, in order to make it do anything. The lab had very powerful machines that were the size of a room. Although they seemed very fast, they were painfully slow compared to computer today. [...]

661.title: Mel Bochner, Singer Notes (Technical File)
661.ref_bibliographic: « Mel Bochner - Singer Notes ». MFC-Michèle Didier. URL: http://www.micheledidier.com/index.php/gb/mfc-exhibitions/mfc-archive/exhibition-mel-bochner-singer-notes.html.
661.text:
Mel Bochner
Singer Notes, 1968
About Singer Notes, 1968 by Mel Bochner
Singer Notes, 1968 is a book by Mel Bochner published by mfc-michèle didier in 2017.
The first section of Singer Notes, 1968 comprises an exact copy of the Singer Notes, the whole of the drawings and the notes by Mel Bochner between September and December 1968.
The second section of Singer Notes, 1968 comprises the conversation between Mel Bochner and Sébastien Pluot looking through each page of the notes. Singer Notes is an important work by American artist Mel Bochner yet strangely it remains little-known. While encapsulating the germination of ideas which later proved to be fundamental in Bochner’s extremely influential work since the late 1960s, the Singer Notes have been generally ignored.
In early 1968, Bochner replied to an open call organised by the already renowned “Experiments in Art and Technology” programme. Robert Rauschenberg and Billy Klüver initiated E.A.T. in 1966, when scientific optimism within American culture was at its climax. Bochner was selected to partake in a residency at the Singer Laboratories in New Jersey. Between September and December 1968, he was to visit the labs three times a week. The Singer Notes are made up of notes and drawings which resulted from the conversations he held with scientists and engineers there. Although, in his application letter, the artist expressed his interest in a computerised “numerical photographic translation”, the residency actually consisted mainly of conversations and dialogical speculation. It was inspiring and instructive but Bochner remained sceptical with regards to the scientists’ positivist predicates. The Singer Notes, which were the primary outcome of such conversations, tackle several themes: how do scientists translate their research into more concrete applications? how do they design experiments? the nature of colour as a type of energy; the fundamental differences between the analog and the digital; how do scientists (and in a broader sense, people) know what they know? It was in this context that Bochner furthered his interest for intellectual research that he had developed as of 1964, while studying philosophy at Northwestern University in New York, reading the theories of Wittgenstein, Sartre and Heidegger. During the residency, his lack of a preconceived plan and his strong critical view on positivism led Bochner to formulate ideas for new works, as well as for projects which were to exist only conceptually. For example, texts written in the snow with heat-sensitive ink that would only be visible at a certain temperature then would disappear; or images created purely from algorithms, with no preliminary manmade drawings. The Singer Notes end on the first utterances of certain speculations which will later become one of Bochner’s most important works, the Measurement Series.
In 2013 Bochner mentioned this work during a conversation with Sébastien Pluot. They conceived of a project to record a conversation based on the discussion of each page of the folder. In 2015 Michèle Didier proposed to publish the entire Singer Notes along with the Bochner / Pluot conversation. 
Specifications
• Singer Notes, 1968 is a book by Mel Bochner.
• The first section contains the original 98 pages of Singer Notes, 1968.
• The second section contains 34 pages of A Conversation Between Mel Bochner and Sébastien Pluot.
• Together they comprise a book of 132 pages.
• The book is 258 mm high x 205 mm wide x 14 mm thick.
• The typeface is Univers 47 Light Condensed.
• The book is printed on Lessebo Design Natural 130 g.
• The book is placed in a Muskat Grey 290 g Swiss bound cover.
• The front cover is embossed in black.
• A black bookmark is placed in each section of the book.
• The book is printed and bound by Cultura in Wetteren, Belgium.
Production
• Limited edition of 200 signed and numbered copies + 50 A.P
Produced and published in 2017 by mfc-michèle didier
©2017 Mel Bochner and mfc-michèle didier

663.title: Hans Ulrich Obrist and Sandra Antelo-Suarez interview Mel Bochner
663.ref_bibliographic: Obrist, Hans Ulrich, Sandra Antelo-Suarez, and Mel Bochner. « Hans Ulrich Obrist and Sandra Antelo-Suarez interview Mel Bochner ». E-Flux. http://projects.e-flux.com/do_it/notes/interview/i003.html.
663.text:
HANS ULRICH OBRIST:  I interviewed Billy Kluver a few years ago for the same series of interviews, and speaking about experiments in art and technology, he mentioned your "Singer Project" which is very much related to what John Latham in England set up, the Artists Placement Group. Kluver had a similar project in which people were invited for residencies. I wondered if you could tell me a little about your experience with EAT in this "Singer" lab. I imagine there must be a lot of realized and unrealized issues because "The Measurement" series grew out of this, it was one of the things that was triggered by it, but at the same time there were a lot of unrealized projects in this context. 
 MEL BOCHNER:  The "Singer Project" proved to be important to me, for a number of reasons. But I had two requirements before I accepted the project, because I didn't want to be there as a "tourist." I wanted to be there on exactly the same terms as the scientists, so I demanded a salary - whatever the average salary was for a research scientist. I knew it was the only way to be taken seriously. My second requirement e was an office, so I was physically part of that situation. 
 HANS ULRICH OBRIST:  You were infiltrating.  
MEL BOCHNER:  You could see in those terms. The daily process was quite simple; we sat around a table drinking coffee, and talking. I talked about the things I was thinking about and the things that I wanted to do, and they did the same. One of my projects was to feed numbers into the computer and the computers would generate permutations of those numbers which would be printed out as photographs.  
HANS ULRICH OBRIST:  That must have been a very early moment of digital photography, that's incredible.  
MEL BOCHNER:  Unfortunately a bit too early, because they didn't have the technology to do it. The programmer told me, 'do you know what, you can make these faster by hand than I can' because, in 1968, he couldn't write a complex enough program. At that time you had to translate everything into FORTRAN. That sort of washed out the one project I had intended to do there. So after that we sat around for three months just talking. 
 HANS ULRICH OBRIST:  Coffee breaks! 
 MEL BOCHNER:  Basically a day-long coffee break. But this is what they did for a living, what they did every day. It was research and development, brainstorming new things for the company to produce, sitting around the table, scribbling notes to themselves. So, right from the very first day, I started saving every scrap of paper.  
HANS ULRICH OBRIST:  And has that been published?  
MEL BOCHNER:  I made a Xerox edition of two, which I called "The Singer Notes."  
HANS ULRICH OBRIST:  So it remains kind of unpublished. 
 MEL BOCHNER:  Yes. What was exciting was that the conversation roamed all over the place. One scientist was very interested in color theory. So we started designing a motorized three-dimensional color model. It never got built, but it led to some interesting conversations about the chemistry of color. They told me about some dyes that had recently been invented that were temperature sensitive. Only at certain temperatures would you be able to see them. One project I came up with was to draw or write things in a landscape using dyes that you could only see when it was very cold. Suddenly when the temperature fell below 32F, a message would come out of the ground.  
HANS ULRICH OBRIST:  A form of public art which according to the weather would be... 
 MEL BOCHNER:  Invisible. Anyway, many of the ideas weren't meant to be realized, they were pure speculation, meant to provoke the conversation, because it was clear to me that the conversation themselves were "the project." The conversations often centered around the idea of objectification - how can we find a common language, and that invariably came down to some form of measurement. It was about how experience can be communicated, and at the same time, the fallibility of every measurement system.  HANS ULRICH OBRIST: No absolute.  
MEL BOCHNER:  Exactly and that's where perception came into the equation.  
HANS ULRICH OBRIST:  Perhaps there are some connections with Merleau Ponty? 
 MEL BOCHNER:  In a way, very close to his ideas. The first measurement piece that I did was for the sake of the conversation. I secretly went around the laboratory measuring things, marking dimensions on the walls and floors with letraset numbers.  
HANS ULRICH OBRIST:  That was an intervention directly into the science lab? 
 MEL BOCHNER:  Yes. For example, I measured the distance from a spray can to the end of the wall.  
HANS ULRICH OBRIST:  And so if the can is removed it leads to disorder!  
MEL BOCHNER:  Or if the door is closed the signifier disappears. I had photographs taken of these interventions and when I looked at the photographs the interesting thing was that there was no way to know the actual size of the object in the photograph. So I next drew twelve inches on the wall and photographed myself against it, then gave the negative to the printer and asked him to print it so that the measurement in the print would be exactly twelve inches, or actual size. By doing that the photograph became the index of the index, or a vicious circle. That, for me, was the end of photography.  
HANS ULRICH OBRIST:  So the time of your residency at the Singer lab was not only the beginning of "The Measurements" but also the moment of the end of photography for you. 
 MEL BOCHNER:  Yes.  
HANS ULRICH OBRIST:  When I interviewed Billy Kluver, it struck me that rather than discussions around round tables about interdisciplinarity, bringing practitioners together in a very pragmatic sense with a concrete project is a truly visionary model. Do you think this is the case? 
 MEL BOCHNER:  Yes, I do. The EAT project was visionary also in terms of the openness and generosity of it. Rauschenberg and Kluver made so much time and energy available for other artists, I can't think of anything else that's been like that. EAT was unique because it wasn't ideological in any sense - that in itself was pretty radical in the sixties.  
HANS ULRICH OBRIST:  And transgenerational too. Before we were talking about misunderstandings, (and I was curious about this in relation to science and engineering) there can sometimes be productive misunderstandings, and this was just at the moment that you made the amazing work entitled Misunderstandings. Could you talk a little about these issues and this work?

676.title: On Moon Museum Conception and Production (Bureaud-Dellinger)
676.ref_bibliographic: Dellinger, Jade, et Annick Bureaud. "All Systems Are Go: A Museum for the Moon". Festival @rt outsiders 2009. (In)habitable ? L’art des environnements extrêmes, 2009. pp. 20-22.
676.text:
Moon Museum: The Story of a Tiny Space Object
Forrest Myers had been dreaming about Space since the Russian launch of Sputnik. As a young sculptor, he was influenced by the work of Alexander Calder. As Myers recalls [1]: “As an artist considering Calder, I was thinking about the unique possibilities of a zero-gravity environment”. He continues: “The first Moon landing was like the salamander crawling out of the soup”. From Myers’ perpective, Darwinian evolution seemed to happen in fossil time, but seeing Man leave the Earth and step foot on the Moon was both instant and epic. It lead him to propose sending art to the Moon – his art and the art of others he admired.
While working on the Pepsi Pavilion for the Osaka Fair with numerous artists and engineers, all associated with Experiments in Art and Technology, Myers pitched his idea to E.A.T. founders Dr. Billy Klüver and Fred D. Waldhauer who responded with strong support.
In the tradition of the Boîte-en-valise – or “box in a suitcase”, the miniature monographic “traveling museum” that Marcel Duchamp assembled between 1935-41, and the “Legitimate Gallery” that Robert Filliou conceived in his hat in 1962, the Moon Museum was both portable and unconventional. Measuring a mere 9/16 x 3/4 x 1/32 inches, it reproduced a unique cache of drawings through lithographic means on an Alumina ceramic wafer (like a computer microchip) with Tantalum as “color” on a Tantalum nitride surface. It was manufactured at Bell Telephone Laboratories by Fred D. Waldhauer and Robert N. Merkle whose expertise was computer circuitry, a cutting edge technology at the time. As a former assistant [2] to Waldhauer recalled in 2005: “A number of us worked to photographically reduce the original artists’ drawings onto ceramic tiles. Our area of expertise at the Labs was high speed thin film technology”. The total number of copies remains uncertain: as many as forty seems to have been produced, but reports are contradictory and far fewer have actually been located.
[...]
Moon Museum: An Artwork Composed of Six Artworks
Myers later remarked that contributors were all quite serious about the project. Although Claes Oldenburg sending a cartoon to the Moon may seem a little absurd, his Geometric Mouse Kite drawing was related to a large-scale sculpture now in the Collection of the Museum of Modern Art. “From Mickey Mouse, he created his own iconic, artistic interpretation” says Myers. Robert Rauschenberg’s “line” drawing or Warhol’s “AW” penis sketch [4] could appear casual, but, in context, the artist’s initials and the line seem about basic mark-making. Like Neil Armstrong’s boot impressions on the lunar surface, both can be interpreted as the conceptual footprint of an artist.
The contributions of David Novros and John Chamberlain were related to their paintings at that time. As David Novros recalled [5]: “I made similar diagrammatic instruction drawings for the guys commissioned to make the stretcher bars necessary for my large-scale paintings. I was firmly against drawing as an expression of touch or verisimilitude. Drawing was a way of thinking about these big paintings I wanted to make.”The white lines in the Novros drawing were the spaces that separated the panels in his large-scale, architectural works. Whereas, Chamberlain’s composition echoes the template he was using to candy-apple spray (with an automobile finish) grids on small square panels.
Myers’ own drawing was related to a preexisting sculpture. Invited to a group exhibition at MIT, he showed a large, deceptively simple metal work. At first glance, it appears to be aligned geometric forms, but, upon closer inspection, the forms are interlocking and derived from a continuous line. According to Myers, he was then approached by several MIT professors. “They confessed that my work was a precise physical manifestation of a computer rendering they had spent the entire semester plotting”. Much to Myers surprise, they were able to take his sculptural form and manipulate it in virtual space. He says: “The ‘computer drawing’ I included on the Moon Museum was, in fact, a screen-capture taken with a Polaroid camera”. Rendered on a computer, Myers drawing is a 2-dimensional representation of a sculptural form that was plotted in virtual space.
1. Quotations from Myers are from the two interviews conducted by Jade Dellinger with the artist in March 28 and May 13, 2009.
2. Declining to be named, in a private email correspondence with Jade Dellinger.
[...]
4. Hidden on the picture reproduced in the New York Times of November 22, 1969 and emphasized as being his “calligraphic squiggle made up of the initials of his signature”.
5. Interview with the artist by Jade Dellinger on March 28, 2009.

677.title: On Moon Museum Travel (Bureaud-Dellinger)
677.ref_bibliographic: Dellinger, Jade, et Annick Bureaud. "All Systems Are Go: A Museum for the Moon". Festival @rt outsiders 2009. (In)habitable ? L’art des environnements extrêmes, 2009. pp. 20-22.
677.text:
After numerous attempts through official NASA channels and a letter written on their behalf by Henry Geldzahler, curator at the Metropolitan Museum, were ineffective, an engineer at the Grumman Aircraft Corporation [3] assured their success by surreptitiously attaching a Moon Museum to the LEM. On November 12, 1969, Myers received a telegram. Mysteriously signed “John F.”, the Cape Canaveral origin and message that read, “YOUR [sic] ON ‘A.O.K. ALL SYSTEMS ARE GO” provided ample confirmation. Given overwhelming evidence that those involved were capable and committed, created within a few months, it seems that the Moon Museum made its way.
3. Wishing to remain anonymous.
